abstract: On Monday night, a serious affray occurred in a drinking saloon, on the corner of Third-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street, between two men named JAMES J. WALL and OWEN PHELAN, which resulted in PHELAN being shot with a pistol. The physicians who attended him, pronounced the wound to be of a very dangerous nature. An investigation of the circumstances connected with the quarrel developed the fact, that a dispute arose between the parties while in the saloon, and that HALL became so exasperated that he made threates of shooting his adversary, unless an apology was made. An officer was then called in, who searched WALL, but no weapon being found, he left. Scarcely liad he done so, when the report of a pistol was heard. He immediately returned, and found PURLAN lying on the floor, with WALL standing over him, with a pistol in his hand. The latter had secreted his pistol during the search, and when the officer was gone, the quarrel was renewed, which resulted in PHELAN being shot in the groin. He was conveyed as soon as possible to Bellevue Hospital, where the physicians in attendance pronounced him to be in a very critical condition, and stated that in all probability he could not recover. WALL was immediately arrested and locked up to await the result of PHELAN's injuries. The prisoner is a clerk on board of the steamboat Sylvan Shore, which runs on the East River, between Harlem and the lower part of the City.

abstract: Mason-Slidell (Trent) Affair: editorial on settlement based on rights of neutrals
snippet: Mason-Slidell (Trent) Affair: editorial on settlement based on rights of neutrals
lead_paragraph: Several of our contemporaries seem anxious to prove that, in disavowing the act of Capt. WILKES, our Government has taken a step damaging to the honor and hostile to the interests of the country. We cannot but think that, in expressing such an opinion, they consult the disturbed and angry sensibilities of the moment, rather than the settled dictates of sober judgment. That act, and the principle on which it rests, would involve consequences which we cannot disregard in forming an opinion upon it. If we defend it, we admitthe right of the cruiser of any belligerent to visit and search any neutral, and to seize and carry away from her any person or thing which the Captain of that cruiser may deem contraband of war. If we may do this toward English vessels, England or Spain, or Mexico may do it toward American vessels. It puts neutral commerce absolutely at the mercy of every belligerent that has any naval force upon the high seas.

abstract: There are rumors of fighting in diferrent parts of Kentucky. The telegram we published yesterday of a reported fight at Paducah is yet in doubt. The dispatch via Philadelphia, which we give this morning, furnishes little additional information, though it seems to give a coloring of truth to the report by mentioning the name of a Captain who was killed. Rumors prevail in Lou-...
lead_paragraph: There are rumors of fighting in diferrent parts of Kentucky. The telegram we published yesterday of a reported fight at Paducah is yet in doubt. The dispatch via Philadelphia, which we give this morning, furnishes little additional information, though it seems to give a coloring of truth to the report by mentioning the name of a Captain who was killed. Rumors prevail in Louisville of a general engagement in Southern Kentucky; but they lack confirmation. It was also said there that BUCKNER's plan was at once to attack, in force, MCCOOK's Brigade, (our advance body in Central Kentucky,) destroy the bridge across Green River, for the second time, and retire. All these exciting rumors only show the imminence of an engagement at more than one point in Kentucky. Indeed, it does not seem possible, considering the position of our troops and of the rebels, that many days can pass over without seventy-five or a hundred thousand of our gallant Western troops measuring swords with the rebels.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen last evening concurred with the Councilmen in granting $2 50 each extra allowance to the clerks. They adopted a list of 150 Commissioners of Deeds. On motion of Alderman DAYTON, resolutions of thanks to the retiring Chairman, the clerks and the reporters were adopted. The new Board meets next Monday. The Board of Councilmen held another prolonged meeting. Fifteen months additional time was allowed to the contractor for macadamizing a part of the Second-avenue, on account of delays caused by the construction of a sewer in the avenue, although it was shown that the sewer was not built until fifteen months after the time fixed for the completion of his work. The Captain of the Montgomery troop, which went to Virginia on the first c. 11 for troops, petitioned to be reimbursed expenses incurred, but a resolution to pay $5,900 for that purpose was laid over.

abstract: editorial on European views
snippet: editorial on European views
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Etna and Borussia at this port, and the Asia at Halifax, we have advices from Europe to the 22d inst. The papers received are to the 18th, and contain comments upon the Message of President LINCOLN to Congress. The document is generally most mercilessly attacked, and comparisons are drawn between it and the one lately emanating from the traitor JEFF. DAVIS -- much to its disadvantage, the English newspapers contend. The point made of the President's silence relative to the Trent affair is that it is indicative of immediate war -- the exceptions to this view being few. In fact, it appears to be difficult for the English Press to accept any other solution of the Trent difficulty but that of war, in any contingency. The Observer, the Ministerial organ, says that England wishes for peace, but that she will gain by war, as it will enable her to rectify her American frontiers, open the ports of the South, and give a lesson to the United States. Passengers by the Asia also report a rumor that the blocking up of Charleston harbor with stone is likely to lead to difficulty; that England's warlike preparations will continue in view thereof, and that her demands do not end with the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL. The war preparations in England continued unabated.

abstract: The Norfolk Day Book, which was received by a flag of truce to-day, gives a curious account of the capture of the schooner Sherwood. abstract: On Monday evening, about 6 o'clock, a German soldier, named LOUIS FRIEDBACH, became involved in a quarrel with JOHN CARPENTER, at the recruiting-office, No. 1 126 Clinton-street. During the dispute, CARPENTER drew a pistol and shot his adversary in the left side. Dr. KIMBARK, who was in the vicinity, promptly attended the injured man, and temporarily dressed his wound, so that he could be conveyed to the hospital. The doctor pronounced the wound a dangerous one, and recommended that CARPENTER should be kept in close custody. The latter was wrested, and committed to await the result of FRIEBACH's Injuries.
lead_paragraph: On Monday evening, about 6 o'clock, a German soldier, named LOUIS FRIEDBACH, became involved in a quarrel with JOHN CARPENTER, at the recruiting-office, No. 1 126 Clinton-street. abstract: Editorial on relationship between US Government and banks in financing Civil War; Editorial on relationship between US Government and banks in financing war
snippet: Editorial on relationship between US Government and banks in financing Civil War; Editorial on relationship between US Government and banks in financing war
lead_paragraph: The suspension of specie payments has, to a certain extent, necessarily brought the Banks and the Government into antagonistic relations, though this may not, and probably does not, amount to more than a difference of opinion as to the policy best calculated to safely conduct the Gorvernment out of its embarrassment; for whatever accomplishes this, is the policy most beneficial to the Banks which are the representatives of the commercial public. Suspension was inevitable. The Banks contracted to do more than they could perform. The original contract with the Government did not contemplate their conversion from Banks into capitalists, whose whole means are in Government securities. For them to part with their capital in the shape of money would be the most fatal step possible, both for the people and the Government. They are a most important part of the machinery of business. As this is embarrassed or paralyzed, the wealth and consequently the power of the country is weakened or destroyed. We presume that the Secretary of the Treasury fully assents to this proposition. He would not think it wise to take their last dollar in coin. New-York is the heart of the country, whose pulsations heat with its own. New-York cannot he crippled without crippling, in a much greater degree, whatever depends upon it.
headline: {'main': 'The Government and the Banks.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Government and the Banks.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Though brighter, happier advents of a New Year have been seen in New York, there was still enough of gayety and busy preparation around the City last evening to denote general recognition of our annual Winter festival, and to show a fixed determination to celebrate it as cheerily as, under the peculiar political circumstances of the hoffa, might be compatible with the serious thoughts and avocations that occupy the public mind.

abstract: The journals of France and Belgium testify the deepest regret for the loss which the British nation has sustained by the death of Prince ALBERT. The Moniteur, the Constitutionnel, the Dabats, the Presse, the Brussels Independance, and many others, are full of expressions of sympathy. In Prussia the melancholy intelligence naturally created a peculiarly profound impression. The Prussian Court is to go into mourning for four weeks. Immediately on receiving the news the King and Queen of Prussia paid a visit of condolence to the Crown-Princess, and the King dispatched his Aid-de-Camp to testify to Lord LOFTUS his sympathy with the Royal family of England. Throughout Berlin a sensation of deep regret was produced among all classes when the fact of Prince ALBERT's death became publicly known.
lead_paragraph: The journals of France and Belgium testify the deepest regret for the loss which the British nation has sustained by the death of Prince ALBERT. abstract: Editorial
snippet: Editorial
lead_paragraph: The darkest and gloomiest year in our country's history has passed away. It opened with a portentous cloud in the Southern sky, then not bigger than a man's hand; but which has since overspread and wrapped as in a pall the whole nation. Last New-Year's Day, only South Carolina had committed herself to dis-union; and almost every one then thought and hoped that the process of disintegration would not go any further; but that the conservative element in the South, and the conciliatory element in the North, would speedily devise some way by which the old fraternal Union would he peacefully maintained, and the Ship of State, compact and strong though storm-beaten, would again pursue her course in placid seas. But beforethe first mouth had passed away, seven States were in the hands of the mutineers, and it seemed for a time almost as though the whole National fabric would tumble to pieces. The second mouth of the year shaped and compacted the revolt, by giving it a Confederated legislature and an Army, and by placing at its head the adroitest of the conspirators. In April the war -- henceforth to become a war of sections and systems -- opened in Charleston Harbor. Then followed the formation of the two great armies -- by this time thirteen rebel States contributing their troops to the one, while twenty-three Union States furnished the soldiers for the other. Since then, for nine dreary months past, the progress of the National arms has been fitful and uncertain -- reverse and victory checquering the record of each week. But at the close of the year of rebellion, we can at least say that the military forces of the nation; on land and sea, have been brought together, and are, apparently, ready to descend effectively upon the nation's foes.

abstract: FESTIVAL AT THE HUDSON RIVER INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL. -- A festival was held recently at the Hudson River Industrial School, (connected with the Children's Aid Society.) corner of Twenty-fifth-street and Ninth-avenue. After the services, which were conducted by Rev. Mr. SPAULDING, and Messrs. EASTMAN and TEAUY, the little ones partook of a bounteous feast of turkeys, roast meat, and an ample dessert of pies and confectionery. They wore the comfortable dresses presented to them at Christmas by the kind ladies interested in the school; and the parents of many of them were present, delighted spectators of their children's happiness, and also partakers of the collations. After dinner, the contents of the attractive Christmas Tree furnished by the considerate ladies -- the friends of these little ones -- were distributed among them, and each one was particularly delighted with his or her own prize. There was some very sweet hymn-singing by the children, and the facility with which they repeated numerous Scripture passages and Bible texts does their teacher, Miss TRACY, much credit. The influences of the school for good in its neighborhood were practically illustrated by this scene. There was a large attendance of the lady patronesses and friends of the school. They were deeply interested, and have reason to be much gratified with their good work.
lead_paragraph: FESTIVAL AT THE HUDSON RIVER INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL. -- A festival was held recently at the Hudson River Industrial School, (connected with the Children's Aid Society.) corner of Twenty-fifth-street and Ninth-avenue. abstract: The foreign news, of which we have dates later by a week than those previously received, betrays an extreme feverishness in the British mind. The President's Message had been received and eagerly scanned to find what attitude the American Government proposed to take in regard to the search of the Trent; and the absence of all reference to the subject was interpreted as indicative of hostile purposes. This view was reinforced by the allusion to Capt. WILKES and his exploit in the report of Secretary WELLES, and the unanimous vote of thanks in popular branch of Congress. The English and French Press concur in the idea that these evidences, duly collated, show the intention of the President to stand by the act of the San Jacinto, retain the rebel Envoys, and defy England. The London Star, always friendly to the cause of the North, alone ventures dissent from this conviction. It believes the President could not, with propriety, introduce into his Message any discussion of a point in regard to which he had no means of predetermining the attitude of Her Majesty's Government, and to this motive is the omission to be solely ascribed.

abstract: The following-named prisoners were yesterday released from Fort Lafayatte by order of the Secretary of State: Jas. Hopkinson, Arthur Wardell, Wm. Cuthbert, Geo. Watt, Michael O'Brien, William Sanger, Williams, (composing the crew of the British bark Express,) released unconditionally; John Q.A. Butler, Henry Sutler and Arthur McAbey, (crew of the prize ship Lida,) released unconditionally; Casper Klock and William Brown, released on taking an oath not to enter the rebellious Slates or take up arms against the Government.

abstract: One of our men captured by the rebels, (a man by the name of CLINTON,) and carried to Springfield, has just returned, having left that place on Christmas. He says that Gen. PRICE, with 8,000 men, had taken all the houses in Springfield for his troops, turning the women and children into the streets. He had unloaded his wagons, and was making preparations for a long stay.
lead_paragraph: OTTERVILLE, Tuesday, Dec. 31.

abstract: Under the influence of the death of Prince ALBERT and the American advices per Asia, the Stock Exchange on Monday, the 16th, was dull in the extreme, and a general decline took place. On the 17th, however, a stronger tone prevailed, and there was a recovery of 1/8@1/4 in Consols, which closed at 90@1/4 for both Money and Account. The Times says the recovery was attributed to the increased abundance of money seeking investment, rather than to any material alteration of views on the prospects of the American question.

abstract: Editorial decries waste of public money
snippet: Editorial decries waste of public money
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen led off last night in a very excellent proceeding. They adjourned sine die, although four full days of order remained to them. The public will feel profoundly grateful to the Common Council for this act of forbearance and self-denial. They will unquestionably be somewhat surprised at it, and may perhaps be a little incredulous as to the motive which prompted it. But the saving grace of the act itself nevertheless remains. It is something certainly for such a body deliberately to throw away the opportunity of prosecuting for four days longer the system of voting gratuities to everybody within reach, which they had commenced so splendidly.

abstract: Report on military buildup in Canada
snippet: Report on military buildup in Canada
lead_paragraph: The NEW-YORK TIMES was the first journal to announce that a Military Board, in session at Quebec had determined to prepare the Provinces for a contest with the United States. Since then the Canadian people have responded with alacrity to the warlike summons; and defensive works, on a large scale, have been commenced in exposed portions of the frontier lines. Apropos of this confirmation of the truth of our announcement, the Tribune has not had the manliness to apologize for its false statement that the Canadian news in the TIMES was manufactured for the occasion." But when the truth of our assertions is as triumphantly established as it has been in the present case, we can afford to overlook a cotem porary's spleen at failing to obtain an important item of intelligence.

abstract: SIR: If the heading of this article carried such force when we were struggling to be a nation, shall we sink into supineness when the cry comes up, aye, reaches our very door-steps, "That our soldiers are starved with hunger and with cold! "While other States are adding honor to their heritage, must we alone blush for our half-clad men? The appeal for relief from those quartered on the little island that is our harbor's boast, must reach the hearts of our New-York and Brooklyn ladies. Can we not emulate the women, of the country, whose contributions to camp and hospital are the results of long and untiring industry in families where there may be one, perhaps no domestic, to lighten the labors of the household?
lead_paragraph: SIR: If the heading of this article carried such force when we were struggling to be a nation, shall we sink into supineness when the cry comes up, aye, reaches our very door-steps, "That our soldiers are starved with hunger and with cold! abstract: President LINCOLN's Message, though necessarily silent on the affair of the Trent, is full of interest to English readers. The President would have nothing to say to Congress upon a matter of which he had no official cognizance. To the Naval Department belonged the duty of reporting the action taken by Commander WILKES ; and upon that report, no doubt, Congress grounded its vote of thanks, as to an officer who had shown his zeal in the service of the Republic. Whatever communications might have passed between Lord LYONS and Mr. SEWARD, it is certain that the former, had not received the important dispatch which left England only a day or two before the delivery of the Message. The President had therefore no reason to suppose that the relations of England and the United States had undergone any change, or called for any special remark. On the only question that had arisen between the two Governments-that of the British ship seized under a mistaken opinion-he reports an amicable settlement, and recommends a grant in compensation.

abstract: Editorial on need for postage rate reforms
snippet: Editorial on need for postage rate reforms
lead_paragraph: We hope our members of Congress -- and particularly the Post-office Committees of the two Houses -- will read an article in to-day's TIMES, from the pen of Mr. PLINY MILES, the Secretary of the New-York Postal Reform Committee. They will be more than amused at the array of facts given. The expose is complete. Mr. MILES has, of course, gone to the postal law for his figures that give the rates of postage on transient printed matter. We doubt if there are many readers -- even officers of the Post-office -- who would have believed that we had three hundred and twenty "regular" rates of postage for transient printed matter on packages under four pounds in weight. In the table of parcels, from one to sixteen ounces, there are eighty different rates. The scale proposed by Mr. MILES, and the Postal Reform Committee, reduces all these to three. These are a fair average of the others, have great convenience and simplicity to recommend them, can be readily remembered, will require no consulting of postal laws to know what they are, will barely need a resort to the weighing scales, and there will be no necessity to examine the packages to see the sort of matter they contain, or the number of pieces comprised. This style of rating postage on printed matter by quarter and half pounds, has been for years in use in England, with the greatest convenience and success. Since its adoption, there has been a vast and rapid increase of all kinds of printed matter in the English mails, affording at the same time great convenience to the public and a good profit to the Department.
headline: {'main': 'Rates of Postage--The reforms Proposed and those Needed.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rates of Postage--The reforms Proposed and those Needed.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Observations of British and French press
snippet: Observations of British and French press
lead_paragraph: The Journal des Debats publishes, from the pen M. XAVIER RAYMOND, a very remarkable article on the chances of the war which now seems likely to break out between England and the United States. M. RAYMOND sets forth very clearly that as regards naval warfare the odds are tremendously in favor of England, and then proceeds to consider whether the probability of conquering Canada may not have induced the Cabinet of Washington to provoke a war with Great Britain; but he comes to the conclusion that the possible advantages they might derive from it does not justify the aggression of the Federal Government. He reminds his readers that the British possessions in North America are contiguous to the United States on a line of frontier several hundred leagues in length, and which runs from one end of the continent to the other in its widest part, from the territory of British Columbia on the Pacific to the mouth of the St. Lawrence on the Atlantic. M. RAYMOND thinks that:

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Columbia, we have received files of the Havana papers, and letters from our correspondents, announcing the highly important intelligence that the flag of Spain floats, once more, from the battlements of San Juan de Ulloa, and over the entire City of Vera Cruz, which was surrendered on Monday, Dec. 16, to the Spanish combined naval and military expedition, under Gens. GASSET and RUBALCABA, without one shot ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Columbia, we have received files of the Havana papers, and letters from our correspondents, announcing the highly important intelligence that the flag of Spain floats, once more, from the battlements of San Juan de Ulloa, and over the entire City of Vera Cruz, which was surrendered on Monday, Dec. 16, to the Spanish combined naval and military expedition, under Gens. GASSET and RUBALCABA, without one shot having been fired or one blow struck for the honor of Mexico. Havana was, of course, to all outward appearance, in ecstasies of rejoicing at this unlooked-for bloodless, yet important success, particularly as it is entirely a Spanish triumph. The third and last division of the Spanish fleet, which left the harbor of Havana on the 2d ultimo, after fair weather and an easy run, on the 4th joined the divisions that had preceded it. By the 8th, the advanced portion of the fleet anchored off Anton Lizardo, where, on Tuesday, the 10th, it was joined by the remainder of the whole force. After a visit from the French and English consuls, who came off from Vera Cruz on a French steamer, the Spanish commanders held a council of war, and decided to attempt a landing in force on the ensuing day, unless the place should be surrendered upon a formal demand to be made by certain officers detailed for the purpose. A heavy northerly gale delayed the execution of this plan until the 14th, when Gen. URAGA, the Governor of Vera Cruz, expressed his willingness, in the presence of such overwhelming force, to evacuate the place, merely asking twenty-four hours' time to complete his withdrawal. On the 15th he retired with all his troops, leaving the fortress of Ulloa with all its splendid armament and munitions and the "heroic" city to the invader. On the 16th, the Spanish officers and, on the 17th, their forces formally landed and took possession amid the acclamations, as their haughty bulletins declare, of the entire people, headed by their local magistrates, Gen. GASSET, at the latest date, had issued proclamations full of promises, had placed the city and environs under martial law, and was reorganizing the Government on a military basis. The fall of the first port of Mexico is complete.

abstract: The British bark Empress, of Hull, from New-Orleans Bar, in 30 days, has arrived at this port. She was from Rio Janeiro for New-York, as her Captain reported, and had been ordered off from Pass a l'Outre previously; was taken by the United States sloop Vincennes as a prize. She has a cargo of 6,500 bags coffee. She lies at the Navy-yard.

lead_paragraph: The belligerent attitude which England has assumed toward this country since the capture of Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL and their Secretaries, renders a description of the military strength of Great Britain, at the present time, a matter of no slight interest. We therefore place before our readers some account thereof, in the preparation of which we have availed ourselves of the most recent authorities upon the subject.

abstract: observance, NYC, described
snippet: observance, NYC, described
lead_paragraph: The observance of New Year's day in this City, so far as the suspension of ordinary business, was quite general, but the long-established and muchabused custom of making indiscriminate calls, was for once, more honored in the breach than in the observance. Nevertheless there was a goodly number of callers to be seen in the streets, and this branch of New Year's day business was fairly and moderately attended to. It was a common remark, that by far a larger number of families than usual had their card-baskets swing outside, as an indication that no visitors would be received, and among these were many families who have heretofore given special [???] to this occasion. In some cases, houses were closed against visitors on account of recent deaths in the families, others to discourage the custom, but a still larger class, we apprehend, were influenced by economic motives. If outward indications can be relied upon, those who made professional rounds among their friends, did not, to any great extent, reflect discredit upon other similar occasions. They undoubtedly indulged unhesitatingly in partaking of the good things set before them -- particularly of the drinkables. In evidence of this -- we have it from high authority -- every ash barrel in the city was upset last night, and the contents rolled into the street at the mercy of the high wind that prevailed all night. The contractors for cleaning the streets are not in the best of humor to-day, in all probability. Neither are some house-keepers we wot of whose parlort have been sanded by the debris from the ash barrels.

lead_paragraph: The Committee appointed to examine this vessel have made their report. We understand that they are unanimous in approving the general objects of the vessel, and all its principal features. But a majority have made some objections, chiefly to matters of detail, which have induced them to report against the expediency of completing the work on the plan proposed by Mr. STEVENS.

abstract: --The Memoirs, Letters, and Remains of De Tocqueville, translated from the French by the translator of "Napoleon's Correspondence," are published by TICKNOR  FIELDS, in two volumes. The Memory of DE TOCQUEVILLE will ever be reverenced in this country, and even had the work before us no intrinsic merit, the magic of the name of the author of Democracy in America would secure for it an extended sale. lead_paragraph: -- The Memoirs, Letters, and Remains of De Tocqueville, translated from the French by the translator of "Napoleon's Correspondence," are published by TICKNOR FIELDS, in two volumes. The Memory of DE TOCQUEVILLE will ever be reverenced in this country, and even had the work before us no intrinsic merit, the magic of the name of the author of Democracy in America would secure for it an extended sale. But the work possesses an absorbing interest of its own, aside from the associations it revives. It admits us to the domestic circle, and satisfies us that the man who succeeded in exciting our admiration in his public career, is entitled to an affectionate esteem for the virtues which adorned his private life. The charming memoir of BEAUMONT presents DE TOCQUEVILLE to us in a new phase. We behold in him the industrious student, the solicitous friend, the devoted lover and the tender husband, as well as the brilliant and successful author, who attained to those honors in life which are too often reserved to be bestowed only after death. In the man we are enabled to distinguish the traits which so preeminently distinguished the writer. The same clear perceptions of duty and evident determination to adhere rigidly to the line of truth, the same charming candor and earnest good faith are visible alike in his life as in his works. The brief account which M. BEAUMONT gives us of the tour of the two friends on this Continent, when the materials for that master-work of book-making, Democracy in America, were collected, has for us a deep interest. The indefatigability with which DE TOCQUEVILLE pursued his labors, the industry with which he delved where a less discriminating and earnest seeker after knowledge would scarcely have dreamed of digging, the fairness with which his conclusions were formed, and the generosity which made him willing to attach a favorable construction where others would have tortured their ingenuity to produce an entirely different result, incline us to rank him as the very prince of travelers. The majority of our visitors come with a predetermination to find fault -- not to point out the good that exists among us, but to search out and bring into bold relief the bad. So full are they, generally, of this mania for unfavorable mention, that even of a valley where they find abundant grapes they too often return and report nakedness and sterility. It is pleasant to travel with DE TOCQUEVILLE, who journeys in an entirely different spirit, and with whom a spirit of fair inquiry takes the place of the passion for universal condemnation which actuates the great body of travelers in foreign countries.

abstract: SERIOUS AFFRAY IN WEST HOUSTON-STREET. -- About 4 o'clock A.M., yesterday, (Wednesday,) a man named ANDREW J. FOWLER became involved in an affray at a house of ill repute at No. 80 West Houston-street. During the quarrel. JACKSON drew a knife, which was soon taken from him by force, and he was immediately stabbed in the head by one of the two persons who were in the room at the time. The Police of the Eighth Precinct were soon on hand, and arrested the parties engaged in the quarrel, viz.: JULIA SHERWOOD, CHARLES GOLDEN, and a man known as "Bouquet BILLY." The wounded man was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he died at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The accused parties are detained at the Eighth Precinct Station-house to await the result of the inquest. Coroner WILDEY will investigate the case this afternoon, when it is believed the party who give the fatal stab will be ascertained.

abstract: The theatre of exciting events is transferred for the moment from our own coast to that of Mexico. We learn from that distracted and unhappy country that the long-impending blow has at length fallen, and that Vera Cruz is now occupied by Spanish troops. By this time, probably,...
lead_paragraph: The theatre of exciting events is transferred for the moment from our own coast to that of Mexico. We learn from that distracted and unhappy country that the long-impending blow has at length fallen, and that Vera Cruz is now occupied by Spanish troops. By this time, probably, the British and French contingents, appointed to operate against Mexico, have joined their forces with those of Spain, and the allies have commenced to carry out the policy adopted by the three Powers in the Convention of the 31st of October last. In connection with the news received to-day, we publish a variety of important information concerning this great European coalition. The treaty signed by the representatives of France, Spain and England develops their policy in regard to Mexico, and the naval and military strength of the expedition would seem to indicate that no transient occupation of the country is intended, but an occupation to last until some form of government, more pleasing to European statesmen than a Republic, has been securely established under a European protectorate.

abstract: On New-Year's Day, when everybody was making the compliments of the season, Messrs MASON and SLIDELL were quietly conveyed from Fort Warren and placed on board the British war-steamer Rinaldo, which forthwith put to sea; and if the hurricane which blew the whole night did not send DAVIS' "ambassadors" ...
lead_paragraph: On New-Year's Day, when everybody was making the compliments of the season, Messrs MASON and SLIDELL were quietly conveyed from Fort Warren and placed on board the British war-steamer Rinaldo, which forthwith put to sea; and if the hurricane which blew the whole night did not send DAVIS' "ambassadors" to Davy's locker, they are now on the fair way of completing the voyage which Captain WILKES cut short six weeks ago. It having been decided in the great Council of Trent, that England has a right to the two worthies, the corpora delictorum have been cheerfully yielded up by the Government; and as the "mob," that dreadful creation of the London Times' fancy, which it was predicted would sooner see the country smashed than the prisoners given up, has not interposed any obstacle, but, on the contrary, has shown itself most languidly indifferent to their taking off, the strange episode in the history of the times with which the names of MASON and SLIDELL are connected, may be considered as ended.

abstract: PRESENTATION OF A SWORD, SASH AND BELT. -- On New-Year's Day, Lieut. GEO. BISHOP, of the Eagle Brigade, was presented with a handsome sword, sash and belt, by the employes of Mr. W.E. BROCKWAY, of East Eleventh-street. Mr. PETER MCNALLY made the presentation on behalf of his colaborers, and in so doing spoke at some length, wishing the Lieutenant every success, and hoping that at the end of the war he would return at least a Colonel, if not a Brigadier General. In response Lieutenant BISHOP thanked the donors most warmly, and assured them that whatever he could do to crush this vile rebellion would be done most willingly, and that the bright blade with which he was presented would never be sullied with dishonor. The sword, which is a very handsome one, has the following inscription engraved on it: "Presented to Lieut. GEO. BISHOP by the employes of W.E. BROCKWAY, Esq."
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATION OF A SWORD, SASH AND BELT. -- On New-Year's Day, Lieut. GEO. BISHOP, of the Eagle Brigade, was presented with a handsome sword, sash and belt, by the employes of Mr. W.E. abstract: The London Times is very rapidly losing the little temper it has hitherto shown in the discussion of American affairs. It either assumes that we shall refuse reparation for the Trent affair, and, therefore, regards the two countries as virtually at war,--or else it fears we shall not refuse, and finds it necessary to...
lead_paragraph: The London Times is very rapidly losing the little temper it has hitherto shown in the discussion of American affairs. It either assumes that we shall refuse reparation for the Trent affair, and, therefore, regards the two countries as virtually at war, -- or else it fears we shall not refuse, and finds it necessary to resort to some other method of stimulating the passions and feeding the hatred of the English people. We prefer to rest upon the former supposition. We are not yet prepared to assume, or even to suspect, that any considerable portion of the British nation have resolved on war with the United States, per fas aut nefas, and that the Times is simply doing the work of men capable of so base and so baseless a malignity. We presume the Times takes it for granted that the demands of the British Government in the Trent affair will be rejected -- that the English will, therefore, be speedily engaged in active hostilities, and that it is feeding the hatred on which such hostilities must live by maligning the Americans to the utmost of its very considerable and utterly unscrupulous ability.

lead_paragraph: There are two great National roads leading from Vera Cruz to the City of Mexico -- one, the more northern via Jalapa, and the other to the south via Orizaba. The distance by either route is about he same, say 280 miles. In other days, and in times of peace, these two roads have been great thoroughfares, both for passengers and freight Fine stage-coaches filled with passengers, rolled rapidly on their way, and trains of freighted mules, and more recently, of wagons, would be met at brief intervals, making their slow but steady progress along the entire of both routes. Brigandage has always flourished more or less on these roads. Sometimes the strong arm of power has suppressed the highwaymen, and again they would come forth, particularly in times of civil commotion, such as have prevailed for three years past, more numerous and more rapacious than ever.

lead_paragraph: Our details of European advices this morning are one day later than those previously received. There is but little additional news of interest American vessels at Havre were arming them selves with rifled ordnance, in order to repel the privateers which were finding rendezvous in Bugland. Our Paris correspondent says that the astonishment of the French knew no bounds when it was discovered that President LINCOLN, in his Message, did not even mention the Trent case; but they consoled themselves with the thought that he had forgotten it, and that the Americans were the most wonderful people on the face of the earth. It is the belief in France that England intends to convert the Southern States into an English colony; and in that case France would join with England so as to get a share of the spoils in the Louisiana region. M. XAVIER RAYMOND, on the other hand, publishes an article in the Journal des Debuts, showing that the Northern Americans have commenced the war for territorial aggrandizement, and that they desire to annex the wealthy provinces stretching from Canada to the the North Pole! He does not think, however, that they will succeed. It is very evident that the intelligent French Press is yet capable of being taught in regard to some matters.

abstract: From the text of the Convention entered into between the three Powers concerning Mexico, we learn that it is the design of the Allies "to seize and occupy the several fortresses and military positions on the Mexican coast;" and for that purpose it is ordered that "the combined forces shall be assembled in the neighborhood of Vera Cruz." It is thus the eastern or Gulf shore of Mexico only on which the Allies design to operate. There have been fought all the foreign wars of Mexico. On that side is the bulk of the population, the principal cities and the great commercial ports; and to command the cities and commerce of the Gulf is, in the opinion of the Allies, to command the whole of Mexico.

abstract: In the Senate, after the presentation of petitions Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, offered a resolution, which was agreed to, asking the President to transmit to the Senate all the correspondence which has taken place since the Congress of Paris relative to neutral and belligerent rights on the ocean. The Committee on Finance was instructed ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, after the presentation of petitions Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, offered a resolution, which was agreed to, asking the President to transmit to the Senate all the correspondence which has taken place since the Congress of Paris relative to neutral and belligerent rights on the ocean. The Committee on Finance was instructed to inquire into the expediency of establishing a distinct bureau for the Treasury Department, to regulate and control the Mint. The Committee on Military Affairs was instructed to inquire into the necessity of modifying the act of July, 1861, increasing the military status of the United States. An inquiry was addressed to the Secretary of War relative to cavalry regiments. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill relating to sutlers in volunteer regiments.

abstract: What the Spaniards under CORTAZ did three and a half centuries ago, those of the nineteenth century have repeated. They have landed without resistance at Vera Cruz. That city and the castle of San Juan d' Ulloa are in their possession; their armada rides secure in the harbor; the task of conquest has been begun with the happiest auspices.
lead_paragraph: What the Spaniards under CORTAZ did three and a half centuries ago, those of the nineteenth century have repeated. They have landed without resistance at Vera Cruz. That city and the castle of San Juan d' Ulloa are in their possession; their armada rides secure in the harbor; the task of conquest has been begun with the happiest auspices. If would seem but the easiest task in the world to proceed from the coign of vantage thus obtained into the interior of the country, as the great leader whose traditions they cherish and endeavor to revive, proceeded with a tithe of the force over the same track from victory to victory. But the tradition is more easily cherished than revived. The great difference is that the present is the nineteenth, and not the sixteenth century. The contest has to be waged, not against Aztec and Toltec, aghast at the familiar resources of civilized warfare; but against a people trained by incessant internal dissensions to the use of arms; embittered by every historical recollection against the invader, and taught by the issue of the wars of independence to regard themselves as more than a match for his utmost strength. In these different circumstances, the successors of CORTEZ may find very unexpected results.

abstract: The first day of the new year was marked by the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL to British authority, and their departure from the shores of the United States for the British dominions. The matter was managed very quietly. A steamtug took them from Fort Warren at 11 o'clock in the forenoon, and conveyed them to Provincetown, Cape Cod, where they were placed on board the British gunboat Rinaldo, which was there in waiting, and left about 5 o'clock in the afternoon. The wind has since been blowing a hurricane.

abstract: New-Year's day was quite generally observed, and the custom of calling was participated in by very many, though apparently not to the extent of previous years. The absence of exhilarating beverages on many of the festive boards was a noticeable feature, and the indulgence of stimulants appeared to have been partaken of with moderation. In the evening, many of the dwellings in Jersey City and Hoboken were brilliantly illuminated, and merry parties were on their rounds to tender the compliments of the season.

abstract: Hon. ALFRED ELY, lately released from a Richmond prison, where he had been confined as a prisoner of war, arrived in this City, from Washington, at 8 o'clock last evening, by way of the Camden and Amboy boat. He immediately took a carriage which was in waiting at the pier, and, accompanied by two friends, proceeded to the St. Nicholas Hotel. A deputation of the officers of the Sixty-ninth Regiment waited upon him at his rooms, where an exchange of congratulations took place.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held their regular meeting yesterday P.M., but as the other Board has adjourned sine dic no new business could be transacted, the attention of members being directed solely to papers sent from the other Board for concurrence. A large lobby was in attendance, but the floor of the Chamber was kept entirely free, thus avoiding much unnecessary  noise and confusion. After the passage of one unimportant paper, Mr. BARNEY moved that when the Board adjourn it meet again on Saturday. Two amendments, viz.: to meet on Friday and to adjourn sine dic, were defeated, and Mr. BARNEY's motion was adopted. Some few reports in favor of fencing in vacant lot's, flagging sidewalks, &c., were concurred in. A report in favor of paying Jas. S. Murray $132 79 for damages done to his premises by rioters on election day, Dec. 3, was concurred in. A resolution to pay $775 to B.F. Brady for engrossing resolutions complimentary to ex-Alderman Peck was lost for want of a constitutional vote. Mr. PINCKNEY moved to adjourn, which was lost, and the vote on the appropriation to Mr. Brady was reconsidered and the resolution laid over. A resolution to pay J.H.W. Cabe $175 for filling in sidewalks in Fifty-second-street was lost, but reconsidered. The report in favor of appropriating the room formerly occupied by the Superior Court (over the engine house corner of Chambers and Centre streets,) as a bunk room for Hose Company No. 28, and fitting it up at an expense of $200, was concurred in. The Board then adjourned until Saturday at 5 P.M.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held their regular meeting yesterday P.M., but as the other Board has adjourned sine dic no new business could be transacted, the attention of members being directed solely to papers sent from the other Board for concurrence. A large lobby was in attendance, but the floor of the Chamber was kept entirely free, thus avoiding much unnecessary noise and confusion. After the passage of one unimportant paper, Mr. BARNEY moved that when the Board adjourn it meet again on Saturday. Two amendments, viz.: to meet on Friday and to adjourn sine dic, were defeated, and Mr. BARNEY's motion was adopted. Cabe $175 for filling in sidewalks in Fifty-second-street was lost, but reconsidered. The report in favor of appropriating the room formerly occupied by the Superior Court (over the engine house corner of Chambers and Centre streets,) as a bunk room for Hose Company No. 28, and fitting it up at an expense of $200, was concurred in. The Board then adjourned until Saturday at 5 P.M.

abstract: The weather on New Year's morning was very fine, with a light wind from southwest--the barometer standing 29 7-10, indicating a blow, which about 12 P. M. commenced from southwest, and during the evening shifted to west northwest and has been blowing furiously since from that quarter. There have been numerous trifling cases of damage among the shipping in exposed situations. At the Union...
lead_paragraph: The weather on New Year's morning was very fine, with a light wind from southwest -- the barometer standing 29 7-10, indicating a blow, which about 12 P. M. commenced from southwest, and during the evening shifted to west northwest and has been blowing furiously since from that quarter. There have been numerous trifling cases of damage among the shipping in exposed situations. At the Union Stores at Brooklyn, where were moored numerous prize vessels, there was a lively time. The ship North Carolina parted all her hawsers and has her stern badly stove in. The brig Mary McRae parted all her moorings, stove rails, carried away house on deck, and received considerable other damage. The brig Delta had her stern frame carried away, and is badly chafed. The main rail and several stancheons of the brig Sarah Stark are gone, and she is badly chafed. The schooner Lynchburgh is badly chafed, and had a boat stove to pieces. The bark Sally McGee lost her figure-head, and had her stern badly stove. The bark Winfred is considerably damaged. The brig H.C. Brooks has the whole of her stern frame gone, and part of her rudder, and at one time it was thought she would sink.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury estimates the loss in real estate by the late fire at about $3,500,000, on which was an insurance for about $1,500,000. The chief burden has been borne by local companies. The amounts paid by the Charleston Insurance and Trust Company, South Carolina Insurance Company, will swallow up the capital stock and surplus of these institutions. The losses among agencies out of South Carolina have been about $300,000.

abstract: The importance of distrusting telegraphic abstracts of news cannot be overstated. The Halifax summary by the Asia gave no intimation that Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch to Mr. ADAMS, in reference to the affair of the Trent, had reached London. Yet, from the files of
lead_paragraph: The importance of distrusting telegraphic abstracts of news cannot be overstated. The Halifax summary by the Asia gave no intimation that Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch to Mr. ADAMS, in reference to the affair of the Trent, had reached London. Yet, from the files of English papers since received, we learn that a knowledge of the dispatch, and its conciliatory contents, had become current in well-informed circles, had acted favorably upon the Stock Exchange and Bourse, and had created a general anticipation of a peaceful settlement of the controversy.

abstract: -- It will gratify awide circle of acquaintance, who suffer with fortitude the prolonged absence of Mr. HIRAM FULLER from this city, to know the health of that gentleman to be excellent, and that he has just made his debut on British boards in London Assurance. Specifically, he has lectured in a West End hall before some scores of Americans, sprinkled with Yankee-hating Englishmen, in favor of the rebellion and in reprobation of the tyrannical abolition crusade the Lincoln Government is waging against the brave and independent spirits of the South. The success of this first appearance of the brave "Colonel" was marred by two or three circumstances. One was that he caused himself to be announced in puff preliminary by the London papers, as a gentleman amply, and, of course, favorably indorsed by the American Press; and to be introduced to his auditory as a "Colonel of the American Army;" whereas, it is needless to say, he will find it as difficult to produce such indorsement from any respectable print in America, as the commission under which he has been authorized at any time to command a regiment. It was another exceedingly unpleasant incident that the lamentable matter of his lecture was vigorously hissed throughout; the only applause following an allusion, which none could make more touchingly than the "former editor of the New-York Mirror," was to the sorrow of the Queen. The truth is, the Colonel FULLER, of the American Army, is, in more respects than one, a bit of imposter. Could his audience have found it out?
lead_paragraph: -- It will gratify awide circle of acquaintance, who suffer with fortitude the prolonged absence of Mr. HIRAM FULLER from this city, to know the health of that gentleman to be excellent, and that he has just made his debut on British boards in London Assurance. It was another exceedingly unpleasant incident that the lamentable matter of his lecture was vigorously hissed throughout; the only applause following an allusion, which none could make more touchingly than the "former editor of the New-York Mirror," was to the sorrow of the Queen. The truth is, the Colonel FULLER, of the American Army, is, in more respects than one, a bit of imposter. Could his audience have found it out?

abstract: It is impossible to say when that general advance of the army, from the different military centres, which has been so often predicted, will really take place. But one thing can be said now, which could never have been said before-that at very many points affairs
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to say when that general advance of the army, from the different military centres, which has been so often predicted, will really take place. But one thing can be said now, which could never have been said before -- that at very many points affairs are almost, if not quite, ready for a grand forward movement. The advance of the main body in Kentucky has been impossible heretofore for the reason that that superb structure, the railroad bridge over Green River, had been destroyed by the rebels, and there was no other means by which our army could cross that stream, so difficult of passage. It was over this bridge, also, by the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, that supplies and stores of every kind would necessarily have to be conveyed to our army after it began its Southward march. But the bridge is now repaired, and a large part of our Kentucky army is already on the south side of Green River, while the remainder is pouring over with all possible rapidity. When the whole of the body now on the line of the railroad shall have crossed, it is likely enough that there will be somewhere about sixty-five or seventy-five thousand Western soldiers within five hours' march of the rebel works and the rebel horde at Bowling Green. It is hardly within possibility that, situated as things there are, and with the spirit which pervades that division of the army, a general and a very fierce engagement can now be delayed. It is hardly possible that the army will sit down on the warm side of the river and intrench itself, in Potomac style. Such a policy has been necessary in the latter case; but nothing could be gained, and very much would certainly be lost, if Gen. BUELL were also to adopt it. All the signs in the Western sky will fail if there be not a movement before the current month runs out. Certainly everything there now seems ready.

abstract: ARRESTS FOR AN ATTEMPT AT PRIZE FIGHTING.-At an early hour yesterday morning a large number of arrests were made by the Police of persons who were suspected of being about to engage in or to attend a prize fight which, it was said, would take place in New Jersey, about ten miles beyond Hoboken. The Police Department were apprised of the contemplated encounter, and active measures were
lead_paragraph: ARRESTS FOR AN ATTEMPT AT PRIZE FIGHTING. -- At an early hour yesterday morning a large number of arrests were made by the Police of persons who were suspected of being about to engage in or to attend a prize fight which, it was said, would take place in New Jersey, about ten miles beyond Hoboken. The Police Department were apprised of the contemplated encounter, and active measures were at once taken by Superintendent KENNEDY to frustrate the entire plan. Officers were stationed at the several ferries leading to New Jersey, and as soon as any suspicious-looking persons arrived in a carriage, if the driver was unable to give a satisfactory answer to the question as to whither he was bound, the inmates of the vehicle were taken into custody and forthwith dispatched to the Station-house. In this way about thirty arrests were made at the different ferries between 2 and 6 o'clock yesterday morning. The parties arrested were yesterday taken before Justice CONNOLLY, and no evidence as to their intent to violate the law being produced, they were released. The officials succeeded, however, in putting a stop to, for a time at least, an illegal and bloody encounter.

abstract: The partial strike at the Brooklyn Navy-yard has been considerably exaggerated, but may now be looked upon as settled altogether. A great number of the artisans did not go to work until one o'clock yesterday, but at that time they were all present, with the exception of about fifty of the extremists, who, after mature deliberation, came to the wise conclusion of resuming work this morning.

abstract: The steamship Asia reached this port yesterday, with advices from Europe to the 22d inst., a very full summary of which was telegraphed from Halifax. The reception of the first dispatch from Mr. SEWARD to Mr.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Asia reached this port yesterday, with advices from Europe to the 22d inst., a very full summary of which was telegraphed from Halifax. The impression then conveyed by the news is borne out by the details -- that a much better feeling prevailed regarding the Treat affair, both in England and France. The reception of the first dispatch from Mr. SEWARD to Mr. ADAMS had become known, and somehow its character had leaked out, and created a partial revulsion in the public feeling, to the extent of giving the funds a decided rise. As early as the 19th, the London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian wrote that the impression in well-informed circles was decidedly in favor of the probabilites of peace; and most of the English papers -- of course we except the Times, which is bitterly and determinedly hostile -- speak hopefully of the possibility of avoiding war. The diplomatic correspondence of Mr. SEWARD, as first published in the NEW-YORK TIMES, had been received, and was extensively and variously commented upon. The Times finds in it nothing to praise and much to condemn, while the Star points out the revelation that the attitude of the British Government toward that of the United States has been one of continued hostility throughout our troubles.

abstract: The one hundred little children who compose the attendance at this school, and who have been sought out from the sloughs that infest our crowded thoroughfares, assembled yesterday, at 1 o'clock, in their school-room, and were received by their Principal, Miss MACEY, with a "Happy New-Year." There was music on the melodeon, accompanied by the youthful choristers in hymns, instructive glees, and answers to Biblical questions relating to the life of our Saviour. After this a line was formed, and the dining-room was the next consideration. The children passed through the beautiful garlands of green which were hung on either side of the passage and decorated the walls of the rooms, and luxuriated in a hearty dinner for once at least.

abstract: editorial speculates on Spanish intentions
snippet: editorial speculates on Spanish intentions
lead_paragraph: -- The proclamations of the Spanish commander of the Mexican expeditionary force, to his soldiers and the inhabitants of Vera Cruz, announce to us what Spaniards propose to accomplish in Mexico. "The Spanish troops who occupy your city," says Don MANUEL GASSET to the Vera Cruzans, "have no mission of conquest, no merely interested views. They have been led hither solely by the duty of demanding satisfaction for the failure to comply with treaties, and the acts of violence committed against our countrymen, as also by the necessity of obtaining guarantees that similar outrages shall not be repeated." But these are not the only objects of the expedition. "To reconquer the affection of those who were, in other times, our brothers," is also one of the achievements which, the General assures his comrades, in his military address, they are expected to perform.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening, President CROOKE in the Chair. After some routine business had been transacted the Committee of the Volunteer Relief Commission made a report, by which it appears that at their previous report they had on hand $28 65. Received since from County Treasurer $38,350. Paid out $37,645 to families of volunteers and $613 71 for current expenses, leaving a balance on hand of $119 94. The Committee continue to find persons who have drawn money improperly. A resolution was adopted cutting down the weekly stipend of grown persons to $1 50 per week instead of $2, as heretofore paid, and children to 30 instead of 50 cents per week, and allowing no family to receive more than $3 per week. A motion to rescind a resolution continuing the salaries of employes who go to the war was laid upon the table. The draft of an act was presented authorizing the County to issue bonds upon which to raise money for the families of volunteers, and adopted, and the Clerk directed toforward the same to Albany. The form of a petition was presented, calling upon the Legislature to assume the debt incurred by the several counties in supporting the families of volunteers. The matter was laid upon the table. The Board adjourned to Wednesday, the 15th inst.

abstract: Suppose, as will probably happen, some of the harbors of the South to be closed by the deposit of stones referred to, the effect would be but temporary. This war cannot last very long, and when it is ended, the opening of the ports will depend on nothing but the expenditure of a few thousand pounds. The talk of strangling commerce and destroying the ports for all time is mere rant. The proceeding in question has all the oddness and irregularity which the American character so much affects; but it is a bona fide operation of warfare, and not of unmeaning revenge. The Times tells us that, in the development of this war, we shall be witnesses of such scenes of horror as the world has not seen since men fought like wild beasts. But our cotemporary exhausted his vocabulary of horror last May in similar prophecies, which are yet unfulfilled. If he really wants to be enrolled among the guardians of the civilization of mankind, he has an opportunity of showing his ambition in a field where the responsibility of England is directly engaged. Impartial minds will judge newspapers as they judge men, not by the sentiments they may utter, but by the aim and tendency of their conduct, and will decline to believe in the superior humanity of those who are moving heaven and earth to entangle two Christian and Protestant nations in a fratricidal war.

abstract: " I presume the history of this distinguished officer is familiar to you. It ought to be landliar to the people of the Confederate States. It would show that in this age, as well as in former ages, circumstances develop genius, and that the pressure of events is enough to stimulate the qualities of the hero, even when heroism has been latent and unsuspected. Gen. PRICE'S campaign in Mexico waas decidedly one of the
lead_paragraph: "I presume the history of this distinguished officer is familiar to you. It ought to be landliar to the people of the Confederate States. It would show that in this age, as well as in former ages, circumstances develop genius, and that the pressure of events is enough to stimulate the qualities of the hero, even when heroism has been latent and unsuspected. Gen. PRICE'S campaign in Mexico waas decidedly one of the most brilliant episodes of the war. His conquest of New-Mexico, with a slender force of volunteers, his fertility of resource, and extraordinary energy and enterprise, displayed in suppressing the subsequent rebellion, and in his remarkable Winter campaign against the insurgent Indians, deserve to be recorded as the most shining page of the history of the Mexican war. Among the victories gained by Gen. PRICE, in that war, were the battles of Faos and Rosales, the latter fought against a very superior force, commanded by Don ANGEL FREAS, Governor of Chihuahua, a gentleman who has of late years become well known in the country as a distinguished leader of the Mexican leaders. The same characteristics have marked Gen. PRICE's recent campaign in Missouri; the same originality of conception, energy of action, readiness of invention and audacity of enterprise. The attack upon Lexington, which, after its successful finale, was admitted to be one of the most brilliant affairs of the whole war, was, it is understood, discouraged here by the partsans of the cautious and dilatory policy.

abstract: A war has broken out at Albany, between the old and the new State Treasurers. Mr. LEWIS, the new Treasurer, neglected to file his bond before the 1st inst., as required by law, and Mr. DORSHEIMER, the old Treasurer, contends that this neglect disqualifies Mr. LEWIS for the office, and that consequently it is his duty to retain possession. Meantime the Comptroller refuses to accept drafts drawn by Mr. DORSHEIMER, and the business of the office is consequently clogged, and will remain so until the question is legally settled.
lead_paragraph: A war has broken out at Albany, between the old and the new State Treasurers. Meantime the Comptroller refuses to accept drafts drawn by Mr. DORSHEIMER, and the business of the office is consequently clogged, and will remain so until the question is legally settled.

abstract: A SCHOONER LOST ON THE SOUND. -- We learn from a gentleman who came from New-York by the Stonington boat, on Wednesday night, that a schooner, name unknown, was run into by the Norwich boat, City of New-York, and sunk -- all on board being lost. The casualty occurred off Stratford, Conn. Another account says the schooner capsized. Unavailing efforts were made by the steamer to find the crew. -- Providence Post.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday continued the inquest upon the body of ANDREW J. FOWLER, who was killed during a fight early Wednesday morning last, at a disreputable house, No. 80 West Houston-street. Six witnesses were examined yesterday, and seven the day previous. The testimony thus far does not fix the murder upon any one particular person, except
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY yesterday continued the inquest upon the body of ANDREW J. FOWLER, who was killed during a fight early Wednesday morning last, at a disreputable house, No. 80 West Houston-street. Six witnesses were examined yesterday, and seven the day previous. The testimony thus far does not fix the murder upon any one particular person, except so far as the evidence of Mrs. Virginia Mones, -- who was examined yesterday, -- tends to that result. She testified that she resides at No. 70 West Houston street, and has a room on the third floor in front; she heard a loud noise in the street at about 3 3/4 o'clock on Wednesday morning; she went to the window and raised it, looked out, and saw a man lying on the sidewalk; saw a short man, dressed same as the prisoner (GOLDEN) now is, in the act of striking the man as he lay upon the walk; saw him strike two blows with a knife, and afterwards saw him kick the man who was down; the man who gave the blows and kicks then went into the house No. 80, and shut the door with a slam; there was a gaslight near the house, so that I could see all that took place; I saw the glitter of the knife-blade, as the blows were struck; the man who lay upon the walk hallooed, "Oh! Watch!" three times; as the man went back into the house, he jumped very quickly upon the steps; I heard the slam of the door very distinctly.

abstract: A telegram from Halifax gives currency to the terrible rumor that the British steamship Parana, with eleven hundred troops on board, had been lost in the St. Lawrence River. The rumor has not been traced to any reliable source, but there is a possibility that it may be true. The hurricane of New-Year's night was very severo in that latitude.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SUN IN OLD HANDS. -- Among the many changes brought to our notice by the incoming of the New Year, none has been more gratifying than the resumption by MOSES S. BEACH of the entire control, pecuniary and editorial, of the Sun. During many years there was no more thoroughly conscientious or laborious member of the editorial fraternity than he, and when, a year since, he announced his retirement from the management of his paper, and his determination thenceforth to devote his life to rural enjoyment and domestic repose, he met with sincere congratulations at all hands, that the fruits of his labor had been so plenteous as to permit him to act thus wisely. Circumstances not necessary to notice, have altered his determination, and with the New Year he came again, and has formally written himself Editor and Sole Proprietor of the New-York Sun. Of his new career, we have a brief programme in the announcement of various improvements in the character of the paper; among others, one of those continued tales which were among its most popular characteristics in the days of its highest popularity. The name of the writer, Mrs. SOUTHWORTH, is a warrant that the story of "The Hunted Down," will be of the utmost melodramatic interest Mr. BEACH is assisted in his labors by Mr. CHURCH, who, while connected with the Sun for months past, has been a protestant against and a dissenter from the policy which its recent managers substituted for that of its founders and earlier conductors.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SUN IN OLD HANDS. -- Among the many changes brought to our notice by the incoming of the New Year, none has been more gratifying than the resumption by MOSES S. abstract: -- The Message which Gov. ANDREW has just sent to the Massachusetts Legislature is certainly the most extraordinary document of its kind ever penned. It fills seventy-five huge octavo pages, and is of a vastness of design that takes for granted the whole theory of a future state of being. We print on another page a finite portion of it -- "the rest is silence." Nothing could be more curious than the effect produced by this strange mixture of mundane affairs with rapt transcendental speculation, and the Governor seems to have drawn his inspiration now from official statistics and now from the Vishnoo Parana. But it contains a splendid record of work done by Massachussetts, nevertheless, and the recital of the raising, recruiting, training, arming and equipping the twenty-seven thousand men she has in the field in defence of the Republic, and the zeal, earnestness and vigor that pervades the whole movement, give the effect of a living war-ode thrown off by the old Puritan Bay State.
lead_paragraph: -- The Message which Gov. ANDREW has just sent to the Massachusetts Legislature is certainly the most extraordinary document of its kind ever penned. But it contains a splendid record of work done by Massachussetts, nevertheless, and the recital of the raising, recruiting, training, arming and equipping the twenty-seven thousand men she has in the field in defence of the Republic, and the zeal, earnestness and vigor that pervades the whole movement, give the effect of a living war-ode thrown off by the old Puritan Bay State.

abstract: Capts. MANSON and SHILLINGLAW, of the New-York Seventy-ninth (Highland) Regiment, arrived in this City last night, having just been released from their captivity in Richmond, Va. Capt. MANSON was serenaded shortly after his arrival, and there was a large gathering of his friends at his residence, corner of Spring and Varick streets, to welcome him home. He is hale and hearty, and is delighted at his return to liberty and his family. Capt. SHILLINGLAW, it will be remembered, was severely wounded at the battle of Bull Run. His left thigh was shattered by a ball, as also his left arm, and in the same arm he received a musket-ball which has not yet been extracted. He still suffers considerably from his wounds, but expects soon to be relieved, as he will now have the skill and attention of New-York surgeons. The prisoners at Richmond still suffer grievous hardships, and long greatly for a release.

abstract: Editorial on pro-South views of British diplomat T C Grattan, just published in pamphlet form; Editorial holds Union armies ready for advance
snippet: Editorial on pro-South views of British diplomat T C Grattan, just published in pamphlet form; Editorial holds Union armies ready for advance
lead_paragraph: Mr.THOMAS COLLEY GRATTAN, formerly British Consul at Boston, has contributed his quota to the volume of abuse and misrepresentation that the English Press has been engaged in pouring out upon the United States since the seizure of the Confederate Commissioners became known in that country. Mr. GRATTAN's qualifications for the task he has applied himself to, are well known through his work on Civilized America; and he has furnished further proof of them in the pamphlet which he has just published. The North is, throughout its pages, treated with contempt and contumely, whilst the South is praised and encouraged. To repeat all that is written in this strain, would be throwing oil on flame, and it is more to the purpose to set forth Mr. GRATTAN's views as to what is likely to come out of the affair of the Trent. There is, he assures us, for the time,

abstract: To bear excessive hardships and privations without complaint or demoralization, men must be inspired with a great motive or principle, the vindication of which is abundant compensation for every sacrifice, even death itself. What can be the principle that sustains ...
lead_paragraph: To bear excessive hardships and privations without complaint or demoralization, men must be inspired with a great motive or principle, the vindication of which is abundant compensation for every sacrifice, even death itself. What can be the principle that sustains the rebel army at Manassas, shivering under their clothing of cotton, -- for that of all the dead bodies but two of the rebels found after the fight at Dranesville consisted entirely of cotton, overcoats and all? An army ill fed, badly sheltered, destitute of nearly all the comforts of life, and whose ranks are consequently thinned faster by disease than they could be by a succession of severe engagements in the field? The rebel soldiers are directed to the destruction of a Government which a year or two ago they were as loud in praise of as those now contending in its defence. The Stars and Stripes, the symbol of our nationality, stirred their hearts to a pitch of enthusiasm as intense as it did our own. There is hardly a perceptible cause of personal antipathy. They can be sustained by no motive of personal advantage; for whatever the dreams that were indulged in in the outset, these must, by the inaction in which they have been held, have completely dissipated all expectation of an advance into Northern territory. The greater part of this army has no motive or interest in sustaining Slavery, but really even interest in its destruction. They are not the owners of human chattels whose labor stigmatizes their own industry. The absence of any adequate motive or principle might not prove entirely destructive, if the rebels were as well fed and cared for as are our own soldiers., The lack of occupation would be unfortunate but it might have left the men contented in their ranks. But when this is relieved by no purpose or material comfort, the effect must be immediate and most disastrous. Hence we can readily credit the statement of a Richmond paper, smuggled through by one of the exchanged soldiers in his boot, that the army at Manassas is so thoroughly demoralized that regimental drills are almost entirely abandoned; that the men spend their time at games at cards; that those who have means are offering very large sums for substitutes, and that enlistment of new recruits has almost entirely ceased.

abstract: On the 28th of February last a little girl, whose parents reside at No. 61 James-street, was very mysteriously taken from them. Mr. MICHAEL GREENAN, the father of the child, made every effort in his power to ascertain the whereabouts of his daughter, but all to no purpose. The police were notified, thd telegraph ...
lead_paragraph: On the 28th of February last a little girl, whose parents reside at No. 61 James-street, was very mysteriously taken from them. Mr. MICHAEL GREENAN, the father of the child, made every effort in his power to ascertain the whereabouts of his daughter, but all to no purpose. The police were notified, thd telegraph brought into requisition, and the office for the temporary detention of lost children was visited day after day by the anxious relatives, but no clue could be obtained. The last seen of the child was on the sidewalk in front of the parents' residence, on the day above named. Recently Detective WILSON and officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct, undertook to ferret out the mystery, and after much labor and time spent in the search, they have at last succeeded in restoring the lost child to its parents. They found the girl in the company of gipsies, near Sing Sing, on the Hudson River. A young woman, named ANN MCCLUSKY, was arrested and brought to this City with the child. ANN states that she took the little girl as she was playing on the sidewalk in front of its parents' house. The accused is only 19 years of age, and appears quite intelligent for a gipsey. Justice CONNOLLY, before whom she was taken yesterday, committed her to await a further examination. The child is about 2 years of age, and though naturally bright and interesting, it has become rather wayward and forbidding in appearance during its ten months sojourn among the gipsies.

abstract: -- By a letter received in this city from Capt. DAVIS, of the bark Helen W. Almy, dated Sydney, Oct. 22, 1861, we learn of the rescue from captivity of one of the crew of the bark Superior, which was burned by the natives of Treasury Island, in November, 1860. It appears from a statement in the Sydney Herald of the 21st October last, that the Rebecca, Capt. DEVELIN, engaged in the Island trade, under instructions from the American Consul, touched at Treasury Island on the 30th March last. The natives, as usual, gathered about the ship, and the Chief, COPAN, and his son came on board. Capt. DEVELIN at once secured them, and demanded the liberation of three of the Superior's crew held in captivity. The chief stated that two of them had escaped by seizing a canoe and reaching a whaler on the coast, but that he would give up the other. He sent on shore, and the man, POWLIN, a Portuguese, was brought off, who confirmed the story of the escape of the other two. Capt. DEVELIN brought of several articles belonging to the ship, together with her boat. Capt. DAVIS writes that POWLIN was in the hospital at Sydney. The log-book of the Superior, and the watch of the ill-fated Capt. WOOD, in a mutilated condition, are in the hands of the United States Consul.

abstract: The agent who was intrusted by Secretary SEWARD with the duty of delivering MASON and SLIDELL into British custody has returned to Washington and made his report.
