abstract: One of the most destructive fires that has ever visited this village took place last evening. The fire broke out in the Eagle Hotel about 7 o'clock. The hotel was occupied and owned by ISAAC FAIRCHILD and was entirely consumed, together with a majority of the furniture. All the property saved was in a damaged condition. FAIRCHILD'S loss is about $8,000; no insurance.

abstract: The resources of the great store-rooms in our new Arsenal, situated at the corner of Thirty-fifthstreet and Seventh-avenue, have been heavily drawn upon during the past season, no less than 100 regiments having been fully equipped from its ample supplies; yet, so systematically are its facilities for replenishment planned, that at the present time a larger and more valuable stock of military equipments crowd its varied and appropriate receptacles than ever before.

abstract: Editorial on war frenzy in Canada
snippet: Editorial on war frenzy in Canada
lead_paragraph: The course of things in Canada since the capture of MASON and SLIDELL has been noticeable. The Canadians received the news of that capture without much disturbance of their equanimity, but the news that England had flown into a rage over it at once stirred up all the Canadian deeps, and ever since then the Canadians have out-heroded Herod in the fierceness of their wrath against us, and their threats of what Canada and England would do for us in case we refused to give the traitors up. This state of mind among them is the natural effect of their colonial relation to England. That makes them look across the water for their fashions and for their public sentiment as well. It is natural that they should do so. We see the same thing in individuals all the time. The boy who goes away from his father's house and sets up in business for himself, always looks back toward home for sympathy, and it takes time as well as strength of character on his part to enable him to judge of affairs in opposition to the views of those to whom he has been accustomed to look for praise or blame. It is the effect of this tendency in human nature that colonies always reflect the tone of the mother country. Canada was not angry at first, because she was uncertain how England was going to take it, and her nearness to us made her share our feelings in the matter; that feeling that the affair was not one of very great consequence, which has been such a marvel to all our friends on the other side of the water, as THURLOW WEED wrote in one of his last letters.
headline: {'main': 'The War Frenzy in Canada.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The War Frenzy in Canada.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday Gen. SHIELDS arrived in the steamer Northern Light, from California. Some time ago orders were sent from the War Department for Gen. SHIELDS to report himself at headquarters. Being in ill-health at the time, the General was in Mexico in order to recuperate. Consequently, the commands for his return remained in California, awaiting his arrival from Mexico, for over a month. Immediately on receipt of his orders he left for New-York, so as to report at Washington at once. It was supposed that Gen. SHIELDS would be appointed Brigadier-General of the Irish Brigade, has owing to the delay of his arrival, Gen. MEAGHER was appointed in his stead. At present Gen. SHIELDS has not been appointed to any definite command, but no doubt will be, directly he reports himself to Gen. MCCLELLAN. Gen. SHIELDS is stopping at Judge DALY's residence, No. 84 Clinton-place. Previous to leaving California, Gen. SHIELDS published the following card, relative to the verbal attack made upon him by Senator MCDOUGALL;

abstract: There were shrewd hints in the latest news direct from Port Royal, published yesterday, that Com. DUPONT and Gen. SHERMAN were about to strike a blow at South Carolina in a new quarter. We are indebted to rebel sources for intimations that the blow has in all probability been struck, and if we can judge from the very imperfect details we as yet have, it is likely to be a telling one. It is simply stated that " a large force of Nationals" had landed on North Edisto, and seized possession of a point on the Charleston and Savannah Railroad. The importance of advancing up from Beaufort and securing command of this important line of communication at Coosawhatchie has been repeatedly pointed out, but the advantage of striking the blow at the locality mentioned, Edisto Island, is evident. Edisto is one of the group of islands and islets lying between Port Royal and Charleston, and the point at which we have obtained possession of the railroad is within about twenty-five miles of that city, which is but half the distance it is from Coosawhatchie to Charleston. The spot is admirably adapted for the combined operation of land and naval forces, and gives us an excellent point from which to strike at the heart of the secession rebellion. We shall look forward with interest to direct tidings of these operations in South Carolina. Commodore DUPONT and Gen. SHERMAN must surely know that no "Happy New-Year" they can possibly send the Nation would be half so welcome as a bulletin from the Union Army in Charleston.

abstract: This pleasant little city yesterday welcomed the advent of a New Year in a spirited and very agreeable style. The presence of a large number of military officers, and a general suspension of business, which enabled all classes to enjoy the day, gave the streets a very lively and fashionable appearance.
lead_paragraph: This pleasant little city yesterday welcomed the advent of a New Year in a spirited and very agreeable style. The presence of a large number of military officers, and a general suspension of business, which enabled all classes to enjoy the day, gave the streets a very lively and fashionable appearance. The mansions of the more wealthy portion and middle classes were thrown open to all, and a succession of "calls" consumed the forenoon. The officers residing in town were not behind in tendering the hospitalities of the occasion to their less fortunate brother officers and citizens. Gay uniforms reflected the bright sunlight in every street, and greetings were as cordial and happy as a reunion of lovers.

abstract: Editorial sees Memphis, Tenn, in state of panic
snippet: Editorial sees Memphis, Tenn, in state of panic
lead_paragraph: The few big cities situated in the dominions of JEFF. DAVIS are all in an exceedingly bad way. New-Orleans, whose levees last year at this time were piled mountain-high with the products of the Gulf cotton fields and the produce of the Mississippi Valley -- whose port was crowded with ships of all nations, and whose streets were filled with life and commerce -- is now minus ships, commerce, cotton, corn and cash, and is mentioned only occasionally in connection with some "grand review" of seedy old Home Guards, or as being the place after which is named those irrepressible rebel blackguards, the "New-Orleans Tigers." Charleston, the next largest city in Secessiondom, is in a still worse plight -- a wretched, charred, ruined old town. Richmond, which is third in size, is the rebel capital; and no more need be said of it. Its own papers describe it as sunk below the level of the most debauched cities in or out of Christendom. Mobile is a commercial city that was. It trembles, too, at the echo of every gun from Fort Pickens. Savannah has run away panic-stricken. There is only Fort Pulaski between it and Tybee. Memphis, which is the only other secession town of twenty thousand people, has now also been attacked by a panic which would be extravagant, had it not a well-founded cause.
headline: {'main': 'Memphis in a Panic.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Memphis in a Panic.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Stevens Battery demonstrated for military personnel, Hoboken, NJ
snippet: Stevens Battery demonstrated for military personnel, Hoboken, NJ
lead_paragraph: The invited guests assembled at 11 A.M. in the Battery office, in Hoboken, where carriages were in waiting to convey them to the scene of the proposed experiments. EDWIN A. STEVENS, Esq., was present in person, and received his guests with great cordiality. The latter comprised Hon. Robert J. Walker, Ex-Secretary of the U.S. Treasury; Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Harrington; Collector Hiram Barney, Collector of the Port of New-York: Gen. Benham, of Western Virginia fame; Major-General Sanford; Hon. Geo. Opdyke, Mayor of New-York: Gen. E.R.V. Wright, of New-Jersey; Ex-Gov. King, of this State; Col. Lefferts, of the Seventh Regiment N.Y.S.M.; Gen. Barry and Col. Kingsbury, of Gen. McClellan's Staff; Gen. Prosper M. Wetmore; Denning Duer, Esq., and R.H. McCurdy, of the N.Y. Chamber of Commerce; Hon. Simeon Draper, of the N.Y.Union Defence Committee; Capt. Meace, of the U.S. receiving-ship North Carolina; Capt. Foote, of the New-York Navy-yard; Col. Loomis, Dr. Griscom, Mr. Park Godwin, of the New-York Evening Post; Capt. Nye, Capt. Rogers, Judge Hoffmann, Mr. Craven, Chairman of the Croton Water Works; Wm. E. Morris, President of the Long Island Railroad; Henry R. Dunham, Civil Engineer; Commodore Stringham and Chief Engineer Stimers, of the Government Commission appointed to investigate and report upon the battery and many others of note.

abstract: Editorial views Southern secession as form of insanity
snippet: Editorial views Southern secession as form of insanity
lead_paragraph: However the past year may leave us as regards the material extinction of the rebellion as it shows itself in armed forces, there is the best assurance that morally it is, in a great measure, broken. The new year finds the Southern people in a quite other temper than the last did. The frenzy into which the conspirators succeeded in working the South, and on the strength of which they had hoped to effect the ruin of the Republic, has passed its crisis and rapidly subsides. That misguided people, stripped of a thousand illusions, already realize through some of its fruits, the true character of the stupendous folly into which they permitted themselves to be "precipitated." It will not be long before they will, themselves, be able to see, in the light of returning reason, what all loyal men have throughout seen -- how completely their rebellion bears the aspect of a fit of madness.
headline: {'main': 'The Southern Madness and its Cure.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Southern Madness and its Cure.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The recent exchanges of prisoners have  been of a proportion that gives leave to hope that hesitation is at an end in regard to this vital matter. In another column we ...
lead_paragraph: print the names of the two hundred and forty Union soldiers lately released and who reached Fortress Monroe on Friday. One can imagine the joy the release brought to our brave fellows who have for long weary months been pining in Southern prisons, -- we may say dungeons -- for Mr. FAULKNER has made known the shameful contrast in the Northern and Southern treatment of captives. It is to be hoped this example will be imitated on a still larger scale. The incubus that long paralyzed action in this matter was the conviction that to consent to an exchange of prisoners would be in some sort a concession of belligerent rights to the rebels. It will be remembered by the readers of this Journal that we showed some weeks ago, in an elaborate historical examination of the mode of treating the question during the Revolution, that there was no difficulty in our realizing all the benefits of an exchange of prisoners, without in the least impugning our sovereign rights over the rebels. We showed that it was freely done by the military chiefs during the War of Independence, when the colonies were rebels against a Power tenacious, if ever nation were, of both the substance and the shadow of its sovereign rights. Since then the subject has been taken up by the Massachusetts Historical Society, and an elaborate memoire prepared thereon by their committee, consisting of three eminent historical and legal scholars -- JARED SPARKS, EDWARD EVERETT and GEORGE T. CURTIS. They arrive at precisely the results we indicated in the article mentioned. They show that exchanging prisoners began almost with the war, it having been effected in the case of those taken on each side at the battle of Lexington. It was, however, done, throughout, by individual arrangements between the commanders, the Royal Government not being willing to come to any general agreement -- as "it might imply an acknowledgment inconsistent with the claims of the English Government." And so it continued till the end of the war -- thousands and thousands being exchanged in this informal manner. There can surely be no objection to our conceding as much as Britain was willing to do, at a day when National pride and prerogative reached their amplest development. And as the dictate of common sense in the matter is reinforced by historical analogies and antecedents, it is to be hoped that our Government will see the importance of giving the principle its widest application, and gladden the hearts of thousands of loyal men, restored once more to the protection of the flag in whose defence they lost their liberty.

abstract: I came over from London last night, leaving the station near London Bridge at 8  P.M., and reaching Paris at 7  this morning. In crossing the Channel, the weather being clear, I remained on the deck of the steamer all the way from Dover to Calais, watching the lessening lights of the Cliffs of Dover as we progressed, until, long before we were half across, the Calais lights appeared.

abstract: Poor old BENNETT, who has lately announced that he has "had religion," not content with being as pious as a monk, has become as metaphysical as a schoolman. In yesterday's Herald he addresses his patrons of the concert saloons, rum-holes, junk-shops and brothels in an elaborate article on the "Berkeleyan Theory of Vision." Hear him:" To BERKELEY is the world indebted for the true theory of human vision as well as the explosion of philosophical fallacies supported by great names." Old BENNETT's optics are certainly advantageously located for studying "the true theory of human vision" -- adding to the Shakespearian power of looking before and after, that of squinting round the corner with an eye for a cowhide. But it is probable that there is a deeper meaning in the philosopher's metaphysical speculations. BERKELEY's theory of vision was simply the doctrine of the unsubstantiability of matter -- that the material world is "all in your eye," so to say. Now there is not the least doubt that BENNETT feels the need of the consolation derived from this doctrine -- for the ruinous decline in the Herald's circulation and advertising patronage is calculated to make him think this world is all a fleeting show. His chief reliance now is on the advertisements of the concert saloons. But as the Grand Jury has taken in hand to squelch these infamous haunts of prostitution, he will soon lose the support of the columns of serried capitals showing forth the charms of the "pretty waiter girls." Poor old BENNETT is making ready to withdraw then, with a full stock of brimstone, to the study of "the true theory of human vision."

abstract: -- BENJAMIN FRANKLIN JOSLIN, M.D., LL.D., one of the most prominent homoeopathic physicians of this city, died at his residence, Dec. 31, 1861. He was born in Exeter, R.I., Nov. 25, 1796, and in 1799 removed to this State, where he has since resided. He graduated at Union College in 1821, and as a physician at the College of Physicians and Surgeons in this City in 1826. He did not, however, enter at once upon the practice of his profession, having received the appointment of Professor of Chemistry and the Natural Sciences in the Polytechny, Chattenango, in 1826, which position he held until 1827, when he was made Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy in Union College. There he remained until 1837, when he determined to devote himself exclusively to the practice of medicine, and for this purpose he entered into partnership with Dr. B.F. BOWERS, of this City. His reputation as a man of scientific attainments had preceded him, and he was induced to accept the position in the University in the City of New-York which he had so well filled at Schenectady. In 1844 he resigned his Professorship, and from that time until within about a week of his death he practiced medicine. His conversion to homoeopathy was the result of investigations, which he was induced to make by receiving a request from a friend to give his opinion of the system. Dr. JOSLIN was an industrious, faithful student, a profound and original thinker, [???] his ideas with remarkable clearness and precision. He was the author of several standard works on homoeopathy, and a frequent contributor to various scientific and professional journals. He was a widower, and leaves two sons, residents of this City, Rev. TITUS JOSLIN, a clergyman, and BENJAMINS F. JOSLIN, Jr., M.D., a physician. At a special meeting of the Homoeopathic Medical Society of the County of New-York, of which Dr. JOSLIN was President, held Thursday evening, the 2d inst., resolutions of respect for the deceased, and of condolence with his family, offered by Dr. BAYARD, were unanimously adopted.

abstract: Recruiting for the army continues very dull. Six or eight men were enlisted here last week, only one of whom was for general service. It was expected that the office for the Twelfth Infantry would be closed on the 31st December, but it is still open, and will remain so for some time. A few of the companies of the Twelfth at Fort Hamilton are not quite full yet. The men are in the new wooden barracks just completed, and find themselves much more comfortable than when in tents.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the army continues very dull. Six or eight men were enlisted here last week, only one of whom was for general service. abstract: Gov. WASHBURNE sent in his message to the Maine Legislature on January 1. Briefly adverting to the causes of the present war, and declaring that the people expected and demanded that all lawful, usual, efficient measures and policies should be adopted which would tend to promote its speedy and successful termination, he states that while the war is not to be carried on for the abolition of slavery, but for the preservation of the Government, nevertheless the people will permit no Congress, no Administration, no officers of the army or navy to protract it, increase the expenditures of blood and treasure which its prolongation would cost, and shake the popular confidence in a successful issue, by holding and treating property in negroes as more sacred than property of any other description. If by striking the chains from the slaves of rebels, and destroying the property claims of traitors in black men, the war may be ended sooner than it can be if such claims are treated as sacred and inviolable; and if, thereby, millions of treasure and thousands of the lives of our brothers, the young, the gallant and the true, the pride and the hope of the country, may be saved, they will demand and insist, in tones that will be heard and respected, that the chains shall fall and the war cease.
lead_paragraph: Gov. WASHBURNE sent in his message to the Maine Legislature on January 1. If by striking the chains from the slaves of rebels, and destroying the property claims of traitors in black men, the war may be ended sooner than it can be if such claims are treated as sacred and inviolable; and if, thereby, millions of treasure and thousands of the lives of our brothers, the young, the gallant and the true, the pride and the hope of the country, may be saved, they will demand and insist, in tones that will be heard and respected, that the chains shall fall and the war cease.

abstract: REORGANIZATION OF THE STATE MILITIA IN KINGS COUNTY. By a recent order from the AdjutantGeneral's office, a new brigade is to be organized in this county, and the following district assigned to the same: First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, Tenth and Twelfth Wards of Brooklyn, and appointing JESSE C. SMITH, late Colonel of the Fourteenth Regiment, and present Senator representing the Second District, to the command thereof.
lead_paragraph: REORGANIZATION OF THE STATE MILITIA IN KINGS COUNTY. -- By a recent order from the AdjutantGeneral's office, a new brigade is to be organized in this county, and the following district assigned to the same: First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, Tenth and Twelfth Wards of Brooklyn, and appointing JESSE C. SMITH, late Colonel of the Fourteenth Regiment, and present Senator representing the Second District, to the command thereof. The brigade district is divided into four regimental districts, as follows: A regimental district to be known as the Twenty-third, to comprise the First, Second and Third Wards; Forty-seventh Regiment, comprising the Fourth and Fifth Wards; Fifty-second Regimental District, to embrace the Sixth and Twelfth Wards; and the Fifty-sixth Regimental District, embracing the Eighteenth and Eighth Wards. The Fifth Brigade District to comprise the whole of the County of Kings not included in the Eleventh Brigade District. The regimental districts of the Fifth Brigade are divided as follows: Thirteenth Regiment -- Seventh and Eleventh Wards; Fourteenth Regiment -- Thirteenth, Fourteenth and Seventeenth Wards; Twenty-eighth Regiment -- Fifteenth, Sixteenth and Nineteenth Wards, and the Seventieth Regiment -- Ninth and Eighteenth Wards and county towns. Brig.-Gen. CROOK, of the Fifth, and Brig.-Gen. SMITH, of the Eleventh Brigades, are ordered to divide the districts in their respective brigade districts into company districts, and report such division to the Commander-in-Chief, to the end that an order may be issued for the assignment of companies in such districts.

abstract: Intelligence through private as well as public channels, indicates the existence of severe suffering among the National troops, owing to the severily of the weather. Save in exceptional instances unprovided with Winter quarters or fuel, they are exposed to all the  unwholesome effects of the keen cold, without...
lead_paragraph: Intelligence through private as well as public channels, indicates the existence of severe suffering among the National troops, owing to the severily of the weather. Save in exceptional instances unprovided with Winter quarters or fuel, they are exposed to all the unwholesome effects of the keen cold, without other beds than the frozen ground, or other covering than the regulation blanket. Their case is not so desperately hard perhaps, as that of the British army in the [???]. They are at least supplied with abundance of warm clothing, and have a liberal Commissariat, food being the producer of animal if not of artificial heat; but animal heat, unaided by fires and the comforts of a warm bed, escapes too rapidly to permit the resting or sleeping soldier to retain the active vitality necessary to uninterrupted health. The tent invented for use in tropical climates, is a wholly inadequate shelter amid such rigors as the present. Its easy carriage adapts it partially to the wants of an army in active motion, whatever the season; but for armies at rest, and at rest in the most inclement of Winter weather, nothing could be more unsuitable. And what forests or coal-pits, could furnish, heat to a host of two hundred thousand men, situated as is the Army of the Potomac? It is no matter of surprise, therefore, that the individual soldier complains, and finds no consolation in the assurance that the enemy, coming from a region of perpetual Summer, and half-clad, half-fed, and demoralized, must be suffering far more acutely than himself. The case is not one of those where the pains of others act as an agreeable panaced for the dissatisfied and ill at case.

abstract: The annual statement from this office for 1861, imparts some valuable information, and makes some practical suggestions, the adoption of which will undoubtedly tend to greater public convenience, and much facilitate the operations of the Department.
lead_paragraph: The annual statement from this office for 1861, imparts some valuable information, and makes some practical suggestions, the adoption of which will undoubtedly tend to greater public convenience, and much facilitate the operations of the Department. The estimates for the present year are $1,564,478 being $233,698 less than was required last year, and there remains unexpended from last year's appropriation a balance of $32,500, which speaks well for the economical manner in which the affairs of the various Bureaus have been managed. The reports of the different Bureaus give in detail the various works which have been commenced or completed during the past year, the greater part of which have heretofore been noticed in the daily prints. In the Bureau of Street improvements, the most important in the Department, a radical change has been effected by advice of the Corporation Counsel. It was formerly supposed to be necessary to advertise in all the Corporation papers for ten days for objections on all resolutions and ordinances of the Common Council, directing any improvement involving any assessment upon property; then the advertising was repeated on inviting proposals for the work, making, with the first advertising of the resolution or ordinance by the Clerk of the Common Council, three times advertising of each matter of improvement, which was a rather expensive programme. Under Mr. BRONSON's opinion, however, the advertisement, in each case, is now only given out with the invitation for proposals, he holding that the ordinance directing the Street Commissioner to advertise past notices is set aside when the Common Council orders the work to be done. Property-owners would do well to remember this, and not hereafter wait to be invited, by special advertisement, to object to any plan of improvement.

abstract: -- The Herald is trying to induce some of its neighbors to print and comment upon the "report" of the Van Wyck Investigating Committee. The fact is, a few extracts from the testimony taken by the Committee compose the public document the Herald alludes to, the matter given being only so much as relates to Gen. FREMONT's Department, with enough evidence of a different sort to disguise the apparent fact that the premature issue of so much was hastened in order to prejudice the case of that officer. The testimony taken by the Committee, and already in print, forms, we understand, a volume of more than a thousand pages, and analyzes, with much thoroughness, the entire contract business of the War Department. When that is made public, it will be a matter of interest to see whether the Herald will print even a digest of its contents, and give it fair editorial consideration.
lead_paragraph: -- The Herald is trying to induce some of its neighbors to print and comment upon the "report" of the Van Wyck Investigating Committee. lead_paragraph: As indirect taxes can probably not be imposed by Congress to so large an extent as to provide, without [???] inconvenience, the [???] for carrying of our present war, and for conducting, at the same time, the ordinary operations of the National Government, some direct taxes will doubtless be imposed, and among those which offer themselves to our choice, a tax on property and income similar to that which, for twenty years, has produced so large a revenue in England, seems likely to be adapted to the financial emergency in which we find ourselves at the opening of the present year.

abstract: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, Gen. SHIELDS left for Washington in a special train of cars. He was accompanied by Major SMITH, Capts. COLLINS and WHITTLESEY, Lieuts. HAYCOCK and MARTIN, and Drs. HASSEN and BROWN, all of the United States army. After the departure of the General, the residence of Judge DALY, at which place he stopped while in the City, was literally besieged with people anxious to pay their respects to Gen. SHIELDS. A deputation from the Sixty-ninth Militia Regiment also called in order to make arrangements to serenade the General, but of course were disappointed, as he had already left for the Capital.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, Gen. SHIELDS left for Washington in a special train of cars. He was accompanied by Major SMITH, Capts. COLLINS and WHITTLESEY, Lieuts. abstract: If there is any subject, into the minutest details of which a Government conducting one war, and [???] by another, may searchingly and experimentally inquire with entire propriety, it would appear to be the subject of coast and harbor defence. Our own Government, inspelled by the pressure of haste and the conduct of operations infinitely diversified as well as infinitely important has been content to substitute for it an amount of amateur opinion and guess-work which would be deemed wholly inadequate by individuals in the management of their own affairs, and is unprecedented in the more deliberate counsels of foreign States. And it has been left -- necessarily, perhaps -- to the enterprise and patriotism of a private citizen to show the public, at his own cost, and in the most trustworthy manner, the first perfectly protected marine structure, as against the heaviest and most destructive [???] in the naval practice of any country.

abstract: The State Legislature meets to-day. A majority of the members were already in Albany on Saturday night, and yesterday much interest was manifested in the organization. The prominent candidates for the Speakership are HENRY J. RAYMOND, of New-York, Mr. HURLBURT, of St. Lawrence, SAMUEL STETSON of Clinton, and THOMAS G. ALVORD, of Onondaga. Some other gentlemen are also put forward, but not prominently. Mr. RAYMOND appeared last night to have the most positive strength. With reference to the State Treasury imbroglio, it is understood that Mr. DORSHEIMER has agreed to abide by the decision of the Attorney-General, who is not at present in Albany.
lead_paragraph: The State Legislature meets to-day. A majority of the members were already in Albany on Saturday night, and yesterday much interest was manifested in the organization. abstract: When the cynical, censorious Jaques says  to Orlando, in the forest of Arden, "I do not like your love's name," he receives the conclusive answer, "There was no thought of ...
lead_paragraph: When the cynical, censorious Jaques says to Orlando, in the forest of Arden, "I do not like your love's name," he receives the conclusive answer, "There was no thought of pleasing you when she was christened." So we retort to the objections which the London Press continue to make to the President's Message, that it was not written either to phase or to instruct them, and that British subjects, as such, have little or no interest in it. The Messages of the President of the United States are written in compliance with a provision of the Constitution that "he shall from time to time give to the Congress information of the state of the Union, and recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient;" and if Congress, and the people represented by that body, are satisfied with his information and advice, he may well think lightly of the [???] of other people.

abstract: The Board, after having acquired possession of the ground in the Park, commenced the erection of the New Court-house on or about the 15th of September, 1861, and expended for said work the sum of $10,999 75 -- when on the 30th of October, 1861, the legal adviser gave an opinion that the erection of said building should be proceeded with under the direction of the Commissioners appointed under the Act of 1858, to build a New City Hall. The Board then transferred the further prosecution of the work to the care and custody of said Commissioners.

abstract: Though but a unit of your number, and without influence, may I be permitted to suggest that in the present unfortunate misunderstanding with our native county, a word from us may be of some service in allaying the troubled waters of contention.
lead_paragraph: Though but a unit of your number, and without influence, may I be permitted to suggest that in the present unfortunate misunderstanding with our native county, a word from us may be of some service in allaying the troubled waters of contention. We have all escaped a great peril, and need not therefore fear a charge of selfishness or want of patriotism if we make an attempt, by a calm statement of facts which our position here qualifies us for knowing, to interpose some check to the bitterness of feeling gradually springing up to estrange two great nations which have every interest in being on the most friendly terms with each other. Surely, it is not only a noble, but a Christian duty, if, at a moment like this, when there is danger of having the worst passions of human nature stirred up, we use what influence we have to allay them.

abstract: -- An individual styling himself Rev. A. MAY has been swindling the good people of Livingston County quite extensively. Passing himself off as a Union refugee from Arkansas, he enlisted the sympathy of the benevolent people where he stopped, and sustained his character so well that he actually succeeded in getting the signatures of forty clergymen to a petition asking that he might be appointed Chaplain of the Wadsworth Guards. A few weeks ago, having borrowed two horses with harness, &c., from the neighbors, he started off, and after a series of tradings brought up in Buffalo, where his suspicious movements attracted the attention of the police. Disarmed of their suspicions by the certificates of character which he produced, they set him at liberty, and the rascal by this time is safe in Canada.
lead_paragraph: -- An individual styling himself Rev. A. MAY has been swindling the good people of Livingston County quite extensively. abstract: Both branches of the Common Council meet this day at 12 M., to organize for the year, by the  election of President, clerks and employes. Many caucuses have been held, but the determination arrived at, if any, is a secret which has thus far been well kept. In the Board of Councilmen the spirit of harmony has not prevailed, and it is asserted that up to Saturday night the President had not been agreed upon by the Democrats, who have the power, if the Mozart men, of whom there are two, are admitted, but it is said that they have not attended any of the private meetings, being determined not to bind themselves to any candidate in advance. The great bone of contention in this Board is the clerkship, some of the new members (understood to be the Mozart men) being specially anxious to oust the present incumbent, who has held the post for many years, and discharged all its duties faithfully and acceptably. An attack upon his official integrity in one of the daily papers a day or two since, was promptly met by an action for libel.
lead_paragraph: Both branches of the Common Council meet this day at 12 M., to organize for the year, by the election of President, clerks and employes. The great bone of contention in this Board is the clerkship, some of the new members (understood to be the Mozart men) being specially anxious to oust the present incumbent, who has held the post for many years, and discharged all its duties faithfully and acceptably. abstract: A single week of comedies at Mr. WALLACK'S handsome up-town establishment, has wrought so complete a change in the strength and character of the audiences there, that the manager will scarcely need to be urged to continue a style of performance so eminently successful with the classes to whom he looks for support.
lead_paragraph: A single week of comedies at Mr. WALLACK'S handsome up-town establishment, has wrought so complete a change in the strength and character of the audiences there, that the manager will scarcely need to be urged to continue a style of performance so eminently successful with the classes to whom he looks for support. We do not remember that any sensation piece has ever drawn a succession of houses so thoroughly satisfactory in numbers, or so quick and appreciative in kind. From Monday to Saturday night the theatre was simply taxed to its greatest capacity; hundreds, indeed, were turned from the door. To-night, when BOURGICAULT's "London Assurance" is to be played, it is fair to presume that there will be no falling off in this hearty recognition. And it would be wrong if there were, for Mr. WALLACK in these revivals, has done all that lay in his power to secure the approval and patronage of the classes who now rally so generously to his support. The standard comedies have never been seen to greater advantage. The brightness of the theatre; the brilliancy of the costumes; the appropriateness of the scenery; the talent of the artists, and the contagious enthusiasm of the audience, are separate sources of enjoyment which, when combined as they are now, become irresistible. Thus far, GOLDSMITH's comedy "She Stoops to Conquer," has been the most successful of the revivals, -- displaying the talent of the Company without overtaking it, as seemed to us to be the case in the "School for Scandal." Both these works have been played twice during the past week, the remaining evenings being filled with Mr. BROUGHAM's five-act farce, called "Playing with Fire." A little pardonable managerial latitude is exercised in elevating this curious and most amusing production to the level of a "standard comedy." It will be "standard, " how ever, so long as the fourth act is played as well as it is by Mr. WALLACK's company, and perhaps no longer. It is certain that neither GOLDSMITH nor SHERIDAN excited the audience to such vociferous demonstrations of delight as did the jovial author of "Playing with fire."

abstract: Editorial on epidemic of fires in Southern cities
snippet: Editorial on epidemic of fires in Southern cities
lead_paragraph: It is imposible not to be struck with the extraordinary concurrence of fires in Southern cities of late. Here is a ten-day's record: 1. Fire in Charleston--the work of an incendiary; loss, $12,000,000. 2. Montgomery "fired in six different places by slaves." 3. Nashville fired, and commissary stores destroyed to the amount of a million dollars. 4. Fire in Norfolk -- the Custom-house, Post-office, and a number of buildings destroyed. 5. Richmond on fire twice -- the last time destroying divers public buildings. 6. Destruction of a powder-mill at New-Orleans -- the work of an incendiary. In addition to, and later than these, we learn through Southern papers that, on the 17th December, the greater part of Greenville, Alabama, was destroyed by fire. Also, that during the night of Sunday week Charleston "was fired in several places," as though with the intent to destroy what remains of that ruined city.

abstract: -- A CHANCE FOR ECONOMY. -- A Committee has been created by Congress to ascertain and report methods of reducing the expenses of the war. There is one, (already, we think, suggested by Secretary CAMERON,) the Committee is besought not to overlook. The regimental bands of an army of 700,000 men must reach an aggregate of 15,000 performers. These receive better pay than the soldier, with rations quite as generous, and must be clothed, and their instruments and music provided, the entire expense reaching $6,000,000 a year. There are only two theories to justify the maintenance of such an establishment. One, that their brazen notes in some way contribute to the efficiency of the army; and yet it is well known that for all the practical uses of drill and march, the drum and fife are alone put in requisition. The other, that the bands, in some degree, mitigate the tediousness of camp-life, by their performances; whereas, it is well known that the rank and file entertain the profoundest disgust for entertainments which, with a dozen repetitions, pall on the hearing; and would be only too glad to exchange them for a bevy of negro minstrels, or the tricks of a prestidigitator. For the empty vanity of dress reviews alone are the regimental bands of any plausible utility, and the cessation of such displays will be an acceptable assurance to the people that National soldiering at a million and a half a day is not purely a holiday business. Let the Committee strike first at those brazen monstrosities, the bands.
lead_paragraph: -- A CHANCE FOR ECONOMY. -- A Committee has been created by Congress to ascertain and report methods of reducing the expenses of the war. There is one, (already, we think, suggested by Secretary CAMERON,) the Committee is besought not to overlook. The regimental bands of an army of 700,000 men must reach an aggregate of 15,000 performers. These receive better pay than the soldier, with rations quite as generous, and must be clothed, and their instruments and music provided, the entire expense reaching $6,000,000 a year. There are only two theories to justify the maintenance of such an establishment. One, that their brazen notes in some way contribute to the efficiency of the army; and yet it is well known that for all the practical uses of drill and march, the drum and fife are alone put in requisition. The other, that the bands, in some degree, mitigate the tediousness of camp-life, by their performances; whereas, it is well known that the rank and file entertain the profoundest disgust for entertainments which, with a dozen repetitions, pall on the hearing; and would be only too glad to exchange them for a bevy of negro minstrels, or the tricks of a prestidigitator. For the empty vanity of dress reviews alone are the regimental bands of any plausible utility, and the cessation of such displays will be an acceptable assurance to the people that National soldiering at a million and a half a day is not purely a holiday business. Let the Committee strike first at those brazen monstrosities, the bands.

abstract: -- Mr. E.L. COOK, of this city, received, yesterday, a letter from St. Domingo, stating that Mr. CHARLES ROOT, of New-Haven, and Mr. EDWARD CROWELL, of Perth Amboy, N.J., who went out to Santiago, St. Domingo, some two months since, with the intention of going into business there, had suddenly died of fever. They had opened extensive and profitable manufactories of corn meal and brick, and had every prospect of doing well, when they were suddenly taken ill, on the 29th of November, and died, one on the 3d of December, and the other on the 4th. They had only just arrived there, but had got their mills into operation when they were taken sick. Mr. CROWELL married a Miss SARAH COOK, of this city, who was with him at the time of his death, and is expected home daily. The affliction is a very sudden and sad one. -- New-Haven Journal, Jan. 4.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. E.L. COOK, of this city, received, yesterday, a letter from St. Domingo, stating that Mr. CHARLES ROOT, of New-Haven, and Mr. EDWARD CROWELL, of Perth Amboy, N.J., who went out to Santiago, St. Domingo, some two months since, with the intention of going into business there, had suddenly died of fever. They had opened extensive and profitable manufactories of corn meal and brick, and had every prospect of doing well, when they were suddenly taken ill, on the 29th of November, and died, one on the 3d of December, and the other on the 4th. They had only just arrived there, but had got their mills into operation when they were taken sick. Mr. CROWELL married a Miss SARAH COOK, of this city, who was with him at the time of his death, and is expected home daily. The affliction is a very sudden and sad one. -- New-Haven Journal, Jan. 4.

abstract: Editorial on contracts pending in US Congress for iron-clad gunboats; favors model now being built in NYC; Editorial on contracts pending in Congress for iron-plated gunboats; favors model now being built in NYC
snippet: Editorial on contracts pending in US Congress for iron-clad gunboats; favors model now being built in NYC; Editorial on contracts pending in Congress for iron-plated gunboats; favors model now being built in NYC
lead_paragraph: People addicted to naval matters have become suddenly awakened to the importance of iron-clad vessels of war. It is generally thecase, where we have been criminally apathetic upon a subject of National importance, and have finally come to give it attention, we go at once to the opposite extreme. So, in this instance, we delayed too long the construction of iron-clad vessels, of which every great Power should possess a few, and when we tardily determine upon providing ourselves with this class of war-engines, we pour out our ten or twelve million dollars like so much water, to build twenty vessels upon entirely novel plans, designed by people who have never seen such ships, or even the detailed designs of any of the considerable number which have been built in Europe.

abstract: -- The Board of Councilmen so far forgot old habits yesterday as to place a Republican in the Chair. Mr. CHARLES C. PINCKNEY, the new President, has had useful experience in municipal legislation and parliamentary practice, and a desirable reputation for zeal, application and integrity. The latter qualities might have been employed perhaps to better purpose on the floor, where they are not always as abundant as could be wished; but the former so strongly recommend him to the Chair, that his election may be considered a topic of congratulation. Let us accept the fact as an omen of a public-spirited forgetfulness of party on the part of the new Board.

abstract: The arrival yesterday from Port Royal brings us news of how our boys down in Palmettodom spent New-Year's; and it is pleasant to learn that they have not forgotten the good Yankee traditions of the day.
lead_paragraph: The arrival yesterday from Port Royal brings us news of how our boys down in Palmettodom spent New-Year's; and it is pleasant to learn that they have not forgotten the good Yankee traditions of the day. A visiting party from Beaufort, three or four thousand strong, took the opportunity to pay their devoirs to their nearest neighbors on the mainland, and the result was an interchange of civilities, in which the hospitable, high-minded and chivalrous Carolinians, it pains us to say, did not show themselves the preux chevaliers, sans peur et sans reproche our fancy delights to paint them. The affair, as narrated in the interesting letters of our special correspondents, if not of great proportions or for a prime object, was admirably planned and successfully executed, harmoniously combining, on a small scale, land and naval operations; and gives the effect, if not of a grand battle-piece, at least of a neat cabinet picture.

abstract: The United States steam transport Vanderbilt Capt. LEFEVRE, arrived yesterday from Port Royal S.C., which port she left on the 3d inst., at 9 A.M., with the mails and passengers, and 3,697 bales of Sea ...
lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Vanderbilt Capt. LEFEVRE, arrived yesterday from Port Royal S.C., which port she left on the 3d inst., at 9 A.M., with the mails and passengers, and 3,697 bales of Sea Island cotron, consigned to Col. D.D. TOMPKINS, United States Quartermaster. The Vanderbilt brings intelligence of the result of the battle at Port Royal Ferry. Gen. STEVENS' Brigade advanced on the main-land on the 1st inst., and took possession of the rebel batteries after a short resistance by the rebels; the brigade being assisted by the gunboats, which shelled the batteries. Gen. STEVENS then followed up the rebels to within six miles of the Charleston Railroad. A flag of truce was sent by the rebels, asking permission to bury their dead, which was granted, one hour being allotted for that purpose, after which they fell back upon the fortifications near the railroad, which are very extensive, leaving behind them one large gun, which they had spiked.

abstract: editorial on Union successes there
snippet: editorial on Union successes there
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the credentials of BENJAMIN STARK, who has been appointed by the Governor of Oregon to succeed Senator BAKER, were presented. Various accounts have come from Oregon, throwing discredit upon the loyalty of the appointee, and Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, moved that the administration of the oath be suspended until the facts could be inquired into. A debate sprung up on the question, which terminated in laying Mr. STARK's credentials on the table for the present. Petitions were presented praying that FREMONT be appointed Lieutenant-General; that Gen. MCKINSTRY be released from prison; that the slaves be emancipated under the war-power; that the example of WASHINGTON and JACKSON be followed in regard to slaves; that no further agitation of the Slavery question be tolerated in Congress; and that certain duties on arms be remitted. The Secretary of State transmitted to the Senate the correspondence relating to the Trent affair, which was made the special order for Thursday next. In regard to the Kansas contested seat, the report of the last extra session was reaffirmed, that Mr. STANTON is entitled to the seat. Resolutions were offered asking the Secretary of War by what authority a certain sutler had been appointed; urging the expediency of placing a tax on telegrams; advising the President to exchange the privateers of the Jeff. Davis; authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to rectify a mistake in regard to the duty on coffee and tea -- all of which resolutions were agreed to. A Bill was introduced to repeal the fishing bounty act. The Bill to establish a new armory was taken up, and postponed. The Pension Bill for 1863 was passed. The Judicial District bill was postponed. The Bill to define the pay of certain army officers was referred. After which, the Senate went into Executive Session.

lead_paragraph: The report of Comptroller ROBINSON is received. He sets out by observing that, while our people will always submit cheerfully to taxation for the simple purpose of Government, "taxation to pay the expenses of profligate legislation will always cause discontent." The condition of our State Treasury is healthy, in view of the novel situation of public affairs.

abstract: We learn from Albany that the members of the Legislature, elected on the Republican and People's tickets, met yesterday in joint caucus, and nominated candidates for officers of the Assembly.
lead_paragraph: We learn from Albany that the members of the Legislature, elected on the Republican and People's tickets, met yesterday in joint caucus, and nominated candidates for officers of the Assembly. Two ballots were had for a candidate for Speaker, in both of which HENRY J. RAYMOND, of New-York, had a large plurality of votes, and he was then declared to be nominated unanimously. There is no doubt that he will be elected. JOSEPH B. CUSHMAN, of Oneida, was nominated for Clerk.

abstract: The first Artists' Reception of the present season was given last evening at DODWORTH'S up-town room No. 204 Fifth-avenue a small but pleasant salon  and attracted as usual a pleasant gathering of the folk who move in society and the men who stir in art.
lead_paragraph: The first Artists' Reception of the present season was given last evening at DODWORTH's up-town room No. 204 Fifth-avenue -- a small but pleasant salon -- and attracted as usual a pleasant gathering of the folk who move in society and the men who stir in art. It would be doing an injustice to the occasion to speak with any closeness of the merits of the pictures exhibited. Art touches society with a gloved hand and seeks a recognition not a criticism. Still, if the times were better, it is probable that we should have had some larger works to testify to the industry of our artists; being bad, it is reasonable that they should be economical in size as in price. The collection was a small one. There were old faces on the walls, too, but this circumstance did not detract from the hearty recognition which old friends have a right to expect at this time of year. Pleasant social chat, tinged with art and flavored with music made the hours fly fast. Among the exhibitors whose works attracted the most attention were EASTMAN JOHNSON, (Card-Players;) GIGNOUX, (An Autumnal Sunset, unpretending, and a study, but thoroughly effective and purely American in tone;) EDWIN WHITE, CHURCH, WHITTREDGE, GIFFORD, (a little gem, called the Bronx River;) CROPSY, (A Study;) HUBBARD, YEWELL, JAMES M. HART, S. COLMAN, Jr., (two excellent pictures, full of quiet effect;) WUST, L. THOMPSON, (two busts, -- one of a Western Hunter, superb in every respect;) W.J. HENNESY, JAMES MCENTEE, RONDEL, CAFFERTY. There was no catalogue, an oversight which ought to be remedied at those meetings. It need scarcely be added that we have not attempted to classify the merits of the artists we have named.

abstract: "A report reached this city, yesterday, that a detachment of the Yankee troops crossed over from Port Royal Island to the main land a few nights since, and attacked a picket of our soldiers, eight in number. During the skirmish which ensued two of our men were wounded, and the whole picket, numbering as above, were captured by the enemy. On the next day, a flag of truce was dispatched from our head-quarters to inquire after the condition of the prisoners, when information was obtained that the two wounded men had died from their injuries, and that the six others were held as prisoners. The captured soldiers are said to be members of Col. JONES' Regiment South Carolina Volunteers."
lead_paragraph: "A report reached this city, yesterday, that a detachment of the Yankee troops crossed over from Port Royal Island to the main land a few nights since, and attacked a picket of our soldiers, eight in number. abstract: The schooner Wm. H. Northrop, hailing from Nassau, N.P., and last from Havana, Dec. 1, was brought into this port yesterday, by prize-master RHOADES and five men from the gunboat Fernandina. She has a cargo of 18 bags of coffee and a quantity of quinine and other medicines. She was taken Dec. 25 off Cape Fear, by the gunboat Fernandina, while attempting to run the blockade at Wilmington, N.C., and ordered to this port. She was formerly a Charleston pilot boat, and is of about 80 tons burden.

abstract: For some time a battle between the two noted pugilists, ELLIOTT and WINKIE, of this City, has been the theme of conversation among fighting men. Yesterday morning the fight tookplace.
lead_paragraph: For some time a battle between the two noted pugilists, ELLIOTT and WINKIE, of this City, has been the theme of conversation among fighting men. Yesterday morning the fight took place. The scene of the encounter was fixed at Weehawken, N.J. At an early hour scores of the votaries of the P.R. wended their way, plodding along through the heavy snow-storm on foot and in various descriptions of vehicles. At least two hundred persons were present on the occasion -- amongst them a large number of the leading "fancy men about town." They reached the ground by various routes -- some even going by cars to Newark and thence by conveyance to Weehawken, in order to effectually elude the police. The heavy snow-storm rendered it difficult to select a spot for the fight, but at length, after a little surveying, a place was chosen and the snow removed, the distances measured, the ring formed, and the other preparations made. At a little past 8 o'clock the two principals, with their seconds and referee, drove up in separate carriages, and at six minutes past 9 o'clock ELLIOTT threw his cap into the ring and then followed it, accompanied by his seconds, CLARK and WOODS. WINKIE also threw his cap and entered the ring with his seconds, KIT BURNES and ----- ROACH. ELLIOTT won the choice of corners, after which the men were attired in fighting costume by their respective seconds. MARTIN BUTLER was selected referee, and at 9:20 o'clock called the combatants to face each other. In response to the summons, both men walked to the centre of the ring, looking as agreeable and well pleased as though they were going on a jaunt into the rural districts in Summer. The snow fell in large flakes thick and fast, but neither appeared to notice it.

abstract: -- The advices we receive from Europe are of the most satisfactory character. Confidence in a pacific solution of the Trent affair seems to have become general, and to have diffused an universal sense of relief. The markets are, in such matters, the critical test of public opinion. When consols rise it is because the apprehension of war declines; and, in the present instance, if cotton advances it is because the prospect of obtaining new supplies through a forcible opening of the rebel ports disappears. These simultaneous phenomena are presented in the news by the Bohemian, given elsewhere, and in connection with other less distinct indications, show how great was the fear of war and how much it is relieved. On this side of the sea, the fact is in the highest degree cheering. We have had irresistible reasons for accusing the leaders of British party of seeking to force a quarrel upon the United States. Unsupported by the commercial and manufacturing interests of the country, they dared not become the challengers, and they accordingly extracted from an unauthorized act of an American officer an apparent right to represent the American Government as the aggressor. The failure of this monstrous trick, leaves them without pretence for hostilities; and at the same time brings to light the real anxiety of the British people for peace, and their satisfaction at escaping from what a reckless Press represented as an inevitable war. When the news of the actual surrender of MASON and SLIDELL reaches England, we may expect to witness an outburst of delight, only equaled by that of our people when the scoundrels were caught. But there need be no mistake in the matter. The relief from the supposed necessity of making war upon their own kindred will be the real cause of gratitude; the thought of humiliation to America having as little to do with the demonstration, as had insult to England with our own jubilation over the feat of Capt. WILKES.

abstract: Early yesterday morning the City was visited with the second snow storm of the season. The snow continued falling at intervals throughout the day, and at sundown it attained an average depth of four inches. Several sleighs were observed on the principal streets, but the snow was hardly in a condition to warrant good sleighing, consequently this mode of conveyance was not generally adopted. Both the East and North rivers were filled at ebb tide with large quantities of ice, rendering them an unsafe anchorage for small craft, and even dangerous for a row-boat. The various ferry-boats were not seriously detained in their trips, although their wheels came in contact with, and crushed some immense cakes of ice.

abstract: The Savannah News notices that among the late arrivals in that city from Cuba, is a large box of beautifully prepared lint, presented, through Capt. GLADDING, to the soldiers of the Confederate army, by a number of the Senoritas of Havana. The lint is drawn in threads four or five inches long, from the finest linen fabrics; is white as driven snow and soft as down. It is put up in neat little hanks, and tastefully tied with colored ribbons. The lint was made and contributed by a number of the first ladies of Havana, and is sent as a testimonial of their heartfelt devotion to our cause.

abstract: The Union force in Western Virginia shows no disposition to hibernate after the usual pattern in its Winter quarters. Since the departure of Gen. ROSECRANS to Wheeling, and the ...
lead_paragraph: The Union force in Western Virginia shows no disposition to hibernate after the usual pattern in its Winter quarters. Since the departure of Gen. ROSECRANS to Wheeling, and the transfer of the bulk of his recent army to the column of Gen. BUELL, there have been two principal camps maintained by the National troops -- one under Gen. COX, at Charleston, on the Kanawha; the other under Gen. MILROY, at Cheat Mountain, with lines extended toward Elk Water and Huttonsville. Gen. COX has been relieved by the departure of Gen. FLOYD into Tennessee of any enemy within striking distance. But in front of Gen. MILROY, at Monterey and Huntersville, the main body of what was recently Gen. LEE's command is quartered, and with these the Union leader finds occasion to refresh and keep alive the war temper of his force. It was only on the 13th ult. that MILROY sought out the enemy at Camp Alleghany, in Pocahontas County, inflicted a frightful loss of life and other damage upon him, and retired in safety to his quarters. A similar expedition, with even better results, is now reported by telegraph. At Huntersville among the Alleghanies, the rebels had established a depot of army stores guarded by some seven hundred and fifty men. Against this post, Gen. MILROY dispatched a force of nearly the same strength, which after a sharp and curt contest, obliged the enemy to retire, with the loss of eighty in killed and wounded, and the sacrifice of the stores valued at $80,000, and of much greater value doubtless to the Union troops in their distant mountain quarters, now almost inaccessible from the Ohio side. The success was brilliant and important, in this, that it adds proof to proof of the superiority of our soldiers on a fair field over the adversary, and it goes to intimidate the scattered Secessionists of that quarter, who, without such frequent demonstration of Federal strength in their midst, would hasten to organize, and commit every imaginable excess upon their loyal neighbors. As it is, the spirit of rebellion, within the bounds of the new State of Kanawha, is practically extinguished.

abstract: The Message with which Mayor OPDYKE has accompanied his accession to office is quite the shrewd and practical paper the public had a right to expect from a person of his thorough business qualifications.
lead_paragraph: The Message with which Mayor OPDYKE has accompanied his accession to office is quite the shrewd and practical paper the public had a right to expect from a person of his thorough business qualifications. Mr. OPDYKE not only realizes the demands of the extraordinary occasion, but offers a variety of suggestions, many of them evidently sound and acceptable with which to meet them. A country engaged, in a deadly internal war, straining the resources and patriotism of the people to their utmost tension; a City prostrated and disheartened with misgovernment, and depleted by corruption; a Mayor chosen to office because believed to be loyal and energetic in his support of the National Government, and to bring to his important place the intelligence that shall reform and the honesty that shall purify the administration of municipal affairs; these are the unusual circumstances which attend the birth of this new political era, which is expected to relieve the people of burdens too weighty to be longer borne.

abstract: FELIX SANCHEZ, the Spanish negro, who has been several years in the Tombs for the murder of his father-in-law, in Sullivan-street, was arraigned yesterday before Justice BRENNAN to answer the charge of felonious assault upon JACOB MYERS. The case of SANCHEZ has been appealed, and it was apprehended that he might be discharged, in which case the authorities had determined to hold him upon the above charge. The Justice committed him in default of $2,000 bail. MYERS is detained as a witness.

abstract: Detective officers DEVOE and SAMPSON, attached to the United States Marshal's office, arrested, on Friday last, MORGAN FREDEREEKS, alias Gunderson, who was acting captain of the slave bark Cora, which arrived at this port, from the Coast of Africa, in charge of a prize-crew, some eighteen months ago. It will be recollected that he escaped from the vessel while lying in this port, under the guns of the North Carolina, and has not since been heard of. The account he now gives of his escape is, that he got the marines, who had him in charge, drunk, and took the opportunity to leave the vessel through the cabin window. He was arrested on board the United States ship North Carolina, where he was acting as master's mate, having received his commission from the Government on New-Year's day. He stated that after his escape he went to the Marshal's office and got his baggage from Marshal RYNDERS, and that he subsequently ate game suppers with other prisoners at the Eldridge-street Jail. He was yesterday committed to the Tombs.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. J.S. CLARKE, the popular Comedian, made his appearance here last evening, and notwithstanding the snow-storm and the irresistible attractions it offered to the lovers of out-door fun, succeeded in winning a good and thoroughly appreciative audience. Three pieces were on the programme, none of them new to our public, but all of them acceptable when played well, and with Mr. CLARKE in the leading comic role. The most notable was the pleasant little school sketch, called "To Parents and Guardians," in which Mr. CLARKE impersonated the part of the fat "fag" Waddilove. The awkwardness of the good-natured simpleton, and his ridiculous fear of punishment from one considerably less than his size -- the redoubtable Bob Nettles -- were excellently portrayed, and kept the house in a roar of merriment. The character named was played with much spirit by Miss FANNY BROWN, a young lady whom we are glad to welcome back again to the boards of this theatre. The Tourbillon of Mr. C. HILL was one of the best performances of the part we have ever seen. All the other parts were well placed, Miss ADA CLIFTON adapting herself with the skill of an artist to the small part of Mary Sursh. The afterpieces were "My Neighbor's Wife," and the extravaganza called "P.P." To-night Mr. CLARKE will appear in the "Toodles," an announcement which will, we are sure, fill the house to overflowing. It is one of the most original performances ever seen in this City.

HILL was one of the best performances of the part we have ever seen. abstract: ROBBERY BY A POLICEMAN. -- Officer GEORGE H. TOMPKINS was arrested on Monday by Officer SMITH, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, upon the charge of grand larceny. The complaint against him is made by Officers HARRINGTON and DAVIN, of the same Precinct. HARRINGTON alleges that the accused stole a coat from him valued at $20, and the other complainant charges that a pistol and a pair of white bed-blankets were stolen from him, at the Twenty-seventh Precinct Station-house, on the 10th of November last, and he has reason to believe the prisoner is the guilty party. The delinquent officer was taken before Justice BRENNAN yesterday afternoon, where, after an examination, he was committed to the Tombs in default of bail. Capt. BOGARE has also made a complaint against him before the Board of Police Commissioners.

abstract: Hon. JACOB M. HOWARD, the newly-elected Senator from Michigan, was one of the earliest settlers of that State. Having gained an extended reputation by the success which he achieved in his legal practice, he was elected to represent his district in Congress in 1841. In 1859 he was elected Attorney-General of Michigan, and now is promoted to a seat in the Senate, to fill the unexpired term of the last Hon. K.S. RENSHAW.

abstract: The process against the ship Cheshire, seized as prize, was returned to-day. Mr. Edwards stated that he appeared for the vessel, but was unable to put in any answer in the cause, owing to an irregularity on the part of the United States, to which, as it was becoming quite common in these cases, he desired to call the attention of the Court. He proceeded to state that the officers of the ship and all the crew, but two, were taken from the ship and kept by the United States squadron, instead of being sent on with the ship; and he mentioned several other cases where a similar course had been pursued.

abstract: The Ninety-first New-York Volunteers are preparing to leave Governor's Island, and expected to get away yesterday, but as the steam transport Ericsson, which will convey them to their destination, was taking in stores and provisions during the day, it is probable that they will not leave until this afternoon. The men have received all the pay due to them since their enlistment.

abstract: -- The disposition of Congress to enter just now upon the discussion of the Trent question is to be profoundly regretted. The issue is still pending. Negotiation may have much to adjust and much to explain away before that peace which the surrender was to purchase shall be secured; and all such ill-judged speeches as that delivered yesterday in the House by Mr. THOMAS, of Massachusetts, will only tend to perplex and, perhaps, defeat a pacific accommodation. Had it emanated from VALLANDIGHAM or other declared sympathizer with rebellion, the object of the outburst would have been obvious, and must have rendered it innoxious. But Mr. THOMAS comes from the "Quincey" district of Massachusetts, is regarded as a conservative, as well as a loyal supporter of the Government; and professes to be chiefly animated by a desire to suppress the rebellion. He even believes that peace with foreign nations should be sought at any price, rather than that aim should be postponed. But when he speaks of a sacrifice of principle submitted to by the Administration, of a humiliation inflicted by England, of a cause abandoned in the support of which we were sure of the sympathies of mankind. Mr. THOMAS shows an utter ignorance of the settled policy of this Government on international questions, or a disposition to pander to that misguided popular sentiment, which he represents as existing in Massachusetts. We have surrendered SLIDELL and MASON, not merely because England demanded them, but because the procedure of Capt. WILKES was not formally correct, and because to have retained them would have been to justify England in adherence to a class of maritime laws, which for half a century the American Government has sought to abrogate. And, so far from persistence in holding the captives securing us the sympathy of the world in the resulting contest, our Government had express assurances that France, our ancient ally, could not sustain us, and the evidence of the entire European Press, that our cause was held to be unjust and indefensible. Every Continental Power in Europe had manifested its eagerness to accept the American doctrine, that "free flags make free ships;" while England alone dissented; and while we may be prepared to turn our backs upon that doctrine, it is certainly too much to expect of the other Powers of the world to abandon at once their obvious interests and their consistency, simply to follow our capricious lead. Had we accepted the search of the Trent as a cause of war, we should have become the champions of an obsolete and tyrannical principle, hateful to mankind, and should have presented to the world the spectacle of a nation justly punished for inconsistency.

abstract: -- For fifty years the 8th of January -- St. Hickory's Day -- has been one of our chief National fasti. In New-Orleans, especially, it has annually been observed as a great gala day. Will the programme be carried out this year as usual? It is doubtful. JACKSON had a way of treating secession and Secessionists, the reminiscence of which, under present circumstances, cannot be particularly exhilarating to the rebel mind. We incline to think, therefore, that St. Hickory's Day will be apt to get the go-by this year at the South; for it must strike even the Confederate mind as too flagrantly illogical that they should do homage to a man who, they know, were he alive to-day, would put forth his utmost power to crush those who, while professing to revere his memory, seek to destroy what he held most sacred.

abstract: The annual sale of pews at auction in Plymouth Church for the year was held last evening. As usual, there was a very large attendance of people, and the buying was quite as spirited as ever, though the premiums offered were not so large.
lead_paragraph: -- The annual sale of pews at auction in Plymouth Church for the year was held last evening. As usual, there was a very large attendance of people, and the buying was quite as spirited as ever, though the premiums offered were not so large. Mr. BEECHER commenced the proceedings in a few remarks, stating all necessary particulars for those who desired to purchase to know. He said this was the thirteenth annual sale that had taken place under his auspices, and notwithstanding the troublesome times the church was still in a prosperous condition. The first pew was struck off to Mr. DENNIS at $100 premium, and the next at $75 premium. When 100 pews had been sold, the premiums ran down to $20, where they remained some time. All of the pews except thirty-two were sold. The pews sold were appraised at $12,050. On these the premiums amounted to $6,323, or about half the amount of premiums received last year. The sale was entirely satisfactory to the Trustees.

abstract: We learn from Washington that the House Committee of Ways and Means have determined to provide by taxation for raising during the current year the sum of one hundred and fifty million dollars. We print this morning the bill matured by the Committee to authorize the issue of Treasury Notes payable on demand; also the General Banking bill, in the shape in which it is now before the Committee. The latter is thought to be very nearly complete.

abstract: A season of Comedy would certainly be incomplete without a taste of the old masters of the craft, who are still regarded with reverence by theatre managers, if not precisely in the same light by thoetergoers. Hence Mr. WALLACK, who never does things by half, revived CONGREVE'S comedy of "Love for Love."
lead_paragraph: A season of Comedy would certainly be incomplete without a taste of the old masters of the craft, who are still regarded with reverence by theatre managers, if not precisely in the same light by thoetergoers. Hence Mr. WALLACK, who never does things by half, revived CONGREVE'S comedy of "Love for Love." When we say this, it will be taken for granted, that everything in the way of scenery, costumes and appointments was complete and satisfactory. The rapidity with which Mr. WALLACK succeeds in laying these massive works before the public, is only equaled by the curious excellence that marks each revival -- seeming in fact to separate it from its predecessors by a new condition of merit. It is a pity that the same cannot be said of the plays themselves. Only in the spirit of a past generation can a work like "Love for Love" win the enthusiastic approval of criticism. We have outgrown the kind of love that it deals with, and our morals, if they have not improved, are at least amenable to a sense of decency. The licentiousness of CONGREVE and others is a reproach to, and blemish on, the brilliant epoch that produced them. The few works that time has spared reflect this pruriency only to make us wonder why time has spared them. Were it not for judicious pruning, even "Love for Love" would not be tolerated. Mr. WALLACK's version preserves all the better parts, and illustrates the author's wit and felicity of expression. Beyond this it would be difficult to find matter for praise. The plot is weak, the characters all unreal, and, worse than all, a couple of acts at least are dull.

abstract: Dr E Everett speaks, NYC Academy of Music, on origin and character of war
snippet: Dr E Everett speaks, NYC Academy of Music, on origin and character of war
lead_paragraph: An immense audience assembled, last evening in the Academy of Music, to hear the distinguished and venerable orator and statesman of Massachuselts deliver his already celebrated address upon. "The Origin and Character of the Present War." The hour announced for the commencement of the evening's exercises was 8 o'clock, but soon after 7 every nook and corner in every part of the vast building, from the parterre to uppermost gallery, was crowded with an intelligent and respectable multitude, of which ladies formed a great proportion. The stage, like the rest of the house, was brilliantly lighted, and above it hung a magnificent American ensign, expanding over its entire breadth. Upon the stage sat a throng of eminent personages in every profession, and from many States, and a table draped with the American colors stood to the front and centre for the accommodation of the speaker. The representatives of the Press were comfortably provided with convenience for their toils in an eligible position on the right of the platform.

abstract: Gov. Morgan annual message
snippet: Gov. Morgan annual message
lead_paragraph: In the presence of events so momentous as those now surrounding us, we can but realize that man's strength is weakness, his wisdom foolishness, and human forecast a mockery. It is most fitting, therefore, that we seek the favor of the great source of all power and knowledge, and implore the counsel of Ommiscience in our deliberations. Let us remember that from devastation and bloody strife God restores the wasted land and evokes peace; while from a condition of apparent prosperity and mutual faith. He may permit the spirit of discord to enter, and suddenly bring a whole nation to the verge of humiliation.

abstract: -- If the rebel deserter who reports the resignation of Maj.-Gen. PILLOW be a "reliable" gentleman, we may congratulate the rebel army on the loss of its most bombastic and thin-brained General -- always, of course, excepting Gen. HENRY A. WISE. PILLOW's campaign has not been a glorious nor a bloody one, though it will do well enough as an afterpiece to those celebrated feats of military engineering in Mexico with which his name is associated. When he first took command in Memphis, about eight months ago, he commenced operations by issuing a fearful proclamation and levying forced contributions for the support of his army on the counties of West Tennessee -- a proceeding which almost produced an insurrection against rebellion. He then began, might and main, to erect those fortifications and earthworks for the defence of the city, which so much astonished Mr. RUSSELL when he was there. Since he was superseded in the chief command on the Mississippi River, he has devoted his energies to intrenching and building fortifications at the most remarkable points. Latterly he has been in command of the works at Columbus, below Cairo, while HOLLINS is reported to have charge of the river naval forces. But as it now looks likely that PILLOW's skill, generalship and pluck would very soon be tested on the open field, he has wisely resigned his position in advance of that terrible ordeal -- if, indeed, he has resigned. It would be no ordinary reason that would induce PILLOW to relinquish a Major-Generalship. If he has really done so, it must be because he thinks the rebel cause is failing.
