abstract: Hon. EDWARD EVERETT delivered his address "On the Character and Origin of the Present  War," before an audience of 3,000 persons, last evening, at the Academy of Music. His portraiture of the evils of secession and the secret history of its progress was received with continued and enthusiastic acclamation.
lead_paragraph: Hon. EDWARD EVERETT delivered his address "On the Character and Origin of the Present War," before an audience of 3,000 persons, last evening, at the Academy of Music. His portraiture of the evils of secession and the secret history of its progress was received with continued and enthusiastic acclamation. The address occupied two hours' time in the delivery, and we but briefly sketch it, in another column, it having been reported in full on a previous occasion.

abstract: In the Senate, petitions for the emancipation of slaves and for the exchange of prisoners were presented. The bill in regard to the appointment of sutlers was reported back from the Military Committee, with amendments, and ordered to be printed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, petitions for the emancipation of slaves and for the exchange of prisoners were presented. The bill in regard to the appointment of sutlers was reported back from the Military Committee, with amendments, and ordered to be printed. A resolution, offered by Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, making inquiry as to making purchases for the Navy through other than recognized agents, was passed. Mr. HALE also notified the Senate that he should introduce a bill to punish frauds on the Treasury. A bill to abolish the franking privilege was introduced by Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky. The bill to increase the number of cadets at West Point was then taken up and discussed by Messrs. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, CLARK of New-Hampshire, GRIMES, of Iowa, LANE, of Kansas, DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, WILSON, of Massachusetts, NESMITH, of Oregon, and HALE, of New-Hampshire. The Senate finally refused to pass the bill -- 25 to 12. The bill to punish fraud upon the Treasury, brought in at the extra session, was taken up and recommitted to the Committee on the Judiciary. The bill relative to the arrest of fugitive slaves by officers of the Army or Navy was taken up, but its consideration was again postponed for the present, after a refusal of the Senate to postpone it indefinitely. The Kansas contested seat case was then taken up, but the Senate adjourned without proceeding with it.

abstract: The passage of the Treasury Note bill is to be followed, we learn, by a comprehensive system of taxation to provide not only for the payment of the notes issued, but an adequate system of finance to meet what must be the enormously increased expenditures of Government for some time to come, at least, on a peace footing.
lead_paragraph: The passage of the Treasury Note bill is to be followed, we learn, by a comprehensive system of taxation to provide not only for the payment of the notes issued, but an adequate system of finance to meet what must be the enormously increased expenditures of Government for some time to come, at least, on a peace footing. Were the rebellion subdued to-morrow these expenditures must equal twice and perhaps thrice the average for years past. We shall do well if we get on with $200,000,000 annually. We must keep up, for years, a large standing army, which costs $1,000 a year for each man, rank and file. We shall not hereafter be content without a powerful navy. We are to render impregnable, if possible, all our important harbors. The civil list is grows apace with our increasing years. We shall have on the 1st of July next an annual interest account of $40,000,000. For the present, consequently, we must bid adieu to the golden era in our history in which we were scarcely conscious that we had a Government, so lightly did its burdens rest upon us, and enter upon that in which the almost sole problem of a statesman will be to make the credit balance the debit side of the national ledger.

abstract: LEUTZE is busy at work upon his great picture for the western staircase of the House gallery. It is to be entitled. "Westward the Star of Empire takes its way." The sketch in color is finished, and is in many respects the finest of Mr. LEUTEE'S works. The completion of the painting (the main picture, with the arabesques and smaller designs) will require a twelvemonth's work at least.

abstract: Brevity is not the most conspicuous merit of the Message which Gov. MORGAN yesterday laid before the Legislature, and to which we devote this morning so large a share of our space.
lead_paragraph: Brevity is not the most conspicuous merit of the Message which Gov. MORGAN yesterday laid before the Legislature, and to which we devote this morning so large a share of our space. The Winter indeed brings with it an avalanche of such documents, few of them falling short of the dimensions of that with which Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, fills seventy-five large pages, and all of them pregnant with topics of extraordinary moment. Nor can we justly complain. If we crowd our years as we have crowded the last, with thick-coming events, effecting every department of our social and political systems, we must expect the yearly discussion of them by the officials from whom we submit to receive such annual reviews to be proportioned fully to the matter, and to be all the more explicit and definite, because the issues are so novel and of such unprecedented importance. Gov. MORGAN, it must be owned, has not abused his privilege. In addition to the ordinary subjects upon which he is required to throw light from time to time, there are the war, its causes and consequences, the armament of the State, the provision for extraordinary expenses, the welfare of the army, and all those various results of the strange crisis through which the nation is passing, upon which the Message must expatiate more or less diffusely. And thus we find ourselves obliged to accept such weighty documents as one of the necessary evils of the times upon which we have fallen.
headline: {'main': "The Governor's Message.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Governor's Message.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Missouri Republican and other St. Louis papers having given credence and wide circulation to the report that Brig.-Gen. SIEGEL has resigned his command, and that his resignation would be followed by the withdrawal of a large number of officers associated with him, the Anzeiger des Westens indorses the statement, and remarks that "for a long time things have looked as though the intention were to trifle with him, and that he (Gen. SEIGEL,) had seemed to think so too. Where he sowed, where he wasfirst in the field, and was the first to strike, and while his name rang, like that of Mars, from every German lip throughout the Union and helped to fill the camps others are now to reap the harvest. But he must linger on the shore and languish in the tent. JEFF. C. DAVIS and SCHOFFIELD, the two most capable, if not the only capable, American officers hare, are winning laurels on the path marked out by SIEGEL, and he must, in the meanwhile, be held in leading-strings by CURTIS. Should he bear this yet, it is perhaps, but for a little space."

abstract: On Thursday last an increase in the number of vessels off this hartor was noticed. On Friday morning not less than twenty-three sail, of all classes, were in sight.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday last an increase in the number of vessels off this hartor was noticed. On Friday morning not less than twenty-three sail, of all classes, were in sight. As well as could be judged, using a spyglass at a distance of three or four miles, there were some four gunboats, one large steamer, apparently a frigate, and the rest seemed to be mostly sailing vessels. One of the steamers was stationed at the northeast of the bar, near the Rattlesnake Shoal, and the remainder of their fleet was near old Ship Bar. During Thursday night and Friday morning, with the weather calm, the sea smooth, and a moonlight night, they succeeded in sinking some seven hulks, consisting of two ships and five barks, in one of the channels. Later in the day, the enemy sunk eight more of the "stone fleet," making fifteen in all. From appearances, it is inferred that all their hulks which have been brought here up to this time have been made use of, and that those now outside are blockaders.

abstract: An Italian, named PETER BONAVENTURA, appeared before Justice CONNOLLY yesterday at the lower Police Court, and made a complaint against CESAR E. POGLIANA, a lawyer of this City, residing at No. 378 Fourth-sreet.
lead_paragraph: An Italian, named PETER BONAVENTURA, appeared before Justice CONNOLLY yesterday at the lower Police Court, and made a complaint against CESAR E. POGLIANA, a lawyer of this City, residing at No. 378 Fourth-sreet. The complainant alleges that some time in September last, he and his wife were arrested upon the charge of a felonious assault made by G. RATZ, and that upon this charge they were for a short time confined in the Tombs. Two days after they were imprisoned, he says the lawyer POGLIANA called upon complainant, in the Tombs, and desired to be engaged to defend him. He was, says the complainant, accordingly employed, and paid the sum of $10 as a retaining fee, which was all the money then demanded. A few days subsequent, the man of the law called again and asked for $25, as he said, to give to Justice CONNOLLY, who would then surrender the papers upon, which he and his wife were held. This was also paid. In the afternoon of the same day, he called again and obtained $15 for preparing the bail bond. On the 20th of September he asked and received the sum of $20. This money the lawyer said was for the purpose of giving, to the District-Attorney, to induce him to surrender the prosecution papers. On the 30th of the same month, he induced the complainant, BONAVENTURA, to pay him an additional $20, which it was said was to be paid to the clerks in the District-Attorney's office for copying papers. The further sum of $20 was obtained from him on the 14th of October; this amount was for the bondsmen. The next day he demanded and obtained an additional $20 for the Judges' clerks, and two or three days subsequently he came to the poor man, who by this time was nearly destitute, and demanded the further sum of $50, to square up all arrearages in the different offices, and at the same time promising to release him from all the consequences of his arrest, as above mentioned. The man said he had but $15, and this he gave to the attorney; and in order to make up the balance, his wife's earrings, brooch, and the only bed they had in the house were delivered over. The complaint further alleges that the only thing that the lawyer has done for him was to draw a bail bond, and that he was discharged in a few days after being put in the Tombs. Justice CONNOLLY held the accused in $1,000 bail to answer the charge.

abstract: -- We have recently received, through the kindness of a friend at Arica, Peru, a quantity of petrified Indian eyes, taken from the Indian burying-grounds in that neighborhood, which are probably as great a curiosity in their way as has ever come to light. The ball of the eye is exceedingly perfect, displaying the pupil and other parts very distinctly. It is apparently of a hard, horny substance, and peels off in thin transparent flakes. The face of the eye presents a reddish hue with yellow circles, and when reflected in the light it becomes brilliantly illuminated. The back part is of a bright, glossy, yellow tinge, looking much like damaged pearl, but when the outer flakes are taken off, the entire eye becomes the color of bright amber, which it is easily mistaken for. These eyes are found at times loose inside the skulls, and at other times on the ground of the cave or grave, having fallen out after becoming dried up.

lead_paragraph: The Legislature met yesterday at noon, and immediately proceeded to business. In the Senate, Lieut, Gov. CAMPBELL administered the oath to the members. JAMES TERWILLIGER was then elected Clerk, and RICHARD N. OWENS, Sergeant at Arms; and the subordinate offices were filled without difficulty. The first petition presented was to prohibit the sale of swill milk. A petitionwas also presented setting forth the defenceless condition of Cape Vincent, and asking for the construction of a fort there. It was referred to the Committee on Public Defences.

abstract: -- There was a great deal of heavy ice adrift yesterday, which cleared the rivers of all vessels at anchor. The steamship Vanderbilt, lying in the North River, not being able to find a berth, was carried adrift by the ice. Owing to the thaw, a much greater quantity will probably come down during the next day or two. The ship Guy Mannering, while being towed out of the East River yesterday, by three steam-tugs, took the bottom opposite the barge office at Whitehall, owing to a large field of ice coming in the river. She came off immediately, and proceeded to sea.

abstract: The first meeting of the Republican General Committee for 1862, was held last evening, at the rooms of the Committee, No. 9 Court-street. A temporary organization was effected, by the election of WM. COIT, Esq. as Chairman, and S. ALPHEUS SMITH as Secretary.
lead_paragraph: The first meeting of the Republican General Committee for 1862, was held last evening, at the rooms of the Committee, No. 9 Court-street. A temporary organization was effected, by the election of WM. COIT, Esq. as Chairman, and S. ALPHEUS SMITH as Secretary. The room was crowded with delegates and others, and it was quite evident that there was to be an exciting time, and in this there was no disappointment. The old antagonistic feeling existing between the "Union" and "Straight" Republicans, burned more fiercely than even before the last Fall election, and it only required a very little thing to bring this feeling out in full force -- and the occasion for its exercise was not long wanting. After some preliminary wrangling about minor matters, credentials were received when it was found there were contested seats in the Eleventh, Thirteenth and Fourteenth Wards and protests against the admission of delegates from the First and Twelfth Wards. The Chairman decided that all persons claiming to be delegates must be admitted to seats who presented prima facie evidence that they had been legally elected. Under this ruling the First Ward was passed over, but when the Twelfth Ward was reached, the admission of the accredited delegates was most strenuously opposed. The Chairman refused to put test motions because the Committee was not properly organized, and a scene of excitement followed which beggars all description. Motion upon motion was made by different parties, each claiming the right to have their motion put to the Committee. Several impromptu fights were suppressed by the timely interference of the cooler members. Finally the Chairman decided to modify his decision so far as to put the motions made, -- only those delegates whose names had been called having permission to vote thereon. This was accepted and the business of the Committee was proceeded with in comparative order. Subsequently two delegates from the First Ward, Messrs. CARLIN and EAMES, were admitted by a vote of the Committee and also the delegates from the Twelfth Ward. At a later hour the excitement subsided, and the members of the Committee appeared to be on as good terms as ever, when the following named Committee on Credentials was appointed, to whom was referred all the contested seats and protests: Messrs. Winslow, Bradley, Nodyne, Reeve, Hathaway, Lindsay and Donovan. The Committee adjourned for one month.

abstract: Editorial on proposed bill for forfeiture of property of those engaged in rebellion
snippet: Editorial on proposed bill for forfeiture of property of those engaged in rebellion
lead_paragraph: Senator DAVIS, of Kentucky, has introduced into the Senate a bill, of which we have already given an abstract, in relation to the rebels and their property. In the main purpose of the bill, viz., the forfeiting all the property of those who shall be engaged in the rebellion, we heartily concur. Hitherto it has been the interest of every inhabitant of the seceding States to join and aid the rebellion, because if he did not, his property was swept away from him at once by the rebels, while if he did they would not seize it, neither would the United States forfeit it, if they should prove victorious. The passage of this bill will tend to equalize matters. The scales will no longer be weighted to favor rebellion, and any one who hereafter joins the rebels can have no cause to complain, if he loses all his property in punishment. The main purpose of the bill, as we said, we heartily approve. Some of its provisions, however, need more careful arrangement and some modification.
headline: {'main': 'Forfeiture of Rebel Property.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Forfeiture of Rebel Property.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- In military parlance, certain strategical points, natural or artificial, are designated as the keys of certain positions or sections of country. Cumberland Gap is said to be the key of East Tennessee, Memphis of West Tennessee; Bowling Green is the key of Middle Kentucky, Paducah of Western Kentucky ; Springfield is the key of Southern Missouri, and, under present circumstances, of the whole State; Cairo is the key of an immense extent of country; Key West is the key to a great part of Florida, and Fort Pickens to a great part of Alabama; Fortress Monroe is the key of Eastern Virginia, and Cheat Mountain and Romney, of the western part of the State. Our navy carries in its capacious pocket the key of the Gulf and Atlantic coasts, and this has created for us several minor keys to the States there bordering -- such as Port Royal, Biloxi, Hatteras, &c. And so we might designate other points, on the coast and inland, that are keys which open the way to large sections of rebel territory. Some few of these keys are yet in the hands of the rebel robbers, but most of them are in possession of their legal owner, the National Government. Those which are not yet in our hands, such as Bowling Green, Memphis, Springfield and Manassas, we are just about ready to capture from the robbers by means of our military police. When we once get hold of them, our police will make rapid strides across the country toward the original dens of thieves and pirates, in South Carolina and on the Gulf, and scourge the bandits into honesty. And after these lost keys are again ours, as we believe they will be before the Winter passes away, we may be sure that the nation will not again let them slip out of its hands.

abstract: The steamship Bremen arrived at this port last evening, and the Canada reached Halifax yesterday morning the latter bringing two days later advices from Europe, and  50,000 in specie.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Bremen arrived at this port last evening, and the Canada reached Halifax yesterday morning the latter bringing two days later advices from Europe, and 50,000 in specie. The news, however, is unimportant. Troops were still continuing to leave England for the British Provinces, and the iron-plated Warrior had her sails bent in readiness to leave. The people were in a state of great suspense and anxiety, and the funds were flat. M. THOUVENEL's dispatch on the Trent case, had been published in London. The substance of Earl RUSSELL's letter had also been published. The Prussian Government had addressed a note to its Minister in this country condemning the proceedings of Capt. WILKES in the Trent case. The action of our Government, in the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL, had been anticipated in Paris. The London Times correspondent in this country writes, under date of Dec. 9, that military affairs move on in a "hum-drum sort of parade and review order," and is somewhat sarcastic in his criticism on affairs. Business of all kinds was dull. The stock of cotton at Liverpool and Havre was considerable. There were prospects of troubles with the Sikhs in India, and warlike preparations were being made to meet them.

abstract: The Report of the Inspector-General submits the following plan relating to the agency between the State and the troops in the service of the United States: First -- To establish an here, to gather into it all data and interest of importance in regard to New-York troops, and make such information available to all parties interested. Second -- To make this office the of communication between the State officers and State troops. Third -- To act for the State Executive in such matters as might require personal attention at the various military departments of the General Government. Fourth -- To act for the military authorities here in any matters referred to me relating to our troops, supplies and other military business.

abstract: The Republican Central Committee met last evening for the purpose of reorganizing for the year 1862.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Central Committee met last evening for the purpose of reorganizing for the year 1862. Contesting delegations from the Seventh, Fourteenth, and Twentieth Wards presented themselves, and the evening was spent in endeavoring to dispose of their claims, which were finally referred to a committee of three for each contested Ward. The Gilbert delegation from the Twentieth then withdrew, and the Central Committee adjourned until Thursday, the 16th inst., at 8 P.M.

abstract: In the Senate, Mr. POWELL presented a number Of resolutions passed by the Legislature of Kentucky, principally relating to National affairs  denouncing the rebellion, and pledging Kentucky  to pay her portion of the direct tax. Petitions for
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Mr. POWELL presented a number Of resolutions passed by the Legislature of Kentucky, principally relating to National affairs -- denouncing the rebellion, and pledging Kentucky to pay her portion of the direct tax. Petitions for the emancipation of the slaves were also presented. The House bill for the construction of twenty mail-clad steam gunboats was reported from the Naval Committee by Mr. HALE, with an amendment authorizing the President to have the work done, and not the Secretary of the Navy -- the intention of the report being to censure the Secretary for his course in making purchases for the Navy. This caused some debate, which continued until the expiration of the morning hour. The joint resolution from the House, providing for the withdrawal from bond of tea, coffee and sugar, without the payment of the additional duties, was laid over until to-day. The Kansas contested election case was then debated until the adjournment.

abstract: One of the most ridiculous characters in all imaginative literature is "The Physician in Spite of Himself," in MOLIERE'S comedy of that name.
lead_paragraph: One of the most ridiculous characters in all imaginative literature is "The Physician in Spite of Himself," in MOLIERE'S comedy of that name. But both in his absurdity and his misfortunes he is eclipsed by the editor of the Herald, who, having exhausted all other means of making himself the laughing-stock of the town, has been compelled to abandon quackery in journalism for quackery in medicine, and who has undertaken to qualify himself for his new part by a careful study of the advertisements of patent medicines. The physician in spite of himself is beaten by his wife, is beaten by other people, (of course we mean MOLIERE's physician,) is laughed at for his ignorance: puts the liver on the left side, and the heart on the right: justifying himself by the famous reply "we have changed all that" -- and is the butt, the laughing-stock and the cat's-paw of the play. In all these points he is beaten by his modern imitator. But on one he is entirely eclipsed by his rival. The former, living in a coarse age, is tolerably decent, tolerably clean; the latter, living in these decorous days is intolerably -- other-wise. For, proud of the newly acquired knowledge which is so much to his taste, he goes into particulars, and drags into his editorial columns, and explains to the best of his ability, those phrases which are to other people entirely without meaning and without interest, and which in other journals are left undisturbed in advertising columns, resting there upon the responsibility of professional advertisers, and to be seen only by those for whom they have interest, or to whom the remedies which they promise are necessary.
headline: {'main': 'The Physician in Spite of Himself.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Physician in Spite of Himself.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The new Board met for the first time, last evening, at the Halls of the Board of Education, and was called to order by the Clerk, Mr. BOESE. All the members were present.

abstract: -- Sharp dashing and successful movements seem to be quite the rule in Western Virginia. In addition to the neat affair of MILROY's, at Huntersville in the Alleghanies, the other day, we have news this morning of a successful movement by another detachment of the same commander's forces in Tucker County; and also of a successful operation, on day before yesterday, by a detachment of KELLY's command, near Romney. The former affair resulted in half a dozen rebels being killed and captured, and the rest of the troop being put to flight; and the latter operation resulted in the routing of 2,000 rebels, with a loss of fifteen and the capture of prisoners, ordnance and stores. More important still, as a result of the last mentioned action, it is said that the rebel JACKSON, who marched up so pompously the other day to Hancock (on the Potomac) and commenced shelling the town, has retreated, probably to Winchester. The point where the fight took place is at a gap of one of the Alleghany ridges, about twenty miles of where JACKSON's force was stationed, and on the road leading to Winchester; and if JACKSON had not thus hastily retreated, his lines of communication would have been cut, and the large force sent out on Monday, from Gen. BANKS' division, to confront him, would have made brief work with his rebel regiments. The rebels will not now be able to make a stand, in that line, anywhere short of Winchester. With the force at Romney properly reinforced, and with the dashing Gen. LANDER in command at that part of the Potomac, they will not long find themselves safe at Winchester either.
lead_paragraph: -- Sharp dashing and successful movements seem to be quite the rule in Western Virginia. abstract: In the Senate, a memorial was presented by Mr. WOODRUFF, asking that the auction duties paid in this City revert to the City Treasury.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a memorial was presented by Mr. WOODRUFF, asking that the auction duties paid in this City revert to the City Treasury. The customary preliminary notice was given of two bills -- one to authorize incorporated banks to hold United States Stocks, and the other providing for the inspection of steam boilers in this City and Brooklyn by Commissioners. Resolutions complimentary to Gen. SCOTT were introduced by Mr. WOODRUFF. They also provide for an appropriation to purchase an album similar to that presented to LAFAYETTE by the City of New-York.

abstract: Editorial opposes suspending US Coast Survey work; Editorial opposes suspending service
snippet: Editorial opposes suspending US Coast Survey work; Editorial opposes suspending service
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce has, we learn, been called to-day, for the purpose of protesing against the suspension of the Coast Survey. It is understood that the House Committee of Ways and Means, prompted by a well-meant but ill-directed economy, has stricken from the Treasury estimate the greatly reduced appropriation for the next fiscal year, so that upon the 30th of June next, unless the sum be restored, the most important scientific and practical enterprise our Government has ever undertaken, will be suspended. Of the many reasons why the entire country must lament this step, we enumerate a few.

abstract: We print elsewhere the draft of the bill by the Committee of Ways and Means at Washington, to provide what is termed a new National currency, based upon a deposit of United States stocks.
lead_paragraph: We print elsewhere the draft of the bill by the Committee of Ways and Means at Washington, to provide what is termed a new National currency, based upon a deposit of United States stocks. Under this bill, banks may be organized in any portion of the country, with capitals not less than $50,000; and upon depositing with the Bureau, to be constituted for the management of the system, bonds of the United States, shall be entitled to receive bills for circulation to a like amount. In addition to such security for the redemption of the bills, it is provided that each bank shall keep on hand, in moneys of the United States (which provision is intended, we presume, to embrace Treasury Notes,) 25 per cent. of the amount of its circulation outstanding at any one time. The bills of banks organized under this law are to be received in payment of the dues to Government, except customs. The provisions for the management of the Banks, and the proceeding to be taken in case of default in redemption of bills, are similar to those of the banking law of the State of New-York, and do not require extended notice. The scheme also provides that 30 per cent. of the capital of each Bank; shall be paid up at the time of the commencing business. When 60 per cent. of the capital is paid up, the Bank may apply to the Comptroller, who may extend such time for paying up the remainder as he may deem compatible with the public interests.
headline: {'main': 'The Scheme for a National Currency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Scheme for a National Currency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Isaac Dayton vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This case has been fully stated in the TIMES, both in point of fact and law. The argument was concluded yesterday by GILBERT DEAN, Esq., on behalf of the Corporation, in an argument elaborating the points stated in the TIMES of yesterday: First, that the plaintiff had no such pecuniary interest in the matter as gave him a standing in court. Secondly, the Common Council is a legislative body, and cannot be controlled by the Courts, under the Charter of 1857. The provision under which this point is raised was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. The Court reserved decision.

abstract: At the meeting of the Seventh Regiment, National Guard, last evening, a ceremony of an interesting nature took place. The occasion was the presentation of a handsome National standard to the regiment by the ladies of California. After the manoeuvres, Col. LEFFERTS conducted Senator J.N. MCDOUGALL, who was to make the presentation on behalf of the ladies of California, upon the platform. Senator SPINOLA, RICHARD O'GORMAN, Esq., and Rev. Mr. WESTON were also upon the platform. In making the presentation, Senator MCDOUGALL said that the ladies of California presented that tribute to the Seventh, as having been one of the first to fly to arms to subdue treason when it had arrived at a giant's strength. And he assured them that none were more loyal than the ladies of the far-off land from whence he came. Col. MARSHALL LEFFERTS, on behalf of the regiments, returned thanks for the gift in a brief and appropriate manner. The band of the regiment was in attendance, and enlivened the scene by some most excellent music. Nearly a thousand people were present who witnessed the ceremony.

abstract: ANOTHER GAMBLING-HOUSE BROKEN UP. On Tuesday night, at a late hour, Capt. WILLIAMSON, of the Fouateenth Precinct Police, made a descent upon a gambling-house, situated at the corner of Hesterstreet and the Bowery.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER GAMBLING-HOUSE BROKEN UP. -- On Tuesday night, at a late hour, Capt. WILLIAMSON, of the Fouateenth Precinct Police, made a descent upon a gambling-house, situated at the corner of Hesterstreet and the Bowery. The movement was made by order of Superintendent KENNEDY, who says he is determined to break up all establishments of a like character. The saloon was kept by John JACKMAN and ROBERT HUDSON, who were arrested. About twenty of the inmates were also taken into custody, who, at the time of the arrests, were all engaged in gambling. So sudden and unexpected was the entrance of the officers, that the gamblers had no time to remove their implements of trade. The Police took possession of a large number of dice, cards, dominoes, and also $100 in gold. The arrested parties were conducted to the Station-house, where they gave their names as follows: Daniel Powers, James Wilson, Benjamin Paine, John Bridge, Louis Zilson, George Sinclair, John Halsey, H. Bugbee, Henry Coleman, Wm. Stinson, Henry Joslyn, Joseph Cregier, James Bayard, Henry Baker, James Stevens, Solomon Rothschilds, Henry Myers, James Herrey, Henry Graven and John Bragg. A portion of the persons arrested, who were only visitors at the house, were discharged, while some were held as witnesses. The proprietors were held to bail in the sum of $800 each.

abstract: Editorial urging Congressmen use powers wisely during crisis; Editorial on key military positions in war
snippet: Editorial urging Congressmen use powers wisely during crisis; Editorial on key military positions in war
lead_paragraph: Nothing could be more foolish than the clamor which certain journals are raising against discussion of public measures in Congress. If the criticism were directed merely against unwise or untimely talk, no sensible man but would approve the sentence; but when it is urged that the people's representatives shall abrogate their proper legislative functions, and confine themselves to voting appropriations and imposing taxes, it is difficult to resist the conviction that the clamor proceeds either from a pitiful subserviency, or from a very inadequate conception of what Congress is. Were the duty of the National Legislature limited to blindly voting budgets, a far simpler contrivance than the complex machinery of our representative system would answer the purpose. But we hardly think the American people are prepared to accept any such theory; and, on the contrary, they will continue to expect, that those whom they have sent to Washington as their agents shall exercise to the full their right to give or to withhold, to censure or commend those set in the high places of civil or military trust -- shrinking from neither the duties nor the responsibilities of their position.

abstract: Two more important successes in Western Virginia are recorded this morning. Gen. MILROY has followed up his victory at Huntersville with another one in Tucker County, north of his position at Huttonsville, in which three hundred of the Thirty-second Ohio Regiment, under Capt. LACEY, dispersed four hundred rebels, and captured a Commissary, with a large amount of his stores, besides killing and wounding several.
lead_paragraph: Two more important successes in Western Virginia are recorded this morning. Gen. MILROY has followed up his victory at Huntersville with another one in Tucker County, north of his position at Huttonsville, in which three hundred of the Thirty-second Ohio Regiment, under Capt. LACEY, dispersed four hundred rebels, and captured a Commissary, with a large amount of his stores, besides killing and wounding several. The second success was at Blue's Gap yesterday morning. A detachment of Gen. KELLY's forces at Romney, under command of Col. DUNNING, of the Fifth Ohio, left Romney, on Tuesday night, at 12 o'clock, and attacked the rebels, two thousand strong, at daylight. The rebels were completely routed, with the loss of fifteen killed, two cannon, twenty prisoners, including a commissioned officer, their wagons, &c., and all without the loss of a man on our side. This is an important success, as it endangers the left wing of the rebels on the Upper Potomac.

abstract: -- The Sanitary Commission has submitted to the War Department a report of its operations in behalf of our soldiers. A digest of this paper, prepared by a member of the Commission, we admit into other columns of this paper, not merely to show that the Board has done something beside quarrel with the regular medical staff of the army, but as furnishing that clear and detailed account of its labors, which we have long argued the right of the public to receive. The report leaves no doubt of the zeal and industry, if not of the uniform discretion of the Commission. It will be read with interest.

abstract: -- In the absorption of the public mind in the stirring events of the rebellion, the Mormon territory out in the Great Salt Lake region has probably been the last thing thought of; and it is a little startling to hear that Utah is knocking at the door of the Union, and asking to be let in. A Convention is to meet on the 20th of this month, to draw up and adopt a Constitution for a State Government, which will be submitted to the people for their approval. When the people have voted for it, application will be made to Congress for the admission of the State into the Union, and the people of Utah hope it will be accomplished during the present session.
lead_paragraph: -- In the absorption of the public mind in the stirring events of the rebellion, the Mormon territory out in the Great Salt Lake region has probably been the last thing thought of; and it is a little startling to hear that Utah is knocking at the door of the Union, and asking to be let in. abstract: The report of the Judge-Advocate contains valuable suggestions as to the measures desirable to increase the efficiency of the State Militia. The Act of 1792 is pronounced as an utter failure, and should be at once repealed. Instead of attempting to make all...
lead_paragraph: The report of the Judge-Advocate contains valuable suggestions as to the measures desirable to increase the efficiency of the State Militia. The Act of 1792 is pronounced as an utter failure, and should be at once repealed. Instead of attempting to make all men in peace soldiers, in an agricultural community, the principle should be to form a good nucleus of military around which all men could cluster in time of war, making all persons capable of bearing arms liable to military duty in war times. General training days, instead of promoting the efficiency of the militia, are days of drunkenness and dissipation. A draft of a new law is transmitted, the main features of which are as follows:

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE NEW-YORK BIBLE SOCIETY. -- The annual meeting of the New-York Bible Society was held last evening at the Bible House, Fourth-avenue. After the Secretary's and Treasurer's reports had been read and adopted, and various other business of a routine nature gone into, the election of officers for the ensuing year took place. The result was as follows: President -- WM. ALLEN BUTLER Esq.; Vice-Presidents -- T.A. Brower, No. 36 Warren-street; Chas. A. Davison, No. 51 Wail-street; S.B. Caldwell; No. 20 Old-slip; J.W. Dunning, No. 182 Washington-street; John S. M'Clean, No. 282 West-street; Samuel Holmes, No. 4 Beekman-street; Corresponding Secretary -- R. McCartee, Jr., No. 20 Exchange-place; Recording Secretary -- Jas. C Holden, No. 13 Cliff-street; Treasurer -- Thos. C.M. Paton, No. 88 Leonard-street.

abstract: SOLDIERS OF THE ARMY OF THE KANAWHA: The campaign in the western portion of this State is now, as far as you are concerned, ended. At its close you can review it with pride and satisfaction. You first encountered the enemy five months since on his unobstructed march into the intorior of the State. From that time until recalled from the field, you were engaged in perpetual warfare with him.
lead_paragraph: CAMP NEAR DUBLIN DEPOT, Dec. 26, 1861.

abstract: The Police have succeeded in breaking up another gambling house in this City. At a late hour on Wednesday night, Sergeants WILSON and WADE, of the Eighth Precinct, having received orders from Capt. HELME to that effect, proceeded to No. 551 Broadway, and in the second story of that building they found a number of men engaged in playing the game of "Faro." They arrested CHARLES NEVILL, the clerk and dealer employed in the establishment; CHARLES BOYD, a speculator; GEORGE SMITH, who claims to be a blacksmith, and ALFRED REILLY, (colored,) who was a waiter in the saloon. The officers seized all the tools and implements of the business, consisting of one dealing-box, one lay-out, one cue-box, one large table, one set of checks, a check rake, four packs of cards, and a quantity of dice. The prisoners and property were taken to the Eighth Precinct Station House. Yesterday the parties arrested were taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and held to bail for examination, which will take place on Saturday next. The name of the proprietor is ROBERT GREENE, alias Blake. He was not in the room at the time the descent was made, and consequently escaped arrest. The authorities state that this establishment has of late been doing a very extensive business, and many complaints have recently been made against it. The same saloon was broken up about five weeks ago.

abstract: -- Everybody must notice the extraordinary richness of our columns these days in documents of public interest. Now is the time when the results of the year are summed up in Governors' and Mayors' Messages, and Annual Reports of Bodies, Corporations and Institutions of every kind -- material, educational, scientific, financial, statistical, social, sanitary, religious and what not. These are the stuff from which our Buckles and philosophic historians are to weave the history of the times -- these the material for genuine scientific inductions. He must be blind indeed, who does not see a kind of living poetry in these presentations of the wondrous richness of our American life and activity. They are, indeed, the rough eleements of such a real epic as was never written.

abstract: -- The dispatch this morning from Cairo is somewhat stirring, but of its fundamental truth there need be no doubt. The telegraph yesterday announced that Flag-officer FOOTE had at length handled his flotilla on the Mississippi, making a reconnoissance within two miles of the great rebel works at Columbus; and we know that the army at and near Cairo is ready for motion. Gen. HALLECK has worked hard for ten weeks in maturing the details of this expedition, and he has certainly achieved wonders. It only remains for him now to lead forward his magnificent column either to the points named in the dispatch, or to some other point, equally eligible, not named in the dispatch. The prospects are bright for an advance, a fight and a victory in the Mississippi valley.

abstract: -- The Herald is exultant over its possession of the Post-office advertising for the current year, and points to it as an evidence of the desirableness of its columns as an advertising medium. The evidence is the other way. A paper like the TIMES, having no end of decent advertisements, at paying rates, must always decline the Letter List, simply because it does not pay, and crowds from its columns matter of far greater interest and variety. The Herald, on the contrary, is poor and exhausted, and, moreover, is compelled to compensate the poverty and impurity of its advertising pages by such expiation as this, the weekly list being a sort of Friday fasting and penance for the sins of the week. But were the Post-office patronage desirable, there is a sufficient reason why no respectable paper can ever seek it in competition with the Herald. It is given to that paper which swears to the largest circulation within certain limits. An attempt to rival the Herald in swearing is, of course, lunacy; and the fortunes of a respectable journal must be desperate, indeed, when it will consent to measure its talent for perjury with the pet sheet of the bawdy-houses and grog-shops. The satanic organ, for this reason alone, is secure of an indisputed lease of this boasted patronage.

abstract: The steamship Kangaroo arrived here yesterday. The advices have been generally anticipated. The British journals were mainly occupied with the American war question; but as they probably by this time received Secretary SEWARD's letter, announcing the giving up of MASON and SLIDELL, they will now have an opportunity of moderating their passions and their manners. The Tories, however, seemed to be clamorous for a war with America, on general principles. From Ireland we learn that THE O'DONOGHUE had been removed from the commission of the peace of the Counties of Cork and Kerry, for the part he took in the recent Dublin meeting of sympathy with America. The Journal des Debats gives Archbiscop HUGHES a castigation for a Pro-Slavery letter which appeared in his organ here some time ago, and which has now been published in Paris.

abstract: In the Senate, a petition was presented, praying that the State assume its share of the National tax. Preliminary notice was given of a bill to incorporate the New-York Cab Company, and of one to regulate the Concert Saloons in this City. The latter compels every place of public dramatic performance to procure a license, and forbids the sale of liquor to the audience by females, under certain pains and penalties. A bill was introduced to authorize the Supervisors of Kings County to provide a tax for the support of the families of volunteers. The Health bill, passed last year by the Assembly, was again introduced. Concurrent resolutions, requesting the President to provide for an exchange of prisoners, were also introduced.

lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives has fairly taken hold of the abuses of franking. There seems to be no doubt of its passage.

abstract: Matter of the Petition of the Trustees of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Public School. In 1796 Dr. John Baker, by his will, left a valuable estate in the Nineteenth Ward of this City, in trust to Trinity Church, for the purpose of establishing a "Charity...
lead_paragraph: Matter of the Petition of the Trustees of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Public School. In 1796 Dr. John Baker, by his will, left a valuable estate in the Nineteenth Ward of this City, in trust to Trinity Church, for the purpose of establishing a "Charity School," at which it was proposed to educate, support and maintain such children as should be admitted as pupils. At the expiration of the life estates in the property, the Governor of the State was authorized by the will of the testator to collect the rents, &c., of such property, and apply such collections to the uses mentioned.

abstract: -- The Tribune is moved by the annual report of the Police Commissioners to demand a reduction of the pay of the police. It also proposes to double or quadruple their duties. Nothing could be more unjust, or more characteristic of a journal which has traded so extensively upon a reputation for a jealous guardianship of the rights of labor. The fact is, even without imposing new tasks upon the service, it would doubtless be found impracticable to obtain the proper material at any price seriously lower than that now offered. At the old rates we should have to content ourselves with a force as worthless as the Ex-Mayor's Municipal police. It is the generous pay which has given the department its present admirable and serviceable personnel. What is wanted is a transfer of additional duties to the force. They will no doubt be cheerfully undertaken by men who would gladly relieve the irksome monotony of patrol duty by such variations of their daily task. Let the entire inspection of streets, pavements, cleanliness, lamps, gas-meters, and other similar objects of civic supervision be assigned to the Police Commission; and a judicious economy will be had at a less cost than the demoralization and degradation of the service; while the interests of the City will be more faithfully looked after. The report of the Commissioners upon this point is sensible and practical. It will afford the true basis of reform.

abstract: The first annual meeting of the Women's Aid Association to found a German Hospital was held yesterday afternoon, at the rooms in Clinton Hall. The chair was occupied by Mrs. HUGO WESENDONCK, and there was a large number of ladies present. The report of the Executive Committee, which was read, speaks of the liberal support the Germans have given to the enterprise with thankfulness, and exhorts them to continued effort. Mrs. ANNA OTTENDORFER, the Treasurer, reported the number of members of the Association to be 392, who paid as their annual dues $457, and collected $1,361 93. In addition to that amount, the Association received $1,215 68 from the ball held Jan. 17, 1861; $267 93 from a benefit in the Stadt Theatre; $242 20 from a concert in April; $115 14 from a picnic held in September; $68 from a maunee by GUS. SATTER; $44 93 in interests, and $67 45 from various sources; making the aggregate receipts $3,830 26. The expenditures amounted to $36 80, leaving a balance of $3,793 46, of which $3,793 were deposited in the German Savings' Bank. After the reading of the annual reports, the Committee on the Ball held on the 29th of December, reported that the ball had resulted favorably to the fund, and that thus far $800 had been collected from its proceeds, but that the amount would be much larger. The attention of those present was called to the engravings on exhibition at GOUPIL's, which are to be disposed of by chances for the benefit of the fund. After the acceptance of the reports and payment of does the meeting adjourned.

abstract: A subscription list has been opened at the office of the Eco d'Italia, No. 298 Broadway, by the Italian residents of this City, on behalf of the suffering people of the once beautiful and populous town of Torre del Greco, in the vicinity of Naples. The terrible eruption of Mount Vesuvius which, accompanied by earthquake, desolated the country for miles around its base, on the 8th of December last, has left 12,000 of the 15,000 souls who so lately inhabited Torre del Greco houseless and homeless. Their condition is represented by official statements to be pitiable in the extreme, the fearful convulsion of which they have been the victims having almost totally destroyed the town.

abstract: News from Confederate States
snippet: News from Confederate States
lead_paragraph: We had the pleasure of an interview yesterday with Mr. FRY, of Mobile, a young man of much intelligence, who has just returned from Europe; who, in addition to dispatches to the President from our Commissioners, and London papers, communicates intelligence of a most gratifying character in regard to the feelings of the English people, and the purposes of their Government toward the Confederate States. Mr. FRY left London on the 10th of November, on board the British steamer Gladiator, laden with 30,000 Enfield rifles, 200 tons of powder, sabres, pistols, medicines, surgical instruments, camp utensils, etc., for the Confederate States. The 9th of this month the Gladiator entered the harbor of Nassau, for the purpose of coaling, and to receive instructions as to the Confederate port she should approach. On the second day after, the United States gunboat Flambeau made its appearance in the harbor, sent thither for the special purpose of intercepting the Gladiator. There they both lie now -- the Gladiator afraid to venture out, and the Flambeau not daring to lay hands on her; and there they are likely to remain until Great Britain enters the ring, when not only will the Gladiator be convoyed over to a Confederate port, but the Flambeau be picked up and brought along with her.

abstract: The United States Vs. The brig. Sarah Starr and cargo. This brig. was captured by the Wabash on  the 3d of August, 1861, about 25 miles from the bar at Cape Fear River.
lead_paragraph: The United States Vs. The brig. Sarah Starr and cargo. -- This brig. was captured by the Wabash on the 3d of August, 1861, about 25 miles from the bar at Cape Fear River. She was bound from Wilmington, N.C., to Liverpool, with a cargo of naval stores, and was libeled for condemnation as prize on the ground of being enemy's property and of having broken the blockade. The bark was claimed by Cowlan Gravely, a British subject, residing in Charleston, S.C. The register of the vessels in 1859, showed that she was then owned by C.B. Eddy, of Fall River, Mass., Wm. J. Munro, of Charleston, S.C., and Geo. C. Munro, of Newport, R.I. On May 10, 1861, Eddy and Wm. J. Munro conveyed their two-thirds to Geo. C. Munro, for $100, and he, on July 1, 1861, conveyed the whole vessel to Gravely for the expressed consideration of $10,000. In the bill of sale he described himself as of Wilmington, N.C. For the consideration Gravely gave his note for $3,000, and the residue was agreed to be paid out of the freight to be earned by the brig on her arrival at Liverpool, to which port she was to be forthwith dispatched with a cargo. Munro, who was going as passenger in the vessel, and was captured with her, on his examination in preparatorio, stated that none of the purchase money was paid, but there was some evidence from an agent of the vendors tending to show that the note had been subsequently paid.

abstract: Editorial urges moving US Mint from Philadelphia to NYC; Editorial urges removal of US Mint from Philadelphia, to NY
snippet: Editorial urges moving US Mint from Philadelphia to NYC; Editorial urges removal of US Mint from Philadelphia, to NY
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia is suffering its yearly attack of a peculiar local affection, termed "mint-fever." The paroxysm commences with the annual meeting of Congress, and rages with more or less violence until that body adjourns. It is only necessary to suggest the propriety of creating an Assay Office at New-York, or of adding to the Assay Office facilities for coining, whereby the expense and delay of sending to the other side of New-Jersey may be avoided, to produce the most painful symptoms, which may be made very nearly fatal by asking why there should be a mint at all in an out-of-the-way and wholly provincial borough like Philadelphia. It is to the circumstance of our having propounded a milder sort of interrogation in this line, that the agonies of our sister city are at the present moment due. Congress has been petitioned to add the implements of coinage to the machinery of our Assay Office. Whereupon the Philadelphia Board of Trade, the Philadelphia Press and the Philadelphia people are wrought to the acutest excitement, and the symptoms we allude to have already supervened. Every conceivable argument is presented why our petition should be denied. Economy forbids it; the prosperity and self-respect of Philadelphia forbid it; those indefinite things, the true interests of the Government, forbid it; and, indeed, every aspect of the case is so forbidding that the wisdom and public spirit of Congress are confidently appealed to, to repel a proposition so repulsive.
headline: {'main': 'The Mint Controversy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mint Controversy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ANOTHER RAILROAD ACCIDENT. -- Yesterday morning the 7 1/2 train on the New-York and Erie Railroad to Paterson, ran off the track at Hackensack junction, caused by the breaking of a switch. Two of the passenger cars were thrown down a slight embankment and considerably damaged, and several rails were torn up. Several passengers received slight bruises, but no person was seriously injured.

abstract: In the Senate, the bill to promote the efficiency of the Dead Letter Office was reported from the Post-Office Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the bill to promote the efficiency of the Dead Letter Office was reported from the Post-Office Committee. It provides that all dead letters shall, when possible, be returned to the writers. Its consideration was postponed until to-day. The Judiciary Committee reported in favor of the expulsion of Senator JOHNSON, of Missouri. Various bills relating to the organization of the army, were reported from committees, but were not acted upon. A petition was presented from citizens of Pennsylvania, reflecting upon the Secretaries of War and the Navy, for the appointment of Messrs. CUMMINGS and MORGAN to make contracts. Mr. WADE introduced his bill to punish frauds upon the Treasury. It provides for fine and imprisonment. It was referred. The House resolution relating to bonded coffee, tea and sugar, was passed, 23 to 15. The correspondence relating to the Trent affair was then taken up, and Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, delivered his expected speech upon the subject, which will be found reported in full in this morning's TIMES. After Mr. SUMNER concluded, the bill providing for twenty mail-clad gunboats was taken up, the question being, on the proposed amendment to substitute the President for the Secretary of the Navy as the person to obtain their construction -- thus implying a censure on Secretary WELLES. The debate upon the proposition was continued at considerable length, and it was finally thrown out by the adoption of a resolution, offered by Mr. WILSON of Massachusetts, making a direct inquiry of Secretary WELLES as to his employment of GEORGE B. MORGAN, and the amount of compensation paid him.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. That there is a striking difference between the skillfull concentrations of an able dramatist and the diffuse wordiness of a bungler when both undertake the task of preparing a novel for the stage, was pleasantly demonstrated at this house on Wednesday night, and unpleasantly at another establishment not far distant, a week or so back. Mr. BOURCICAULT has converted the "Cricket ...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- That there is a striking difference between the skillfull concentrations of an able dramatist and the diffuse wordiness of a bungler when both undertake the task of preparing a novel for the stage, was pleasantly demonstrated at this house on Wednesday night, and unpleasantly at another establishment not far distant, a week or so back. Mr. BOURCICAULT has converted the "Cricket on the Hearth" into a delightful drama full of spirited effects, strong contrasts, and seasonable lessons of geniality. The other dramatist, in trying to do the same thing by the "Christmas Carol," failed in every one of these requirements, succeeding only in hacking and hewing his material into a shapeless and meaningless mass, wearisome to him who was not familiar with the source whence it was chipped, and irritating to all else. But why dwell on a matter that has been disposed of by the public? BOURCICAULT'S piece remains, and the other has been consigned to that limbo whence good scenery cannot rescue it. Coming as a lesson of life, such a fact would be heeded, but as an experience of the stage it will have no significance. It would be vain to hope that good plays will take precedence of bad ones -- useless to suggest that a man should understand his business ere he attempts to practice it. The stage gravitates naturally to mediocrity, and managers think no more of a literary man than they do of a bootblack. It is only by stern examples, such as the absolute failure of one piece and the complete success of another, that they will be brought to a sense of their dependent condition, -- and now that the mania for tinseled flummery and local bosh -- called burlesque -- has subsided, these examples will be frequent.

abstract: A few troublesome alarmists among us are tormenting themselves with forebodings that, notwithstanding our graceful surrender of MASON and SLIDELL, we are in danger of war  and that some other cause will inevitably produce a rupture, and lead sooner or later to hostilities.
lead_paragraph: A few troublesome alarmists among us are tormenting themselves with forebodings that, notwithstanding our graceful surrender of MASON and SLIDELL, we are in danger of war and that some other cause will inevitably produce a rupture, and lead sooner or later to hostilities. A ready answer to these prophets of evil may be found in the fact that nowhere but in the columns of the New-York Herald and a few similar uninfluential journals, which secretly abet secession, are the rumors fomented in this country, while abroad, Mr. REUTER, the Jewish telegraph agent, is only playing his usual and well understood part in the rebel programme, by tampering with the dispatches which first reach the European newspapers. Meanwhile the public on both sides of the Atlantic, who have anything to lose by a war, will rejoice in the assurance, that in spite of the schemes of secession sympathizers here and rebel emissaries abroad, the prospects of peace between this country and England, were never more promising.

abstract: We print on another page the elaborate speech of Senator SUMNER in the Senate yesterday, touching the affair of the Trent.
lead_paragraph: We print on another page the elaborate speech of Senator SUMNER in the Senate yesterday, touching the affair of the Trent. If any one, looking at the formidable proportions of this discourse, and bearing in mind the exhaustive treatment the subject has already received from official and unofficial pens, should be disposed to regard it as a needless waste of oratorical powder that person would be forgetful of the mental condition of Congressmen, as lately displayed. The honorable members of either House, who have hitherto uttered their sentiments on this question, have only too painfully exhibited their need of enlightenment. It would be neither just nor creditable that such unintelligent and prejudiced utterances as those of Messrs. HALE and THOMAS -- we leave VALLANDIGHAM out -- should go abroad as the settled sentiment of the country. And certainly there is no man in either House so well fitted by his position and his studies both to present to Congress a well-considered legal view of the case, and to represent to Europe public opinion here with dignity and acceptance, as the distinguished Chairman of the Senate Committee of Foreign Affairs.

abstract: This vessel sailed from Picton, N.S., Dec. 15, bound to Boston, with a cargo of coal, in charge of Capt. HENRY THOMPSON.
lead_paragraph: This vessel sailed from Picton, N.S., Dec. 15, bound to Boston, with a cargo of coal, in charge of Capt. HENRY THOMPSON. Nothing particular occurred until Dec. 28, when she experienced a heavy gale from the north, which continued forty-eight hours, during which she shipped several heavy seas, and was strained badly, causing her to leak. Jan. 1, lat. 42° 30', lon. 64° 30', took another gale from northwest, which lasted until the 5th; during the gale was struck by a tremendous sea, which sprung the bowsprit, swept the decks, and carried away mainboom, fore and main gaft, stove the boat and cabin-windows, and washed away the bulwarks, the vessel making water very fast; all hands at the pumps. On the 5th, the crew being exhausted and frost-bitten, they had to be lashed to the pumps to keep from being washed overboard -- at this time had four feet of water in the hold, and the schooner was settling fast. The ship J.L. Bogert, Capt. CONWAY, from Havre, being near by, took off the crew, we saving only what we stood in. When leaving the schooner the sea was breaching over her. This was in lat. 40° 10', lon. 67°.

abstract: -- The Secretary of the Treasury must find some mitigation of the difficulty of instituting a new scheme of revenue, in the promptitude with which the State Governments assume the task of collecting the direct National tax. The lead of New-York and Pennsylvania will no doubt be followed by the other States, tempted by the premium offered by the Treasury; so that the country is not to be vexed by that new and fearful legion of assessors and collectors, indispensable to the gathering of the revenue by the National Government directly. If the rule be made universal, one-half the embarrassment and odium of the business will be removed. Let the example of the Empire State influence the others to like action.
lead_paragraph: -- The Secretary of the Treasury must find some mitigation of the difficulty of instituting a new scheme of revenue, in the promptitude with which the State Governments assume the task of collecting the direct National tax. If the rule be made universal, one-half the embarrassment and odium of the business will be removed. Let the example of the Empire State influence the others to like action.

abstract: Our  columns this morning contain abstracts of two decisions in prize cases, made recently by Judge BETTS.
lead_paragraph: -- Our columns this morning contain abstracts of two decisions in prize cases, made recently by Judge BETTS. The case of the Sarah Starr is interesting from the fact that she was claimed by a British subject named GRAVELY, resident in South Carolina, who set up that he had bought the vessel there, (though it appeared he had never paid for her,) from persons resident in South Carolina, and further, that under the provisions of the Treaty of 1794, between this country and Great Britain, which provided that in case of war between the two countries, merchants belonging to one country, but resident in the other, should be allowed to continue their trade so long as they behaved peaceably. He further claimed that since the passage of the act of July 13, vessels could not be seized and forfeited except under that act.

abstract: A dispatch from Cairo announces that the great Mississippi Expedition was in readiness to leave on Thursday, but was delayed in consequence of a dense fog upon the river. Yesterday, however, the fog raised, and at last advices the expedition was expected to start immediately. The steamers and gunboats were ready, and the troops and stores were all on board, and a part of the forces had already proceeded to some point down the river. We may look for stirring news from the West in a day or two.

abstract: There has been enough of doubt in the attitude of the British Government to create a very natural anxicty to learn with what reception the news of the surrender of the Trent captives will meet in England. ...
lead_paragraph: There has been enough of doubt in the attitude of the British Government to create a very natural anxicty to learn with what reception the news of the surrender of the Trent captives will meet in England. The impression that the mother country seeks a quarrel with her over-grown child, has taken deep root in the American mind; and if the search of the West India packet was not the cause of a justifiable anger, and the resentment appropriate to national honor grossly outraged, but rather the signal for the explosion of a politic passion and the pretext of a war, for which a pretext only was wanting, we may reasonably watch with solicitude the effect of our unexpected moderation. If the wrath of John Bull was genuine, our prompt concession must not only extinguish it, but excite the regret always realized by the generous when they have been guilty of hasty injustice. If not genuine, the American amend will be received grudgingly and scrutinized critically and disdainfully, and other causes of discord will not long be wanting.

abstract: We are in receipt of our foreign mails by the steamship Canada. Our Paris correspondent writes that up to the 27th ult., the excitement on the Trent case was as high as ever, and everywhere it was the grosse affaire. The Emperor NAPOLEON is so firmly convinced of the necessity to him of English alliance, that he will follow the lead of England in regard to American affairs, even at the risk of a breach with this country. Nevertheless a pamphlet, entitled Cannoneers! to Your Guns! had been published, which took strong ground for the North as against England. Probably the Emperor permitted the pamphlet to go out as a feeler of public sentiment, which he will not be slow to follow.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. We are glad to see, by an advertisement which appears elsewhere, that Mr. J. GRAU who seems to be the only manager in the country who does, instead of talking about doing, something ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- We are glad to see, by an advertisement which appears elsewhere, that Mr. J. GRAU who seems to be the only manager in the country who does, instead of talking about doing, something has succeeded in effecting an arrangement with the Directors of the Academies of Music in New-York and Brooklyn for the purpose of giving a couple of performances of opera in each city. In times of famine, half a loaf is decidedly better than no bread; and in the present condition of musical matters, we ought to regard Mr. GRAU's enterprise as a feast. It is at least a bold experiment, and will, we trust, reward the enterprise that suggested it.

abstract: The Committee appointed on Tuesday night to take measures for the purpose of holding a mass meeting of the German Republicans of New-York in reference to the resignation of Gen. SIGEL, met again last evening at HELD'S Hotel. A larger number of sympathizers with the object in view were present than had appeared upon the former occasion, and the liveliest interest was manifested. ...
lead_paragraph: The Committee appointed on Tuesday night to take measures for the purpose of holding a mass meeting of the German Republicans of New-York in reference to the resignation of Gen. SIGEL, met again last evening at HELD'S Hotel. A larger number of sympathizers with the object in view were present than had appeared upon the former occasion, and the liveliest interest was manifested. The meeting organized by calling Mr. FRIEDRICH KAPP to the Chair, and making Mr. WEIL VON GERNSBACH, Secretary. Mr. TZSCHIRNER, in a brief but spirited address, urged the importance of immediate action in the Sigel affair, and moved the appointment of a Committee of Arrangements, to consist of six persons, to be named by the Chair. The motion was passed, and Messrs. Glaubensklee, Sturn, Mann, Schwarzwaelder, Willmann and Windmuller selected as the Committee.

abstract: FIRE IN AN IMPORTER'S STORE. Between 3 and 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered on the fourth floor of premises No. 48 Water-street, occupied by JAMES SALTER, an importer. Mr. SALTER'S loss is about $6,000. He is insured for $3,000 in the Unity Insurance Company.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN AN IMPORTER's STORE. -- Between 3 and 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered on the fourth floor of premises No. 48 Water-street, occupied by JAMES SALTER, an importer. Mr. SALTER'S loss is about $6,000. He is insured for $3,000 in the Unity Insurance Company. The third floor was occupied by Dr. HORN & Co., as a drug-store. The damage to their stock was $5,000. They are insured in the St. Mark's and Relief Insurance Companies for $4,000. The second floor, occupied by N. LEVY & Co., dealers in cigars and liquors, was damaged to the amount of $5,000. They were insured for the same amount in the Exchange Insurance Company. The first floor, occupied by E.H. KELLOGG, as an oil store, was damaged by water to the amount of $200. Insured in the Etna Insurance Company, of Hartford, for $3,000, and in the Standard Insurance Company for $2,000. The building was damaged to the extent of $2,000, and is fully insured. It is owned by OBADIAH HOLMES. The cellars of the adjoining buildings, Nos. 46, 50 and 52 Water, and No. 80 Pearl-street, were flooded with water, but the amount of damage sustained is not yet known.

abstract: Editorial attacks Herald editorial policies
snippet: Editorial attacks Herald editorial policies
lead_paragraph: Some of the English newspapers have at last begun to perceive the true character of the New-York Herald. That it was vulgar, indecent, mendacious, and, above all, ridiculous, they found out long ago; for eyes, and common decency, and common sense were all that were required to make that discovery. But the moral status of the paper, the place which it holds in the estimation of the community, its own readers included, they have only just begun to apprehend. The notion is at last dawning upon their minds that such a monstrous and absurd performance as daily issues from the Herald office, cannot possibly have any influence with creatures of a higher grade of intelligence than gorillas, or be justly regarded as expressing the sentiment of human beings who have sufficient coherence of thought and consistency of action to be allowed to remain on the outside of a lunatic asylum. Seeing this, they yet stand puzzled over the facts that this queer paper has a considerable circulation, and that it is regarded as the cause of certain effects -- always evil, be it observed. At their puzzlement out comes the mountebank's trumpet, and we hear the long and well-known blast, followed by the query. "Who then can doubt the tremendous influence of the Herald?" A query, indeed, sufficiently impudent and ridiculous to excite a stare and a laugh on this side of the water, where the querist is well known, and which would be entirely unworthy of serious notice, were it not for the uninformed people upon whom it might possibly impose abroad.
headline: {'main': 'The Herald Appreciated in Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Herald Appreciated in Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on renewed Union loyalty with inauguration of Gov. Bradford; Editorial notes renewed Union loyalty in Maryland with inauguration of Gov. Bradford
snippet: Editorial on renewed Union loyalty with inauguration of Gov. Bradford; Editorial notes renewed Union loyalty in Maryland with inauguration of Gov. Bradford
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the new Governor of Maryland, who succeeds the loyal and faithful Gov. HICKS, delivered an inaugural address to the Legislature, which had convened in regular session. Gov. BRADFORD is a worthy successor to the late occupant of the Gubernatorial chair; and now that he has a Legislature to aid him which has a working majority of Unionists in both of its branches, we may expect that Maryland will put itself right on the record and right in its official action. The State will thereby relieve the National Government of one of its most difficult and embarrassing duties, and at once substitute civil for martial law in all parts of the State.
headline: {'main': 'Loyalty in Maryland.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Loyalty in Maryland.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The following changes have been made among the regular officers on Governor's Island and Bedloe's Island: Capt. THOMAS H. NEIGL Fifth Infantry, commanding the battalion of the First and Third Infantry, in the course of foundation on Governor's Is1and, has left for New-Mexico, to join his regiment; Capt. JOSEPH UPDEGRAFF, Fifth Infantry, in command of the permanent party, has been relieved by Capt. WILLIAM CLINTON, Tenth Infantry, in command on Bedloe's Island for some time past, and will shortly join his regiment; Lieut. JAMES M. BROWN, Seventh Infantry, has taken command of the company of Texan soldiers on Bedloe's Island.

abstract: SHIP. -- Mr. DION BOURCICAULT recovered a verdict of $500 in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, against Messrs. FOX & LINGARD, of the New Bowery Theatre, for violation of his copyright of the play of "The Octoroon." Mr. BOURCICAULT's recent performances have not been such of late as to raise a peculiarly affectionate feeling toward him in the hearts of the public of New-York. It has been thought that one who had been so treated as he was here, might have been a little less quick to expose the Stars and Stripes to insult, and to exalt the Stars and Bars to honor. Perhaps, however, we should have asked too much in expecting him to refrain from any course which, under the pressure of public excitement, would aid in filling his boxes by reason of any such sentiment as gratitude to audiences of the past, now three thousand miles away from him.

abstract: An investigation was commenced yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, at the New-York Hospital, in the case of THOMAS RYAN, who was shot in the head on New-Year's night, at a public house in James-street. The unfortunate man lingered until yesterday morning, when he expired in great agony at the Hospital, where he has been attended since the night of the occurrence. There were seven or eight witnesses examined yesterday afternoon, but their testimony is, for the most part, of a very conflicting character.

abstract: long lull in privateering. The piratical act of the Nashville is the last thing of the kind, and that was an affair as profitless to JEFF. DAVIS as it was dastardly. ... There has been a
lead_paragraph: -- There has been a long lull in privateering. The piratical act of the Nashville is the last thing of the kind, and that was an affair as profitless to JEFF. DAVIS as it was dastardly. The Sumter, instead of being the terror of the seas, which she was for a week or two, is now reduced to being the skulk of the West India Isles. It is all she can do to keep out of the way of her pursuers. The small pirate craft which for a while pounced out with impunity from Bull's Bay, Savannah, the Gulf Coast, or the North Carolina sounds, and seized our unsuspecting traders as they passed by, have all been quiet lately. They are neither able to get out from their dens nor to get in again, and are leisurely rotting by the Southern docks; while those who manned them have become disheartened and disgusted at their ill-luck. That fearful Confederate fleet, which has been anchored in James River for half a year, waiting for a chance to run out and devour Northern ships, must be nearly sunk with its weight of barnacles, and the jolly tars who man it must be lean with waiting. The pirate steamboats which JEFF. DAVIS commissioned to prey on the commerce of the inland rivers, the Tennessee and the Mississippi, have captured, in the gross, one scow. In fact, it must be acknowledged all round, that Confederate privateering is not much of a success. If the Sumter and the Nashville were nabbed -- and it is not creditable to us that they have not been nabbed -- the whole system of Confederate piracy might be considered as effectually disposed of. The ravages of the privateers in the Mediterranean, the China Seas, and the Pacific, have thus far existed only as dark and ominous prophecies in rebel newspapers.
