abstract: In the Senate, petitions were presented for the emancipation of the slaves, and in favor of employing homoeopathic physicians in the army. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, made a personal explanation, in which he denied the truth of certain statements made in the New-York Herald. In the course of his remarks he stated that he had accepted the Brigadier-Generalship tendered him by the Government. The Secretary of State was called upon for a list of all the Consuls. The reports of the Judiciary Committee, in favor of the expulsion of WALDO P. JOHNSON and TRUSTEN POLK, Senators from Missouri, were taken up and unanimously adopted. A copy of the resolutions for their expulsion was ordered to be sent to the Governor of Missouri. The bill in regard to the administration of criminal justice in the District of Columbia, relating especially to the incarceration of fugitive slaves, was made the special order for Tuesday next. The bill providing for the construction of mail-clad gunboats was not considered -- an answer from the Secretary of the Navy to the resolution adopted on Thursday being waited for. The case of Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, appointed in place of Col. BAKER, was taken up, and after considerable debate, it was decided that his credentials must go to the Judiciary Committee before he could be admitted to a seat -- only eleven Senators opposing such action. The bill for the organization of the Signal Department of the army was passed. The bill relating to the appointment of Sutlers in the army was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment, which was until Monday.

abstract: William Alwater et al. vs. James B. Hixon. -- This was an action upon an account. The defence was that the goods sold were sold to the firm of Geddings & Hixon, and not to the defendant solely. The evidence was conflicting on the question whether the goods were sold upon the sole credit of Hixon or to the firm. It appeared that the goods were delivered to a Mrs. LOVETT in the Fall of 1860. The Court decided that the decision of the questions of fact was peculiarly the province of the jury, and that it was their duty, not disregarding such instructions as they might receive from the Court, to harmonize the conflicting evidence so far as practicable, and, in case of palpable contradictions, to say which testimony was worthy of belief and what witnesses were worthy of belief. The jury had not agreed upon a verdict at a late hour in the afternoon.

abstract: Dion Bourcicault vs. George L. Fox et al. This was an action brought to recover damages against the defendants for an alleged violation of the plaintiff's copyright of the play called "The Octoroon," concerning which, as will be remembered, there was great litigation some two years ago between the present plaintiff and Mr. Stuart, who then controlled the Winter Garden.
lead_paragraph: Dion Bourcicault vs. George L. Fox et al. -- This was an action brought to recover damages against the defendants for an alleged violation of the plaintiff's copyright of the play called "The Octoroon," concerning which, as will be remembered, there was great litigation some two years ago between the present plaintiff and Mr. Stuart, who then controlled the Winter Garden. The plaintiff giving in evidence the copyright of the play, proved by Miss Burke, who acted in the piece, that the play was performed for nine nights at the New-Bowery Theatre, of which the defendants were lessees. The defendants gave evidence in relation to the old controversy between Stuart and Bourcicault, and proved that they bought from Stuart the manuscript of the play and the scenery for $350. At the time of the purchase the controversy between Stuart and Bourcicault was pending, and it was mentioned in the negotiation, both Stuart and Lingard agreeing, that Stuart had the right to the play, but Stuart only sold what right he had in the piece. After the piece had been played several nights at the New Bowery, the plaintiff caused notice to be given to them that they were infringing upon his copyright, and they then desisted. Some of the witnesses were asked as to the similarity between the play and Mayne Reid's novel of The Quadroon, but the evidence was excluded by the Court.

abstract: The seventh annual Convention of Ward delegates met last evening at the German Republican headquarters in the Steuben House, at 8 o'clock, to reorganize the German Republican Central Committee for the year 1862. Three delegates from every Ward in the City, elected at the close of the by gone year, were present, and the best spirit prevailed.
lead_paragraph: The seventh annual Convention of Ward delegates met last evening at the German Republican headquarters in the Steuben House, at 8 o'clock, to reorganize the German Republican Central Committee for the year 1862. Three delegates from every Ward in the City, elected at the close of the by gone year, were present, and the best spirit prevailed. A working organization was effected by calling HENRY RICHARD, of the Twentieth Ward, to the Chair, and appointing GEORGE MANCHOT, of the Sixteenth, and EMIL KIRCHNER, of the Eighteenth Ward, Secretaries. Mr. RICHARD, on taking the Chair, made a brief address, in which he congratulated the Convention upon the late success of their party and the bright prospects of the future. When the acclamations that greeted these remarks had subsided the roll was collated and called, whereupon it was discovered that the Twelfth and Thirteenth Wards were represented by two sets of delegates. A Committee of six was, upon motion, appointed by the Chair to investigate the claims of the contestants, and in a few moments they presented a majority and a minority report in both cases. Finally, after extended debate, in which the claims of the F. Malignon and Henry Frank Parties of the Twelfth Ward were warmly sustained by their respective champions, it was finally decided by the Convention to admit the Malignon delegates to regular recognition.

abstract: In accordance with advertisements previously published, a portion of the Sea Island cotton confiscated by the National forces in South Carolina was sold yesterday by public auction under the direction of Assistant Quartermaster-General Col. D.D. TOMPKINS, at Nos. 65 and 67 Wall-street, at 12 o'clock. Messrs. BURDETT, JONES & Co., were the auctioneers, and about two hundred merchants attended the sale. It was announced that the terms were cash, and the order for the goods would be the receipted bills. The storage paid until the 24th inst., and the buyer to take care of the insurance.
lead_paragraph: In accordance with advertisements previously published, a portion of the Sea Island cotton confiscated by the National forces in South Carolina was sold yesterday by public auction under the direction of Assistant Quartermaster-General Col. D.D. TOMPKINS, at Nos. 65 and 67 Wall-street, at 12 o'clock. Messrs. BURDETT, JONES & Co., were the auctioneers, and about two hundred merchants attended the sale. It was announced that the terms were cash, and the order for the goods would be the receipted bills. The storage paid until the 24th inst., and the buyer to take care of the insurance.

abstract: Editorial on medical practice in US Army
snippet: Editorial on medical practice in US Army
lead_paragraph: There is quite a commotion just now among the doctors in regard to homoeopathic practice in the army. An effort is making in Congress to give this school of practitioners the same privileges, and the same right to position, in the army, as any other medical school or sect. It is claimed that the Government has no more right to create an established form of medicine than an established form of religion; and that the civil and military authorities are as incapable of deciding the scientific questions involved in the dispute between homoeopathy and allopathy, as they would have been of deciding the great theological controversy between the Homoousians and the Homoiousians. Therefore, as a regiment may choose a priest, a minister, or a rabbi, from any one of a hundred sects, to cure its souls, it is argued that it should be permitted, with equal freedom, to say whether, in physic, it will follow the doctrines and practice of Hippocrates, or Hahnemann, or Priessnitz. The homoeopathists are besieging Congress for a definition of their constitutional rights in this respect; and a bill, we believe, is to be at once introduced putting them on an equal footing in the army with any other medical school. They also claim the right of establishing a military homoeopathic hospital in Washington, that the merits of the rival systems may be tested before the world on a large scale. They are greatly encouraged lately in their efforts for official recognition from the fact that when, a few weeks ago, Gen. MCCLELLAN's charger was indisposed, he submitted to homoeopathic treatment, and the General, himself, in his recent sickness, has had homoeopathic advice. It seems at present likely enough that the system may get a chance of being put into recognized practical operation in the army. The Water Cure school will then undoubtedly claim the same rights -- to be followed by the Botanic doctors, the quack doctors, and a host of nameless medical sects.
headline: {'main': 'Homoeopathy in the Army.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Homoeopathy in the Army.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Thursday night a light air prevailed from south and east, which was accompanied by a thick fog which settled over our cities and bays the entire day, and at sunset became very dense; the progress of the ferry-boats was much impeded, and the navigation of all vessels rendered very difficult and dangerous both by fog and ice, large quantities of the latter being broken up by the soft and murky weather and drifting about. Should this weather continue but a short time, there is no doubt but that the ice will disappear. As yet we have heard of no serious accidents to the shipping or about the harbor. The Sound boats bound east are all detained in consequence of the fog.

abstract: Colt, (Col) Samuel; Dies
snippet: Colt, (Col) Samuel; Dies
lead_paragraph: -- Col. Samuel Colt, who died at Hartford, Ct., on Thursday, was born in that city, on July 19, 1814. Entering a factory belonging to his father when ten years old, he worked faithfully four years, and then was sent away to school at Amherst, Mass. He managed to run away from this establishment, and shipped as a boy before the mast on a ship bound to the East Indies. On his return from this voyage, he served a short apprenticeship in a factory at Ware, Mass., but getting weary of this manner of life, assumed the name of Dr. Coult, and traveled through the United States and British Provinces, lecturing on Chemistry. The money thus earned enabled him to perfect his famous revolver, of which he had conceived the idea when on the way to Calcutta, and in 1835, when but twenty-one years of age, he took out his first patent for revolving fire-arms. A company was formed in 1835, with a capital of $300,000, to manufacture these arms, but there was at first so little demand for them that it was obliged to suspend in 1842, and when the Mexican war broke out they had gone so entirely out of use that Col. Colt found it necessary to make a new model before he could fill Government orders. Since that time the business has increased so rapidly that the manufactory in Hartford, which has cost altogether over $1,000,000, has been found insufficient to fully supply the demand, although the arms are also made both in England and in Russia, at establishments erected under Col. Colt's supervision. Col. Colt's ingenuity was not confined to the perfection of fire-arms. He has invented a submarine battery of great power and efficiency, and as early as 1843 laid and operated a submarine cable from Coney Island and Fire Island to this City, and from the mouth of the harbor to the Merchants' Exchange. Although overwhelmed with business cares, Col. Colt has always manifested the greatest interest in the welfare of his employes, having erected for them remarkably tasteful and convenient places of residence, and established a public hall, where they have the privilege of attending courses of lectures and concerts.

abstract: A year or so since there was great curiosity to know who wrote Rutledge. It was never very clearly established whether the author was sought for in order to be made the recipient of a aurel wreath, or simply that a morbid anxiety to know who could have written so very stupid a book might be satisfied. Any way, the author- ...
lead_paragraph: -- A year or so since there was great curiosity to know who wrote Rutledge. It was never very clearly established whether the author was sought for in order to be made the recipient of a aurel wreath, or simply that a morbid anxiety to know who could have written so very stupid a book might be satisfied. Any way, the authorship has never been avowed; and in this fact we discover in the author an evidence of genius which we failed to find in the book. Another novel, The Sutherlands, "by the author of Rutledge," is printed by CARLETON. Some profound critic remarks that "this second effort of 'the author of Rutledge' is in all respects equal to the first." And such is our candid opinion, -- it is certainly no better -- it could not well be worse. Rutledge was a remarkably weak imitation of Jane Eyre, possessing all the faults of that remarkable book without one trace of its abounding vigor and weird interest. The Sutherlands is a book coined from the same metal as Rutledge, but cast in a different mold. It has the same hollow ring, the same galvanic glitter. There is a weak straining after effect -- a lamentable "falling short" of reaching any. As to plot, if the book has any, we have failed to discover it. Scenes and episodes seem to be only introduced that the author may be delivered of a deluge of words, which lie like water on the brain. We question whether so many words with so few ideas were ever before -- except in the memorable instance of Rutledge -- gathered together in the same space. Occasional horrors are crowded in to awake the morbid appetite which is supposed to lie dormant in the minds of most readers, but they are so unusual, so far removed in their ghastiliness from anything approaching life, that a weary feeling of disgust is the only emotion excited. It will be well, we think, for the author to preserve anonymousness to all time, lost a deputation from the reading world take summary vengeance for all they have been called upon to endure.

abstract: When, at the height of the secession fever, it became necessary for the Government to restrain, in some few instances, the liberty of lawless and licentious printing, the English Press sent up a chorus of indignant howls over the despotic extinction of freedom of thought in the United States. But there is a recent English case of ...
lead_paragraph: -- When, at the height of the secession fever, it became necessary for the Government to restrain, in some few instances, the liberty of lawless and licentious printing, the English Press sent up a chorus of indignant howls over the despotic extinction of freedom of thought in the United States. But there is a recent English case of persecution for conscience' sake that should admonish them to look nearer home for food for their indignation. Rev. Dr. WILLIAMS, one of the writers of "Essays and Reviews," is now being tried for heresy before the Court of Arches in England. The gentleman's contribution to that now famous volume is simply an exposition of some of the more recent German rationalistic principles of criticism with respect to prophecy, and are stated not so much as his own views, as those held by the late Baron BUNSEN, the noble-hearted leader of vital Protestantism in Germany. And yet he is hauled up and tried for heresy! When the National authority of the United States was put forth to suppress the publication of inflammatory [???] to create sedition, it was a measure of public safety imperatively demanded by the voice of all loyal men. It is reserved for England in the Nineteenth Century to give us the example of a public prosecution for a difference of speculative opinion on a matter of faith. One would suppose that this should close the mouth of English defamers of America in regard to one slander. Will it?

abstract: Intelligence is received, from three different sources, that the second invasion of Eastern Kentucky by the rebels has ended still more disgracefully for them than the first, and that HUMPHREY MARSHALL, from whom the rebels expected so much, has failed signally in establishing his reputation as a military leader.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence is received, from three different sources, that the second invasion of Eastern Kentucky by the rebels has ended still more disgracefully for them than the first, and that HUMPHREY MARSHALL, from whom the rebels expected so much, has failed signally in establishing his reputation as a military leader. On Monday last, our dispatch states, Col. GARFIELD, in command of the National forces, had advanced up the Big Sandy River as far as Painesville, seven miles from the rebel camp, when he was met by a flag of truce from MARSHALL, who wished to know if matters could not be arranged without a fight. Col. GARFIELD, however, had no arrangement to offer but a fight, or an unconditional surrender of the rebel forces. Whereupon MARSHALL addressed his men, and gave them the choice of scattering or surrendering, and they concluded to scatter, after burning all their wagons, tents, camp equipage, &c. Nothing was taken away by the rebels but their cannon, which were expected to be captured by Col. GARFIELD's cavalry, which went immediately in pursuit.

abstract: History and nature of excise laws
snippet: History and nature of excise laws
lead_paragraph: As the experience of European nations has proved that internal taxes on articles of general consumption are a reliable source of revenue, and may be so apportioned and collected as to benefit rather than to impoverish the industrial resources of the people, these taxes, which are known as excise duties, will probably occupy an important place in the new revenue laws which the war for the Union has rendered necessary. Every true patriot must desire that these new taxes should be distributed so as to press as lightly as possible on the country, and since we have not, like the Monarchies of the Old World, any obstinate long-established prejudices to combat, nor any relics of exploded unscientific systems of taxation to clear away we may hope at once to inaugurate a fiscal system which shall be in accordance with those great principles which the latest teachings of the science of taxation demonstrate to be the best for the people and the most productive to the Government.

abstract: GEN. THUMB SURRENDERS TO COMMODORE NUTT The smallest dwarf in the world is undoubtedly Commodore NUTT, of Manchester, N.H. He was born April 2, 1844, hence is eighteen years of age. His sponsorial appendage is GRORGE WASHINGTON NUTT. He is the son of Maj. RODINA NUTT, a thrifty ...
lead_paragraph: GEN. THUMB SURRENDERS TO COMMODORE NUTT. -- The smallest dwarf in the world is undoubtedly Commodore NUTT, of Manchester, N.H. He was born April 2, 1844, hence is eighteen years of age. His sponsorial appendage is GRORGE WASHINGTON NUTT. He is the son of Maj. RODINA NUTT, a thrifty and highly respected farmer of the above town Special attention has been paid to the education of the pigmy Commodore. He is not only a good. English scholar, but is also tolerably proficient in the French language. He amuses himself in farming, especially in driving the team, having quite a passion for horses. He is also fond of hunting and fishing, and is a bright and graceful specimen of minute humanity, being symmetrically formed, and a most polite and refined gentleman. In stature he is inconceivably small. All other dwarfs tower as giants by his side. Gen. TOM THUMB, with whom Mr. BARNUM created such a furor in Europe some years ago, stands thirteen inches higher than Commodore NUTT, "boots and all." Liberal overtures have been made by our first showmen for the privilege of exhibiting the little Commodore to the public, but his parents, and indeed the little NUTT himself, have decided objections to his being made "a show" of. Gen. TOM THUMB called on the little man a short time since. It is said that after looking down upon him for some time, Gen. TOM exclaimed, "Well, Commodore NUTT, I must confess you are a hard nut to crack!" Mr. BARNUM, with his usual enterprise, has gone to Manchester for the purpose of making overtures to the Commodore, with a view of exhibiting him at his Museum.

abstract: Editorial on Union's commercial relations with Great Britain; Editorial on Unions commercial relations with Great Britain
snippet: Editorial on Union's commercial relations with Great Britain; Editorial on Unions commercial relations with Great Britain
lead_paragraph: It appears from the accounts issued by the Board of Trade, in London, that the total quantity of raw cotton imported into British ports during the eleven months ending Nov. 30, was 10,432,099 cwt., being but 677,875 cwt. less than in the corresponding portion of the preceding year, and 1,375,978 cwt. more than in that of 1859. If we exclude from the account all but American cotton, the proportions differ somewhat more, the imports of this staple amounting to 7,312,940 cwt., which was 1,606,129 cwt. less than in 1860, and 173,065 cwt. more than in 1859. The imports of American cotton diminished but little until October, when, of 487,636 cwt. of raw cotton imported, only 3,630 cwt. were of American growth. In November, the quantity fell to 286 cwt., the total imports being 328,576 cwt. The stock of all kinds is greater now than at this time last year, but the Indian supply alone has increased. Of the total quantity imported during the eleven months, 2,600,280 cwt. was obtained from India, 316,917 cwt. from Egypt, 129,512 cwt. from Brazil, and 72,450 cwt. from all the rest of the world. These latter small supplies from acknowledged sources show, however, a disposition to increase the supplies derived therefrom, amounting to 5,378 cwt. in October, against 3,754 cwt. in the corresponding period of the preceding year, and to 18,672 cwt. in November, against 10,001 cwt. The advance in price is shown by the fact that the value of the cotton imported during the ten months ended Oct. 31, is computed at £34,718,348, being £3,755,963 more than for the corresponding portion of 1860, though the quantity imported was less. The exportation of raw cotton from Liverpool does not appear to have been so large as was feared, the total exports of the eleven months being 2,528,824 cwt., against 2,160,197 cwt. in the corresponding period of the preceding year. In November, only 111,885 cwt. were exported, against 136,925 cwt. The diminished consumption is shown by the diminution of the declared value of the manufactures, exclusive of hose, sewing-thread, lace, and other small wares, from £36,102,681 to £33,416,527, as compared with the corresponding eleven months of 1860. Two-thirds of the total decrease is due to the diminished exportations to the United States. The computed real value of the cotton yarn exported during the eleven months was £8,730,223, against £9,069,052; and the lesser branches of manufacture, above referred to, and which could add about a million and a quarter sterling to the total value of the exports, have fallen off in about the same proportion.

abstract: Coroner COLLIN, yesterday, concluded the inquest in the case Of THOMAS RYAN, who died at the New-York Hospital, on the 9th inst., in consequence of injuries received by a pistol-shot wound on NewYear's night, at a saloon in James-street, an account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: Coroner COLLIN, yesterday, concluded the inquest in the case Of THOMAS RYAN, who died at the New-York Hospital, on the 9th inst., in consequence of injuries received by a pistol-shot wound on NewYear's night, at a saloon in James-street, an account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES. The testimony was of a very conflicting nature; some of the witnesses testifying that at the time the pistol was fired there were only three persons in the room besides the deceased and the proprietor of the establishment, whose name is FREDERICK LOWERE. Several other witnesses state that when they heard the report of the pistol there was a great crowd in the room, and that nearly all the lights had been extinguished by LOWERE, who was behind the bar.

abstract: editorial on coalition and Monroe Doctrine
snippet: editorial on coalition and Monroe Doctrine
lead_paragraph: The formidable force sent against Mexico by the "combined Powers" has excited the surprise of every one on this side of the Atlantic. A fleet numbering fifty-six vessels of war, carrying 1,453 guns, and manned by 27,931 sailors, marines and soldiers, seems to Americans an armada entirely over-proportioned to the accomplishment of the professed objects of the expedition. To exact reparation for alleged grievances from a State so feeble as Mexico, which has neither navy nor regular army, that vast armament was assuredly not needed. The fact is, however that the professed objects of the allies are not the only and most important objects which they have in view. They aim at something more worthy of their power and prestige than redressing their subjects' wrongs, or oppressing a poor, distracted and impotent Republic. Those latter designs, indeed, are not yet officially and openly avowed, but the candor of Mr. THOMAS COLLEY GRATTAN, in his recent pamphlet on the Trent affair, and the propriety of recognizing the Southern Confederacy, gives us very plainly to understand that they are actually entertained. That writer does not hesitate to affirm that the chastisement of "miserable Mexico" is merely the "nominal purpose" of the nations whose fleets and armies are now beleaguering her borders, and seizing on her ports. If, however, the chastisement of Mexico is only the "nominal purpose" of the coalition, what is its real purpose?
headline: {'main': 'The Triple Coalition and the Monroe Doctrine.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Triple Coalition and the Monroe Doctrine.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The table which is presented below will slow at a glance the rates of ad valorem duty equivalent to the specific duty levied on some of the principal articles imported. The table has been very carefully ...
lead_paragraph: The table which is presented below will slow at a glance the rates of ad valorem duty equivalent to the specific duty levied on some of the principal articles imported. The table has been very carefully prepared from the invoices at the Custom-house, and may be relied on for its correctness. It is necessary that members of Congress should understand how the duty levied on any article compares with its value, in order to pass proper revenue laws. This knowledge it might be difficult for many to acquire, and hence we supply the information.

abstract: We have information from Bowling Green up to yesterday, some of which is not suitable to be made public, and the rest not important. The stampede of the Federals last week across Green River was Causeless a fact which they soon found out, and endeavored to repair by recrossing to this side with additional force. They are maneuvering with great ...
lead_paragraph: We have information from Bowling Green up to yesterday, some of which is not suitable to be made public, and the rest not important. The stampede of the Federals last week across Green River was Causeless a fact which they soon found out, and endeavored to repair by recrossing to this side with additional force. They are maneuvering with great circumspection, and are under constant apprehensions of a whipping. They are intrenching on this side of Green River, and have their pickets within six miles of Cave City, having an advance of some twenty regiments on this side of the river. They are trying all sorts of tricks to entrap our forces, but have failed, as they always will. Their latest effort has been to create the impression that they designed, and are about to execute, a double flank movement on either side of Bowling Green, calculating on an advance on this city by way of Hopkinsville.

abstract: In the matter of Frederick J. Conant, a bankrupt. This was an application to set aside a conveyance made by the General Assignee in Bankruptcy, on various equitable and legal reasons.
lead_paragraph: In the matter of Frederick J. Conant, a bankrupt. -- This was an application to set aside a conveyance made by the General Assignee in Bankruptcy, on various equitable and legal reasons. The final action of the Court in what strictly belonged to the case in bankruptcy terminated in December, 1842, and on a collateral matter in October, 1858, more than two years before the present application. The question arises whether it is not too late to make any application in the matter.

abstract: -- It will please all who have a regard for the public morality of the City, that so promptly on the meeting of the State Legislature a bill has been introduced (by Senator ROBERTSON, of Westchester,) aiming a vigorous blow at those infamous hot-beds of vice, the so-called Concert Saloons, which within the past twelve months have come out like a pestilent eruption on our great public thoroughfares. It is gratifying to us that it was in these columns that the crusade against this vile nuisance was begun. Our expose of the true character of these places called the attention of the Grand Jury to the subject, and resulted in their presentment. Our efforts, after some weeks, brought the respectable among our cotemporaries also into the field in the same good work, and the result is a powerful current of wholesome indignation which cannot but be felt at Albany. The bill which Mr. ROBERTSON has introduced into the Senate is adequate to the purpose aimed at -- the suppression of this public scandal. We sincerely trust it will promptly receive the authority of law.

abstract: The contro versy provoked by Ex-Treasurer DORSHEIMER, in regard to the qualifications of his successor, has resulted in favor of the latter.
lead_paragraph: -- The controversy provoked by Ex-Treasurer DORSHEIMER, in regard to the qualifications of his successor, has resulted in favor of the latter. Mr. LEWIS, who was duly elected in November, was tardy about filing his bonds; and owing to the absence of certain State officers from the capital, was unable to get his papers perfectly en regle before the 1st inst. The outgoing Treasurer thereupon took ground that the election of Mr. LEWIS was invalidated, and that he, DORSHEIMER, was entitled to hold on until the job could be done over again. He accordingly retained possession of the [???] and records, and sturdily refused to [???] either to Mr. LEWIS. Judge PECKHAM has now decided the title of the latter to installation to be perfect. The point raised by the usurping officer is pronounced frivolous, and a peremptory mandamus will at once terminate his usurpation.

abstract: -- Advices from Buenos Ayres to Dec. 12 state that in consequence of the defeat of the army of the Argentine Confederation by that of Buenos Ayres, Dr. DERQUI, the President of the Confederation, took refuge on board of the British ship-of-war Ardent, Capt. PARRISH. When the Ardent was at anchor off the Island of Martin Garcia, the Buenos Ayrean Commander sent on board a demand that Dr. DERQUI should be given up to him for trial by the Supreme Court of Buenos Ayres. Capt. PARRISH met this demand by a reply that it is not customary for officers of the British navy to give up political prisoners who had once been received under the protection of their flag. The flight of Dr. DERQUI, it was thought, would leave Buenos Ayres free to treat with the Provinces, and gradually to reassume her proper position as the capital and seat of Government of the Confederation, which ought never to have been at any other place.

lead_paragraph: In the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 3d instant, we gave a list of the vessels and regiments comprising the Spanish Contingent of the Allied forces against Mexico; but as it is highly probable, in consequence of the Government of the latter country having acceded to the terms demanded by England and France, that Spain will now have to light her battle single-handed, it becomes a matter of interest to ascertain what power she is enabled to bring into the field. We therefore lay be-fore our readers a full account of the naval and military forces of that country, as it is found to exist at the present time.

abstract: Recruiting fort the regular army presents no feature calling for special comment. It is as dull as it can possibly be, both in New-York and other cities, and will doubtless continue so until Congress passes some stimulating measure.
lead_paragraph: The number of men enlisted here does not exceed ten, although there are seven offices open. The business done in the country, may be estimated by the fact that in Buffalo alone there are seven regular, rendezvous, and that, during the month of December, 1861, the total number of men booked was only eight. In some instances country offices have been open as long as three months without making more than two enlistments.

abstract: At a late hour, last evening, a letter was received in this City, from Albany, stating that, on Saturday, a mass meeting was held there, in SCHNEIDER's House, No. 362 Broadway, in reference to Gen. SIGEL's resignation, and that the same had organized, by appointing GEORGE SCHNEIDER President, Mr. FISCHER Vice-President, and LOUIS BETCKE Secretary; and that after expressing a determination to sustain SIGEL in all proper reclamations, they had resolved to await instructions from the Sigel Committee, in New-York.

abstract: The force of good example was never more happily illustrated than in the change which has suddenly overspread the heretofore distorted face of the drama and converted it once more into something pleasant to behold.
lead_paragraph: The force of good example was never more happily illustrated than in the change which has suddenly overspread the heretofore distorted face of the drama and converted it once more into something pleasant to behold. It is but a few weeks -- we might almost say days -- since the affiickes at all the theatres announced some repetition of a worn-out, sensational or spectacular drama. From Mr. WALLACK's hand, some up-town establishment to BARNUM's down-town American Museum, there was a glut of show pieces many of the concert-rooms, by the way, competing' and not unsuccessfully, with our beat theatres in this specialty of a vicious existence. It was a rage, and like all other rages, doomed speedily to exhaust itself. The managers, too, were careful to labor for their own destruction. They perceived that gorgeous scenery, and utterly inconsequential set-tableaux caught the eye of the public, and brought down the house with applause. Hence they became worshipers of the paint-pot, and in every piece presented at least one picture full of broad glaring effects and sensual dreaminess, but having no more relation to the plot than BARNUM's cartoon in Broadway has to the life of the merchant who passes it in an omnibus Not for a moment did it occur to their minds that something more than the eye had to be pleased; that after a while, these brilliant shams would pall on the appetite, and people would begin to talk about the intense stupidity of the dialogue they had listened to. On the contrary, what little literary merit the pieces possessed at the outset was speedily discarded, as superfluous. It was trifling enough, in all conscience but better than the vulgar clap-trap which took its place, and owed its origin to the gagging propensities of the actors. How long this state of affairs would have lasted, it is impossible to say. The public had probably wearied of it when Mr. WALLACK conceived the Idea of reviving the old comedies. Certain it is, that from the moment of doing so he has wrought a change in things theatrical, and been the recipient of the heartiest patronage. His beautiful theatre has been crowded with the best audiences we have ever seen in a place of amusement, and this, too, despite the unfavorable weather which has prevailed for a couple of weeks. The public rejoices like a school, boy relieved of his task. It is a good thing for a community when it can choose its recreation; a bad thing, when it is compelled to put up with that which neither improves the mind nor the heart. There is now no longer a doubt that given this choice, a New-York audience will always prefer what is healthful to that which is meretricious.

abstract: When the Devil was sick, the song goes, the Devil a saint would be. So poor old BENNETT, overcome with the prospective loss of the patronage of the Concert Saloons, and "pretty waiter girls," has lately been talking about his "religious principles," and claiming to teach decency to other papers.
lead_paragraph: -- When the Devil was sick, the song goes, the Devil a saint would be. So poor old BENNETT, overcome with the prospective loss of the patronage of the Concert Saloons, and "pretty waiter girls," has lately been talking about his "religious principles," and claiming to teach decency to other papers. To aid his budding piety it will be well for him to reread the following description of himself and the Herald some twenty years ago. The limner is Capt. MARRYAT, who says of himself, in his Diary: "before I had been six weeks in the country I was attacked by this wretch, and at the Same time, the paper was sent to me with this small note on the margin: 'Send twenty dollars and it shall be stopped.'" We quote from the Captain's "Diary in America," 1840:

abstract: A man named THOMAS WOLVEN, in the employ of CHARLES ANDERSON, corner of Oxford-street and Park-avenue, on Saturday last, stole $420 from his employer and left for parts unknown. Officer WALDRON, of the Fourth Precinct, was put upon the track of WOLVEN, and, late Saturday night, succeeded in arresting him, and recovered $394 25 of the money he had stolen. The accused was committed to answer.

abstract: editorial on ways to finance war now being discussed in Washington
snippet: editorial on ways to finance war now being discussed in Washington
lead_paragraph: It is greatly to be desired that the questions of Finance pending at Washington should be promptly determined. The Ways of conducting the Treasury, under the recent suspension of Specie payments at Bank, are immediately necessary -- pressingly so -- if the Public Finances are not to fall into utter confusion. The Means for making, such Ways easy and creditable are in one sense doubly important, but demand no crude or very hasty adjustment. A simple resolution that Congress will, at an early day, from the highest sense of public duly and pursuant to the known readiness of this whole loyal People to bear the burden, impose all-sufficient taxes to support the National credit, so as to render the Public Stocks created and to be created by the Loan Bills of Congress, not only negotiable, but every way desirable above all other income securities, would be sufficient, for the moment, to give direction to the preliminary question of Currency. Whatever shape or forms this question may be made to assume, to relieve the existing and painfully growing suspense, whether Exchequer Bills, as proposed by some banking authorities, having a few years to run, and bearing a moderate rate of interest, or United States Treasury Notes, to be made a legal tender, not alone for the convenience of the Treasury, in the absence of Specie payments at Bank, but in all the transactions of business between the People of the different States and of the same State, they will all undoubtedly be made fundable into the Public Stocks of the United States. The point therefore to be determined, and that we hope speedily, is the most practical form of Treasury Currency.

lead_paragraph: The Indiana Democratic State Convention met at Indianapolis on January 9. Hon. T.A. HENDRICKS was chosen President, and made a speech, denouncing the Administration in the strongest terms. JOHN S.DAVIS made a characteristic speech, alluding to his reported flight, and abusing Mr. LINCOLN in the grossest manner. He said, among other things, that he was not very particular about platforms, but one he could not sanction. He would never agree to any platform indorsing, in any way or degree, the present Administration, and would never vote for any proposition looking to the vigorous and unconditional prosecution of this war. W.H. ENGLISH also made his appearance on the platform, but spoke briefly. A series of resolutions, of which the following are a sample, was adopted by a vole of 431 to 52.

abstract: The corner-stone of a place of public worship for the first Jewish Synagogue ever organized in this city, was laid yesterday, with appropriate exercises. The congregation is known as "Baith Israel," of which Rev. JOEL ALEXANDER is the Rabbi.
lead_paragraph: The corner-stone of a place of public worship for the first Jewish Synagogue ever organized in this city, was laid yesterday, with appropriate exercises. The congregation is known as "Baith Israel," of which Rev. JOEL ALEXANDER is the Rabbi. Six years ago it was organized by sixteen persons, and a place for worship was secured at No. 155 Atlantic-street, where it has remained from that time until the present, gradually increasing in numbers, usefulness and prosperity, until now, even in these times when the whole financial world is deranged, and the country involved in war, the members feel warranted in supplying the necessity which exists of increased accommodations for public worship. Although the people of this faith are not very numerous in our midst, nevertheless this synagogue -- not to be behind the fashion -- has had its little dissensions, which resulted in a split, and the organization of a new synagogue known as "Bethlehem," in December last, now occupying a portion of Grenada Hall, Myrtle-avenue, as a place of worship. Hut the dissension in this case is likely to prove to be the seed of the church in this City, for where we have had only one society heretofore there exists two, and each is vieing with the other in the path of usefulness. There are also three or four Synagogues in the Eastern District, neither of which have as yet found it expedient to erect a house of their own. The Synagogue of Baith Israel, being the first to lay a corner stone in this City, there was much curiosity felt to witness the ceremony, and, notwithstanding the very disagreeable weather and that the ground was covered with snow and water, there was a very large attendance of the believers in the faith of Abraham, and a still larger attendance of others attracted to the spot by curiosity. But as the ritual of the Jewish Church does not specially provide for the laying of cornerstones, there is nothing very peculiar about the exercise, save and except the presentation of a silver trowel to the person selected to put the stone in place. The recipient of this distinguished honor -- for such it is considered -- is usually a leading and active man in the synagogue, who by his efforts und liberality in its behalf has been particularly identified with its success. The individual selected furnishes the corner-stone, and the congregation present to him the trowel, which is ever kept as a sacred heir-loom in the receiver's family.

abstract: In the TIMES of the 8th inst. there appeared a report of a meeting at Buffalo, called to consider the subject of frontier defence, and addressed by Ex-President FILLMORE. The Buffalo Commercial desires to know of us if we pretend that any such meeting was held. The only knowledge we have is founded upon the facts that the call for the meeting was published in the Commercial on the 2d; that we are not in the habit of accepting reports, save from correspondents whose reliability has been vouched by faithful service; and that we have received numberless congratulatory letters from Buflalo, complaining of the want of enterprise among the local papers, in permitting a New-York journal thus to monopolize a report of proceedings in which there was so deep a local interest. The evidence may be satisfactory to our doubting cotemporary.

abstract: Orders have been received from the War Department, for the Battery located at Meriden, Conn. to proceed to Fort Columbus, Governor's Island. It will leave New-Haven this afternoon, by steamer City of Hartford, arriving at the Fort early on Tuesday morning. The Battery is fully armed and equipped, with four 6-pounder bronze rifled guns, two 12-pounder howitzers, one hundred and ten horses, and one hundred and fifty-six men. It is considered unsurpassed by any Battery from New-England, and reflects the highest credit upon the skill of Brig. Gen TYLER, under whose immediate supervision it has been raised.

abstract: editorial holds Spain occupied Vera Cruz to get foothold ahead of Great Britain and France
snippet: editorial holds Spain occupied Vera Cruz to get foothold ahead of Great Britain and France
lead_paragraph: After all there is some chance for Mexico. The arrogance and precipitancy of Spain will most probably work out her salvation. Spain's invasion of Mexico and seizure of Vera Cruz were, it seems, unauthorized acts, of which the other Powers were ignorant, and will hardly approve. The terms of the Convention of London do not sanction this Spanish aggression. By that instrument, indeed, France and England admitted Spain to participate in the expedition against Mexico, to aid and assist them in putting the affairs of that ill-fated Republic in order, but the Allies, when conferring on Spain this honor, merely intended that she should act in concert with themselves, and had no idea of permitting her to intervene alone, and before they were ready to cooperate in the enterprise. The proper course for Spain to have taken, therefore, was to assemble her armament at the place of rendezvous, and there await the arrival of her confederates. The truth, however, is that the Court of Madrid regarded the intervention of France and England in Mexico with the greatest aversion, and was determined, if possible, to get the start of them. Accordingly the commander of the naval and military force at Havana received secret instructions to proceed forthwith to Mexico and commence operations; and so, giving the slip to their allies, the Spaniards sailed away to their destination, and took possession of Vera Cruz. When intelligence of this audacious aggression first reached us, though surprised at finding Spain alone in her glory, and unsupported by the other Powers, we yet fancied she was merely carrying out the programme agreed on, and that, however outrageous her conduct seemed, all was still right. But, as we have already intimated, the last European mail has brought us information on the subject which leads us to conclude that the contrary is the case. The invasion of Mexico by Spain had excited astonishment in France and England. The two nations were quite unprepared for it, and the Patrie goes so far as to affirm that the commander of the Spanish armada must have acted without orders from home. "Marshal SERRANO, at his departure from Havana," says this Parisian paper, "could not have known of the last arrangements made in London. He could not have received the dispatches from his Government informing him of the common cooperation of the three Powers." But is it probable that the Spanish commander ventured on so important a step without instructions? And the tenor of those instructions may be judged from the result.
headline: {'main': 'Spain in Mexico The Combined Powers not Combined.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Spain in Mexico The Combined Powers not Combined.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are all sorts of speculations as to the destination of the Burnside Naval Expedition, which is now riding in Hampton Roads. The rebels speculate, the soldiers of the expedition speculate, the country editors speculate, and almost every person has a private theory on the subject.
lead_paragraph: -- There are all sorts of speculations as to the destination of the Burnside Naval Expedition, which is now riding in Hampton Roads. The rebels speculate, the soldiers of the expedition speculate, the country editors speculate, and almost every person has a private theory on the subject. Nearly everybody agrees that it will not go further South than North Carolina, and a good many people think it will not go even as far away as that. The rebel MAGRUDER's opinion is that it is undoubtedly going up the James River, and "on to Richmond "by that route; and in expectation of it he has retreated to Yorktown, and has got everything ready for another retreat. The Richmond Examiner has reliable advices that the expedition is bound up the York river, as that is a far more eligible route to the rebel capital than by the James, and as it would be an easier way to get in the rear of the rebel right wing on the Potomac. It is given out by others that it is neither of these Virginia rivers by which the expedition will operate; but by a third stream, still further east, the Rappahannock, and that the design is to take in the rear the rebel batteries and rebel forces on the Potomac, and threaten the railroad connections of the rebel army with Richmond. A fourth theory sends the expedition up the Potomac, to take these same batteries in front, and to put an end to the river blockade which has so long and so disgracefully interrupted our communication with the National Capital. Other speculators look further South than either of the points mentioned, and judge from a number of significant indications that not Richmond nor the rebel right, but the city of Norfolk, is the point to be assaulted by a combined land and naval force; and that the expedition will sail to Cape Hatteras, enter Pamlico Sound, skirt along the inland water way, and the forces will take Norfolk in the rear. This theory is popular among the rebels; so they have fortified Roanoke Island and other points on the North Carolina Sounds, and dispatched the heroic Gov. HENRY A. WISE to take command of the rebel forces on the mainland in that vicinity. The rebels have many other theories on the subject, and almost every coast town from Norfolk to Galveston fancies that it is surely the point which, above all others, is most likely to be assailed. The likelihood is, however, that beside our high military authorities, there is no one in the country who can say certainly whither the expedition is bound, excepting JEFF. DAVIS and his immediate counselors; and probably even they are somewhat unsettled on the subject. Let every one in the meantime, look up his geography, and form his theory; but do not, make any wagers that the expedition will certainly go to either of the points which the rebels and the knowing ones so confidently name. The secret of the expedition's destination will be published in the TIMES, as soon as it effects a landing.

abstract: Lieut. MAURY, conscious that his conduct as an ingrate traitor and rebel is not calculated to make him appear in a very advantageous light abroad, has been of late trying to varnish it over in a series of letters to various distinguished European savans, replete with the most audacious falsifications. It seems, however, that he is not very successful, and that whatever reputation, mostly factitious, he ever enjoyed as a scientific man, is now dead. Not long since somebody proposed him as a candidate for the honor of corresponding member of the French Institute. His claims were referred to a Committee of eminent savans who reported unanimously that "the public reputation of Mr. MAURY was the work of men who knew nothing of the subjects they discussed." The fact is, scientific men in this country have always looked on him as a quack and charlatan. But now that he has turned out a traitor, the whole world, it seems, begins to appreciate him at his just value.

abstract: Editorial says Seward favors annexing Canada
snippet: Editorial says Seward favors annexing Canada
lead_paragraph: For the last six months the tone of the British Press towards Mr. SEWARD has been that of intense hostility. It seems to have been taken for granted that he was an enemy of England, -- that his public course had been marked by hatred of English institutions, and by a special desire to humble her pride and break her power, and this feeling, it is perfectly apparent, has had very much to do with the extraordinary excitement which pervaded the Press and people of England in regard to the consequences of the seizure of MASON and SLIDELL on board the Trent. It was assumed that this must lead to war, because it was believed to be Mr. SEWARD's determination to force the two countries into hostilities.

abstract: A rifle' capable of firing forty shots in as many seconds, has lately been invented by Rev. J.D. MOORE, of Birmingham, lowa. Mr. MOORE is very fond of hunting, and is an excellent marksman, and contrived the above-mentioned weapon for his own use in hunting sports. The rifle is intended for hunting game of all ...
lead_paragraph: -- A rifle' capable of firing forty shots in as many seconds, has lately been invented by Rev. J.D. MOORE, of Birmingham, lowa. Mr. MOORE is very fond of hunting, and is an excellent marksman, and contrived the above-mentioned weapon for his own use in hunting sports. The rifle is intended for hunting game of all kinds, from a squirrel to a deer, and the specimen will kill with accuracy a distance of three hundred yards. Its calibre is ninety-five balls to a pound, and it has the Maynard primer attached. The powder and balls are put into two tubes, which extend from the chamber about one foot up the barrel, parallel with each other, and both can be filled with ammunition in a few seconds. These serve the purpose of a cartridge box, and the rifle is charged by a partial revolution of the stock, which is quickly reversed, and the gun is ready for firing. The ball is rammed into the chamber with a sliding rammer, by the movement of returning the stock to its place. The manner of handling it may be learned thoroughly in a few minutes.

abstract: CORONER'S INQUESTS. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a girl, named ROSANNA CAULFIELD, six years of age, whose parents reside at No. 281 West-street.
lead_paragraph: The child had been attacked some days ago with the scarlatina, but was pronounced by the physician to be fast recovering, until Saturday, when, having taken some medicine obtained of a neighboring druggist, she immediately grew worse, and died shortly after. Suspicion that the child had died by reason of malpractice, as was published in some of yesterday's papers, was at once raised in the minds of the family. The father determined to have the case thoroughly investigated, and he therefore secured the services of one of the first chemical anatomists in the City, who, in conjunction with the Coroner and his Deputy, Dr. BEACH, yesterday proceeded to the house and made a thorough post mortem examination. The result was such as to satisfy all concerned that death was the result of the disease, and not of the medicine administered. A verdict of death from scarlatina was accordingly rendered.

abstract: Editorial on war-financing methods now under discussion in Washington; Editorial lauds instances of British and American democracy despite war; Editorial on NY Herald reporting of war
snippet: Editorial on war-financing methods now under discussion in Washington; Editorial lauds instances of British and American democracy despite war; Editorial on NY Herald reporting of war
lead_paragraph: It should be understood in England, as is always assumed here, that when our Press and people speak with bitterness of the English feeling and policy toward us in this struggle, they refer to but a portion of the British nation. Americans understand too well the position of the Liberal Party in Eng land, to include them in their reproaches. They have watched with admiration and deep sympathy, the persevering efforts of a few leaders during many years, struggling against every kind of obloquy and the prejudices of caste, to enlarge the domain of popular rights. They have felt for the silent multitudes behind them, who through their mouthpieces, were protesting against the pride and oppression of the aristocracy. They have beheld and applauded the victories of peace, gained by these noble men, more glorious than the most brilliant conquests won by the cannon and the bayonet. It is not too much to say that COBDEN and BRIGHT are names more familiar and more beloved, among the millions of America, than those of any European statesmen. Every intelligent American citizen sees that those men, and their great party of the middle and working classes in West Britain, are contending for precisely the same cause which this Nation has represented in the world -- the cause of the Many against the Few -- Democracy against Aristocracy. Not, of course, that the English Liberal Party ever calls for, or perhaps desires, a republican form of Government; but the principles of extended suffrage, of popular education, of opposition to an aristocracy and a State Church, and of peaceful relations among nations, belong to that policy which the people in all countries must inevitably support. We have accordingly all appreciated the difficulty in which a superficial view of our struggle, and ad captandum arguments drawn from our civil war, would place the English Liberals. While we knew that so far from Democracy being the cause of our troubles, it was precisely because we had admitted a false aristocratic principle into our policy -- the power of a slaveholding class -- that we were now in danger; yet we could understand with what force the aristocratic organs would employ the American troubles against English Reform.

abstract: A fog of unusual density set in about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, with wind very light from E.N. E., rendering navigation to and from sea very dangerous, and almost an impossibility.
lead_paragraph: A fog of unusual density set in about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, with wind very light from E.N. E., rendering navigation to and from sea very dangerous, and almost an impossibility. Those most prudent remained inactive, in consequence of which a large number of inward-bound vessels are detained below awaiting the clearing away of the fog. The Eastern boats arrived at an early hour. The ferryboats were all more or less retarded in their trips. The Union Ferry Company ran only one boat on each ferry. The Staten Island Ferry ceased running after 10 A.M., making only two trips the entire day. We have heard of no accident up to 9 P.M.

abstract: The Herald has no sooner lost one opportunity to make mischief, and precipitate the entire country into ruin, than it devotes itself to the creation of others.
lead_paragraph: The Herald has no sooner lost one opportunity to make mischief, and precipitate the entire country into ruin, than it devotes itself to the creation of others. Its misrepresentations of Northern sentiment, and falsehoods as to the purposes of Mr. LINCOLN in assuming the Presidential office, did more than anything else to render possible the plans of the Southern conspirators last Winter; and had it not been checked by a popular demonstration, it would have urged the surrender of the entire Union to its confederates in treason. Its efforts in this direction having failed, it turned them elsewhere. A war with England would bring that country into our domestic quarrels, as an ally with the Herald's Southern friends, and accordingly through the Summer and Fall the Herald devoted itself to inflaming the resentment of our transatlantic brethren, as it before inflamed the resentment of the South. Now there is this peculiarity about the status of the Herald. Where it is understood, it is utterly destitute of influence, insomuch that the men it assails are at once assured of popular confidence, and the measures it advocates are instantly killed. But at the South, distant and unenlightened, its lies pass for probabilities, and in England, yet more distant, for absolute truths. So that, misled by its recklessness, the British public had come to believe the American people to be actuated by the bitterest impulses of hostility, only to be quieted by a war which the act of Commodore WILKES was designed to inaugurate. This result of the Herald's diabolical spirit of mischief-making and covert zeal in behalf of the rebel enterprise, was only balked by the wise and salutary readiness of our Government to make that concession to justice and English resentment, which must satisfy the British public how false were the representations of the Herald, and how really solicitous for peace is the great body of our people. The war-cloud which the Herald attempted to create having been dissipated, it is again compelled to find a new field for the exercise of its mischievous faculties.

abstract: Some time ago, a private in the Nineteenth Indiana Regiment was tried by a Court-martial for deserting his post, and found guilty, the punishment for which is death. His execution was deferred for some time, and he was kept in a painful state of suspense. At last the time was fixed for his execution, and five regiments were drawn up in line to witness it, while a file of twelve men were in advance to execute the sentence of death by shooting him.

lead_paragraph: About 11 o'clock last evening a fire broke out at Nos. 22 and 24 Frankfort-street, owned and occupied in part by JENEINS BROTHER, printers and bookbinders. The fire was first discovered on the fourth floor. It was a seven-story brick building, and was tenanted by quite a number of different parties, who conducted therein all the various branches of bookmaking. The building was totally destroyed.

abstract: MENT. -- The heads of the Western District Fire department have recently obtained badges so that they can be easily distinguished from other members of the Department. The badge is about three inches in diameter, and made of silver. The outside edge is neatly worked to represent a wreath, in the centre is a group of Firemen's utensils in relief, including hats, axes, torches, hose, ladder, hooks and trumpet. Above the centre is the office of the wearer in a scroll, and underneath, on an ornamental scroll, is "Brooklyn Fire Department." The whole face of the Chief Engineer's badge is plated with gold; those worn by the Assistant Engineers are all silver; those for the Fire Commissioners have the raised work gold plated, and the ground work silver plated.

abstract: President LINCOLN has appointed Hon. JOSEPH POLAND, J.B. PAGE, State Treasurer, and JOHN HOWE Jr., of Vermont, as Commissioners under the new law to visit the Vermont troops in camp and obtain their signatures to the allotment rolls. These gentlemen have been for a week past visiting the camps with, gratifying success, -- very few refusing to assign anything, and nearly all assigning at least half of their pay for the benefit of their families.

abstract: In war we may inflict death, but have no right to indulge in cruelty. Cruelty consists in inflicting pain for the sake of the pain, to satisfy the last of revenge, or a fiendish hatred. No doubt the whole world would consider it cruel if pain were inflicted upon an enemy to extract an important secret.
lead_paragraph: In war we may inflict death, but have no right to indulge in cruelty. Cruelty consists in inflicting pain for the sake of the pain, to satisfy the last of revenge, or a fiendish hatred. No doubt the whole world would consider it cruel if pain were inflicted upon an enemy to extract an important secret. The fear of retaliation is one of the most efficient regulators, and curbs in our modern law of war, yet we would not approve of cruelty by way of retaliation against savages, or those who have fallen back into that state. The late proclamation of Gen. HALLECK illustrates this well -- allowing retaliation in case of property, when necessary, yet not in the case of life. Simply inflicting death is not considered cruelty.

abstract: The losses by the fire in Frankfort-street on Sunday night were more extensive than was at first reported. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning nothing remained of the two buildings Nos. 22 and 24, except a small portion of the walls and the smouldering ruins.
lead_paragraph: The losses by the fire in Frankfort-street on Sunday night were more extensive than was at first reported. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning nothing remained of the two buildings Nos. 22 and 24, except a small portion of the walls and the smouldering ruins. The Globe Hotel was considerably damaged. It took fire in several places, but owing to the active exertions of the firemen, and the efficient action of the steam fire engines, the flames were very soon extinguished. The buildings destroyed were owned by MARSHALL LEFFERTS, Colonel of the Seventh Regiment, and not by JENKINS & BROTHER, as was stated in the papers of yesterday. Several of the adjoining buildings on William and Frankfort streets were damaged to a considerable amount.
headline: {'main': 'The Fire in Frankfort-street.; FULL PARTICULARS OF THE LOSSES AND INSURANCES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fire in Frankfort-street.; FULL PARTICULARS OF THE LOSSES AND INSURANCES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on Blair bill for confiscation of slaves
snippet: Editorial on Blair bill for confiscation of slaves
lead_paragraph: With the suppression of the rebellion, its legitimate fruits or consequences must be taken immediately in hand. One of the most important of these is the care of the slaves who will be set free, for they are free the moment the tie by which they are held -- force -- is broken. In cases where their owners have been seeking the destruction of the nation, it is clear that we are not going to return the escaped slaves to their former condition, Other questions of hardly less importance will come up, such as the disposition that is to be made of the property of rebels. All these questions cannot be too speedily ventilated, for great reflection and care must be had in dealing with subjects so novel and intricate as the management and disposition that is to be made of the enfranchised blacks, and the subversion of the social status at the South, so far as the conduct of the rebels has made such change inevitable. We are much gratified, consequently, with the commencement, made by Mr. BLAIR in his report to the House, as Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs. Mr. BLAIR in proposes a very simple method, whereby to vest in the United Slates the estates of the rebels, by enacting that the tax assessed by Congress at its extraordinary session, upon the several States, shall be deemed, in law, to be assessed on the several parcels of real estates in the States or Districts in rebellion; and where the same cannot be collected by the civil process, that the neglect or failure for sixty days to pay such tax shall vest the lands upon which it is assessed in the United Stales, it is provided, however, that any loyal citizen, may, within two years, upon proofs of his loyalty, become reinvested in his estate.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Blair's Confisoation Bill.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Blair's Confisoation Bill.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sheehan vs. Clark. This action was brought to recover compensation for the services of the plaintiff. It appeared on the trial that both parties were in the battle of Bull Run the plaintiff as a private, and the defendant as a captain.
lead_paragraph: Sheehan vs. Clark. -- This action was brought to recover compensation for the services of the plaintiff. It appeared on the trial that both parties were in the battle of Bull Run -- the plaintiff as a private, and the defendant as a captain. Shortly before the battle the captain ordered the private to put aside his musket and act as his servant, and in accordance with this direction the plaintiff attended the defendant with rations and other creature comforts, and shared with him in the incidents and fatigues of the day. Shortly after this the parties returned to New-York, where the defendant employed the plaintiff as bar-tender in one of his establishments. The plaintiff claimed compensation for his service as servant to the defendant while at the seat of war, and salary at the rate of $10 a week as bar-tender, alleging that the defendant had agreed to pay this sum. The Captain, on his part, testified that there was an agreement to pay $4 a week as bar-tender, for which sum he did not dispute ids liability, but he claimed that for the employment of the plaintiff during his military career, the service being in accordance with military usage, and rendered in lieu of service in the field, the private's pay from the United States was in judgment of law a compensation for the labor of brushing clothes, blacking boots and carrying brandy and provisions.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. Whatever may be the merits of Mr. WHITE'S play, called the "King of the Commons," liveliness is certainly not one of them; nor, if we acknowledge the absence of this acceptable element, do we find anything to compensate for it.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- Whatever may be the merits of Mr. WHITE'S play, called the "King of the Commons," liveliness is certainly not one of them; nor, if we acknowledge the absence of this acceptable element, do we find anything to compensate for it. There is not an emotion, an incident, a catastrophe, an accident, that raises it to the level of a tragedy, and most assuredly there is not the plot to entitle it to be called a drama. The author is, we presume, a Scotchman, and he has written a piece with the virtuons intention of rescuing the memory of the fifth JAMES from oblivion. That he has done so with a too kindly eye to the faults and deficiencies of his hero would not detract from the merit of the production if he had succeeded in creating a fictitious interest in the fortunes of be King. But it is here that Mr. WHITE utterly fails. James is as wearisome in the play as he is in history.

abstract: The Twenty-eighth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. WILLIAM MONTIETH, arrived here yesterday in the steamer Connecticut, and were transferred to Castle William, Governor's Island. There was some trouble on the Island with the last volunteer regiment ...
lead_paragraph: The Twenty-eighth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. WILLIAM MONTIETH, arrived here yesterday in the steamer Connecticut, and were transferred to Castle William, Governor's Island. There was some trouble on the Island with the last volunteer regiment quartered there -- caused, it is said, by a suspicion on the part of Col. LOOMIS that the men were supplied with liquor at the quarters of the married soldiers. Stringent orders have been given that the volunteers shall be excluded from the quarters of the regulars, and to prevent liquor being smuggled over, all the women belonging to the Island are now required to get passes signed by the Colonel before they can come to the City. Strangers are not allowed to land on the Island unless they are on official business.

abstract: The country was taken by surprise yesterday on the announcement of the resignation of Hon. SIMON CAMERON as Secretary of War, and the appointment of Mr. EDWIN P. STANTON, of Pennsylvania, as his successor. Mr. CAMERON, it appears, is to take the place of Hon. CASSIUS M. CLAY, as Minister to Russia -- Mr. CLAY coming home to assume an active part in the efforts to put down the rebellion. The nominations were sent to the Senate yesterday by the President, and will be acted upon, in Executive session to-day.

abstract: -- eminent surgeon and philanthropist, to whose discoveries and unwearied labors during the past eight years in this City, the New-York State Woman's hospital owes its origin, returned last week on the steamer Kangaroo from a six months our among the hospitals and surgeons of Great Britain, France and Belgium. This tour, which bas been in contemplation for more than three years, was undertaken at the urgent request of the Board of Managers of the Woman's Hospital who granted him a vacation for this purpose, in order that he might become familiar with the arrangements management and hygiene of the celebrated European hospitals, preparatory to deciding upon the plans to be adopted in the erection of the Woman's Hospital edifice on the magnificent site donated by the Common Council for this object, and also to give him an opportunity to prepare for the publication of his forth coming works on subjects connected with his special department in surgery, embodying the results of his investigation and practice. His observations have shown that the plans which had been proposed, had they been carried out, would have proved totally inadequate to the successful development and working of the institution. Dr. SIMS has been received with the most gratifying marks of consideration, by the renowned practitioners with whom he has come in contact, and has established a reputation for skill and scientific investigation of which Americans may be [???] proud. He has resumed his labors in the hospital on Madison-avenue, and will press forward the erection of the new hospital building with the atmost dispatch.

abstract: THE POLICE AND THE DESERTERS. The Colonels of a number of regiments now among the Army of the Potomac, are continually sending dispatches to Superintendent KENNEDY, urging him to arrest and ...
lead_paragraph: THE POLICE AND THE DESERTERS. -- The Colonels of a number of regiments now among the Army of the Potomac, are continually sending dispatches to Superintendent KENNEDY, urging him to arrest and return to the seat of war, all the deserters to be found in the City. The army officers state that there are many of them here and the number is rapidly increasing. The Superintendent is obliged to decline complying with these requests, for the reasons that he has no place in which to temporarily detain them, and no means for their subsistence. The Commandant on Governor's Island refuses to receive them, unless the military authorities have adjudged them to be deserters. Mr. KENNEDY states that whenever the Government provides a place for their detention, and means of subsistence, he will act in the matter.

lead_paragraph: A Cairo letter dated on Thursday, the 9th, says ; "Yesterday afternoon a portion of the troops sta tioned at Smithland, who were guarding some laborers who were quarrying stone at a place in Kentucky called Carville, to be used in the construction of fortifications at this point, were attacked and driven off by the rebels -- so it is rumored. The gunboats Essex and Lexington went off in that way this afternoon, and, It is conjectured, on account of such assault.

abstract: editorials on Cabinet changes; Editorial on female traitors in war
snippet: editorials on Cabinet changes; Editorial on female traitors in war
lead_paragraph: To those who have followed closely the course of events at Washington, the resignation of Secretary CAMERON will occasion no surprise. It has been evident that the general policy of the Administration, and the opinions of the secretary of War, were irreconcilable. Mr. CAMERON, representing in the Cabinet the least radical of all the loyal States, has from the first been satisfied of the identity of the rebellion with Slavery, and has been persuaded that the suppression of both is essential to the restoration of the Union and the future peace of the Republic. These views he has lost no occasion of advocating. He has embodied them in his instructions to commanding officers, and it is well known that a clause in which they found practical application was, by the immediate influence of the President, expunged from the Annual Report submitted in December. That he should sacrifice his views, or that a Cabinet could cohere with such radical differences of opinion, was not to be expected. Mr. LINCOLN, born in a slaveholding community, and familiar with the institution, believes that if may be perpetuated without hazard to the Union. He considers the Border States entitled to every possible guarantee for the industrial system they have inherited, and is willing to test the possibility of restoring the status in quo with the least possible disturbance to the interests of those States. But Mr. CAMERON saw in Slavery the root of all difficulty. He regarded National restoration as impossible, until the slaveholders had been compelled to retire to that subordinate place to which alone their inadequate scheme of labor entitled them; and he doubted the propriety of prosecuting the war without striking some effective blow at its well-known source. Such contrarieties of opinion could not conveniently exist in the same counsels, and hence the necessity of separation.

abstract: The United States steam transport Patapaco, Capt. BEARSE, from Locust Point, in ballast, arrived at this port yesterday. On the 11th inst., when off Cove Point, she passed a portion of Gen. BURNSIDE's condition, consisting of three steamers, each having in tow three schooners; also several other schooners, under canvas, with horses on board. On the same day, when off Cape Henry, passed two steamers, having each two schooners in tow, coming out of the Capes -- all bound South.

abstract: Editorial compares British means of settling past war debts with US means of financing current war; editorial compares British means of settling war debts with US means of financing war
snippet: Editorial compares British means of settling past war debts with US means of financing current war; editorial compares British means of settling war debts with US means of financing war
lead_paragraph: It is no small compliment to the financial ability for Mr. CHASE that the opposition his plans have evoked from certain theorists in this country, is echoed by the London Times. In a recent article, intended evidently to prejudice the minds of British capitalists, our cotemporary affects to speak well of the fundamental maxim we have always held, that it perpetual debt is alien from the genius of our free institutions, and must not be naturalized in this country. After stating that this is "sound doctrine," he tries adroitly to destroy its force and to misrepresent its meaning. Thus he argues that our Secretary of the Treasury ought to "go to work like Mr. GLADSTONE" lay taxes to the full amount of the National expenditure and refuse altogether "the supplement of a loan."
