abstract: The dis COTTON SEED FOR THE NORTHWEST. The dis cussion of the question of the introduction of cotton culture into the southern part of this State, or rather the revival of its culture there, has awakened wide attention among all interested, and there is an eager inquiry for seed. One thing, however, seems well...
lead_paragraph: -- The discussion of the question of the introduction of cotton culture into the southern part of this State, or rather the revival of its culture there, has awakened wide attention among all interested, and there is an eager inquiry for seed. One thing, however, seems well established by concurrent testimony of those who are excellent authority in the matter. The scheme of looking to the island of Beaufort will fail and give no good result. What is wanted is the green seed known as the Tennessse Upland cotton. The Sea Island cotton has a black seed, and nothing can be expected from its introduction here but disappointment. As to the green seed, we learn that nearly half enough seed will be furnished in Southern Illinois from last season's crop, and the remainder can be procured from the Southwestern States.

abstract: The receipts for duty at the Custom-house during, the past few weeks have been rather larger, and business a little mom brisk, than heretofore. The work continues to be heavy in the Warehouse Department, and the stock of goods in store is continually diminishing, which shows conclusively that the importation of foreign goods is not commensurate with the public demand therefor. The stock of goods still remaining in bond, however, is much larger than it often is at this season of the year, notwithstanding the gradual withdrawal of the oil entries. Many of the goods imported toward the close of last year, when the importation of articles of foreign manufacture was heavy, have not been withdrawn as yet. At that time large quantities of dry goods were purchased from abroad or consigned by foreign manufacturers to their agent here, hot the threatening aspeal of our national affairs made their sale at that time doubtful, and as the three years' warehousing law was then in force, the importers and consignees preferred to leave them in bond, and withdraw from time to time what they needed. This will account for the receipts from this department, which are very large considering the state of trade and the small amount received for goods on which the duty is paid on arrival. In September, 1861, the amount paid for duty on goods, immediately on arrival, amounted to $1,642,382; from goods withdrawn from warehouse. $736,500; In September, 1860, the duty paid on goods, immediately on arrival, was;$3,039,000; that paid on goods withdrawn from warehouse was $909,000. From these figures, it will be seen that the proportion of duty received from bonded goods in September, 1861, was considerably greater than that in 1800. In October, the proportion was still greater. The change in the class of goods imported is noticeable. Last year, at this time, the importation was chiefly of dry goods and sugar. This year, the Importation of the former is insignificant compared with that of the same time last year. The war has changed the character of the goods brought here amazingly. Dining the month of November the following goods were brought here, namely: About 10,000 tons of salt, in sacks or in bulk, comprised in between thirty and forty different invoices; about 2,200,000 pounds of rice, coming from the East by way of Liverpool, and a considerable quantity of opium, say 14,000 pounds. The above articles have been very good ones for speculators to operate in since the war broke out; more especially is this true of rice, for which there has been an active demand, and from the usual supply of which we have been cut off by the blockade of the Southern ports and the non-intercourse between the Northern and Southern States. It will be seen that the quantity of salt imported from Liverpool has been large, notwithstanding the levy of a duty of over 100 per cent, on the invoice value. The duty on opium is quite low compared with that imposed on most other articles. $1 per pound being only about 30 per cent, on the value. Large quantities of all the articles mentioned above have been placed in the bonded warehouses.

abstract: In Danbury, Conn., last September, a man named DORAN was murdered mysteriously, and the offer of a liberal reward failed to detect the murderers. Lately the reward was increased to $200, and PATRICK RYAN (one of the suspected parties) writes a letter to one of the surviving brothers of the murdered man, saying, "If you don't want to lose your money, you draw it back," and offering to give himself up and stand trial. On the day named, the 6th inst., he surrendered himself to the officers.

On the day named, the 6th inst., he surrendered himself to the officers.

abstract: some weeks since that this gentleman would remain in Europe permanently, abandoning his American citizenship on account of our political troubles. Nothing could be more unjust to this prominent and public-spirited merchant, thoroughly identified as he has made himself to the loyal cause of the Constitution. The rumor is believed to have grown out of certain offers to purchase his Fifth-avenue and Newport property, which though liberal in terms, were promptly declined. We have reason to know that as soon as the health of Mrs. BELMONT, on whose account his trip to Europe was made, will authorize his reborn, he will be at his home in this City.

abstract: In the Senate, as usual, several petitions for the emancipation of slaves were presented; also a memorial from citizens of New-York protesting against the appointment of a solicitor of Customs. A bill reported from the Military Committee, ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, as usual, several petitions for the emancipation of slaves were presented; also a memorial from citizens of New-York protesting against the appointment of a solicitor of Customs. A bill reported from the Military Committee, apropriating $150,000 for completing the defences of Washington occasioned considerable debate, the general feeling appearing to be against appropriating any more money for this purpose. It was explained, however, that the money was principally wanted to pay for work already done. A report was made from the Judiciary Committee in the case of Senator BRIGHT, of Indiana. The Committee are of the opinion that the charges against him are not sustained. Their report was made the special order for Thursday. Mr. CARLILE, of Virginia, offered a resolution, which was laid over, instructing the Committee on Finance to consider the expediency of providing a revenue of two hundred million dollars by taxation, and issuing bonds to that amount. Mr. KING, of New-York, also introduced a bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue Treasury Notes to the amount of one hundred millions, at 7 per cent, interest, and providing for a direct tax of ten million a for the payment of the interest. It was referred. A motion was made to take up the House bill for the relief of the owners of the British ship Perthshire, but it was disagreed to. The resolution to after the rules of the Senate so as to prevent the making of special orders was passed. Mr. WILSON's Sutler bill was taken up, but was postponed at his suggestion, to afford him an opportunity to report another, which would meet all objections. The Kansas contested seat case was then considered, and Mr. STANTON, after some debate, was allowed to take the floor and argue his own case. The matter was not disposed of.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, the trial of Peter Folck, for grand larceny, was continued from Saturday, and occupied the entire session. The jury could not agree upon a verdict and the prisoner was remanded for a second trial.

abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped at Camp Cameron, West-Cambridge, Mass., since the beginning of inst. October, arrived in this City yesterday. Col. WILLIAM MONTEITH is the Commandant. Previous to leaving camp, the regiment was presented with a handsome stand of colors by Governor ANDREW. Mayor WIGHTMAN of Boston, also presented the corps with a beautiful regimental color. Upon it is inscribed the following words "Fostered under the care, we will die in thy defence." The Twenty-eighth numbers nine hundred and fifty men, all of whom are fully uniformed and equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. It is expected that before the regiment leaves Governor's Island, where it is at present quartered, it will have reached the maximum number, as men are still being recruited in Boston. Every man in this regiment, from the Colonel downward, is Irish, and it is imagined that the regiment will be attached to one of the Irish brigades. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: Last evening a meeting was held in Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, to listen to WILLIAM DAVIS, a slave, who has been brought to this City by Rev. Mr. L.S. LOCKWOOD, agent of the American Missionary Society at Fortress Monroe. Mr. WM. GOODELL ...
lead_paragraph: Last evening a meeting was held in Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, to listen to WILLIAM DAVIS, a slave, who has been brought to this City by Rev. Mr. L.S. LOCKWOOD, agent of the American Missionary Society at Fortress Monroe. Mr. WM. GOODELL presided, and the meeting was opened by prayer. After some patriotic songs had been sung, Mr. LOCKWOOD introduced WILLIAM DAVIS to the audience. In doing so, he said that he hardly knew what to call DAVIS, but he thought no better name could be found than that he was one of Uncle Sam's slaves, for indeed he was virtually that. WILLIAM DAVIS, a fine, intelligent looking mulatto, then came forward, and spoke as follows:

abstract: The Senate convened at half-past seven o'clock last night. Bills were introduced relating to places of amusement in this City; to the Chenango Canal extension; to the duties of bank officers; to property exempt from taxation; to the idiot asylum, and to the discretionary power of courts in certain cases. Resolutions were introduced fixing the 23d of January as the day for the election of certain officers, and instructing our Congressmen to vote for the abolition of franking. The report of the State Prison Inspector was transmitted. And the Senate adjourned.

abstract: It has sometimes been said that our officers ought to prevent the sending of information from our army to the rebel States. But those who are remote from the field of action can have little idea of the sagacity of the rebels and the endlessness of their resources. The devil can put on the garb of an angel of light, or can come in his own form, as may seem best to suit his purpose. But as our officers become better acquainted with the country and the ways of the people, this nice work is becoming less and less easy of accomplishment.

abstract: On another page of this morning's issue will be found a report in full of the speech made last evening at the Cooper Institute by Mr. WILLIAM LLOYD GARRISON on "The Abolitionist and their Relations to the War."
lead_paragraph: On another page of this morning's issue will be found a report in full of the speech made last evening at the Cooper Institute by Mr. WILLIAM LLOYD GARRISON on "The Abolitionist and their Relations to the War." The subject is an interesting one, and certainly could not have had a more authoritative expounder than the Boston Nestor of Abolitionism. The magnificent uprising of the North in defence of the Constitution and the Union against the Slaveholders' rebellion had the effect to swallow up this like all other secondary issues, and for the time being Mr. GARRISON and his co-workers have carefully refrained from any movement tending to mar the unity of sentiment and action in the great cause. Many of his friends, and followers, it is known, have, under the eaching of the times, greatly changed their ultra views -- the touch of a terrible reality dissipating their theoretic abstractions. Even the organ of Mr. ARRISON himself, the Liberator, has lately struck its ancient motto of the Constitution as "A covenant with death arid an agreement with hell." Mr. GARRISON explains the position of his party, however, by saying that "Death and hell have now seceded" from the Constitution ! and this characteristically bizarre vindication, he thinks, leaves their position perfectly logical. In declaring the Government to be wholly in the right, and the Secessionists wholly in the wrong, as relates to the precise, issue between the parties, the Abolitionists abate no jot nor tittle of their testimony against a Constitution and Union with Slavery. "That Constitution," he says, "could it be enforced, as hitherto, would still be a 'covenant with death,' and that Union, could it be maintained, would still be 'an agreement with hell.'" And hence, argues Mr. GARRISON, the need for immediate and universal emancipation. This is the key-note of his discourse.

abstract: We publish this morning important news from Havana and Mexico. Our advices from Havana are to the 7th inst. On the 28th ult. Gen. PRIM'...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning important news from Havana and Mexico. Our advices from Havana are to the 7th inst. On the 28th ult. Gen. PRIM'after a most enthusiastic reception by the Havanese, left for Vera Cruz to take command of the expedition there. He was accompanied by a portion of the French contingent. Several of the English vessels had also been at Havana, but had not yet gone to Mexico. The first news from Vera Cruz had been received by a steamer which left thereon the 25th. According to accounts brought down from the interior by Sir CHARLES WYKE, the English Minister, who arrived at Vera Cruz on the 24th, the Mexicans are making immense preparations to oppose the progress of the allies into the interior. JUAEEZ had issued a temperate proclamation, calling on all parties to unite to repel the invasion, and his call had been almost universally responded to. It was believed that over a hundred thousand men would soon he in the field, with a hundred pieces of artillery. URAGA was preparing to dispute the passes above Vera Cruz, with about twenty thousand men. Tampice, it is understood, will not be surrendered without a struggle, for which the place is well prepared. It is announced by our Havana correspondent that on the 28th ult. an English steamer sailed from that port for Matamoros, under very suspicious circumstances.
headline: {'main': 'FROM HAVANA AND MEXICO.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FROM HAVANA AND MEXICO.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The annual meeting of the above Society was held at the United States Hotel on Monday evening. It was presided over by Capt. CHARIES H. MARSHALL. A report was read by the Secretary, Capt. JOSEPH TINKHAM, by which it appears that seven new members have been admitted during the past year, and six have died. The pension list contains the names of fifty-six widows. The Society has a fund of $60,200 invested in bonds and mortgages, bearing interest payable semi-annually. The receipts for the past year amounted to $5,811 01. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President, CHAS. H. MARSHALL; First Vice-President, JOHN M. FERRIER; Second Vice-President, THOMAS DUNHAM; Treasurer, JAMES COPLAND; Secretary, JOSEPH TINKHAM; Attorney, DANIEL LORD.

abstract: In the Senate, notice was given of a bill to amend the Harbormaster's act. Bills were introduced to regulate the dividends of Life and Fire Insurance Companies; to amend the Insurance laws: to incorporate the Metropolitan Cab Company, and concerning the public health in New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties -- the latter being the Health bill of last session, which Alderman BRADY says he paid eight thousand dollars to kill. The Standing Committees for the session were then announced.

abstract: Observations of nation-wide press
snippet: Observations of nation-wide press
lead_paragraph: In the year 1835 this JACKSON was one of the Freshman Class, entering Vale College -- then a youth about sixteen or seventeen years of age. This class was a large one, numbering 135 -- larger, in fact, than any which at that time had entered the college. It continued a due proportion of Southern students. At that day all the classes contained more students from the South than in these later years. One-fourth, perhaps, of the whole number were from the Slave States. I think it would have been generally conceded that this JACKSON was the ablest Southern student in the class, and indeed in the college. The writer above quoted has described him correctly -- "a fiery Georgian of great ability." He could not have been characterized, while in college, by any words more fitting. High-spirited, a little haughty and overbearing, but on the whole not uncompanionable -- a vigorous thinker -- an accomplished scholar -- a ready writer and debater, he was regarded as one of the lights of, the class of 139. The reference to his literary abilities, in the passage which we have quoted, does not overstate the matter. Some pieces of his poetry have from time to time strayed through our Northern papers, and have been much admired. He figured with considerable notoriety in the Mexican war. He was for a time United States Minister to Austria. He has held for some years the office of Judge in the Courts of Georgia, and has been generally a very prominent man in that part of the country ever since his studies were closed.

abstract: The United States vs. The schooner Aigburth and her cargo. -- This was a motion on behalf of the United States for an appraisement and sale of the vessel and cargo. Mr. Edwards appeared for the claimants, and objected to the order, urging that a decision in the case, with others, was announced on Dec. 31 by the Court; that the decrees in other cases had been served for settlement, but no decree had been served in this case. He announced that the claimants proposed to appeal in the case, and that an appeal would take the case and the property out of this Court, and thus the heavy expenses of a sale now would be saved.

abstract: By the fearful accident that occurred at the Jackson Ferry, on the Brooklyn side of the river, at 5 o'clock on Monday evening last, four men have met their death. It appears that the accident happened in this wise: The men employed at the Navy-...
lead_paragraph: By the fearful accident that occurred at the Jackson Ferry, on the Brooklyn side of the river, at 5 o'clock on Monday evening last, four men have met their death. It appears that the accident happened in this wise: The men employed at the Navy-yard had just left work, and those who lived in New-York were crowding on the ferry-bridge waiting for the boat. The throng of people was immense, and proved too heavy for the strength of the bridge, for one of the chains that supported it broke, and one of the balance-boxes was drawn go violently up, that it caused the contents, large stones, to be thrown with great force among the crowd. Two men were hurled into the water, but they fortunately escaped with only a severe ducking. Many were bruised, some so severely that they had to be conveyed to their homes. One man, name unknown, had his leg broken, and another, named SIMKINS, living in Jackson-street, was struck so severely in the back that it will be some time before he will be enabled to pursue his usual avocations. The following are the names of those who were fatally injured:

abstract: BAPTIST SUNDAY SCHOOT. TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION. -- A very interesting and numerously attended meeting of this body was held on Monday evening, in the meeting -house of the Pilgrim Baptist Church, in Thirty-third-street, (Rev. G. ALEXANDER PELTZ'.) Some 100 persons were present to listen to the discussion of the question, -- "What is the best mode of Sunday-School teaching?" Mr. FRISNIE opened the question. and was followed by H.C.WARD, and J. C. BAXTER, Esqs. The exercises were enlivened by the sinking of the children of the Sunday-School, led by Capt. J.B. PECK.

abstract: The firing of the British corvette Cadmus at the American bark Gazelle, when the latter vessel was going into Barbados, is explained by Capt. RHODES, who says that he was entering the port with only a private signal flying. The corvette fired a blank shot, which warning being unheeded by the bark, a round shot was fired, striking the water about half a mile in advance of her bows. This shot also was unnoticed, when a third shot was fired, at which the bark ran up the American ensign, and proceeded into port without further molestation.

abstract: A STATEMENT OF THEIR COMPARATIVE VALUE. Ex-Gov. POLLOCK, Director of the Mint in Phila  delphia, has published a circular giving the regulations of the Mint in relation to the purchase of silver bullion for coinage, the receipt of copper coins of the  United States (O.S.) in exchange for cents of the new issue, and the exchange of new cents for the gold and silver coins of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Mint price of silver, heretofore $1 21, is now raised to $1 22 3/2 per ounce of standard fineness. The silver offered for purchase will be weighed, melted and assayed as usual, and the standard weight determined therefrom in ounces troy to the one-hundredth part of an ounce. The receipt given at the first weighing must be presented by the seller or his order. This direction will apply to the Mint at Philadelphia and the Assay Office at New-York. The silver purchased for coinage will be paid for in the silver coins of the United States, of less denomination than the dollar.

abstract: The unequaled enterprise and self-abnegating patriotism of The World qualities in which it claims to surpass and (as all The World knows) does surpass all other newspapers have resulted in the appearance in its columns of some most extraordinary correspondence, correspondence which, it says, in an editorial paragraph, gives "an account of the naval and military forces" composing Gen. BURNSIDE'S expedition "complete in every particular."
lead_paragraph: The unequaled enterprise and self-abnegating patriotism of The World -- qualities in which it claims to surpass and (as all The World knows) does surpass all other newspapers -- have resulted in the appearance in its columns of some most extraordinary correspondence, -- correspondence which, it says, in an editorial paragraph, gives "an account of the naval and military forces" composing Gen. BURNSIDE'S expedition "complete in every particular." Most interesting correspondence this would seem to be, and likely to affect the stock-market, and elate or depress the public mind. This is enterprise. But the reader whose appetite is whetted by the announcement, peruses the next sentence in blank disappointment; for it informs him that all this particular information is "held in reserve" until Gen. BURNSIDE's "blow is fairly struck." This is patriotism. Turning to the correspondence itself, he finds it to be of this stimulating and soul-satisfying nature:

abstract: From our correspondent at Panama, we have news to the 4th inst. At Bogota, Gen. CANAL had agreed to recognize the Government of MOSQUERA and lay down his arms. There had been two fights between the troops of MOSQUERA and those of the old Government Party in one of which one side gained a success, and in the other...
lead_paragraph: From our correspondent at Panama, we have news to the 4th inst. At Bogota, Gen. CANAL had agreed to recognize the Government of MOSQUERA and lay down his arms. There had been two fights between the troops of MOSQUERA and those of the old Government Party -- in one of which one side gained a success, and in the other the other side was victor. Our correspondent thinks that the wretched revolution which has devastated New-Granada for over two years past, is nearly at its close. Our Consul at Colon, Aspin-wall, had written a letter to the Governor of the State of Panama, congratulating him on the fact that that State had become one of the United States of New-Granada, From other points there is nothing of special interest.

abstract: In the Senate, after the presentation of the usual petitions for the emancipation of the slaves, and some other business of minor importance, a communication was received from the President accompanying a copy of the instructions of the Austrian Government to the Austrian Minister, relating to the Trent affair. Mr. POWELL'S resolution, calling upon the Secretary of War for information in relation to Army contracts, was then taken up and debated at considerable length.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, after the presentation of the usual petitions for the emancipation of the slaves, and some other business of minor importance, a communication was received from the President accompanying a copy of the instructions of the Austrian Government to the Austrian Minister, relating to the Trent affair. Mr. POWELL'S resolution, calling upon the Secretary of War for information in relation to Army contracts, was then taken up and debated at considerable length. The objection urged against it was the time it would occupy to prepare a proper answer to the inquiries. The resolution was finally adopted, however, 34 to 3. Marshal LAMON gent in a communication ix answer to the inquiry addressed to him by the Senate, in regard to the exclusion of members of Congress from the precincts of the Washington prison. His answer was considered a highly insulting one, and during the excitement occasioned by it, the bill providing for a jail delivery, introduced several days ago, was taken up and passed. An effort was made to exclude fugitive slaves from its provisions, but it failed; but an amendment was made, that hereafter no person shall be confined in the jail without a warrant from a magistrate or court, or an order from one house of Congress. Only four members voted against its passage, -- Messrs. CARLILE of Virginia, KENNEDY of Maryland, POWELL of Kentucky, and SAULS, BURY of Delaware. The bill for the relief of the owners of the British ship Perthshire was then passed, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The House of Representatives has exceeded the expectations of the most sanguine by its action on the bill for the abolition of Franking.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives has exceeded the expectations of the most sanguine by its action on the bill for the abolition of Franking. It had been considered extremely doubtful whether the measure could succeed at all; but it was thought absolutely certain that the vote would be close, and that to secure a majority, some other bill providing for the payment of Congressional postage would have to be previously reported. The injustice of these suspicions is apparent. The measure adopted [???] for the unconditional abrogation of the privilege; and the vote is 107 to 42. Well done, gentlemen of the House! Now, let the Senate Imitate your capital example, and we shall clear from our system this most indefensible of abuses.

abstract: Hon. Lewis Condict, of Morristown, N.J., is is now lying seriously ill at his residence in that city, from the effects of a fall during last Autumn, in which he suffered a fracture of the thigh. He first entered on public life just before the beginning of the present century as Sheriff of Morris County, and has been more or less prominent in it to a very late date. His last public act was to attend the Baltimore Convention of the Constitutional Union Party, In 1866, as a delegate from New-Jersey. He served in the House of Representatives for the long and honorable term of twenty years, entering Congress with HENRY CLAY, between whom and himself there was an intimate friendship. Mr. Condict maintains his characteristic cheerfulness without abatement, and, although he will be 90 years old In March, his mental powers are unimpaired,
lead_paragraph: Hon. abstract: Editorial favors Newbern, NC, as important base of operations for Union to control
snippet: Editorial favors Newbern, NC, as important base of operations for Union to control
lead_paragraph: All eyes are turned southward, scanning the coast and exploring the interior, in the endeavor to conjecture upon what point the insurgents will next be made to feel the power which is now gradually and steadily brought to bear upon them. Many have been already designated, but so closely has the Government been able to keep its offensive plans and purposes, that we should not be surprised if it proved that all the guesses had been wide of the mark. Meantime, we direct attention to one point, the importance of which, as a basis of operations, seems to have been too lightly passed over. This is Newbern, in North Carolina. Newbern is situated at the confluence of the Neuse and the Trent, near the head of a sound or extended bay, which itself empties into Pamlico Sound, the command of both of the principal entrances to which -- Hatteras and Ocracoke Inlets -- has been secured by the National forces. From Newbern, the Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad stretches through about fifty-five or sixty miles of level country to Goldsborough, which is upon the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, -- the direct line of communication between Eastern Virginia and the Southern seaboard cities; and from Goldsborough it is but forty-eight miles by the. North Carolina Railroad to Raleigh, the Capital of that State, but which possesses at least equal importance as the point through which the secondary and indirect communication of the Southern seaboard States with Eastern Virginia is kept up. This is effected by the. connection by railroad of Charlotte, the western terminus of the North Carolina Road, with the Columbia branch of the South Carolina Railroad and the connection of Raleigh with Petersburgh, Va., by the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad.

abstract: Current scene
snippet: Current scene
lead_paragraph: The Emperor, on New-Year's Day, made an address to the Diplomatic Corps, and received, as usual, the various state bodies. In response to an address from the Senate, he said he counted on the Senate to assist him in perfecting the Constitution, and at the same time maintaining intact the fundamental basis on which it rests. To the Legislative body he merely expressed the hope that they would see in the recent modifications of the Constitution a new proof of his confidence in their intelligence and patriotism. To the clergy, he gave assurance that they might count on his protection and lively sympathy, telling them that they knew how to render to Caesar the things which are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's.

abstract: Gov. MORGAN and his Staff, though it has not been known by the public, have not lost sight of the necessity of strengthening our harbor defences. Last month -- on the 22d -- the State Engineer, Gen. ARTHUR, and a Board of Engineers, met in this City to take into consideration and adopt such plans as might be deemed best to insure the security and impregnability of the harbor. Of course, at present the plans cannot be made public, but to show with what earnestness the scheme has been prosecuted, it need only be stated that all the spare timber in the market has been purchased by, and is now held by the State of New-York.

abstract: A bill to create a hospital fund of $200,000 for the Texan troops in the field is now pending before the Legislature of that State. It authorizes the Governor to appoint agents to visit the different camps, and distribute the fund as necessity may require. By another bill the Governor is also authorized to send agents abroad to purchase arms and ammunition for the defence of the State, and to raise a regiment of mounted men for frontier operations. A resolution was also introduced, from the Military Committee, which provides that the Adjutant-General distribute one rifle, musket, or revolver to each member of the Legislature, at the cost of the same to the State, to be deducted from the per diem of the member drawing the arm.
lead_paragraph: A bill to create a hospital fund of $200,000 for the Texan troops in the field is now pending before the Legislature of that State. abstract: The public has a quiet confidence in the successful issue of the Burnside expedition. Whatever may be its work, and wherever it may be going, no one seems to doubt its safely reaching its destination, or that it will unfailingly achieve the purpose for which it has been sent.
lead_paragraph: The public has a quiet confidence in the successful issue of the Burnside expedition. Whatever may be its work, and wherever it may be going, no one seems to doubt its safely reaching its destination, or that it will unfailingly achieve the purpose for which it has been sent. This proceeds partly from confidence in the men who lead the expedition, partly from the fact that every one believes it will strike in an unanticipated and unguarded quarter, and partly from the success of each of the three coast wise expeditions that have preceded this one. Every one seems to believe, too, that more important results will follow this expedition than either of the others. Though the previous expeditions were successes so far as regards effecting a landing, they are generally regarded as failures in respect of real results. When the first expedition landed on Cape Hatteras, it was popularly believed that a heavy column of troops would be immediately thrown on the mainland of North Carolina, which would penetrate inland and relieve that State, and then attack the main body of the rebels in the rear. But half a year has elapsed without any such result. So with BUTLER's Ship Island expedition. It was only to rendezvous for the day on that island sand-hill, and very soon it was to push on to New-Orleans or Mobile -- which, up to this moment, there is no appearance of its doing. The Port Royal Expedition was to give us possession of Charleston and Savannah a week or a fortnight after it landed -- which it has not yet done. In all this, of course, the public was a little too sanguine in its anticipations, and is now much too depreciatory in its criticism. These expeditions have accomplished a great deal, which will appear clearly enough when the history of the rise and fall of this rebellion comes to be written. But we suspect that BURNSIDE's expedition has work to do whose importance will be more immediately apparent, and whose results will be speedier and more evidently visible than in the case of the other expeditions. The rebels at Manassas have only two direct and effective lines of railroad connecting with the States of the South. One of these lines, that through East Tennessee, is in imminent danger of capture by our victorious column in Eastern Kentucky, joined to our forces near the Cumberland River. It may be, if, as is generally understood, the Burnside column is to operate at some point between Hatteras and Cape Lookout, that the other of these railroad lines, which is within easy striking distance, is about to be seized, and thereby the rebels be compelled either to leave Manassas or to starve. If such be the design, it is to be hoped that our troops will not squat down for any length of time on the coast, and thereby give the rebels a chance to make Goldsboro', which is the point necessary for us to capture, another impregnable Manassas.

lead_paragraph: The King, in addressing the Ministry on New-Year's Day, said the year commenced with a serious aspect throughout the world, rendering it the duty of Prussia to be prepared for any eventualities, and he asserted this should be done. In reply to the congratulations of the army, he said Prussia could calmly behold what events may arise from the state of things in non-European countries, because his army stands ready formed and armed.

abstract: The inclemency of the weather prevented the attendance of a large audience at the Cooper Institute, last evening, on the occasion of the lecture of WILLIAM DAVIS, the contraband. Those who did, however, were amply repaid, as well by the matter of the address as by the attendant embellishments of vocal and instrumental music. Mrs. PARKHURST at the piano, the Waters vocalists in several patriotic songs, and Mr. RONDENOT in a solo, drew considerable applause.

abstract: A private letter to a gentleman of this City from one of the officers of the Lincoln Cavalry states that a few nights since a very serious, and it is feared fatal, accident befel First Major CHARLES OGLE, of that regiment. He was riding from Alexandria, where he had been on duty, on a very dark night, and his horse having stumbled threw him with great violence upon the frozen ground. He struck upon his head,producing such a severe concussion as to render him insensible, in which condition he remained for a long time, and at present he is entirely bereft of reason. He is at the hospital, under the care of Dr. ELLIOTT, of the Lincoln Cavalry, but his condition is very precarious. His death would prove a serious loss to the regiment, as he is one of the most accomplished cavalry officers in the army.
lead_paragraph: A private letter to a gentleman of this City from one of the officers of the Lincoln Cavalry states that a few nights since a very serious, and it is feared fatal, accident befel First Major CHARLES OGLE, of that regiment. abstract: It pains us much to have to record a sad event which occurred yesterday. Gen. PHILIP ST. GEORGE COCKE, of the army of the Potomac, committed suicide at his residence near Richmond, by shooting himself in the mouth with a pistol. The ball penetrated upward, and went through the top of his skull, producing instant death. Gen. COCKE's family were not in the house at the time, they having gone to a friend's in the neighborhood, to spend the day.

abstract: The mor tality of New-York City during the year just closed is quite up to the frightful radio of previous years. The total number of deaths was 22,117, being, says the City Inspector, as compared with the preceding year, a decrease of 593 deaths.
lead_paragraph: -- The mortality of New-York City during the year just closed is quite up to the frightful radio of previous years. The total number of deaths was 22,117, being, says the City Inspector, as compared with the preceding year, a decrease of 593 deaths. But this small apparent deficit is more than counterbalanced by the deaths (natural deaths) which took place among the troops from this City on the Potomac, and which should have been mentioned in a comparison of last year's with previous years' City mortality. This decrease of inhabitants was not made up from other sources; and the gross resident population of the City in 1861 was not otherwise certainly any greater than it was the previous year, so that the old ratio of deaths was probably raised higher even than ever.

abstract: -- In other years, the reports of the Adjutant-General of the State have been but dry and tabular documents. But this year, the report has a significance which makes even its tables and columns of figures fascinating. It is a record of the patriotism and military spirit of the Empire State. A hundred and twenty thousand men raised during the year! A hundred thousand soldiers now under arms! Truly, New-York maintains its old preeminence; and, where all the States have done well, still she leads the column. Adjutant-General HILLHOUSE furnishes the details of these imposing numbers; and gives some idea of the labor involved in putting such masses of citizens in the field. He gives many valuable suggestions in regard to the reorganization of the State Militia, so that we may be still better prepared for any emergencies that may arise in the future. Among other things, he suggests that military drills and the study of tactics should be introduced into our higher schools and academies. This is a good idea, though there is danger, in the present state of the nation, and in the present state of the public mind, that rather too much attention may be paid to military matters by youth. We are at war now only that we may the more surely and enduringly enjoy the greater glories of peace. But an hour's drill one or two days in the week, under proper precautions, would do much to produce a manly bearing in the boys, and would be an agreeable and healthful change from the severe and depressing studies of a modern school-room. There are many other valuable suggestions in the report, which will be found in the abstract we publish in another column.

He gives many valuable suggestions in regard to the reorganization of the State Militia, so that we may be still better prepared for any emergencies that may arise in the future. Among other things, he suggests that military drills and the study of tactics should be introduced into our higher schools and academies. This is a good idea, though there is danger, in the present state of the nation, and in the present state of the public mind, that rather too much attention may be paid to military matters by youth. We are at war now only that we may the more surely and enduringly enjoy the greater glories of peace. But an hour's drill one or two days in the week, under proper precautions, would do much to produce a manly bearing in the boys, and would be an agreeable and healthful change from the severe and depressing studies of a modern school-room. There are many other valuable suggestions in the report, which will be found in the abstract we publish in another column.

abstract: The Florida Legislature has passed an Act forbidding the exportation from that State of any beef cattle, dried or pickled beef, hogs, pork or bacon, corn or corn meal, or salt, or provisions of any kind, whether salt or fresh. The Act also forbids any person or corporation from buying these articles for purposes of speculation, and provides that all provisions of life shall be sold at a price not to exceed over 33 per cent. over cost and charges.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Legislature has passed an Act forbidding the exportation from that State of any beef cattle, dried or pickled beef, hogs, pork or bacon, corn or corn meal, or salt, or provisions of any kind, whether salt or fresh. abstract: Proceedings; Editorial on Eastern bankers Washington meeting with Sec. Chase on financing war
snippet: Proceedings; Editorial on Eastern bankers Washington meeting with Sec. Chase on financing war
lead_paragraph: The telegraph brings us what are called the results of the various conferences among themselves, and with the Secretary of the Treasury, of certain representatives of the Boston and Philadelphia Banks and three or four Bank gentlemen from this City. These results differ from the original programme urged by the same parties upon the Secretary and the Committee of Ways and Means, in recognizing the $50,000,000 of United States Notes already in circulation as worthy of the support and countenance of the Banks, which they promise shall be given, by their free receipt and payment at Bank. They also differ from the earlier conferences on Saturday and Monday last, in leaving out of view the opinions, consent or purposes of the Committee of Ways and Means, which we take to be significant of the present unwillingness of the Committee to forego their own bills on the subject. Nor do we find, from the wording of the dispatch, that the results now arrived at have the concurrence of the Secretary of the Treasury. The whole matter, we presume, amounts to nothing more than the financial conclusions which should be arrived at by the Government, in the opinion of a party of gentlemen presumed to be conversant with the subject, and by no means indifferent to their own interests as money-lenders, any more than to the policy of the Government as the great borrower.

abstract: -- Rebel testimony to the rigorous efficiency of the blockade of the Southern coast accumulates constantly. The latest is from the Memphis Appeal, of the 3d inst., which declares that "the risk of running the blockade at present is too great, and comparatively but few are willing to encounter the losses that are so apt to follow the experiment. It is understood that the rebel authorities have gone to the trouble to prepare a formidable schedule of skiffs, shallops and scows claimed to have evaded the vigilance of our cruisers, which they intend laying on the tables of the members of the French and English Parliaments against their approaching session, in the hope of persuading those Governments to raise the blockade. If evidence is to be offered on this score, it will not be very hard to offset the fraudulent list by an accumulated series of testimonials as to its efficiency from the Southern journals themselves -- testimonials reluctantly wrung from those who have the best means of knowing its extraordinary rigor.
lead_paragraph: -- Rebel testimony to the rigorous efficiency of the blockade of the Southern coast accumulates constantly. abstract: By the steamer Elm City, the First Connecticut Battery arrived at Governor's Island, Tuesday, from Hartford. When the men were about to disembark, Col. LOOMIS informed the officer in command that there was no room for them in Fort Columbus. The steamer then proceeded to Twenty-third-street, where the men disembarked, and finally marched to the Park Barracks, where they are at present quartered. The battery consists of four 6-pound Parrott guns, two 12-pound howitzers, six caissons, one battery wagon, and one forge, each of which is drawn by six horses. The total number of horses attached to the battery, is 130. It takes 150 men to serve this battery, 59 of whom are mounted; the rest ride on the carriages and caissons. All the men are fine, active looking young fellows, averaging five feet eight and a half inches in height, and 26 years of age.

abstract: On New-Year's Day the Pope received Gen. GOYON and French officers. Gen. GOYON spoke of devotion to the Pope, and the latter thanked GOYON for the sentiments expressed. The present French soldiers at Rome would not permit the fulfillment of any irreligious or impolitic act. The Pope concluded by bestowing the apostolical benediction on the Imperial family, the Emperor NAPOLEON, and the whole French company.

abstract: The United States vs. The Cargo of the schooner Solidad Co., formerly called the Anna Taylor. This vessel was captured, Sept 11, 1861, off Galveston Bar, by the United States vessel-of-war South Carolina, ostensibly bound on a voyage from Vera Cruz to Matamoras, or Key West. The owner of the cargo resided in Texas and Louisiana, and went out and returned on board the vessel.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Cargo of the schooner Solidad Co., formerly called the Anna Taylor. This vessel was captured, Sept 11, 1861, off Galveston Bar, by the United States vessel-of-war South Carolina, ostensibly bound on a voyage from Vera Cruz to Matamoras, or Key West. The owner of the cargo resided in Texas and Louisiana, and went out and returned on board the vessel. They sailed with her from Galveston in August previous, owning the outward cargo of cotton she carried. The vessel was in charge of her owner, who acted as mate. He had resided six years in Texas with his family. A sham sale was made by him of the vessel in Tampico, in order, as it appeared upon the proofs in prepatorio, to put her in the name of a Mexican owner for the proposed voyage or adventure. No consideration was paid by the purchaser, and he took an engagement from the vendor, that on the return of the vessel to him in Tampico, his notes for the purchase money should be restored to him, and the vessel be restored to her American owner.

abstract: A correspondent of the New-Orleans Crescent, noticing that Gen. PRICE is set down by some of the papers as a West Pointer, says he owes his success to practical good sense and hard fighting. He never attended a military school in his life -- is a natural soldier, possessing the unbounded confidence of every Missourian. At the breaking out of the Mexican war, Gen. PRICE raised a regiment of Missourians, and for gallant conduct in several battles on the plains of Mexico, was brevetted to Brigadier General. Since and before that, and until the breaking out of the present revolution, he has spent his time on his farm in Chariton County, being one of the wealthiest and most successful planters in North Missouri.

abstract: On Tuesday evening, the above still popular and flourishing musical association held its regular yearly meeting, Mr. FRIEDRICH KAPP presiding, and Mr. S.S. PRETZFELDER, Secretary. The annual report of 1861 showed that the Society numbers 558 regular, 109 active and 17 honorary members. Of these, 2 are life members and 43 have been admitted during the year. Eight candidates are awaiting admission. Owing to various causes arising from the war, the number of members enrolled is now no more than 520, of whom 82 are active. The female members number, on the other hand, 70, while they were but 64 last year. The school of the Society counts 15 pupils. During the year, among other noted pieces, the Society has in its various concerts, under the direction of Mr. A. PAUX, performed the "Approach of Spring," by KREUTZER, the "Walpurgis Night," by MENDELSSOHN, "Paradise and the Peri," &c.

abstract: It will interest our readers, we believe, to know something of the current of public opinion about our and their terrestial luminary, as well as some facts bearing upon its present success and future prospects.
lead_paragraph: It will interest our readers, we believe, to know something of the current of public opinion about our and their terrestial luminary, as well as some facts bearing upon its present success and future prospects. A stream of congratulations, written and verbal, from personal friends and from leading men in public and private life, has poured, incessantly, upon the present Proprietor, since his return to the management of the SUN was made public, and we regret that the confidential nature of those communications prevents their reproduction here. They are, however, measurably symbolized in extracts presented below from the remarks of our brethren of the Press -- selected only as specimens from a supply large enough to fill our whole sheet were we disposed to print them all.

abstract: Henry D. Felter vs. Michael Tuomey et al. -- This action came on for trial, when plaintiff's counsel presented an affidavit showing that Richard B. Connolly, who is a member of the State Senate, had been duly subpoenaed as a witness for the plaintiff, and was not in attendance as such witness; and that he was a material and necessary witness for the plaintiff. The plaintiff's counsel thereupon asked for an attachment to compel Mr. Connolly's attendance, but Justice BALCOM refused to grant it, and remarked that Mr. Connolly was under a constitutional obligation to be in the Senate at Albany, which was in session; and that his attendance there was a valid excuse for his nonattendance here, and excused his disobedience of the subpoena.
lead_paragraph: Henry D. Felter vs. Michael Tuomey et al. -- This action came on for trial, when plaintiff's counsel presented an affidavit showing that Richard B. Connolly, who is a member of the State Senate, had been duly subpoenaed as a witness for the plaintiff, and was not in attendance as such witness; and that he was a material and necessary witness for the plaintiff. The plaintiff's counsel thereupon asked for an attachment to compel Mr. Connolly's attendance, but Justice BALCOM refused to grant it, and remarked that Mr. Connolly was under a constitutional obligation to be in the Senate at Albany, which was in session; and that his attendance there was a valid excuse for his nonattendance here, and excused his disobedience of the subpoena.

abstract: The release of Messrs. SLIDELL AND MASON had not been announced in England at the departure of the Arabia. So universal and assured, however, was the confidence in the preservation of peace, that the last indication of war panic seems to have disappeared, and business was subsiding into its customary channels.
lead_paragraph: The release of Messrs. SLIDELL AND MASON had not been announced in England at the departure of the Arabia. So universal and assured, however, was the confidence in the preservation of peace, that the last indication of war panic seems to have disappeared, and business was subsiding into its customary channels. Consols, which upon the newsof the Trent affair fell off four per cent., had nearly regained their previous level; and while the decline in cotton, caused by the prospect of an early opening of the blockade, had been recovered, breadstuffs were dull. It is to these indications we are constrained to look as the most reliable barometer of public sentiment. In the business marts men venture fortunes upon their opinions; and are not likely to stake them without some better argument for the risk, than purely crude conjecture and speculation. We are authorized to infer that, while assured of nothing more than the American willingness to discuss the pending issue amicably, and refer it, if desired, to arbitration, the British people believed the possibility of war had passed away. When it was learned how much more friendly and decisive a position we have assumed in giving up the rebel agents, we may be sure the demonstration was even more emphatic and gratifying.
headline: {'main': 'England Preparing for Peace.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England Preparing for Peace.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, a favorable report was made on the bill to authorize the Supervisors of Kings County to provide for the support of the families of volunteers by a tax. Among the bills introduced were two which interest our neighbors in Brooklyn one supplementary to the Flatbush- avenue Extension act, and the other to amend the act relative to the Brooklyn Board of Education.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a favorable report was made on the bill to authorize the Supervisors of Kings County to provide for the support of the families of volunteers by a tax. Among the bills introduced were two which interest our neighbors in Brooklyn -- one supplementary to the Flatbush-avenue Extension act, and the other to amend the act relative to the Brooklyn Board of Education. Mr. CONNOLLY, on the part of the Senate, was appointed to apportion the State into Congressional Districts. The resolution requesting the President and Congress to adopt some plan for the exchange of prisoners was called up and adopted.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, Capt. HUTCHINGS, with Sergeant BRACKETT and a platoon of men, made a descent upon a gambling-house situated at No. 17 Ann-street. It was kept by PATERIK HUGHES, who with ten others, were taken into custody, and at a late hour yesterday afternoon they were all brought before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs. HUGHES, the
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, Capt. HUTCHINGS, with Sergeant BRACKETT and a platoon of men, made a descent upon a gambling-house situated at No. 17 Ann-street. It was kept by PATERIK HUGHES, who with ten others, were taken into custody, and at a late hour yesterday afternoon they were all brought before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs. HUGHES, the proprietor, and a man named EARLE, were held to bail in $500 each for trial. The following named persons, who were arrested, were held to bail in $100 each: Eagan Norris, Henry Williams, Montgomery Gillie, Thomas Garles, John Haley, Jacob Depeau, Wm. Riley, Geo. Allen, Dewitt Smith and George Doyle. GEORGE ALLEN is said to be a Deputy-Sheriff, and he had the badge of office on at the time of the arrests. While HUGHES, the proprietor of the establishment, was in custody, he made an effort to seize the money, which the police had taken from the establishment, namely $45. He got a part of it in his possession, but he was immediately discovered by Sergeant BRACKETT, who prevented him from taking the remainder. When the arrests were made, the gamblers were engaged in a game of "faro." They had their table directly over a trap-door in the floor of the room. MORRISSEY was around, watching the proceedings of the police, and when the parties were taken into Court, he stated that, if he could have reached the place a few moments before he did, the police would have found nothing to seize. The property taken by the officers at the time of the arrests consisted of faro tables, cards, dealing boxes, and $45 in money, all of which were taken to Court and deposited with the Justice. The police state that there is a contrivance in the place, No. 17 Ann-street, whereby all the gambling implements may be made to disappear by means of a trap-door whenever there is the slightest warning that the authorities are about to enter. Captain HUTCHINGS so managed it as to elude the suspicion of those who were watching for the officers. The books of the gambling-house were also seized. By these it appears that the net proceeds for the month of December last were $2,154. For the month of January thus far, that is to the 13th inst., it was $268. The amount of the winnings and losses was put down in the books each day, and from this book it appears that on Sundays during the month of December there was more received than upon any other day of the week.

abstract: editorial on resolution
snippet: editorial on resolution
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the bill to increase the clerical force of the War Department and bureaus was reported from the Military Committee, and passed, after being amended so as to give four additional clerks to the Navy Department. A bill for the preservation of the Atlantic fisheries was reported from the Committee on Foreign Affairs. The joint resolution to promote the efficiency of the troops serving in Kansas was taken up, and debated at considerable length. Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, was very much afraid that it was intended to arm the negroes, and declared that the adoption of the resolution would extinguish the last hope of Union. Mr. LANE explained that no such intention was entertained, but that negroes would be used in building fortifications. The resolution was not disposed of. The numerous bills in reference to the confiscation of the property of rebels, referred to the Judiciary Committee, were all reported back, with one as a substitute, which provides for confiscating the property and freeing the slaves of rebels. The Kansas contested seat case was then debated until the adjournment, without any conclusion being arrived at.

abstract: Proceedings
snippet: Proceedings
lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has been encamped at Camp Hale, Manchester, N.H., for some time past, arrived in Jersey City yesterday, by the steamer Con- necticut. On leaving camp, the men proceeded to Allyn's Point, Where they embarked. The regiment numbers one thousand able-bodied men, all of whom are uniformed, equipped and armed with the Enfield rifile. The baggage-train consists of one hospital, eight horses and the officer's baggage. Col. H.S. PUTNAM, the commandant, is a regular officer of the United States army, and has seen active service on the borders. When the regiment arrived at Jersey City, and was about embarking on the cars to proceed to Washington, orders were received by Col. PUTNAM to take his regiment to New-York and go into barracks there, and await further orders. While the men were in camp they were drilled twice a day by Col. PUTNAM; consequently they have arrived at a most efficient state of drill and discipline. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: -- TheHerald is as indefatigable in its assaults upon public morals, as it is upon every foundation of social order and government. It surrenders, our readers are possibly aware, a material portion of its space to the promotion of dicentiousness and indecency; the largest latitude being given to advertisers of assignations, private boarding-houses for ladies, secret dens of unspeakable infamy, astrological cribs, where the simple are fleeced and started upon the road to ruin, mock-auctions of household furniture, gambling hells, horse-races, rat-matches, pugilistic encounters, in fact, every avenue and opportunity wanting to the inexperienced, disposed to enter upon evil courses, is spread before them in that guidebook to the infernal regions. And so utterly crapulous is the compiler of this abominable stuff, that he chafes at the presence of any matter in his columns which is not obviously prurient and distinctly promotive of some kind of vice. His ingenuity is racked to convert what is modest and innoxious into what is obscene and pernicious. The very remedies advertised for the cure of loathsome diseases, he makes the occasion of editorial discussions, which can only tend to propagate the diseases themselves. The practice may possibly have its profitable side. That class of advertisers who can only find admission for their announcements in decent sheets, on condition of pruning them of all impropriety or shadow of offensiveness, will at once see the importance of resorting to a paper, which not only glosses and explains their meaning in its editorial pages, but does so with a grossness and viciousness, which cannot fail to excite the impurest ideas and passions. But, on the other hand, there is a reason to fear that thousands who are induced by an idle curiosity to watch the daily capers of this mountebank, will realize the danger of bringing its filth into the household, and will discard it altogether. The balance of profit and loss will not, therefore, be so certainly favorable; especially as there is the additional risk of the Grand Jury indicting its editor for issuing an obcene publication. Upon the whole, will it not be better for the Herald to recruit its advertising by an expedient less hazardous?

abstract: The Germans of Hudson City held a large and enthusiastic meeting, last evening, in ROEMMELT & LEICH's establishment, appointed a Committee to represent them in union with the Committees of New-York, Brooklyn, Jersey City, Hoboken, Newark and other places, at the Sigel mass meeting to be held in the Cooper Institute, this evening. Resolutions were passed, and the feeling of indignation expressed at the intrigues directed against Gen. SIGEL was extreme. Hudson City will send a large delegation to the meeting.
lead_paragraph: The Germans of Hudson City held a large and enthusiastic meeting, last evening, in ROEMMELT & LEICH's establishment, appointed a Committee to represent them in union with the Committees of New-York, Brooklyn, Jersey City, Hoboken, Newark and other places, at the Sigel mass meeting to be held in the Cooper Institute, this evening. Resolutions were passed, and the feeling of indignation expressed at the intrigues directed against Gen. SIGEL was extreme. Hudson City will send a large delegation to the meeting.

abstract: The money bills of Congress must originate with the Representatives of the People. The Senate cannot initiate either a revenue or an appropriation bill. In this the practice of our Government assimilates to the constitutional perogative of the British House of Commons. In view of these facts, the overwhelming vote of the House of Representatives, yesterday, in favor of ample taxation for the maintenance of the public credit, is doubly auspicious for the success of the measure.

abstract: We begin to pay the penalty for the act of Capt. WILKES in the volley of paper pellets of the diplomatic sort, that arrives from across seas. The example which France has set in defining her position anent the quastio vexata, will doubtless be imitated by all the Great Powers of Europe, and by others not so great.
lead_paragraph: We begin to pay the penalty for the act of Capt. WILKES in the volley of paper pellets of the diplomatic sort, that arrives from across seas. The example which France has set in defining her position anent the quastio vexata, will doubtless be imitated by all the Great Powers of Europe, and by others not so great. Austria has given us a piece of her mind, and it will be found recorded in the dispatch (dated Dec. 18) of Count RECHBERG to the Imperial Minister at Washington, Chevalier DE HULSEMANN, which we printed yesterday, with the accompanying reply of Mr. SEWARD. It is a matter of profound gratitude that Count RECHBERG has contented himself with very briefly indicating the position of the Viennese Cabinet as entirely coincident with that of England, without entering into any discussion on the merits of the case. For what had he chosen to debate the theme under the united influence of diplomatic circumlocution and the German habit of mind to look at things with reference to the subjective and the objective, the "finite, the infinite and the Union between them!" Let us think of it and be grateful.

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF CHARITIES AND CORRECTIONS -- WEEKLY STATEMENT. -- The Commissioners held their regular meeting yesterday, but the business transacted was entirely unimportant. From the weekly statement it appears there were remaining in the various institutions 7,782; admitted since, 1,595; total, 9,377; of whom 56 had died; 1,229 were discharged; 293 sent to Blackwell's Island, leaving in charge at present 7,799, being an increase of 17 over last week. The contract for printing 600 copies of the annual report and 300 of the Lunatic Asylum repot was awarded to FRANK MCELROY, for $314 96. The sum of $1,504 had been received from the sale of barrels, bones, &c., from the various institutions.

abstract: One of the cars upon the Sixth-avenue Railroad took fire, a day or two since, in consequence of a light having been brought in contact with the straw which covered the floor. The passengers escaped, owing, no doubt, to the happy accident of the straw being wet, and to the uniformity with which all ventilation is prevented in the cars on this particular road. The car itself was destroyed. We have received several communications complaining of the practice of thus using straw in the cars. The danger\parof the practice is exemplified by the incident referred to. Had the straw been dry, it would have been scarcely possible for a female passenger, partially clothed with cotton, to avoid a frightful death. And yet nothing is more common than to see one of the flaming lamps of the car taken down to aid in the search for dropped money, and placed so near the inflammable carpeting as to render combustion almost inevitable But other objections are urged by our correspondents. The straw cannot be used to keep the feet warm, for it is well known that the sitex of the straw, being a rapid conductor of heat, is one of the coldest substances with which, they can come in contact. It cannot be used to keep the feet dry, for the straw, what with the wet and snow from scores of feet, and the rain of tobacco-juice front scores of mouths, is usually in the condition of a manure heap, steaming and disgusting to the smell, pernicious to the lungs, miasmatic in its influence upon the human body, and acting like a permanent cold bath upon the feet of sitters. The only conceivable reason for its use is, that it robs the traveling public hugely in the pertinacity with which it covers and retains fallen money. It yields, no doubt, a most important harvest of coin to the employes of the companies. It is simply a change-trap. As we are not to suppose the companies themselves share these miserable profits, it is to be hoped they will give attention at once to this abuse; and, also, to the subject of ventilation, a point of the utmost moment at a time when smallpox and other virulent diseases are so fatally prevalent. There is no way, let us hint, so effective to resist a railroad in Broadway, as a show of some attention to public comfort and health on the avenue lines.

abstract: THE FIRST STEPS TO CRIME. -- Four juveniles from nine to eighteen years of age were taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday, having been arrested on suspicion of being the parties who have entered Public School No. 3 on several occasions and stolen therefrom books and money. They were found secreted in the registry, in the basement. One of the lads admitted that they had purchased a small bottle of gin which they drank for the purpose of getting drunk, and that they crawled into the rear part of the register for the purpose of warming themselves. The boys were admonished and discharged, with the exception of their leader, who was committed to prison.
lead_paragraph: THE FIRST STEPS TO CRIME. -- Four juveniles from nine to eighteen years of age were taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday, having been arrested on suspicion of being the parties who have entered Public School No. 3 on several occasions and stolen therefrom books and money. They were found secreted in the registry, in the basement. One of the lads admitted that they had purchased a small bottle of gin which they drank for the purpose of getting drunk, and that they crawled into the rear part of the register for the purpose of warming themselves. The boys were admonished and discharged, with the exception of their leader, who was committed to prison.

abstract: When these rebel emissaries were removed from the Trent, in November, they were bound for St. Thomas, to take the British West India mail steamer for Southampton, England. On
lead_paragraph: -- When these rebel emissaries were removed from the Trent, in November, they were bound for St. Thomas, to take the British West India mail steamer for Southampton, England. On their subsequent surrender to the British Minister at Washington, the inquiry naturally arose, What will he do with them? But it may be added that the public curiosity on the matter was not especially exercised at the time of their departure from Fort Warren, nor has the question of destination occurred since, except in connection with the non-arrival of the Rinaldo at Halifax, where it was said she had certainly gone.

abstract: Intelligence has been received here that 4,000 Union Indians in the Cherokee country were attacked, on the 6th, by a superior force of Texan rebels. The Indians were compelled to retreat They are now in Kansas.

snippet: mass meeting held, NYC, to protest Sigel resignation
lead_paragraph: A remarkably beautiful evening succeeded the brilliant sunshine and universal thaw of yesterday; and at 7 1/2 o'clock, the hour fixed for the opening of the Sigel Mass Meeting, announced to take place at the Cooper Institute, every space in the vast hall was almost uncomfortably crowded, several hundred ladies occupying the front seats. On the stage were assembled a large number of well-known Germans, representing all the professions.

abstract: A meeting of the above Committee was held, last evening, to take into consideration the contested seats of the Seventh and Fourteenth Wards. After much discussion, which lasted three hours and a half, the Petty delegation of the Seventh Ward was accepted. Two members of the Adolphus Borst delegation, and two members of the John Fitch delegation of the Fourteenth Ward, were also accepted, with power to select a member to add to their number. Permanent officers for the ensuing year, were then balloted for with the following result: Sheridan Shook, President; Abraham Wakeman, first Vice-President; Andrew Blakeman second Vice-President; Hy. H. Hewlett and J.P. Walker, Secretaries.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the above Committee was held, last evening, to take into consideration the contested seats of the Seventh and Fourteenth Wards. abstract: The London Time has been very much exercised in mind upon the barbarism which the war was bringing upon us. The only instances which it mentioned as proof of its statement were the use of the stone fleet -- which it considered an assault upon humanity, although a few thousand dollars would remedy all the mischief caused by it -- and the prospect of a declaration of emancipation -- the last thing, one would say, that an Englishman would find fault with.

abstract: Academy of MUSIC -- VERDI's opera, "La Traviata," was produced here on Wednesday evening, for the purpose of inaugurating -- and half-completing, for that matter -- a brief "season" of two nights, under the direction of Mr. GRAU. The part of the heroine was sustained by Miss KELLOGG. With that singular ill luck which has pursued the lady on almost all her first appearances, the weather was intolerably bad, and fatal to the demonstration which would unquestionably have been made under more element auspices. As it was, the house presented a brilliant, if not crowded, appearance, and represented the best musical taste of our city.
lead_paragraph: Academy of MUSIC -- VERDI's opera, "La Traviata," was produced here on Wednesday evening, for the purpose of inaugurating -- and half-completing, for that matter -- a brief "season" of two nights, under the direction of Mr. GRAU. The part of the heroine was sustained by Miss KELLOGG. With that singular ill luck which has pursued the lady on almost all her first appearances, the weather was intolerably bad, and fatal to the demonstration which would unquestionably have been made under more element auspices. As it was, the house presented a brilliant, if not crowded, appearance, and represented the best musical taste of our city.

abstract: SIR: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of the following resolution of the Senate:  Resolved, That the Secretary of the Navy be directed to report to the Senate the facts in regard to the employment of GEORGE D. MORGAN, of New-York, to purchase vessels for the use of the Government, and to report the amount of compensation paid him.
lead_paragraph: NAVY DEPARTMENT, Jan. 15, 1862.

abstract: This branch of the American Tract Society held its Forty-sixth Anniversary last evening in the Central Church that of Dr. HAWES. A year ago Dr. MURRAY, of New-Jersey, assisted, and Judges WILLIAMS and PARSONS, of this city all three have now gone to their reward, revered and beloved by all who knew them.

abstract: The German mass meeting which met last night to consider the reported resignation of Gen. SIGEL, exhibited anything but Teutonic phlegm. The assemblage was very great, and the oratory fierce and denunciatory. The case is obviously understood to have its origin in latent Know Nothing, and Gen. SIGEL to have been selected as a shining mark for the shafts of that insidious heresy. If it were possible to obtain moderation from these excited gentlemen, we would gladly call their attention to the fact that evidence of Gen. SIGEL's resignation is wanting, while there is no want of evidence that Government will not accept his resignation if offered; but will hasten to redress all grievances of which so gallant and meritorious an officer may have reason to complain. Until the authorities at the head of the army have had an opportunity to ascertain the nature and extent of the wrongs and indignities suffered by Gen. SIGEL, they cannot measure the appropriate reparation. Our German friends, yielding to a just indignation and a too great impetuosity, indulge in language which injures their cause in the estimation of calmer judgments, and which none will regret at leisure more than themselves. It is impossible that a man like SIGEL should be neglected or underrated. With patience, justice will be done to the content of all equitable minds.

abstract: Col Pegram, one of the rebel officers captured by Gen. MCCLELLAN in Western Virginia, has been released from confinement in Fort Warren, and is now on his way to Richmond, whence he hopes to send back some officer of equal grade, as an exchange. Unless he expedites his movements, however, it is possible that the National army may arrive at the Confederate Capital before him, for at last accounts he was in Baltimore junketing with his friends and sympathizers, and looking forward to a happy stay of at least ten days in that abode of easy political virtue. Where the Colonel next proposes to tarry in the course of his pleasure tour we are not informed.
lead_paragraph: Col Pegram, one of the rebel officers captured by Gen. MCCLELLAN in Western Virginia, has been released from confinement in Fort Warren, and is now on his way to Richmond, whence he hopes to send back some officer of equal grade, as an exchange. Where the Colonel next proposes to tarry in the course of his pleasure tour we are not informed.

abstract: Further, we have to beware of any rash conclusion that republican institutions have failed because there is a civil war in America. It ought to be better known here than it is, that those institutions have never had a trial in the country at all. From the first discussions of the original compromises up to the last Presidential election, the liberties of the free States have been bought by the South, for the support of Slavery; and when the process of barter was once [???], it became more uncontrollable, till the last print of endurance was reached. Meantime, the Republic has been ruled by slaveholders and their tools, till the corruption of such a system demoralized the one section politically as much as the other. The ascendancy was obtained by a gross violation of republican principle, in the form of property suffrage [???] to the slaveholding section. Three slaves in [???] have conferred a vote; and thus the smaller population has outvoted the larger, and has been enabled to pass the fugitive slave law and many another  ordinance fatal to republican principle. On the one hand, it is true that such encroachments should never have been permmitted; and on the other the [???] of the North has brought after it its own [???], in the weakness, the divisions and the fluctuations of purpose which now amaze the world. It is for us to remember who have been the [???] and who the victims, in the long struggle. It is for us to remember that the sin of the Northern States has behind us, while the virtue of the struggle to recover its Parties and to destroy the cause of the and is the [???] of to-day. Whether we have to it the Federalists or not, we must beware of any [???] in the Confederates, and of casting my contempt on political institutions which are to have saw, for the first time, the chance of a sincere trial. It is Slavery which has made for South an oligarchy the most tyrannous in fact that the world can now show. It is Slavery which has [???] and corrupted the free spirit of the North. It is Slavery which has made the citizens boastful, arrogant, and vexatious, under the [???] of their actual subservience to the slave power. It is Slavery which has engendered the [???] and schisms of the Federalists themselves, in this critical hour of their history, when it seems almost equally necessary to support the Constitution and to abolish Slavery, while the two needs are absolutely incompatible. At such a time the duty of other nations is to hold aloof from all sympathy with a people who propose to found a polity on the basis of Slavery, and to hope the best for a people who, though late and fitfully, are striving to retrace lost steps, and to become true at last to the principles of their Republic and to the memory of its founders. Can we preserve this just discrimination, this spirit of equity, through all temptations of war or peace? This is one of the questions which must be solved by the coming year.
