abstract: Mr. Murphy's bill, amending the code of procedure, provides for the amendment of section 132, by adding the following to the end of the section: "And as to every such person, the action now or hereafter instituted, in which such notice may or shall be filed, shall be deemed to be commenced and pending from the time of service of the summons on any defendant therein, or from the time of the delivery of the summons with intent that it shall be actually served to the Sheriff or Other officer of the county in which the defendants or any of them usually or lost resided."

abstract: An article from De Bow's Review has been recently republished, in part, in our columns which seems to us to present more carefully considered opinions with regard to the Southern campaign than any that has yet appeared. The reader will remember that the article urged strongly a defensive policy on the part of the South, and the danger of carrying the campaign into Maryland; that Southern victories gained in that State would only arouse the North to new exertions and more desperate efforts, while a defeat would be almost fatal, with an impassable river in the rear.
lead_paragraph: An article from De Bow's Review has been recently republished, in part, in our columns which seems to us to present more carefully considered opinions with regard to the Southern campaign than any that has yet appeared. abstract: A number of gentlemen who have been active in the organization of this new Party, met at Clinton Hall last evening. Other meetings have been held, but they were strictly private in their character, and the meeting of last evening was the first concerning which any publicity has been given. The resolutions will fully explain the objects of the Party. A General Committee has been formed consisting of the following gentlemen: E.J. Brown, Waldo Hutchins, J. De Peyster Ogden, John J. Friedman, T.B. Lawson, Jos. Southworth, John S. Cocks, Daniel Witter, Albert G. Hyde, John L. Cilley, Jas. M. Smith, Joseph B. Varnum, George Peckham, Edward Timpson, Clin. abstract: This command was, yesterday morning, visited by his Excellency Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, at its quarters on Governor's Island. A short time ago the troops were paid off, and have remitted upward of $20,000 to their relatives and friends. In consequence of the complaints recently made by the men in regard to the uncomfortable, and almost unteeable, condition of their quarters, stoves are to be put in the casemates of Castle William, where the regiment is quartered.

abstract: The schooner G.L. Vandervoort, lying at Pier No. 4, North River, is now loading provisions and hay for Port Royal. The United States steam transport Thomas Spars,lying at the Pier No. 2, is loading for Locust Point. She has a cargo of subsistence, also two heavy mortars, four beds, twelve gun carriages and ten battery wagons.

abstract: H S Poor reports on domestic trade
snippet: H S Poor reports on domestic trade
lead_paragraph: It is characteristic of this country that its commerce and wealth, and, consequently, its population are creations rather than growths. Those could never have existed, unless the conditions on which they are based had been supplied by man. The natural routes of commerce, the great rivers of the Continet, had their outlets in inhospitable climes, and far distant from the central portion of the Atlantic slope, which was better fitted than any other of the Continent for commercial and manufacturing enterprise, and as the seat of a dense populating, and at the same time most conveniently placed in reference to the Old World. The proposition set before our people, consequently, was to correct this oversight of nature; to recast a Continent, and adapt it to their convenience and wants. Nature had taken good care, however, that the task should not be too ardous to discourage the attempt, by the slight elevation she gave to the interior of the Continent, and in the gentle and uniform slopes of its great plains. In its centre were the great lakes, so nicely poised as to give almost equal choice of outlet, either into the Gulf of Mexico, Hudson's Bay, or the Gulf of St. Lawrence. A low ridge, of eight feet in elevation, is the only barrier between them and the Mississippi, which was undoubtedly at one time their outlet. The waters of the two mingled in times of flood, allowing the barks of the natives to pass from one to the other. On the North, a similar means of communication exists between the lakes and Hudson's Bay, although the dividing ridge is somewhat higher. The great depression in the Continent, however, in ascending from the Gulf, is to be found in the Valley of the Mississippi and the Red River of the North, whose waters also mingle, so that, at certain periods of the year, boats pass from one to the other. But neither the inhospitable shores of Hudson's Bay, or the Gulf of St. Lawrence, or the insalubrious Delta of the Mississippi, were adapted to become the seals of a people excelling alike in agriculture, commerce, and the mechanic arts, which require for their development the temperate and bracing climates of the Middle and Northern States, beneath whose soil Providence has accumulated in the greatest profusion the two prime agencies in modern civilization -- iron and coal.

abstract: In the Senate, a communication was received from the Secretary of War, in answer to the resolution introduced by Mr. Powell, of Kentucky, relating to contracts, &c. The Secretary states that he has not sufficient clerical force to enable him to answer the resolution; and further, that he personally has not made a single contract for any purpose whatever, but that the contracts have all been made by the heads of bureaus. The matter was referred. Mr. Wilson, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill, which was referred, for the better organization of the cavalry forces. Mr. Bale offered a resolution, which was laid ever, declaring that Mr. Lamon, Marshal of the District of Columbia, had been guilty of breach of privilege and contempt in excluding members of the Senate from the jail without a pass from him. The bill to promote the efficiency of the Dead Letter Office was passed. It provides for the return to the writers or all letters received at the office; where such a course is possible. The resolution asking the Secretary of War what amounts have been paid by the Government to the railroads of Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania and New.York, was agreed to. The bill for the protection or overland emigrants to California and Oregon was passed. Mr. Wilson's bill, forbidding tho arrest and return of fugitive slaves by officers of the army, and providing penalties therefor, was then debated until the expiration of the morning hour. It was amended, on motion of Mr. Collamer, of Vermont, so as to forbid any officer from assuming any jurisdiction in such matters, under penalty of dismissal; and a further amendment, offered by, Mr. Saulsbuby, of Delaware, forbidding the enticement or retention of slaves from their owners, was debated, but not agreed to. The Kansas contested seat case was taken up, and finally decided in favor of Mr. LanE. The Senate then went into Executive Session, and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: A special meeting of the above Society was held at its rooms, in Clinton Hall, last evening, Mr. HENRY GRINNELL in the chair. A report was received from the Council of the Society, treating upon taxation and finance, adapted to the present state of public affairs. Mr. RUSSELL, the chairman of the Council, stated that the report had been divided into four parts, viz.: The financial scheme, the principles of taxaMon,
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the above Society was held at its rooms, in Clinton Hall, last evening, Mr. HENRY GRINNELL in the chair. A report was received from the Council of the Society, treating upon taxation and finance, adapted to the present state of public affairs. Mr. RUSSELL, the chairman of the Council, stated that the report had been divided into four parts, viz.: The financial scheme, the principles of taxation, the machinery by which it is proposed to collect taxes, and the status of the whole matter. The first division of the report was read by Mr. CHARLES GOULD. He said it enforced the doctrine of THOMAS JEFFERSON, who said "It is a wise rule, and should be fundamental in a Government disposed to cherish its credit, and at the same time to restrain the use of it within the limits of its faculties, never to borrow a dollar without laying a tax in the same instant for paying the interest annually, and the principle within a given time, and to consider that tax as pledged to the creditors on the public faith. On such a pledge as this, sacredly observed, a Government may always command, on a reasonable interest, all the fundable money of its citizens, whilst the necessity of an equivalent tax, is a salutary warning to them, and to their constituents, against oppression, bankruptcy and its inevitable consequence -- revolution."

abstract: The agency of Mr. GEORGE D. MORGAN in the purchase of vessels for the Navy Department has been made the subject of inquiry by both Houses of Congress, and in the Senate, soon after the beginning of the ession, a resolution was adopted, calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for information in regard to the facts, which were apparently these: Directly after the opening of the war it became obvious that very large additions would have to be made to the Navy by selections and purchases among the commercial marine. The Navy as well as the Army has Boards of experts qualified to transact its details of business, and the established course for the Secretary of the Navy was evidently to assign to an officer, or a commission of officers, the duty of making the necessary inspections and purchases. Mr. WELLES, however, departed from precedent in selecting a civilian to execute the business, the agent being Mr. MORGAN, a gentleman closely connected with him by marriage, and well known in this City as a brother and partner in business of Gov. E.D. MORGAN. To Mr. MORGAN was intrusted the business of receiving the tenders of those who had vessels for sale, and of arranging the bargain after a subordinate. of the navy had inspected and approved the ships. For these services, he collected from the sellers of shipping commissions at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent., -- commissions which, in the course of five months, resulted in an aggregate sum exceeding $90,000. From the National Treasury, Mr. MORGAN received no direct compensation. A large fortune so easily earned, at a moment when the nation was impoverishing itself to save itself, naturally excites attention, and it is not to be overlooked that the lucky man was so intimately connected with him who placed fortune within his reach. Favoritism is accordingly suspected, and the Inquiry of the Senate is directed to finding how far favoritism was indulged.

For these services, he collected from the sellers of shipping commissions at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent., -- commissions which, in the course of five months, resulted in an aggregate sum exceeding $90,000. lead_paragraph: A very singular case came before the authorities at Police Headquarters, yesterday. The facts, as communicated to Superintendent KENNEDY, were to the following effect. The complainant says his name is Rev. SAMUEL F. RANGENT, formerly of New-Orleans and a Priest of the Roman Catholic Church. He arrived in this City on Wednesday last, from Havana, and put up at the Metropolitan Hotel. During the afternoon, he says he made the acquaintance of a very genteel looking man, who said he boarded at the hotel. Some time in the evening the new acquaintance induced him to visit a concert saloon, situated in the basement of No. 600 Broadway. Mr. RANGENT asked his friend to take a drink in this saloon -- himself taking, as he says, water, peppermint and sugar. He had scarcely swallowed his drink before he became drowsy, and soon he was in a sound sleep. When he awoke, he discovered that a valuable gold watch, chain and cross, and also his pocket-book, containing papers valued at $2,000, were all gone. When he came before the police, about the first thing noticed by the Superintendent, was a commission as Chaplain in the First Louisiana Regiment, properly made and signed by Gov. MOORE. The date of it was May 13, 1861. Among his baggage was found a number of letters, which corroborated the story he told about himself, and which was as follows: He says he is a native of Missouri, where his parents now reside. He was educated for the Church in the City of Paris. When he returned to America he became assistant pastor of St. Patrick's Church, in New-Orleans, and was officiating us such when the war broke out. Soon after a commission as Chaplain was handed to him, and he was told that he must serve in that capacity in the First Louisiana Regiment. He was too much of a Union man, he says, to accept the office; and, seeing no other way to avoid the requisition, he at once fled to the City of Mexico. At this place he began to preach, and in one of his sermons he advised his congregation to read the Scriptures whenever they could find a correct version of them. This caused great excitement among the Mexican clergy, and the people of the city formed a plot to assassinate him. Of this he was informed by Mr. RICHARDS, the United States Consul at that place. Several shots were fired at him while he was sleeping in his room, and but for the fact that he had changed the position of his bed on account of the information from the Consul, his life would have been sacrificed. A day or two subsequently, he was attacked and stubbed in his side. (The marks of a wound are now distinctly visible,) and for weeks after, his life was despaired of by his attendants.

abstract: On Sunday morning last, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER preached what he called a "Charity Sermon," for the benefit of the "City Missionary Society." During its delivery, he touched unexpectedly upon the duty of Christians, and of this Christian nation, to the negro -- or the poorest and most despised of all human creatures. Finding, as he proceeded, that the subject was opening up in full-sermon length, he abruptly closed his discourse, promising to resume the subject in the evening.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning last, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER preached what he called a "Charity Sermon," for the benefit of the "City Missionary Society." abstract: -- The Senate has decided the issue between Messrs. LANE and STANTON, by giving to the former the vexed seat for Kansas. The question was of little public interest. LANE was duly elected, and took his seat as Senator for Kansas; but at the outbreak of the war, eager to aid in the defence of the border, he obtained the offer of a brigadier's commission, and without formally accepting it, hastened to Kansas and took active part in the summer campaign. Assuming LANE's acceptance of the commission, whereby his seat in the Senate would become vacant, the Governor of Kansas appointed Mr. F. B. Stanton in his place. LANE denies that he ever accepted or acted under the commission - the friends of STANTON offer evidence to the contrary, and the Senate, decides to believe LANE. The contest has been one of purely local moment, andhaving secured his point, the victor will no doubt hasten to his place at the head of the expedition destined for the Indian Territory, where he will as certainly give a good account of himself. LANE is a man of talent and infinite shrewdness, but will shine to better advantage at the head of a border brigade, than in the attempt to lead wondering and obsequious Senates.

abstract: In the Senate, the bill to increase the powers of notaries public was reported favorably; also the bills to amend the Revised Statutes relative to the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, and to prohibit bank officers from acting as notaries public. Among the bills introduced was one to amend the Loan Commissioners' act; one to legalize certain acts passed by the Common Council of this City; and one to prohibit Supervisors from holding other office and from making contracts. A concurrent resolution in favor of the State assuming its portion of the National tax was reported from the Committee on Finance.

abstract: The steamship Saxonia, which arrived at this port from Hamburg, yesterday, had on board, for the Government, two batteries of field artillery, comprising sixteen pieces, and about one thousand four hundred packages of war material, including twenty-five thousand stand of arms. A quan-
lead_paragraph: The steamship Saxonia, which arrived at this port from Hamburg, yesterday, had on board, for the Government, two batteries of field artillery, comprising sixteen pieces, and about one thousand four hundred packages of war material, including twenty-five thousand stand of arms. A quantity of saltpetre was also on board. The Hamburg line of steamers, has, within a few weeks, brought large shipments of saltpetre and other war material to this port, consigned to Government. On her last trip the Saxonia did not touch at Southampton, for fear, it is said, of meeting with some difficulty from the British Government on account of this shipment to America.

abstract: The great German demonstration of sympathy with Gen. FRANZ SIGEL took place last night at the Cooper Institute, and even surpassed the expectations of its originators. Five thousand persons, among them many hundreds of ladies,  ware present, and several minor meetings were, dispite the cold, held outside of the building. The spacious interior was dense
lead_paragraph: The great German demonstration of sympathy with Gen. FRANZ SIGEL took place last night at the Cooper Institute, and even surpassed the expectations of its originators. Five thousand persons, among them many hundreds of ladies, ware present, and several minor meetings were, dispite the cold, held outside of the building. The spacious interior was densely thronged with most respectative German citizens. At 8 P. M. the proceedings were opened by calling R.A. WITTHAUS; Esq., to the chair, and selecting 180 vice-presidents and 31 Sectaries. Eloquent and sitting addresses were then delivered by Messrs. Witthaus, Wesendonk, Kapp, Dr.Solger. Mr. S. Kaufmann and Dr. Donai, all of whom entered into the question of the war with great warmth. A series of resolution of sympathy with Gen. SIGEL. were then unanimously adopted and a Committee of Three appointed to bear the; same to Washington, and lay them before the United States authorities, with a request for the appointment of a Committee by Congress to investigate, the causes of SIGEL, resignation and remedy the same. The highest enthusiasm prevailed throughout these proceedings, and with nine others for SIGEL, at a late hour the meeting adjourned.

abstract: A most fearful railroad accident occurred early yesterday morning, on the Delaware Railroad, just where the track crosses the canal, near St. George's station, by which seven persons lost their lives, and fifteen were more or less injured. A wood train, consisting of thirteen platform cars, empty, and one old passenger, in which the conductor, Mr. ALBERT BUTLER, and some twenty laborers were seated, went down the Delaware road for a load of wood.
lead_paragraph: A most fearful railroad accident occurred early yesterday morning, on the Delaware Railroad, just where the track crosses the canal, near St. George's station, by which seven persons lost their lives, and fifteen were more or less injured. A wood train, consisting of thirteen platform cars, empty, and one old passenger, in which the conductor, Mr. ALBERT BUTLER, and some twenty laborers were seated, went down the Delaware road for a load of wood. When the train reached the high bridge which spans the canal, near the St. George's station, the draw of the bridge was discovered to be open; but the discovery came too late to stop the train, the ice on the road preventing it, and it was precipitated into the canal, a ditance of about sixty feet. Car upon car were piled in pieces upon each other, crushing a number of persons. The conductor, Mr. BUTLER, was, fortunately, standing outside of the car, and seeing the train was about to make the fearful plunge, jumped off and escaped; but he had no time to warn the workmen in the car, and the entire number were soon mixed with the ruins in the canal. The engineer of the train, JOSIAH ANDERSON, was killed instantly, as well as the fireman, EDWARD MENAM.
headline: {'main': 'Accident on the Delaware Railroad.; A TRAIN PRECIPITATED THROUGH A DRAWBRIDGE SEVEN PERSONS KILLED AND A NUMBER INJURED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Accident on the Delaware Railroad.; A TRAIN PRECIPITATED THROUGH A DRAWBRIDGE SEVEN PERSONS KILLED AND A NUMBER INJURED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In advertising new contracts for envelopes and stamps, we are happy to see the Post-office Department requires new designs for the latter. The change effected last Spring was not only offensive to taste -- the heads of the Republican fathers being simple  caricatures -- but so wretched and inartistic was the execution of the engraving, and so faint the printing, as to place imitation within reach of the coarsest hands. The rebel Government might, with its deficient resources, have been pardoned for sanctioning such  imperfect work, than which lithography would have served better. We have now fortunately an opportunity to redeem our character for good taste and ingenuity in the arts of design. Let us see it improved.
lead_paragraph: In advertising new contracts for envelopes and stamps, we are happy to see the Post-office Department requires new designs for the latter. The change effected last Spring was not only offensive to taste -- the heads of the Republican fathers being simple caricatures -- but so wretched and inartistic was the execution of the engraving, and so faint the printing, as to place imitation within reach of the coarsest hands. The rebel Government might, with its deficient resources, have been pardoned for sanctioning such imperfect work, than which lithography would have served better. We have now fortunately an opportunity to redeem our character for good taste and ingenuity in the arts of design. Let us see it improved.

abstract: FIRE IN BROADWAY At about 7 o'clock last evening a fire broke out at No. 229 Broadway, corner of Barelay-street. It originated on the fourth floor of the building in premises occupied by P.R. PEATT, agent for fire and steam regulators.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN BROADWAY. -- At about 7 o'clock last evening, a fire broke out at No. 229 Broadway, corner of Barelay-street. It originated on the fourth floor of the building in premises occupied by P.R. PEATT, agent for fire and steam regulators. The flames broke out under the stove, and soon burned through the floor. The fire thence communicated to the story next below, occupied by GEORGE A. MCDONALD, commission merchant. The damage to each of the above was about $50, and was fully insured. The premises of Mr. MCLEOD, merchant-tailor, on the second floor, were broken open by the Insurance patrol, and found to be much damaged by water. The goods were secured, as far as possible, from further damage. The building is owned by J.C. HAMILTON, and was damaged about $50. It is fully insured. We are informed by a physician who happened to be present at the time of the fire, in attendance on a lady who was dangerously ill in one of the rooms above that in which the fire began, that she was carried by two of the firemen to the Astor House when, with characteristic kindness and assiduous care, Mrs. [???] immediately took personal charge of the invalid, who is still suffering from the effects of fright and remains in a very precarious state.

abstract: The schooner Mechanic, which sailed from Boston, Dec. 27, in ballast, for Ellsworth, Maine, having on board a crew of four men and three passengers, on the night of Dec. 28, off Monhegan, was caught by a gale from the northwest, and was driven as far south as latitude 38°. On January 1, had another heavy gale, and was blown to latitude 29° 20', longitude 60 30', when the fore and main rigging parted, and the vessel sprung a leak. On January 4, she was spoken by the Portuguese brig Schreller, which kindly laid by until the next day, when the gale abated, and the men were taken on board. The Mechanic was 25 years old, of 114 tons burden, built in Ellensworth, Maine, where she was owned by CURTIS & [???].

abstract: editorial deplores US Navy failure to overtake Sumter
snippet: editorial deplores US Navy failure to overtake Sumter
lead_paragraph: It will be well to have it clearly understood that, however it may strike the naval authorities, every loyal man will feel the sting of personal disgrace who reads the piece of intelligence we publish this morning touching the rebel privateer Sumter. A dispatch from our Minister at London to Mr. BARNEY, Collector of this port, communicates the fact that the Sumter had put in at Cadiz, Spain, after having burnt three American vessels. The act, the locality and the circumstances, combine to render this the crowning humiliation the imbecility of our navy in allowing this corsair to scour the seas, has put upon the country.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HOWARD, the new Senator from Michigan in place of Mr. BINGHAM, appeared, and look his seat. Petitions were presented for the emancipation of the slaves, and for the employment of homoeopathic physicians in the army. The House bill extending the privilege now enjoyed by soldiers, of sending letters without prepayment of postage, to sailors and marines, was passed. The joint resolution from the House, declaring the purpose of Congress to impose a tax sufficient to insure a revenue of $150,000,000 annually, was reported from the Finance Committee, and passed, with only one dissenting vote, cast by Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky. A bill was introduced by Mr. BROWNING, of Illinois, and referred, providing for the better organization of the artillery. After some further business of minor importance, the Senate went into Executive Session, and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: Editorial on need for uniform national currency during Civil War; Editorial on need for uniform national currency
snippet: Editorial on need for uniform national currency during Civil War; Editorial on need for uniform national currency
lead_paragraph: The House Committee of Ways and Means are understood to be diligently engaged in perfecting their tax and loan bills. The vote of the House, on Wednesday, 133 to 5, is their authority to proceed with the most liberal schedules of import, excise, and other taxes, necessary to insure about $150,000,000 in gross of annual revenue, and the measure, when perfected, will no doubt be such as to settle the question of the undoubted security of the public engagements, principal and interest. In all discussions of the side issue of Currency, we have not heard this point questioned. If the taxes be imposed, the People will promptly and cordially respond to them. And this fact is not denied by the opponents of a National Currency as part of the means for the conduct of the Treasury through the War, as well as for the uniform convenience of the country under the present suspension of Specie payments by the Banks.

abstract: -- Mr. Gilbert Rodman, late Chief Clerk in the Treasury Department at Washington, was in early life a clerk in the mercantile firm of Joseph S. Lewis & Co., of Philadelphia. He subsequently studied law with Judge Fox, at Doylestown; afterwards attended law lectures in Philadelphia, and having completed his studies in the office of Mr. Geo. M. Dallas, commenced practicing in Lancaster. He was appointed to a subordinate clerkship in the Treasury in 1829, during the first year of Jackson's Administration, through the influence of Hon. Samuel D. Ingham, at that time Secretary of the Treasury. During the Presidency, of Taylor, he was sent to California to investigate certain fraudulent transactions in the customs of that State, and after a six months' sojourn, returned to his old position. He passed through the various grades of the Treasury Department till the attainment of the Chief Clerkship, and by his experience and ability rendered his services invaluable.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. Gilbert Rodman, late Chief Clerk in the Treasury Department at Washington, was in early life a clerk in the mercantile firm of Joseph S. Lewis & Co., of Philadelphia. Samuel D. Ingham, at that time Secretary of the Treasury. During the Presidency, of Taylor, he was sent to California to investigate certain fraudulent transactions in the customs of that State, and after a six months' sojourn, returned to his old position. abstract: report on Pres. Juarez December 18 1861 proclamation on threatened intervention; Lrs. on war
snippet: report on Pres. Juarez December 18 1861 proclamation on threatened intervention; Lrs. on war
lead_paragraph: MEXICANS: The warnings of the approaching war which was preparing in Europe against us have begun, unfortunately, to be realized. Spanish forces have invaded our territory; our national dignity is insulted; and perhahs, independence in danger. Under such difficult circumstances, the Government of the Republic believes that it complies with one of its principal duties by placing within your reach the cardinal idea which shall be the basis of its policy in the present state of affairs. The interest of all is concerned, and if all are bound, as good sons of Mexico, to contribute their intelligence, their fortune and their blood toward the salvation of the Republic all claim an equal right to be informed of the conduct and proceedings of the Government.

abstract: The New-Orleans Bulletin, of the 4th, says that on Wednesday morning last, Lieut. WORLEY, the gallantcommander of the ram Manassas, carried his vessel out of Passe a L'Outre, and remained for several hours within sight of the Federal blockading fleet, anxiously waiting for them to attack him. They refused, however, to accept a challenge, notwithstanding the blockaders were the steamer Mississippi and two sailing vessels, which were also joined by two other ships. They evidently held in remembrance the battle of the Passes.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, notice was given of a bill to amend the Usury laws. Among the bills introduced was one for the amendment of the Revised Statutes relative to unauthorized banking, and our to amend the act appointing Commissioners to lay out certain streets. The latter is intended to stay the progress of extravagance in projected improvements in Brooklyn. The resolution in favor of the State's assuming its portion of the war tax was called up and passed; also the resolution asking the New-York Senators and Representatives in Congress to vote to abolish the franking privilege. The bill authorizing the Supervision of Kings County to raise $20,000 for the relief of the families of volunteers was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, notice was given of a bill to amend the Usury laws. abstract: A CURIOUS FIRE AND ITS ORIGIN. -- Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, a servant -- a girl 11 years of age -- in the employ of Mrs. PAGE, who keeps a boarding-house at the northeast corner of Fourth and Arch streets, announced to the inmates in great alarm that a fire had broken out in the cellar of the premises. This was found to be the case, and, although the fire had made some progress among the shavings and wood in the cellar, it was put out without the aid of the firemen. When Fire Marshal BLACKBURN was examining into the case a short time afterward, the inmates of the house were again startled by the cry of "fire." This time it was discovered to be in the attic, and had gained considerable headway. Policemen LOWRIE and HOPEN made their way into the room, notwithstanding the dense smoke, and, with the aid of water passed to them in buckets, extinguished the second fire. Nothing was found to indicate the origin of the fires, and for a while the whole affair remained in mystery, untilthe Fire Marshal suggested that the girl, MARY JANE BENDICK, who had first given the alarm of the fire in the cellar, might know something about it. Mrs. PAGE could not believe this possible, as the child had been with her over two years, and had conducted herself properly, although given to trifling acts of mischief -- such as cutting up clothing. Mr. BLACKBURN examined the child, but she stoutly denied all knowledge in regard to the matter. Satisfied that she was the cause of the fire, the Fire Marshal took her into custody, and when she reached the Central Station, she freely admitted that she had started the fires; that she was fond of playing with matches, and seeing the shavings in the cellar, she concluded they would make a "nice bonfire." After the flames had got some headway, she became frightened lest the house should be destroyed, and she gave the alarm. A few moments afterwards she was directed to carry wood into the upper room, and finding the attic unoccupied she concluded she would have another bonfire, and accordingly she fired some dresses hanging in the room, and these communicated to a barrel containing cast-off clothing. The girl is intelligent and has a full appreciation of the penalty for her offence, but can give no reason for committing it, other than a desire to see a bonfire. She was held for a hearing to-day.

abstract: You express delight, in your paper this morning, at the action of the House of Representatives on the bill to abolish franking regarding this abuse as "most indefensible."
lead_paragraph: You express delight, in your paper this morning, at the action of the House of Representatives on the bill to abolish franking -- regarding this abuse as "most indefensible." There are other evils in ourpostal system of equal magnitude to this, which need ventilation, and which operate more injuriously on all classes. Take, for instance, a view of the law regulating the mailing of printed matter. What justice or propriety is there in providing that newspapers of the weight of three ounces shall be carried for a quarter cent each, without prepayment of postage, while on transient printed matter, such as circulars, prepayment is demanded in amount fifty times greater estimating the same by weight? Such a discrimination as the law makes is opposed to common sense. A proper reduction of the rates of postage on transient printed matter would tend more to make the postal system self-sustaining than any reform yet proposed, as it would meet the wants of business and commercial classes generally, and from these classes must be derived the most part of the revenue. If the present high rates charged on transient printed matter does not quite amount to a prohibition, it tends at least greatly to lessen the amount sent by mail. No person who has not analyzed this subject has any adequate idea of the vast amount of printed matter, such as books, pamphlets, &c., that would pass through the mail if a proper change in the law were made.

abstract: The Boston Courier has another version of the escape of the Sumter from St. Pierre, Mart., which completely relieves Capt. PALMER, of the Iroquois, from blame. The Sumter, it will be recollected, upon leaving the harbor of St. Pierre at night, steered to the southward. This fact was signalized to the Iroquois, which gave chase, but discovering that the Sumter had put about, the Iroquois turned northward also, and followed along the shore. Much time had not been lost as yet, and Capt. PALMER felt pretty sure of his prize. He could see that the privateer had not reentered the harbor, and had not got an offing.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Courier has another version of the escape of the Sumter from St. Pierre, Mart., which completely relieves Capt. PALMER, of the Iroquois, from blame. abstract: Misfortune does not pursue Mr. GRAU with its ordinary severity. It did not rain last night, nor did it snow, nor did the banditti who watch at the passes of the street, take the opportunity of thrusting well-dressed persons into the mud for the sake of a cent. The evening was not absolutely summery, but like the hole in Mercutio's side, it served. Perhaps three thousand persons availed themselves of its comparative pleasantness, and poured into the Academy with the determination of being pleased. Hence that bright and agreeable establishment was crowded in all the best parts, and well filled, even in the worst. The opera was VERDI's Ballo in Maschera, a work which we have had other opportunities of discussing, and which seems to have stepped pleasantly into the place of the Trovatore. The caste was in all respects the same as last season. Miss KELLOGG was in admirable voice, and thoroughly satisfied the audience. Miss HINKLEY, in the lively music of her part, was, as usual, admirable. The lady has improved in voice and method, especially the latter. Signor MANCUSI has not yet recovered from his cold, and did not, in consequence, do justice to himself. This was noticeable in the aria of the first act, and more unpleasantly in the third. Signor BRIGNOLI sang well. Here all praise ends, for neither the orchestra nor chorus contributed to the pleasures of the evening, albeit the former was under the direction of the ablest conductor in the country -- Mr. CARL ANCHUTZ.

abstract: Senate has before it a bill providing for the sale of Manhattan-square. It does not give the property to the adjoining landholders, and on the other hand, it does not dis-park the ground without indemnity to those whose lots were originally assessed to create it. It simply proposes to convert so much idle and profitless land, which the gigantic proportions of the neighboring Central Park have rendered useless as a public resort, into a source of municipal revenue, by selling it and funding the proceeds to pay the City indebtedness. A measure so strikingly wise, and in all respects equitable, will, we trust, become law. And if it be followed by a similar sale of Hamilton-square, and of the dock and market property possessed by the Corporation, the public, so far from raising a voice of complaint, will hail the present Legislature as public benefactors. It is time this estate of twenty millions should cease to enrich the corrupt jobbers who infest the corridors of the City Hall, and should contribute to ease the public burdens.

abstract: One of the great arguments in favor of the most energetic prosecution of the war, and one we have cause to believe which acts upon those in command of the army, is the enormous cost with which it is waged. In other countries the army is a profession that either brings its own reward, or is entered both by officer and private as a means of providing occupation and support. The rank and file look for nothing beyond. The pay of the French soldier is fifty-six cents per month, but as his profession secures him a comfortable maintenance, and a certain degree of consideration and respect, he is content. He might not be able to better his condition if he could. His relation to the Government is a much closer one than prevails in this country. In most European countries, Governments maintain the right to a certain portion of the time of their subjects for military purposes. With us, Government asserts no such prerogative, and must pay for whatever services it receives at their worth to the party rendering them. And this is necessarily a high rate, as any soldier in the army can, with $100, become the owner of 160 acres of fertile land, from the cultivation of which he can, with ordinary thrift, soon raise himself to a comfortable independence. To make up our armies we must offer wages so high as to tempt the workingman to forego this privilege, or wages which, in the course of a year, should he then get his discharge, will give him a sum sufficient to start him in the world, and make him the owner of a farm. In times past the army has cost this country, on an average, $1,000 annually, per man, rank and file. We are not now getting along at a lower rate. If we have 660,000 men in the field, we are spending at the rate of $660,000,000 annually, for the army alone. We must add $150,000,000 more for the navy, coast defences, and the civil list. It is clear that we cannot long wage war at such cost. The French Budget for 1860 waa 315,000,000 francs, or $65,000,000 for a force on a war footing of 750,000 men, and in addition a reserve on a peace footing of 115,000 men. But such an expenditure has brought the Emperor to his wits' end for money. We are spending at ten times this rate. We are a a richer people, but from the great diffusion of our people over a wide territory, we may not be so well able to pay a larger sum per head to the support of Government. Our armies have rushed into the field. With all that has been borrowed, the floating debt of Government to-day probably equals $100,000,000, and is still running on at a rapid rate. We can pay for the present. But it is evident that we cannot indefinitely prolong the war. We shall, if continued long, sink under the exhaustion. But this need not, and we trust will not, be. We are assured of a movement in every direction, and we are confident that complete success will follow whenever and wherever it is made.
lead_paragraph: One of the great arguments in favor of the most energetic prosecution of the war, and one we have cause to believe which acts upon those in command of the army, is the enormous cost with which it is waged. In other countries the army is a profession that either brings its own reward, or is entered both by officer and private as a means of providing occupation and support. The rank and file look for nothing beyond. The pay of the French soldier is fifty-six cents per month, but as his profession secures him a comfortable maintenance, and a certain degree of consideration and respect, he is content. He might not be able to better his condition if he could. His relation to the Government is a much closer one than prevails in this country. In most European countries, Governments maintain the right to a certain portion of the time of their subjects for military purposes. With us, Government asserts no such prerogative, and must pay for whatever services it receives at their worth to the party rendering them. And this is necessarily a high rate, as any soldier in the army can, with $100, become the owner of 160 acres of fertile land, from the cultivation of which he can, with ordinary thrift, soon raise himself to a comfortable independence. To make up our armies we must offer wages so high as to tempt the workingman to forego this privilege, or wages which, in the course of a year, should he then get his discharge, will give him a sum sufficient to start him in the world, and make him the owner of a farm. In times past the army has cost this country, on an average, $1,000 annually, per man, rank and file. We are not now getting along at a lower rate. If we have 660,000 men in the field, we are spending at the rate of $660,000,000 annually, for the army alone. We must add $150,000,000 more for the navy, coast defences, and the civil list. It is clear that we cannot long wage war at such cost. The French Budget for 1860 waa 315,000,000 francs, or $65,000,000 for a force on a war footing of 750,000 men, and in addition a reserve on a peace footing of 115,000 men. But such an expenditure has brought the Emperor to his wits' end for money. We are spending at ten times this rate. We are a a richer people, but from the great diffusion of our people over a wide territory, we may not be so well able to pay a larger sum per head to the support of Government. Our armies have rushed into the field. With all that has been borrowed, the floating debt of Government to-day probably equals $100,000,000, and is still running on at a rapid rate. We can pay for the present. But it is evident that we cannot indefinitely prolong the war. We shall, if continued long, sink under the exhaustion. But this need not, and we trust will not, be. We are assured of a movement in every direction, and we are confident that complete success will follow whenever and wherever it is made.

abstract: The strike at the Philadelphia Navy-yard which occurred on Thursday last, has not yet had any effect upon the employes at the Brooklyn Navyyard. At the former yard, three sailmakers, 90 carpenters, 62 riggers, 88 caulkers, 43 painters, and 482...
lead_paragraph: The strike at the Philadelphia Navy-yard which occurred on Thursday last, has not yet had any effect upon the employes at the Brooklyn Navyyard. At the former yard, three sailmakers, 90 carpenters, 62 riggers, 88 caulkers, 43 painters, and 482 laborers, and others, have been discharged this week, making a total of 786. About 1,500 have struck, leaving only some 400 men at work, out of about 2,700 men who were on the rolls ten days ago. If the Brooklyn men give heed to the counsels of the Philadelphia men, it is to be feared that the Naval Department of the service will suffer very considerably. Although the purchase of vessels by the naval authorities has ceased, there is yet an immense amount of work to be got through, which ought to be completed within the next six or eight weeks, but which cannot be done if any disturbance occurs among the employes.

abstract: Capt. N.W. MULLEY, Company B, First Regiment Eagle Brigade, Col. DANIEL ULLMAN, was on Wednesday last the recipient of a sword, sash and belt, as a token of esteem and regard, from a number of his personal friends of New-Brighton, Staten Island, Mr. RICHARD CUNLIFFE presented the same, with some very appropriate remarks, which were equally complimentary to the men as to their Captain. Capt. MULLEY replied in a very suitable manner, but somewhat abashed, having no previous knowledge of the presentation.

abstract: The public craving for Photographic Albums has converted half the book-binderies of the country into manufactories of those convenient novelties. Messrs. J.E. TILTON & Co., of Boston, have engaged largely in the business, employing newly-contrived machinery, and giving especial attention to the durability of their work. The sample submitted to our examination, while by no means exhibiting the elegance of those imported from France, and possibly falling below the standard Messrs. TILTON produce at a higher price, was nevertheless made with unusual regard to strength and endurance, and for that reason would commend itself to those who prefer such qualities to external showiness. Of cartes de visite to fill the pages of such volumes, Messrs. TILTON issue a very large variety, embracing the notabilities of both worlds.

abstract: Yesterday morning the Sons of New-Hampshire met at the Girard House, in order to make arrangements to give the officers of the Seventh New-Hampshire Regiment, now in this City, a proper reception before they leave for the seat of war. Messrs. H.B. Perkins, W.N. Brown, N.P. Higgins, E.P. Budd, George F. Peterson, C.A. Soule and Joseph Cushing were appointed a committee to wait upon the officers of the Seventh, and tender them the hospitalities of the Sons of New-Hampshire. The invitation was accepted, and the dinner will take place to-morrow evening, at six o'clock. All New-Hampshire men resident in this City are expected to attend.

abstract: Congress has a bill before it punishing with death frauds in army contracts. We take its rejection for granted. It must be obvious even in the bustle of that hurried legislation which promises anything but salutary fruits, that an overcharged penalty is equivalent to immunity from punishment. No Congressman believes in the possibility of finding a jury to convict a man of the crime, the disproportioned punishment of which is death. Where the offence is even of the most aggravated character -- where, for example, the cool assassin lays in wait for his victim, and slays him pitilessly -- it is difficult to find a dozen men who will agree in consigning the unquestionable homicide to the gallows. Frauds in military contracts have existed simply because there has been no public opinion rigorous enough to condemn and punish the guilty, even with social ostracism. To demand of that enfeebled public sentiment so sudden and stern a reprobation as a sentence of death, is asking more than will be conceded; so much more, indeed, that it will assure to the culprit entire impunity. Truths so evident, Congress will no doubt see. Let it mark the offence with some ineffaceable disgrace; but do not acquit it of all retribution by an overwrought severity.

abstract: The movement from Cairo is scarcely so important in itself as the public have been led to believe. According to our best advices, it consists only of about 7,000 men and three gunboats. Its destination, so far as can be evolved from the mystery which surrounds it, seems to be the occupation of Island No. 1, a point about six miles nearer Columous than Cairo.

abstract: LIFE SAVING BENEVOLENT ASSOCIATION.  The Annunl Meeting of the Managers of the Life Saving Benevolent Association was held at No. 13 Insurance Buildings, Wall-street, on Friday, the 17th of January, instant, at 3 o'clock, P.M.
lead_paragraph: LIFE SAVING BENEVOLENT ASSOCIATION. -- The Annunl Meeting of the Managers of the Life Saving Benevolent Association was held at No. 13 Insurance Buildings, Wall-street, on Friday, the 17th of January, instant, at 3 o'clock, P.M. abstract: Maj.-Gen WOOL is  disposed to sacrifice none of the amenities of war. According to a dispatch from Baltimore, he has given the Commander at Norfolk notice...
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen WOOL is disposed to sacrifice none of the amenities of war. According to a dispatch from Baltimore, he has given the Commander at Norfolk notice to remove the women and children from that place, the inference being that a bombardment is to commence at an early day -- unless, with true military guile, the men-of-war who are steaming up beneath the' guns of Fortress Monroe are to take a sudden and unanticipated direction, and annihilate Yorktown, or pour shells into rebel camps along the James River. At all events, he has furnished the best possible commentary upon the charge of inhumanity which the London Times brings against our Northern campaigning. A city, which had lost its character of a loyal and pacific town, and had suffered itself to become purely a military post, is entitled to no such notice, and its extension is, therefore, an act of exalted benevolence. It remains to be seen how it will affect Gen. HUGER. He may give it so frank an acceptance, as to include the men, as well as the women and children, in the removal -- a step that would very courteously assist the plans of the National General. When, a few years ago, the plague was in Norfolk, and an army of Northern nurses invaded the town, it was observed that not only the women and children, but the men, abandoned it.

abstract: One immediate consequence of Mr. CAMERON leaving for St. Petersburgh, will be the introduction of vitality into every arm of military service at Washington.
lead_paragraph: -- One immediate consequence of Mr. CAMERON leaving for St. Petersburgh, will be the introduction of vitality into every arm of military service at Washington. It is notorious that one-half the requisitions of Gen. MCCLELLAN for the means to effect an advance have been disregarded. Notwithstanding the enormous purchases of arms, vast numbers of which have been landed in this country, a large proportion of the army is furnished with the old-fashioned smooth-bore musket. It was with this latter weapon our brave fellows were sent at Ball's Bluff to encounter the Enfield and Minie rifles of the rebels, capable of mowing down thrice their number, furnished with the less effective arm. And it was because no means of water transportation or pontoons were provided, though urgently demanded by the General-in-chief, that our brave fellows were so sacrificed on that occasion; and that a general advance has been rendered difficult if not impracticable.

abstract: The sons of New-Hampshire, resident in NewYork, extended a cordial welcome to the Seventh New-Hampshire Regiment yesterday, as the latter passed through the City, en route for the seat of war.
lead_paragraph: The sons of New-Hampshire, resident in New-York, extended a cordial welcome to the Seventh New-Hampshire Regiment yesterday, as the latter passed through the City, en route for the seat of war. In the evening a dinner was given to the officers at the Metropolitan Hotel. The repast was expressly designed to meet the sharp appetites of soldiers, and abounded not only in substantials, but in some of the delicacies which the Messrs. LELAND know so well how to prepare. The arrangements were excellently made by the Committee, Messrs. N. HUGGINS, E.P. BUDD, H.B. PERKINS, W.N. BROWN, GEORGE F. PETERSON, C.A. SOULE, and JOSEPH CUSHING.

abstract: Editorial on Confederacy efforts to design another flag
snippet: Editorial on Confederacy efforts to design another flag
lead_paragraph: The Southern Confederacy deserves the commiseration of every pitiful heart for the coils and cares it has had all along of its flag. Somehow or other they can't succeed in getting the bit of bunting just to their mind. It formed the chief subject of deliberation at the first sitting of the rebel Congress months ago. Finally, after a period of incubation, compared with which the hatching of the ovum mundi whereof SANCONIATHON speaks, was a light and frivolous task, the "Committee of the Flag" rushed out, shouting eureka, and bearing in triumph the "Stars and Bars." But it seems the people have wearied of the thing. Perhaps the cause has not, under its inspiration, advanced quite to their mind. Perhaps they find it a constant reproach, from the slight likeness which it retains to that glorious old standard sheet which they have tried in vain to trail in the dust. Perhaps they are merely fickle, and want a change anyhow.

abstract: Article on past taxation and war finances
snippet: Article on past taxation and war finances
lead_paragraph: It may be useful, at the present moment, to state some facts relative to the fiscal system developed in England during the twenty-three years of almost constant war which closed with the battle of Waterloo. For they throw no small fight upon several questions of taxation and war finance which, in the present crisis of our national affairs, are filling the public mind with anxiety and eager desire for information. During the whole period from 1793 to 1815, it is well known that the energies and resources of the British people were put to the severest trial. A large proportion of the wealth-producing classes was sent abroad in the army or navy, or employed in unproductive labor. Subsidies and loans were advanced to foreign Powers. The home markets were not, as in our present struggle, benefited by the war funds being spent in the country. Commerce was for years preyed on by hostile cruisers. English goods were prohibited from entering the continent of Europe. Yet, amidst much individual suffering, and in spite of all that a NAPOLEON, wielding the strength of the twenty-eight millions of France, could do for its destruction, the British nation prospered and grew rich with a rapidity and steadiness seldom seen in the history of nations. The war cry seemed to rouse the energetic masses of the British people from their lethargy. The indomitable spirit which gave victory to battalions in the field, fired the hearts of the peaceful workers of the productive army at home, and stirred all classes and all men to labor, to save and to accumulate capital. Hence, in the words of one of England's greatest statesmen, "commerce and war flourished side by side and both achieved unwonted victories."
headline: {'main': 'TAXATION AND WAR FINANCES IN ENGLAND.; Uprise of the Actual System--Its Loading Traits--Its Defects--Characteristics and Principles Appropriate to America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'TAXATION AND WAR FINANCES IN ENGLAND.; Uprise of the Actual System--Its Loading Traits--Its Defects--Characteristics and Principles Appropriate to America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: EXPENSIVE FIREWOOD. -- For several months past extensive depredations have been committed upon the ship-yard of Messrs. MARTIN & GRANT, in Hudson-street, Jersey City, and plank, pieces of spars, knees and various kinds of ship timber, valued at several hundred dollars, have disappeared in a mysterious manner, notwithstanding efforts were made to detect the thieves. On Friday the Police discovered about $25 worth of the timber in a yard in the rear of the tenement-house known as the "Canary Castle," in Sussex-street. The supposed thief -- a shoemaker -- made his escape.

abstract: The destination of the Burnside flotilla is the occasion of much sagacity on the part of certain of our newspapers; also of some bad faith.
lead_paragraph: The destination of the Burnside flotilla is the occasion of much sagacity on the part of certain of our newspapers; also of some bad faith. One journal, of insignificant circulation, reproves another with having disclosed the precise spot prematurely, and itself hastens to lay before its readers "full details" of the organization of the expedition; a description of matter which the Press was distinctly pledged to withhold until the success of the movement had been announced. Fortunately, these "full details" so abound with errors, as to convey nothing but misinformation to the enemy. But the "precise spot," so untimely revealed, is upon the coast of North Carolina, within the sand bank which frames Pamlico and Albemarle Sounds; "not to put too fine a point upon it," it is Roanoke Island. And over this momentous and tremendous disclosure, the prints we refer to exhibit a degree of tremulous agitation, proportioned to the magnitude of the announcement.

abstract: Editorial attacks inflammatory editorial policy of NY Herald on war; Editorials on proposed bill to tax newspapers; Editorial on Confederacy efforts to design another flag
snippet: Editorial attacks inflammatory editorial policy of NY Herald on war; Editorials on proposed bill to tax newspapers; Editorial on Confederacy efforts to design another flag
lead_paragraph: The Herald, with that facility forlying which distinguishes it, had the audacity the other day to assert that the impetus which trade and labor have received verifies what it had all along predicted. This does not even rise to the dignity of the Herald's favorite ideal -- a "lie well told." It is a pitifully bungled and botched concern, plainly showing that the erst nimble apprentice of the Father of lies is losing the only talent he over possessed. For if there is one thing in which the Herald ever was consistent, day after day, week after week, and month after month, from the time of the election of Mr. LINCOLN up to its remarkable conversion to better principles after the fall of Sumter, it was in the damnable iteration with which it proclaimed the certain and irretrievable ruin that would befall the commercial and laboring classes, unless immediate submission were made to the rule of JEFF. DAVIS and his rebel crew. Scarcely a day was allowed to pass without flaming editorials on the "Impending Anarchy," "Fearful Times Ahead," etc., etc., and the following are but mild specimens of its daily diabolical predictions and instigations:

abstract: Editorial on Union loyalty in parts of Tennessee
snippet: Editorial on Union loyalty in parts of Tennessee
lead_paragraph: As there is prospect of a speedy military advance upon Tennessee, its real condition with respect to the rebellion becomes a matter of the greatest interest. It is the only seceded State, if we except Western Virginia, which has representatives in the National Congress: JOHNSON in the Senate, and Messrs. MAYNARD and CLEMENS in the House. It is the only seceded State that has regiments of loyal troops in the National service. In the eastern part of the State, loyalty, protesting and fighting loyalty, is greatly in the ascendant. In the central section, refugees aver that the same spirit is now becoming dominant; and even in the West, where treason has been most rampant, it is evident, from many signs, that there is still an undercurrent of Unionism, which will appear strong and active as soon as the people are relieved by our army from the terrorism inaugurated by the rebel leaders. We have published scores of news items, lately, from the Tennessee rebel papers, stating that bodies of Unionists, numbering from a dozen to a hundred, had been arrested by the rebels in counties west (as well as east) of the Tennessee River -- in Hardeman, Madison, Gibson, Dyer, &c.; while other counties, as Weakley, are declared to be dangerously Union. Some of these loyal men have been imprisoned, others impressed into the rebel army; and others, hopeless of the success of the National arms, have taken the rebel oath of allegiance.

abstract: A voluntary police, or military guard of some kind, is urged by the Nashville Union and American, as necessary to protect the public property in Nashville, and to guard the city against incendiaries, who are suspected of being at work. It thinks that a volunteer force might be raised in Nashville, from those who are necessarily kept from going into camps, and thus save the necessity of withdrawing any force available in the field. The Union and American thinks that there are evidences of the presence of incendiaries too palpable to be overlooked. Its remarks are forcible, practical, and important.

abstract: -- The developments which have been made since the Government entered earnestly upon the work of ferreting out those engaged in the Slave-trade, show that New-Bedford has been the scene of active operations, and that the business of fitting out as unsuspicious whalers vessels really intended for the Slave-trade has been carried on to a considerable extent; but the reputation of that city is redeemed by the fact, that the money and means used in the business has been furnished by parties in New-York.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner, of the 9th inst., says "The movement of Gen. JACKSON towards Romney and the Northwest has at length taken place, and it is no imprudence to write of it. It was projected and the column organized two months ago, but delayed until lately by that delusion which prevailed with the Government and the people of the South, that the enemy were to make a general advance of their troops, and risk a great battle this Winter. Hence the troops under JACKSON were placed at Winchester, where they could be conveniently used either in an engagement with MCCLELLAN or on the original aggressive intention. Time having expludes the notion of a decisive battle at Manassas during this Winter, Gen. Jackson has thus late commenced his operations. While we do not choose to refer to them further than to state that they are aggressive, we cannot help noticing that fact. While the people of the South have submitted in silence to the defective policy of the Government, it is certain that the majority of thinking people have been opposed to it."

abstract: The Fredericksburgh Recorder of the 3d says that on the previous Saturday night some ten or more negroes, belonging to W.W. TAYLOR, of Mount Airy, and the estate of ROBERT W. CARTER, of Sabine Hall, Richmond County, Va., succeeded in making their escape, it is supposed to the vessels maintaining the blockade of the Rappahannock at its mouth. They succeeded by making use of a boat kept by the overseer of the Sabine Hall tract for the purpose of going to and from a duck-blind. The negroes told one of their number they intended to have a salute fired on their arrival aboard the Federal steamer, and about 4 o'clock on Sunday evening the reports of the discharge of two cannon were distinctly heard.

abstract: During the month of December, 1861, and thus far in January, 1862, some twenty-five British vessels, loaded with grain, bound to Europe, from this port, have been lost. Most of this grain was insured on the other side. In every case these vessels were loaded by means of elevators, which requires but a few hours to load a large-sized vessel. The grain loaded by this method cannot be properly stored in the hold, in consequence of the danger of the grain overrunning the men and suffocating them. The dust arising from the grain renders it impossible for a man to remain in the hold over an hour at a time. Then, again, the grain has no chance to settle or become packed as in the old method of stevedoring, so that when the vessel is in motion, it shifts to the leeward, and works through the celling into the pump wells, causing the boxes to be choked. It is believed there is no agent of Lloyds in this city who makes it a special business to look after this matter. American vessels loading with grain, and some others whose cargoes are insured on this side, are under the immediate supervision of Capt. THOMAS D. TAYLOR, of the Board of Underwriters. Experience has taught the underwriters the necessity of putting a large share of the grain in bags, and the remainder in bulk. Losses of vessels, from the cause specified, are recorded in our shipnews columns of to-day.

abstract: A correspondent  writes to urge the publication in the TIMES of the facts brought out by the Van Wyck Investigating Committee, with the names of those...
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent writes to urge the publication in the TIMES of the facts brought out by the Van Wyck Investigating Committee, with the names of those who, "instead of aiding their bleeding country, aid in bleeding their country." We have only to say, the Report of that Committee is not yet complete, or accessible for publication; and we doubt, even if it were, whether it would answer our purpose to reprint a volume of a thousand pages in these already over-taxed columns. There have been made public a few leaves of the Report; but we were unable to discover the equity which governed the choice of two or three cases thus to be brought prematurely and of course more prominently before the public; and therefore refrained from assisting in their publicity. The wisdom of this course has been justified by the fact that investigations in the more conspicuous of these cases have been resumed; and we should have been guilty of the injustice of publishing ex parte testimony in advance of the entire case.

abstract: WALTER GLOVER, known as the carrier between Dunfries and Edinburgh, in the time of BURNS, died on Sunday last, at Ferneyside, in his native parish at Liberton -- an extraordinary example of longevity, being in his 104th year, having been born on the 18th of July, 1758. Of late there have been recorded the deaths of persons of from seventy to fourscore years who were able to say that when children they had seen our great national bard; but here was a man who was born before the poet himself, and had frequent occasion to meet and converse with him, a recollection the old man warmly treasured. When BURNS was exciseman at Dumfries, rum was extensively imported there, and GLOVER was frequently employed to convey it to Edinburgh. The permits on these occasions required to be signed by the poet, and, contingent on the arrival of the vessels, these documents were often required either at a very late or a very early hour. GLOVER was wont to state, as a proof of BURN's regularity and business habits, that sometimes when he used to apologise for disturbing him at these untimely hours, the poet said: "WALTER, it is but my duty, and never hesitate at any hour to call on me to do it." GLOVER and his connection with BURNS were thus alluded to at the Great Centenary Meeting in Edinburgh, the 25th of January, 1850. The Chairman (Lord ARDMILLAN) said: "I understand that we have now present among us in this great assemblage the only man who saw the day which this day celebrates -- one man alone, when generations have been swept to their graves, lives to be present now who lived when BURNS was born. There is a man in this rooom who is now more than 100 years of age -- (loud cheers) -- who was alive when the poet BURNS was born, and who personally knew that immortal man. He is here in this room -- Mr. WALTER GLOVER -- who was the carrier between Dumfries and Edinburgh in the days of BURNS, who has seen BURNS, whose eye has met the eye of BURNS, whose voice has met the voice of BURNS, whose ear has heard the words of BURNS." [Loud cheers.] Mr. WALTER GLOVER then ascended the platform amidst loud cheers, and to the amazement of the audience, recited "Tam o'Shanter" from beginning to end with a strong voice, and with "due emphasis and discretion." Till within the last twelve-month this memorable old man was in the habit of walking frequently to Edinburgh -- a distance of between three and four miles; and his chief enjoyment was sitting by the fireside playing his fiddle, which he did with considerable skill. Within the last two years he wrote out the poem of "Tam o'Shanter" in a bold, steady, legible hand, amazingly like the poet's handwriting, and this was done without the aid of spectacles. For the last few months Time has been laying his inexorable hand upon him, but very gently, and he retained possession of his faculties, his memory especially, to the very last. It is only a month ago that he was heard to relate with great unction some of his humorous stories, and to make some shrewd observations on recent and passing events. He was a great reader -- an enjoyment of which his failing sight nearly deprived him during the last year; and he had the rare gift of remembering every remarkable event he had seen, heard, or read of since he was three years old. He was kindly nursed and attended by his daughter -- a very worthy person, who has hitherto maintained herself, and supplemented the parochial allowance to her father, by what she earned at outdoor labor. -- Edinburgh Scotsman.

abstract: Mr. COLFAX, with less than his usual good sense, has just introduced a bill into the House of Representatives to prohibit newspapers from being delivered on post roads except by the Government mails.
lead_paragraph: Mr. COLFAX, with less than his usual good sense, has just introduced a bill into the House of Representatives to prohibit newspapers from being delivered on post roads except by the Government mails. If the object of the measure is to increase the revenue, it must prove as bad an expedient as could well be devised. For so offensive a law would he evaded by the public in every possible way, and the heavy expenses entailed on the Department would more than absorb the largest possible proceeds of the tax. And not only would there be failure in point of productiveness. This fiscal expedient would be extremely unpopular in this country, and would expose us to universal derision abroad. For it has always been the boasted policy of our Government to foster the circulation and promote the prosperity of the public Press. Hence no people in the world have so many newspapers, nor does any country contain as many newspaper readers. And is it to be endured that, with the proud position of the United States, as regards newspaper enterprise, we should resort to a prohibitory enactment which could be enforced, or would be endured, in no European country? In England, the Government at no time have ventured to prevent the conveyance of newspapers by any method convenient to the sender. The British newspaper tax had its origin in an aristocratic jealousy of the people, and in a desire to prevent them from informing themselves on political subjects. But the impost was always odious. It has long been merely nominal, and was in 1840 repealed altogether. The use of the mails is now open to the Press as to other departments of public usefulness. But now, as always, it is optional to send papers by mail or by any other means. If sent by mail, the postage is two cents, which may be paid either by affixing a postage stamp to the wrapper, or by having a newspaper stamp impressed on the paper before it is printed. There is, however, this concession made by the English Government in favor of the impressed stamp. The newspaper bearing it is transmissible by mail as often as the owner pleases within fourteen days of publication. But the affixed postage stamp, though equal in cost, will only carry the newspaper once. Thus the English Government regards the stamp simply as payment for postage, and charges the public journals for the use of post-office facilities only when these facilities are employed. Perfect freedom being thus conceded, express agents have sprung up in England who convey newspapers to the public several hours earlier than they would be received by mail. The same plan has been adopted here with some improvements. We have hitherto been in advance of Europe in almost every department of newspaper enterprise. The country now needs more than ever the influence of enlightened journalism. Shall we voluntarily recede from our position and without any benefit to the revenue, cause serious inconvenience to the public? If newspapers are to be taxed at all, let the impost be laid by some method which will be as little open as possible to the objections which must lie against all taxes on knowledge.

abstract: This regiment, which has, for some weeks past, been quartered at Albany, arrived here yesterday morning by the Hudson River Railroad. It is composed of a remarkably fine body of men, who have
lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has, for some weeks past, been quartered at Albany, arrived here yesterday morning by the Hudson River Railroad. It is composed of a remarkably fine body of men, who have been chiefly recruited in the Northern counties of the State. Of the field officers, three, the Colonel, Major and Adjutant, are old West Pointers, and, though not practiced in actual service, they must needs derive many advantages from the lessons of early military training. The regiment is filled up to the regulation standard, is well drilled, uniformed in the costume of the regular army, and, altogether, presents a splendid appearance when upon the march. They are, at present, without arms, but Enfield rifles are to be distributed to them before they leave the City. Some thirty men of Company A, who are experienced sharpshooters, carry their own rifles. The following is a roster of the officers:

abstract: The Ninety-second Regiment, Col. SANDFORD, received a handsome and costly regimental flag or Tuesday last, at their camp ground, Potsdam, St. Lawrence Co., the gift of Mr. J.S. CLARKSON, a resident of the place. The flag is of dark blue silk, full size, and seamless. It is beautifully painted, bearing on its broad folds the State and Union arms, with the number of the regiment and the motto, "Deo Fidendum" on an elegant standard mounted with a silver spear, and presented by Mr. CLARKSON in an appropriate speech. Col. SANDFORD's response was brief but impressively patriotic -- accepting the banner in behalf of the regiment -- pledging their honor and lives to defend it, and concluded by calling for three cheers for the family of the donors and the citizens of Potsdam.
lead_paragraph: The Ninety-second Regiment, Col. SANDFORD, received a handsome and costly regimental flag or Tuesday last, at their camp ground, Potsdam, St. Lawrence Co., the gift of Mr. J.S. CLARKSON, a resident of the place. The flag is of dark blue silk, full size, and seamless. It is beautifully painted, bearing on its broad folds the State and Union arms, with the number of the regiment and the motto, "Deo Fidendum" on an elegant standard mounted with a silver spear, and presented by Mr. CLARKSON in an appropriate speech. Col. SANDFORD's response was brief but impressively patriotic -- accepting the banner in behalf of the regiment -- pledging their honor and lives to defend it, and concluded by calling for three cheers for the family of the donors and the citizens of Potsdam.

abstract: Editorial sees Missouri soon ceasing to be area of battle
snippet: Editorial sees Missouri soon ceasing to be area of battle
lead_paragraph: It does not seem likely that these will be much more fighting in Missouri this winter -- if indeed ever again. Gen. PRICE is still at Springfield with some seven or eight thousand men; but as, at the beginning of the present year, he became a "Major General of the Confederate States," (instead of, as heretofore, a General of the Missouri State Guard,) and as he is now under command of JEFF. DAVIS, it is likely that he and his men will be ordered to some point where they can be of practical service. The Richmond leaders must see the hopelessness of the rebel cause at least in Missouri; and they will not be willing to waste powder and men, out of a mere romantic desire to uphold its "rights," as PRICE has done. But if he be not at once ordered to another field, he will undoubtedly stampede the State rapidly enough as soon as the National expedition now forming at Leavenworth is put in motion. At one time the rebellion in Missouri looked formidable; but the army of fifty thousand flushed rebels which marched to Lexington on its way to Jefferson City and St. Louis, has dwindled and scattered; and the second fifty thousand, whom PRICE urged in such piteous terms to rally to his standard, never responded to the call. Not more than five thousand of the "State Guard" transferred their services to the regular rebel army. The rest have quietly gone back to their homes and farms for the Winter, tired of soldiering and rebellion. It is said by PRICE's organ that they have only disbanded for the Winter, and that they are to rejoin him in the Spring; but the system of military police now in operation over the greater part of the State, and which by Spring will be extended over the whole of it, will prevent the formation of these rebel squads, or their coming together anywhere, if any of them should be formed. Henceforward there is prospect of some irregular guerilla fighting, and irruptions of bodies of rebel marauders at one point or another over the State; but so far as the rebel campaign of conquest is concerned, it must soon be formally, as it is at present in fact, abandoned.

abstract: For a long time past the Herald has been endeavoring to impose upon the public the utterly false belief that its daily circulation was very far beyond that of the TIMES and other City journals.
lead_paragraph: For a long time past the Herald has been endeavoring to impose upon the public the utterly false belief that its daily circulation was very far beyond that of the TIMES and other City journals. Its object in this was to create an impression favorable to its superiority over the TIMES as a medium of advertising. From an unwillingness to obtrude purely business affairs upon public attention, and especially to engage in any controversy with that sheet on such a point, we forebore for months to take any notice of its fabrications. But in justice to ourselves we determined to test the Herald's disposition to back up its own veracity -- and offered to stake a certain sum of money on the utter falsehood of each and every one of its assertions concerning its own circulation and concerning ours.
