abstract: A Norfolk correspondent of the Richmond Dispatch, under date of Jan. 13, writes: "Yesterday the Burnside expedition cleared from the place of rendezvous, and went beyond the Capes. This morning there was a high wind and some rain.
lead_paragraph: A Norfolk correspondent of the Richmond Dispatch, under date of Jan. 13, writes: "Yesterday the Burnside expedition cleared from the place of rendezvous, and went beyond the Capes. This morning there was a high wind and some rain. This evening there is a rumor that the expedition returned again, and that the ships are riding out the gale in Hampton Roads. It may be, however, that these ships are merely others of the same armada, which will join their fellows when able to put to sea. Tonight the storm is increasing, and the rain beats furiously against the windows as I write the words 'good night.'

lead_paragraph: We have from Washington, this morning, the first indication that a forward movement of the Grand Army of the Potomac may be looked for to occur soon. A General Order has been issued by Gen. McCLELLAN, notifying all persons engaged in the military service to hold themselves in readiness. abstract: The City Hospital at the Navy-yard is now in successful operation, in care of Dr. CRACRAFT. There are a number of poor patients under treatment there. It has been suggested that a great deal of good can be done by persons having old clothes and sending them there for the poor patients. Many there are very poorly clad, and there is scarcely a gentleman who has not some garment that can easily be spared. Let all such send their spare clothes to the care of Dr. CRACRAFT, and they will be appropriately distributed to the aggregation of the comfort of the poor.

abstract: Last evening was one of unusual interest in the lofty abode of the newsboys. They were addressed in an instructive and entertaining manner by Mr.  MOSES BRACH, who traced the enterprise of estab lishing the Lodging-House back to its earliest introduction to his notice by Mr. BRACE, and declared that he laughed in his sleeves when the proposition to rent his upper rooms for the purpose was broached; but
lead_paragraph: Last evening was one of unusual interest in the lofty abode of the newsboys. They were addressed in an instructive and entertaining manner by Mr. MOSES BRACH, who traced the enterprise of estab lishing the Lodging-House back to its earliest introduction to his notice by Mr. BRACE, and declared that he laughed in his sleeves when the proposition to rent his upper rooms for the purpose was broached; but acceded with heart and soul to the object without the slightest faith in its success. He remembered when there were but twenty-fire newsboys, and taking a retrospect of twenty-five years, he drew contrasts between experiences of thrift and neglect which had some under his observation from that time to the present, when no less than 500 youthful venders represented this branch of trade.

abstract: A letter was received on the 3d at LLOYD's from the Secretary of the Admiralty, stating that the Inspecting Commander of the Coast Guard at Ramsgate had reported that a suspicious-looking steamer was seen cruising about the channel, off Dover, on the 27th ult., which, from circumstances since transpired, there is every reason to suppose it was the Confederate privateer Sumter. It appears that the Sumter, when last heard of by the federal navy, was seen making in the direction of Europe. The Sumter is about 1,600 tons, painted black, and very fast.

abstract: A glance at the theatrical announcements for the present week reveals the curious fact that in va  riety and healthfulness of entertainment the Metropolis was never more happily circumstanced than it is now. The fact is curious simply because in the best of times January is regarded as a period of hard managerial struggle against adverse weather and public indifference. This year there were other circum
lead_paragraph: A glance at the theatrical announcements for the present week reveals the curious fact that in va riety and healthfulness of entertainment the Metropolis was never more happily circumstanced than it is now. The fact is curious simply because in the best of times January is regarded as a period of hard managerial struggle against adverse weather and public indifference. This year there were other circumstances that threatened to be utterly calamitous to art. The most enterprising of our caterers looked forward with gloomy apprehensions to the dull season; but lo! the dull season is here, and instead of empty benches and yawning treasuries, we find eager audiences crowding to all our places of amusement, and struggling at the box offices for the privilege of depositing their Treasury Notes -- green leaves more welcome than those of Spring to the gentlemen on whom they are showered. During the past week all the Broadway theatres were taxed to their greatest capacity, and two operatic performances at the Academy of Music, although they attracted several thousands of spectators, did not have the effect of diminishing the nightly throngs that paid homage to the drama.

abstract: The Baltimore American calls attention to the fact that we have had no demonstration of disloyalty so far as is known, from Hon. A.O.P. NIOHOLSON, of Tennessee, ex-colleague in the Senate of Hon. ANDREW JOHNSON, who was compelled to vacate his seat at Washington, under the pressure of the Secession sentiment gotten up by Gov. HARRIS at Nashville. His silence, when taken in connection with the active loyalty of his colleague, the Hon. ANDREW JOHNSON is full of moaning, since a man of his mark could hardly have been well overlooked as a needed cooperater at Richmond, had his sentiments been in full accord with those of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS and his immediate supporters.

lead_paragraph: The signs of immediate and general movement along the entire line of the army, from Kansas to Port Royal, are unmistakable. The significant revocation of furloughs was hardly needed to prove activity to be the order of the day. The accelerated departure of the boat expeditions, East and West, the concentration of a strong naval force at Fortress Monroe, the dispatch of reinforcements to Port Royal and Ship Island, the readiness of Capt. PORTER's mortar squadron for departure from this port, and the fact that means of transportation are now supplied to the entire army, are proofs that the era of preparation is ended, and that of action begun.

abstract: We attach no importance to the rumor that further changes are to be made in the Cabinet. We see no reason for such changes, and are confident that, in the absence of any special occasion for them, the President would be unwilling to make them. It is always hazard
lead_paragraph: We attach no importance to the rumor that further changes are to be made in the Cabinet. We see no reason for such changes, and are confident that, in the absence of any special occasion for them, the President would be unwilling to make them. It is always hazardous, especially when great responsibilities press upon the Government, to change the personnel of an Administration. It is very apt to be regarded as an indication of weakness; and in time of war the enemy will certainly treat it as a symptom of divided and enfeebled councils. The President's disposition, moreover, has from the beginning been very decided against replacing any members of that Cabinet with which he entered upon the administration of our National affairs. He retained Mr. CAMERON long after he had lost the public confidence, because he was unwilling to do anything which might look like, or lead to, a general disruption of the Cabinet. And when he finally decided upon his dismissal, it was from a conviction that it was absolutely essential to the public good, and upon grounds not applicable to any other Department than that over which he presided.
headline: {'main': 'The Changes in the Cabinet.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Changes in the Cabinet.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SEVEN HUNDRED DOLLARS' WORTH OF PROPERTY STOLEN: THE REOEIYER SENT TO THE TOMBS. A young German, named HENRY MILLER, was arraigned yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY, at the lower Police Court, charged with stealing property to the amount of $700, from his employer, BENJAMIN MARKS, dealer in cloths, at No. 107 William-street, during the last year. For several months Past the proprietor of
lead_paragraph: SEVEN HUNDRED DOLLARS' WORTH OF PROPERTY STOLEN: -- THE RECEIVER SENT TO THE TOMBS. -- A young German, named HENRY MILLER, was arraigned yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY, at the lower Police Court, charged with stealing property to the amount of $700, from his employer, BENJAMIN MARKS, dealer in cloths, at No. 107 William-street, during the last year. For several months Past the proprietor of the establishment has missed large quantities of cloth, and other articles, but it was no until very recently that any evidence could be obtained tending to implicate MILLER, in the transaction. Officer NIVEN, of the Second Precinct, arrested the accused, who, on being conveyed to the Station-house, made a partial confession of the crime. He admitted having taken two pieces of cassimere cloth on the 14th inst. The total value of these pieces was $60. MILLER furthermore stated that he would not have stolen the cloth, had it not been for the urgent persuasion of a man named HEYMAN GEIGERMAN, who is a cap-maker, doing business at No. 415 Eighth-avenue. The two pieces of cloth just mentioned were sold to the latter for the sum of $15. A piece of silk velvet, taken from Mares' store, valued at $28, was disposed of to GEIGERMAN for the small consideration of an ordinary cloth cap, valued at $1. MILLER also states that GEIGERMAN has urged other clerks in the store of M. MARKS to rob their employer and sell the goods to him. Upon the information thus received, Officer NIVEN proceeded to Mr. GEIGERMAN's place of business and took him into custody as the receiver of stolen property. In his possession were found some of the goods which had been stolen from Mr. MARKS. Justice CONNOLLY yesterday sent MILLER to the House of Detention as a witness, and the other prisoner was committed to the Tombs for trial.

abstract: We are requested by Gen. DIX to deny, in the most positive manner, the authenticity of a conversation reported to have taken place between himself and a lady styled Mrs. W -----, which was published in the South of yesterday afternoon, and purported to be copied from a Richmond paper. He says there is no truth whatever in it, so far as he is concerned; no such conversation ever took place, for the reason that he never saw nor spoke to the lady.

abstract: Capt. PORTER describes his encounter with the rebel gunboats near Columbus, we give in another column. The engagement, already described in the correspondence of the TIMES, took place on the 10th inst., when, with two vessels, the Union commander put to flight twice the number of the enemy's boats, disabling one at least, and driving all of them for shelter beneath the guns of Columbus. An exploit of this sort might reasonably authorize a little vainglory; but the worthy son of a here refers to it with the modesty of genuine merit. The bulletins in which Gen. TAYLOR made famous his campaign on the Rio Grande belong to the same manly school of military literature.

abstract: The largest and most capacious carrier of the Cunard line of steamers is the Australasian. During the recent phrenzy in England growing out of the Trent affair, she was takon up by the British Government as a transport for Canada. She was filled to her utmost
lead_paragraph: The largest and most capacious carrier of the Cunard line of steamers is the Australasian. During the recent phrenzy in England growing out of the Trent affair, she was takon up by the British Government as a transport for Canada. She was filled to her utmost capacity with soldiers, and ordnance, and small arms, and hurried off to Halifax, where it seems the charter was made conditionally to expire. She then came round to New-York, consigned to Mr. CUNARD, Jr., who took up a freight of American breadstuffs and provisions, the largest, perhaps, that has cleared from this port for many months, and yesterday morning the good ship sailed for Liverpool, on a mission of peace and plenty!

lead_paragraph: the proposition brought forward in Congress to require all newspapers to be conveyed through the mail. Such a proposition would take effect mainly upon the newspapers published in the large cities, especially in NewYork, from which not less than one hundred thousand newspapers are sent every day into the interior by express companies, and in packages over the various railroad routes. What they gain by this is dispatch. They can reach their subscribers and the public at large in this way much sooner than if sent by mail: and this is a consideration of the very first importance to them.

abstract: As our political relations with the Northern States of America still continue of a most unsatisfactory nature, and as there is no prospect of a speedy reopeding of the Southern ports fo Trade, it becomes necessary that we should enter into some details in reference to that great staple, Cotton, viewed in relation to imports, consumption, stock, speculation, and foreign demand. The year 1861 opened with an adverse movement in the Bank rate for accommodation, and the result was that great disinclination was shown to speculate in the article, even at a reduction in the quotations of 1/2d. lb. In the second quarter, however, owing to the impending civil war, the market became somewhat excited, and prices advanced 3/4d. lb., Middling Orleans having touched 8d. lb. in June. During the following four months the currencies improved 2d. lb.; but in November, arising from a great falling off in the demand on the part of our spinners, prices were slightly reduced. At one time, indeed, a few forced sales took place at 2d. lb. less money. The year closed, however, with some firmness, at 11 7/8d. per lb. for middling Orleans. Thus it will be perceived that the trade has been in a most uncertain state, and surprise may well be expressed, considering that we have imported 739,330 bales less cotton from America than in 1860, that the quotations have not exhibited a far higher range. The fact appears to be, that the large operators in the article have wholly miscalculated the power of India to furnish us with additional supplies. At one period we were told that it would be impossible to draw larger quantities from the East, whatever might be the price offered for it; but official returns inform us that the arrivals from Bombay were 986,290 bales, or 423,550 bales more than in the previous year. This is certainly a most gratifying feature in the trade, because it proves that, eventually, with due care in the cultivation, we may become wholly independent of the States for any amount of supply that we can possibly consume. It may, however, be asserted that we shall never be able to produce elsewhere the exact quality of cotton used in our manufacturing districts -- consequently, that it cannot come into competition with American importations; but those who hold the doctrine that we cannot exist as a great manufacturing and exporting country without States cotton, will probably find that -- though, for the moment, we may suffer some inconvenience and loss from a falling off in our usual quality, and from comparatively high quotations -- English enterprise, skill, and intelligence will, at no distant period, triumph over the prejudice In favor of Southern productions. They have found an extensive market here, simply from their low value and good quality; but if our usual importations are to be withheld for another year, and if we continue to offer a reasonable price to all the world, there will be no want of supply to meet our necessities. In 1860, India furnished us with 562,740 bales: but, in 1861, the arrivals from that quarter were 986,290 bales, as above stated. At one period, we estimated the quantity at 1,000,000 bales, and, subsequently, at 1,250,000 bales, allowing in the latter estimate twelve months [???] Bombay. It will therefore, be seen that [???] first calculation only exceeds by 13,710 bales the actual quantity arrived in, be it observed, a most uncertain and fluctuating market. As there were no large operations in India during the first two months of the year, the supply of 986,290 bales must be considered as merely the effect of ten months' transactions. Give the East a fair scope for the whole twelve months, and the advantage to be derived from highly remunerative prices, and the whole quantity we have stated will be forthcoming.

abstract: There is a single fact which the bullionists are either too blind to see, or else willfully ignore. The national debt of Great Britain is held by some 17,000 persons. If we depend simply upon Bonds, paying interest, our whole indebtedness say $1,000,000,000  will soon be in the hands of a few thousand capitalists.
lead_paragraph: There is a single fact which the bullionists are either too blind to see, or else willfully ignore. The national debt of Great Britain is held by some 17,000 persons. If we depend simply upon Bonds, paying interest, our whole indebtedness say $1,000,000,000 will soon be in the hands of a few thousand capitalists. What is the consequence, both to themselves and to the country? It is simply this. The millions of voters who do not own a penny in the debt, and only feel, year after year, the increasing pressure of taxation, will raise the question, sooner or later, Shall we continue to impoverish ourselves, in order to swell the incomes of non-laboring capitalists? WE WON'T DO IT. Then comes, first, as in Great Britain, a reduction of the rate of interest on the funded debt of the country; and next, REPUDIATION.

abstract: It was naturally supposed that, elected under such diverse and irreconcilable elements, Mr. RAYMOND would find difficulty in satisfying his friends in the formation of his Committees. This expectation has not been disappointed. The distribution of his favors would appear to have introduced universal discord. None but the holders of the particular prizes appear to be satisfied. The Republican Party does not seem to have been consulted as a general rule, nor is any particular section in the possession of sufficient cause for congratulation. We believe that he has been actuated by a determination to place none but honest men in the responsible positions, but he has disregarded the claims of men from this section of the State, at least, and especially from this City, whose characters entitled them to more prominent recognition. The New-York delegation, with the exception of Mr. RAYMOND's personal friends, PHELPS and CODDINGTON, have particularly suffered. CODDINGTON, a novice to legislation, has been placed on the Committee on Cities -- the most desirable position for a representative from this City -- over old members of legislative experience. We learn that Dr. KENNY was the choice of the New-York delegation for this position, but their influence was disregarded. Even NOAH. A. CHILDS suffered badly in the double shuffle. CHILDS, it will be remembered, was elected in the Eleventh District of this City on a Republican nomination, and attended the Republican Legislative caucus, voting there, and afterwards in the House, for Mr. RAYMOND. It was said that he was to receive special consideration -- but he failed of his prize, if not price, and was very inhumanly left out in the cold.

abstract: During the last month our regiment (the First Wisconsin) has been occupied in the ordinary company, battalion and brigade drills, and in picket duty. The latter is the most tedious, as well as the most useful. One can searcely imagine anything more monotonous than waiting, in silent patience, in the same spot for twenty-four hours, meeting with no adventures, nothing in the world to divert the mind or exercise the body.

abstract: The British steamship Arabia, which left Liverpool on the 4th inst., and Queenstown on the 5th, arrived at this port about 1 o'clock this morning. She touched at Halifax to land troops and war material destined for Canada, and a telegraphic summary of her news was forwarded from that point. We give below, however, detalls tending to show more fully the spirit in which the affair of the Trent was treated, in view of the advices from America received by the Africa.

We give below, however, detalls tending to show more fully the spirit in which the affair of the Trent was treated, in view of the advices from America received by the Africa.

abstract: Those who wish to put up pork this season will have to do so between this and the 15th of February. After that it will be too late to cure it. We learn that some of our railroads, appreciating the importance of curing meat, have given directions to receive salt for packing purposes. All our railroads should adopt the same policy, and let the salt be sent forward with all possible dispatch. In this connection we would state that the Southern Express Company occasionally receives and transmits salt for actual meat-packers. They have occasionally taken salt to persons whose meat most needed it, and to accommodate me public they will continue to do so.

abstract: The London Spectator has usually been thought to be one of the English journals most amicably disposed toward this country, and one inclined to report facts as they are, and not, merely to regard American affairs according as they affect English politics. It is supposed to represent a good deal of the intelligent Whig sentiment, as regards this nation and its institutions.
lead_paragraph: The London Spectator has usually been thought to be one of the English journals most amicably disposed toward this country, and one inclined to report facts as they are, and not, merely to regard American affairs according as they affect English politics. It is supposed to represent a good deal of the intelligent Whig sentiment, as regards this nation and its institutions. That it should make occasionally most remarkable statements in regard to our geography, was to be expected from any well-educated British organ. That it should confuse our parties, and rank our public men in a manner which would slightly shock those gentlemen, was also to be anticipated. When a Quarterly, of the character of the Edinburgh Review, could commence a well-studied historical article on this struggle with an important blunder of the most palpable kind, and base thereon its argument, as all may see in the last October number, we surely should not expect great accuracy or wise judgment from a Weekly, however friendly its purpose.

abstract: Editorial sees indications of movements all along Union lines; Editorial on views of British journals
snippet: Editorial sees indications of movements all along Union lines; Editorial on views of British journals
lead_paragraph: In another place, under the Money and Commercial head, this morning, will be found our annual tables of the Foreign Trade of the port of New-York for the calendar year of 1861. They have been delayed a few weeks for the exact Custom-house figures for the closing month of December, and are now presented complete from official data. The results teach that a year of the greatest activity in selling abroad is not incompatible, in this country, with a season of civil war. They also teach that our people readily adapt themselves to the smallest possible amount of buying abroad when the warnings and necessities of domestic troubles, like the present, demand such economy. It was much regretted last Spring that the Morrill Tariff was onaeted, coincident with the threatenings of the civil war which broke out six weeks after its approval by the late Executive. It was believed to be inauspicious for the good feeling and sympathy which we had a right to look for from the great commercial States of Europe. And it is not improbable that it may have done us harm in this direction; though, from the recent conduct of England on questions growing out of the Southern rebellion, it now seems questionable whether any tariff on our side, short of practical free trade, would have altered the course of that portion of her Press and people who have thrown the whole weight of their influence against us, and their undisguised sympathies in favor of armed and unholy rebellion. Insomuch, therefore, as the Morrill Act has contributed to the question of domestic economy in season of War, we have probably less to regret now than we supposed we had in March last. At all events, it is not likely that we shall make haste to repeal its specific duties upon British manufactures to accommodate that particular interest. The staples of iron and iron fabrics, and of woolen goods, of which we are able to command an abundant supply at home, will, no doubt, remain taxed, as against English competition, as they now are, until the end of the war, if not for some time after. In this determination we may not hope to please the factors and special agents of the English interest referred to among us, but we shall, at least, consult our own sense of economy, and do no violence to our partialities for our own wares, which we have both the skill and abundant raw material to fabricate.
headline: {'main': 'What we Buy and Sell Abroad.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What we Buy and Sell Abroad.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Perhaps no patent granted in the Southern Confederacy has contributed so largely to supplying one of the great necessaries essential to civilized society, as that issued to Mr. E.J. PARK for the rapid manufacture of leather. Every day gives fresh evidence of the success of those embarked in the business, and abundant proof that wherever his system has gone into operation the requirements of the community are supplied with good leather, which at present is one of the most expensive luxuries of the South. We are indeed as much pleased as Mr. PARK must feel gratified, over the splendid success of his new system, and the letters of grateful acknowledgment he is daily receiving.

abstract: is reported to have hastened home to Missouri in order to resign his seat, and obtain an appointment as Senator in the place of TRUSTEN POLK. His disappointment would probably be more to the public interest. When the other day, the vacancy in the Senate, caused by the unseating of the recusant BROWN, was to be filled, it was filled by the selection of RODERT WILSON, a sympathizer with the rebellion, whose declarations to that effect were fresh and open. As this choice was made by GAMBLE himself, with the facts before him, we are justified in believing it typifies the secret sentiments of the Governor; and we are at a loss, therefore, to see in what particular the country is to gain in exchanging two bold and outspoken, traitors for two that are simply less courageous. Let us rather have POLK and BROWN back again.

abstract: Reports from Confederate States
snippet: Reports from Confederate States
lead_paragraph: If the war for the Union fail, its failure will probably be caused more by treason than by force of arms. There is every reason to believe that the success of the rebellion hitherto has been secured almost wholly by treasonable communications from trusted men in our own ranks or employed in the management of military affairs. Many such communications are known to have been made, and many more are suspected to have been made, ever since the beginning of the war. Again and again the Confederates have boasted of their previous knowledge of all the movements of our armies; and many facts have proved their boasts true. We have just learned a most astounding circumstance, which may well make every patriot's heart sink in dismay, and almost in despair. An officer of high character has informed us that, to his knowledge, on the day when the Pensacola ran the gauntlet of the rebel batteries, and before the usual hour for communicating the countersign of the day to our pickets opposite one of those batteries, the rebel pickets boatsfully shouted the correct countersign across the river, and added: "The Pensacola is coming down to-night!" What does this fact prove? It proves that the countersigns which are sent from the War Department to our camps, are made known to the rebels by traitors in confidential positions in or near that Department, and that other information in reference to contemplated movements of our naval forces is likewise communicated to the enemy! What is to be the end of alt this? Can there not be some purification of the departments, so as to save our country from the destruction that must otherwise result from such fearful treachery? The depressing fact is known that preference for the Southern rebellion, or base corruption, has led officers of Government to carry on, unsuspected, correspondence with the rebels to an extent unknown and undiscoverable. Shall no effort be made to unmask these vile traitors? If discovered, shall we "swear them and let them go," or shall we rather hang them to the first lamppost? If ever a crime deserved summary and extreme punishment, surely such a base betrayal of confidence as is shown by such acts should be most promptly and severely visited with the law's heaviest penalties. Whether prompted by love of the rebellion, or by bribes offered by the enemy, or by a mercenary wish to prolong the war, and profit by plundering the Government and the poor soldiers, such treason -- aggravated a thousand-fold by the confidence reposed in the traitors -- merits everlasting shame and contempt, and should receive such punishment-torture even-as will make the boldest forever shrink from following the base example.

abstract: The number of recruits enlisted in this City last week, for the regular army, amounted to about sixteen, of whom five were music-boys, who had been on trial for some time past on Governor's Island. Since July, 1861, the recruiting returns have been most unsatisfactory, as our weekly reports have shown; and although every effort has been made to obtain men, it appears to have been impossible for any office to get more than four or five men per week. In several cases offices have been open, in the country, from six weeks to two months without sending in a recruit of any kind. Under these circumstances, a change in the system is very desirable, if not probable.

abstract: The Potter Investigating Committee, appointed by Congress to inquire into the fidelity of Government employes, and especially of the clerks in the various Departments, have suspended the taking of testimony and are now preparing their report. This report will be voluminous,and, if report speaks true, of a character calculated to startle the country. The Committee, it is understood, have come
lead_paragraph: The Potter Investigating Committee, appointed by Congress to inquire into the fidelity of Government employes, and especially of the clerks in the various Departments, have suspended the taking of testimony and are now preparing their report. This report will be voluminous,and, if report speaks true, of a character calculated to startle the country. The Committee, it is understood, have come to the deliberate conclusion, after patient investigation, that there are in the Departments at least five hundred persons who are disloyal to the Government, and would rejoice to witness the success of the rebellion. It is understood, also, that the report will be very severe upon one or two heads of Departments who have thrown obstacles in the way of the Committee in their endeavors to ascertain the truth.

abstract: The citizens of the State of New York now residing in Washington, have formed a Society under the name of "The New-York Soldiers' Relief Association," for the purpose of receiving and distributing among our soldiers such contributions of hospital stores, clothing, or other articles, as may be forwarded for their benefit, and generally giving attention to their wants and necessities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C., Saturday, Jan. 18, 1862.

abstract: When the new postal law came into operation, Mr. BELL, postmaster for this City, to be on the safe side, determined that the postage of letters between this place and the States east should he increased from the three-cent to the ten-cent rate. As has been before observed, this change was by no means popular here, begetting a great deal of grumbling, and some personal feeling toward our then new Postmaster.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: -- An enterprising antiquarian has discovered that the happy epithet of "contraband," which Gen. BUTLER applied to the slaves of rebels, and which was at once universally recognized as both a pun and a stroke of genius, is not so much the impromptu inspiration it was thought to be. It seems the original author of the term is our present excellent Mayor, GEORGE OPDYKE. Ten years ago he published a treatise on Political Economy -- a book whose merit has never received adequate appreciation -- in one chapter of which, treating of Slavery, the following passage occurs: "Slaves are not often furnished, as they formerly were, by African traders, at the cheap rates of stolen goods -- the article being now contraband with us," etc. Now, it is not improbable that BUTLER's happy hit was a reminiscence of this, though it is not impossible -- for such coincidences do occur -- that similar reasonings brought out similar results. If BUTLER has been pilfering, one would like to know it. So good a thing should have its proper paternity. We venture to suggest the matter as a proper subject for inquiry by the V.W.C.I.C -- i.e., the Van Wyck Congressional Investigating Committee.
lead_paragraph: -- An enterprising antiquarian has discovered that the happy epithet of "contraband," which Gen. If BUTLER has been pilfering, one would like to know it. So good a thing should have its proper paternity. We venture to suggest the matter as a proper subject for inquiry by the V.W.C.I.C -- i.e., the Van Wyck Congressional Investigating Committee.

abstract: At 4 o'clock this morning the Pensacola passed by the rebel batteries, extending from Cockpit Point to the entrance of Chapawamsic Creek. As this has been expected for some time past, and was only postponed for the last few days on account of the prevailing fog and the quantity of ice in the river, great interest was manifested throughout the flotilia. The
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the Washington Star.

abstract: On Wednesday a detachment of the Royal Engineers, consisting of five officers and 120 men, together with C battery of the Royal Artillery, consisting of seven officers and 225 men, and No. 6 battery of the Royal Artillery, (garrison,) consisting of five officers and 117 men, accompanied by twelve men of the Army Hospital Corps, arrived in Liverpool by the London and Northwestern Railway. They marched down to the landing stage, and were immediately conveyed on board the Canadian Mail steamer Hibernian. Yesterday, a detachment of the First battallion of the Fifteenth Foot arrived from Dublin in the Dublin steamer Windsor. The detachment. which consisted of 5 officers and 147 men, was immediately transshipped from the Windsor to the Hibernian, which was to sail with them in the afternoon for New-Brunswick. The embarkation was most satisfactorily accomplished, under the able superintendence of Col. GRETHEAD, Quartermaster-General for the district, and Commander LEYCESTER, R.N., Admiralty agent for Liverpool. Besides the troops the Hibernian also took out twelve cabin passengers.

abstract: The bill makes it unlawful for any person to carry newspapers over any post route out of the mails. I object to this as interfering with the purchase and sale of merchandise by restricting the free transportation thereof. Newspapers, magazines and other printed matter are as much articles of merchandise as are dry goods, groceries, hardware or any other thing that enters into the consumption of the people, and should be subjected to no more hindrances in sale and transportation than they are. It is the duty of Government to encourage the production and consumption of home-manufactured articles, not to restrict such production, and if revenue be the object, let taxes be laid on the capital invested in and produced by the profits of manufacturing, whether such profits are made from the production of hats, boots, clothing or newspapers and books. The free and expeditious system of transporting printed matter outside of the mails that is now in practice is one of the most potent agents for the dissemination of knowledge among the people that has ever been devised, and is the result of long experience, prompted by the inability of the mail or post-office system to meet the emergencies of the case. From this system has grown the vast increase in the circulation of daily and weekly papers, magazines, &c., &c., and from this increased sale and circulation has grown a demand for a great amount of labor to produce the presses to print these papers for the paper on which they are printed, the ink they are printed with, machinery for the manufacture of the paper, for the production of twine, for the use of car's, wagons, &c.; in fact, there is scarcely a branch of industry that has not been affected beneficially by the increased sale and circulation of printed matter outside of the mails : and to interfere with these interests is to cause a great wrong to all concerned, with no benefit to the department. The true duty of the Government is to let the people devise their own modes of transportation of their merchandise, leaving them free, however, to use such facilities as Government provides for transporting other matters, without compelling them, under fine and penalty, to use such facilities. The Government claims the right to manage the transportation of the Written correspondence of the country. This requires certain machinery. Now if the people choose to send their PRINTED matter through these channels under such rules and at such prices as the Government makes and demands, they should be [???] to do so, but to compel them to [???] newspapers, magazines and other periodicals that was is an interfereace With the rights of the people that cannot be justified on any ground whatever, 1. Government thus interferes with the transportation of [???] matter, it will be reasonable to expect it will [???] interfere with the transportation of all kinds of merchandise, and then follows a long list of Government officials for the enforcement of the rules and [???] demanded by the law, and from this restriction in transportation ar[???] an increase of [???] This lessens protection. And thus all branches of [???] are elected, and thus Government itself is [???] the loser by the curtainment of wealth or capitation on which to levy taxes. The interest of all, both people and Government, is best promoted by leaving the people to take care of their own interests. A single [???] of my position is all I will make at this time, and no one knows its truth better than Mr. [???]. It is this: The present rate of letter postage [???] weight, have been and is the cause of an unheard of increase in the manufacture of paper, enveloped and the thousand branches of trade connected with their production, giving employment to thousands of persons, who but for this labor, would be seeking work in other branches to the detriment of other workers. The present system of transporting of other workers. The present system of transporting printed matter outside of the [???], has also given labor to thousands of persons, who, but for this, would now be crowding other and overstocked labor markets. The bill proposes the granting of licenses by the Post-master-General. Now, it there is any one thing more than another that the people of this country detest, it is the License System. It is one of the most despised relies of a bygone system of Governmental Espionage that was always condemned by every people, and by none more than by our own. We have none too great a respect for the necessary and proper officers of the Government, such as tax-gatherers' customs officers and the like, who have no license for special purposes, or for private profit, and when it is proposed to create a most odious monopoly, as this bill does, and then license special persons to make a profit out of that monopoly, the system of license becomes utterly abhorrent, and must beget the most intense hatred of the system, and a determination to evade its requirements. The true theory of government is to have as few laws as possible, and have those such as will command the respect and voluntary obedience of its people -- Lot to burden them with odious enactments that they will be sure to revolt against. No more hated officer could be devised than the having a license to use a monopoly for his own selfish ends, and the license proposed in this bill is one of that class.

abstract: -- Alderman BRADY tries to dodge a Legislative inquiry by denying that his boasted attempt to defeat the Health bill, last Winter, by expending $8,000, depended upon the purchase of votes. So far well. But the point remains to be explained, how money can be otherwise employed to influence legislation? Alderman BRADY pretends to have so used it. We demand to know how and upon whom.

abstract: Editorial on blockade-running cases pending in US Supreme Court; comments on legal aspects of blockades in world history
snippet: Editorial on blockade-running cases pending in US Supreme Court; comments on legal aspects of blockades in world history
lead_paragraph: The prize causes which have been carried up to the United States Supreme Court, from this District, have not yet been heard, awaiting, as we understand, the convenience of the counsel engaged in them. The importance of the cases warrants the fullest preparation, and the fullest discussion by counsel, and calls for the most careful deliberation on the part of the Court. The fact that the Court is not full, and that the cases must probably be heard and decided by less than the ordinary number of Judges, demands yet more care on the part of those upon whom this responsibility is to fall, that they may render decisions which shall be readily acquiesced in by all parties.

abstract: Now that nature has so nearly checked all hostile operations by either army, from the Potomac to the Mississippi, it is fitting that we should take advantage of this armistice, consider went out situation, and provide for such measure of safety as may in case of a reverse to our arms keep a cowardly, but vigorous enemy at bay.

abstract: -- This bank, which went into operation in this city Jan. 2, 1860, had loaned out on goods up to the second Saturday of October, 1861, the sum of $332,556 42, and the total amount paid in on loans for the same time was $241,632 84. The average amount loaned to each person was $29 46; and sixty-six out of every one hundred loans made by the bank are for $10 and under; on thirty-six out of every one hundred loans the interest, is less than 21 cents, and on twenty-seven out of every one hundred loans the interest is less than 11 cents; on seven out of every one hundred loans the interest is one cent only. -- Boston Journal, Jan. 18.

abstract: On the evening of the 2d a town meeting, convened by a respectably signed requisition to the Mayor, (Mr. H. MANTON,) was held in the Birmingham town-hall, "to consider the propriety of urging upon her Majesty's Government the importance of having recourse to arbitration instead of an immediate declaration of war, in the event of a serious disagreement arising out of the disturbed condition of our relations with the United Suites." There was a very large attendance, and the Mayor, of course presided.

abstract: -- The Commissioners of Health have begun their yearly labors with economy and sense. They have suppressed a needless office, and have resolved that the City railroad companies shall desist from a practice which converts their roads, during much of the Winter, into canals. The use of salt to remove snow from the tracks is dictated by the same pitiful avarice, which overcrowds the cars, and withholds every possible accommodation from the public; it is cheaper to disobey the laws than to give employment to a few hundred laborers, eager and perhaps perishing for employment. It is quite time the entire code of City railroad legislation were revised. The system should be put under the superintendence of some authority invested with powers to inflict summary penalties for departures from the strict obligations of law; and where lawlessness is persisted in, let the grant be promptly revoked. One effect of these disorders must be to surround further railroad charters with every security for the public comfort and accommodation.
lead_paragraph: -- The Commissioners of Health have begun their yearly labors with economy and sense. abstract: The steamer Oriental, recently arrived at this port from Port Royal, will probably sail to-day for Annapolis, where she will take on board the Forty-seventh Pennsylvania Regiment, numbering nearly one thousand men, and then proceed to Hilton Head. The Oriental has been expressly lilted up for the conveyance of troops, and on this trip will take out a large supply of Wales.

abstract: Last evening the Annual Ball of the New-York Fire Department took place at Niblo's Theatre. The affair was a most brilliant one; the stage being crammed with dancers, indeed, almost too much so, as the votaries of Terpsichore were jostling against each other. But notwithstanding these great disadvantages the light fantastic toe was tripped till an early hour this morning, by those, as Mr. Swiveller says, who delight in the "mazy." The Theatre itself was most prettily and tastefully decorated, and added greatly to the brilliancy of the scene. Both the boxes and family circle were festooned with flowers. On each side of the procenium was draped the Stars and Stripes. At the back of the stage was a brilliant illumination. In the centre was the inscription, "The New-York Fire Department." Underneath was all the paraphernalia of a fireman, represented by jets of gas. The whole was surmounted by a magnificent American Eagle. The Ball of the Fire Department, it is not too much to say, is decidedly, at present, the success of the season.

abstract: We have telegraphic advices from San Francisco to the 17th inst. All the news of interest relates to the floods, which have been devastating the country in the most unprecedented manner. At Sacramento, the damage had been immense. The City has been under water from two to eleven feet, driving people to the second stories of their houses, and preventing the. possibility of cooking. Cooked provisions, in large quantities have been sent up from San Francisco. The, Legislature of the water, which at last accounts was receding. The damage in the State is counted by millions.

abstract: editorial on Zollicoffer death
snippet: editorial on Zollicoffer death
lead_paragraph: Our latest dispatch from Kentucky leaves no doubt of the death of the Confederate General ZOLLICOFFER at the battle near Somerset. His body was left on the field by his retreating army, and is now in charge of the National commander. This gentleman had many acquaintances at Washington, where he served in Congress, and in the City and State of New-York, where, only fifteen months ago, he participated in the Presidential canvass for the Union ticket. In politics he was, until very recently, the reverse of a Nullifier or Secessionist, and his participation in this unholy rebellion against the Union, the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws, was a singular contradiction to the tenor of his political career as a journalist and Congressman. It was, of course, the subject of deep and sincere regret to his old associates of the Whig and American line at the North and his Union friends nearer home, all of whom respected his firm but unobtrusive bearing in public life, and to many of whom he was best known for his integrity and nice sense of honor in private life.

abstract: The Pacific slope has been visited by the most disastrous flood that has occurred since its settlement by white men. From Sacramento northward to the Columbia River, in California, Nevada Territory, and Oregon, all the streams have risen to a great height, flooded the valleys, [inundated towns, swept away mills, dams, flumes, houses, fences, domestic animals, ruined fields and effected damage, estimated at $10,000,000. All Sacramento City, save a small part of one street, part of Marysville, part of Santa Rosa, part of Auburn, part of Sonora, part of Nevada, and part of Napa, not to speak of less important towns, were under water.

abstract: -- The House Committee on Elections has decided against the claims of Mr. JOSEPH SEGAR to a seat. Mr. SEGAR claimed to represent the Accomac District of Virginia, but came without any proper proof of election, and indeed, nobody acquainted with the disloyalty of the eastern shore at the time when the election is alleged to have come off, can doubt the entire factitiousness of his pretensions. Mr. CHARLRS H. FOSTER was similarly defeated in his attempt to represent a district in North Carolina. The only difference between his case and that of Mr. SEGAR, is that the latter is attended with no antecedents suggestive of deliberate imposture. Nevertheless, it is to be hoped the House will sustain the report of the Committee.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, Alderman DAYTON submitted an ordinance prohibiting the sprinkling of salt on any of the streets in the City, including the lines of the railroad routes, as well as other streets. He explained that at present the ordinance in relation to sprinkling salt does not prohibit the salting of railroad tracks, it only refers to stage routes. The proposed ordinance would enforce a penalty of $100 for any sailing of any street, and $250 for every additional offence.

abstract: A letter was received on the 3d at LLOYDS from the Secretary of the Admiralty, stating that the Inspecting Commander of the Coast Guard at Ramsgate had reported that a suspicious looking steamer was seen cruising about the channel, off Dover, on the 27th ult., which, from circumstances since transpired, there is every reason to suppose was the Confederate privateer Sumter. It appears that the Sumter, when last heard of by the Federal Navy, was seen making in the direction of Europe. The Sumter is about 1,600 tons, painted black, and very fast.
lead_paragraph: A letter was received on the 3d at LLOYDS from the Secretary of the Admiralty, stating that the Inspecting Commander of the Coast Guard at Ramsgate had reported that a suspicious looking steamer was seen cruising about the channel, off Dover, on the 27th ult., which, from circumstances since transpired, there is every reason to suppose was the Confederate privateer Sumter. abstract: While eagerly expecting news from the Burnside Expedition, the community were yesterday startled by good news from another quarter. The first one in the great chain of battles has been fought in Kentucky, and has resulted gloriously for the National arms. On Friday night last, we gather from our dispatches, the rebel General...
lead_paragraph: While eagerly expecting news from the Burnside Expedition, the community were yesterday startled by good news from another quarter. The first one in the great chain of battles has been fought in Kentucky, and has resulted gloriously for the National arms. On Friday night last, we gather from our dispatches, the rebel General ZOLLICOFFER, finding that Gen. THOMAS had manoeuvred so as to gain his rear, and had thus forced a fight upon him, marched out of his intrenchments at Mill Creck, on the Cumberland, and proceeded to attack Gen. [???] in his camp at Somerset. The National pickets were driven in before daylight, and the battle commenced in the early morning. The field was a hotly-contested one, and the fighting lasted until 3 o'clock in the afternoon, when ZOLLICOFFER himself having been killed, the rebels fled back in commission to their intrenchments, leaving their dead and wounded on the field. This advantage was followed up rapidly by our victorious troops, who pursued the flying rebels to their fastness, where they were attacked on Sunday by the combined forces of SCHOEPF and THOMAS, and still further punished. Our victory was most complete, and the National Flag now floats over the rebel intrenchments, lately thought to be impregnable. The losses on both sides are stated to be heavy. That of the rebels is put down at 275 killed and wounded. Ours is not yet definitely known. The rebels lost all their cannon, quartermaster's stores, tents, horses and wagons -- in fact, everything.

abstract: -- Some of our cotemporaries seem to be either laboring under the impression, or else endeavoring to create one, that the appointment of Committees in the State Assembly has given rise to a great deal of dissatisfaction and "discord" at Albany. Nothing could be further from the truth. As is inevitable in such cases, there are, doubtless, some individual members who have failed to secure the positions which they especially desired, and they are, naturally enough, profoundly discontented with the existing arrangement. In a very few cases, moreover, there may have been mistakes in overlooking the merits of others. But these are errors of small importance, and can easily be remedied.
lead_paragraph: -- Some of our cotemporaries seem to be either laboring under the impression, or else endeavoring to create one, that the appointment of Committees in the State Assembly has given rise to a great deal of dissatisfaction and "discord" at Albany. abstract: It will be remembered that at the time Mr. [???] LOVELL, Deputy Street Commissioner, ran off to Dixie, Mr. EWEN, then Superintendent of Street improvements, was appointed by G.W. SMITH, the then Street Commissioner, who also resigned and ran away to the same place, Deputy Superintendent, and at once entered upon the discharge of his new duties. Mayor Wood constantly refused to recognize the validity of his appointment, and declined signing the warrants for his salary. Mr. EWEN, however, took no legal steps to test the validity of his appointment, but continued in the discharge of the duties of both offices. Upon the advent of Mr. OPDYRS to the Mayoralty Mr. EWEN was promptly recognized as Deputy Street Commissioner, and at the last pay day all the back payments were duly signed. Mr. EWEN has always been recognized as a valuable and faithful officer, possessing experience in municipal affairs, and especially familiar with everything connected with the streets, having introduced into the Department many highly useful suggestions.

abstract: editorial on Union victory
snippet: editorial on Union victory
lead_paragraph: The first bulletins of victory are seldom full enough to satisfy the popular appetite for that sort of good thing. Our accounts of the battle in Eastern Kentucky are thus incomplete. A first dispatch announces a conflict between Gen. SCHOEPF, commanding Union forces, and Gen. ZOLLICOFFER, in which the latter was killed and his force beaten. The scene of the encounter is located at Somerset, the position occupied by SCHOEPE. A later account places Gen. THOMAS in command of the Unionists, and names no battle-field. And a dispatch yet later represents that Union leader, assisted by Gen. SCHOEPF, as following up the first success by a brilliant attack upon the enemy's intrenchments at Mill Spring, over which the National colors are now waving. THOMAS, we had learned from earlier advices, was advancing with a strong body of troops from Columbia toward the intrenched position of ZOLLICOFFER'S army, at Mill Spring, on the Cumberland River, while SCHOEPF remained in his lines at Somerset. It was probably the purpose of THOMAS to outflank and cut off the retreat of the rebels; and the rebel commander discovering the aim of the National General, and declining to be caught among the hills of Mill Spring, as in a trap, may have advanced to meet the assailant before he could be reinforced, and before SCHOEPF could cooperate. We only know that the battle was offered by the rebels, and lost by them, after what must have been a fierce conflict, and the sacrifice of two leaders as conspicuous as ZOLLICOFFER and young BAILIE PEYTON. The vanquished fell back to their intrenchments at Mill Spring. Thither they were pursued by the victors assailed, and finally obliged to capitulate.
headline: {'main': 'The Union Victory in Kentucky.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Union Victory in Kentucky.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: From the regular weekly report of the City Inspector, it appears that the number of deaths in the City for the week ending Jan. 20, was 413 -- of which 234 were males, and 179 females. abstract: "A political community," says THIERS, "is analagouus to a mutual insurance company, where the payments of each member depend on the sum he has invested, and are proportioned to his interest in the company." To realize this idea is the end of fiscal science, the central principle of which is that every citizen should contribute to the support of the Government according to his stake in society,...
lead_paragraph: "A political community," says THIERS, "is analagouus to a mutual insurance company, where the payments of each member depend on the sum he has invested, and are proportioned to his interest in the company." To realize this idea is the end of fiscal science, the central principle of which is that every citizen should contribute to the support of the Government according to his stake in society, or to the income he enjoys under the protection of the Slate. It is of paramount importance for the public at the present moment to avoid the two-fold error into which certain superficial thinkers have fallen, of overrating the fiscal burdens incident to our present war, and of underrating the strength we have to bear them. One hundred and fifty millions of dollars is surely an annual contribution for the management of our common Government which twenty millions of willing, energetic, free people, can raise without the smallest difficulty. Were it possible to lay a tax averaging about two cents a clay on every person, the problem would be solved; and none of us are so poor as to feel the pressure of such a burden. Even if double the sum were called for, the overflowing of our prosperity, a few crumbs from the table of luxury, a little thrift and self-denial every day, would be enough to meet the demand.

abstract: A picturesque little piece called the "Sentinel of the Watch" was produced here last evening with success. It is of very slight material, only a luminous thread from the consuming fires of the great French Revolution, but trembling with issues of life and death.
lead_paragraph: A picturesque little piece called the "Sentinel of the Watch" was produced here last evening with success. It is of very slight material, only a luminous thread from the consuming fires of the great French Revolution, but trembling with issues of life and death. A veteran soldier discovers a daughter amongst the prisoners under his charge, and to secure her escape, arranges with a comrade for the midnight watch. He is prevented from going on the desired duty by another comrade, who drugs his liquor, and when the number is called, takes his place. The veteran is aroused from his stupor by the sound of shots, and learns with agony that they were aimed at his daughter. Frenzied with rage he seizes the comrade who he fancies has wronged him and wildly tells him the cause of his distraction. This leads to an explanation. The comrade is the lady's husband and an aristocrat; the shots fired were signals, and the drugged liquor was simply the means of securing the opportunity to forward the escape of his wife. But the course of true love never did run smooth. The garrison is turned out, the boat containing the fugitive fired upon and swamped, and the unfortunate brought back. In this serious emergency, a comic deus steps forward and announces that the reign of ROBESPIERRE is at an end and that all the prisoners are free.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented for the employment of homoepathic physicians in the army, and for the continuance of the Coast Survey. A protest against the appointment of a Solicitor of Customs, from citizens of New  York, was presented by Senator HARRIS. A bill authorizing the Secretary of War to appoint more...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented for the employment of homoepathic physicians in the army, and for the continuance of the Coast Survey. A protest against the appointment of a Solicitor of Customs, from citizens of New York, was presented by Senator HARRIS. A bill authorizing the Secretary of War to appoint more Assistant Secretaries was referred. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, introduced a bill, which was referred, repealing the bill excepting witnesses examined before a Congressional Committee from examination before a Court of justice. A bill authorizing payment for property occupied by our troops was introduced and referred. The bill providing the penalty by death for spies and those forcing safeguards was discussed, and laid over until to-day. The Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill was passed. The report of the Judiciary Committee in the case of Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, that no sufficient cause was found for his expulsion, was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment, without being disposed of. It appears to be somewhat uncertain whether the report of the Committee will be concurred in.

abstract: -- It appears that one hundred and fifty thousand dollars forma the total contribution raised by the entire South in aid of the sufferers by the great Charleston conflagration. This sorry show of Southern benevolence, nevertheless, does not prevent their papers from indulging in munificent schemes of subscriptions for the relief of Ireland. Speculatively those people are the most generous of mortals; but when it comes to the practical test, their generosity turns out to be about as much of an abstraction as their other pretended mental and moral qualities. Surely if ever there was an occasion fitted to call forth the gushing liberality to which Southerners have long laid claim, it is the calamitous visitation that has rendered houseless half the population of one of the foremost cities of the South. And yet, up the this day the entire contributions do not reach the amount which Charleston, under Union male, was in the habit of receiving daily from Now-York City alone.

Dyer, alias Davis, a New-Yorker, thirty, three years of age, was tried and convicted, on two indictments, (one for grand larceny, and the other for petty larceny,) and sentenced to the State Prison for three years and two months. The complainants were J. Weidman, whom lie swindled out of a silver watch find $40 in money by a confidence operation, and S.M. Drew, from whom he stole a pair of eyeglasses, valued at $5. The prisoner was a fireman on board the San Jacinto at the time of the arrest of Slidell and Mason, and was subsequently discharged, having received injuries that unfitted him for the service.

abstract: The State Legislature has adjourned until the 21st inst., to allow the water to subside from Sacramento. That city has been under water, from two to eleven feat deep, driving the people to the second stories of their houses, and preventing them from kindling fires and cooking food.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Friday, Jan. 17, 1862.

abstract: -- The Norfolk Day Book, of the 14th inst., records the total wreck of a Spanish ship from Vacntia, on the North Carolina coast, near Bogue's Inlet, on the 5th of this month. We find in the supplementary sheet to Blunl's Coost Pilot, giving a list of several hundred light-houses and light-ships destroyed or extinguished by the rebels, that the Bogue Banks beacon is one of those that have suffered this illustration of the civilizing character of secessionism. Nor is Spanish commerce the only loser; both French and English vessels have been stranded on that treacherous Carolina coast, in consequence of the putting out of the lights which the United States Government set there for the safety of the commerce of the world. Now, to our mere uninstructed sense this seems like a wanton act of barbarism, directed against all mankind. At least there are on record illustrations of how such acts have been looked upon. LOUIS XIV. being at war with England during the building of the Edystone Light-house, a French privateer took the men at work upon the rock, together with the tools, and carried them to France, and the captain was in expectation of a reward for the achievement. While the captives lay in prison, the transaction reached the ears of that monarch. He immediately ordered them to be released, and the captors to be put in their places, declaring that, though he was at war with England, he was not so with mankind. He therefore directed the men to be sent back to their work with presents -- observing that "the Edystone Light-house was so situated as to be of equal service to all nations having occasion to navigate the channel between England France."

abstract: Charles French vs. James C. Willett. This was an action against the defendant as Sheriff, to recover damages alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff, in consequence of the escape of Plin White, who will be well remembereded. The plaintiff was a judgment creditor of Wite's to the extent (judgment and interest) of about $17,000, and it was claimed that such was the extent of his loss by reason of the escape.

abstract: A meeting of the employes in the Navy-yard was called to be held last evening at 5 o clock in Tammany Hall, York-street. At the hour named them were perhaps one hundred people present, principally persons from the ship-joiners' department. Mr. LEAK, who has heretofore presided, took the Chair on this occasion, and called the meeting to order. Messrs. ARCHIBALD and WOOLSEY, of the Committee appointed to proceed to Washington and look after the interest of the employes of the Navy-yard, made a verbal report, showing that in accordance with instructions they went to Washington and consulted with the Naval Committees of both Houses, the Secretary of the Navy, and also a number of Congressmen, relative to repealing the eighth section of the law recently passed regulating the pay and hours of labor for men employed in the different navy-yards. They received but tittle encouragement, but Mr. ARCHIBALD, in behalf of the Committee, prepared a petition a repeal of the obnoxious section referred to, and it had been presented by Mr. VAN WYCK to the House. The report of the Committee was accepted and adopted. After a somewhat lengthy discussion as to what course it was best to pursue, the Chairman was authorized to appoint a Committee to proceed to Washington to press forward the petition, and also to appoint a committee of one in each department of the Navy-yard to collect money to pay the expenses of the committee. Several persons present complained bitterly that they had been misrepresented by the Press in movement; that they were disloyal, &c., when in fact they were loyal citizens, and only sought to secure their rights as mechanics, and in a legitimate way. As we understand it, the new law has not as yet seriously affected their interest. The pay remains the same, but there has been a change in the working hours, which conflicts with their ideas of justice. The most serious objection to the law is, that it leaves the price of work in the Yard to the caprices of those who may be tempted to speculate upon the misfortune of others. For instance, under the new law, the rate of wages to be paid is to be governed by the rates paid in similar empoloyment outside; so that if Messrs. WEBB, and other ship-builders, have it in their power to obtain workmen for $1 50 per day, then the wages in the Yard on that class of work must be reduced to that standard. It is the operation of the law in the future, more than at the present time, which they design to guard against by taking action at the present time. The meeting adjourned to assemble again at the call of the Chairman.

The report of the Committee was accepted and adopted. After a somewhat lengthy discussion as to what course it was best to pursue, the Chairman was authorized to appoint a Committee to proceed to Washington to press forward the petition, and also to appoint a committee of one in each department of the Navy-yard to collect money to pay the expenses of the committee. abstract: TAX. -- Mr. COLFAX, who yesterday, in a speech defending his proposed postal tax upon newspapers, stated that be expected a "mountain would fall upon and crush" him, and heroically proclaimed his willingness to submit, pro bono publico, to the "crushing" process, has had the mortification to see his measure disposed of in a far less formidable way -- namely, by being laid on the table. At the same time there are indications that a plan h being matured at once just, practical and efficacious. Mr. MORRILL stated that the Committee of Ways and Means had in contemplation to propose a bill levying a tax in some form -- perhaps by stumps -- on all newspapers, and also on telegraphic communications. He did not announce what shape the scheme would assume: but this is undoubtedly the right direction for legislative action. A suitable bill, embodying this principle, will give satisfaction both to the reading public and to newspaper proprietors, and when reduced to legal form, will have the effect to produce the desired replenishment of the treasury, at least to the amount of three or four millions, whithout the cumbersome and vexatious accompaniments of Mr. COLFAX's bill.
lead_paragraph: TAX. -- Mr. COLFAX, who yesterday, in a speech defending his proposed postal tax upon newspapers, stated that be expected a "mountain would fall upon and crush" him, and heroically proclaimed his willingness to submit, pro bono publico, to the "crushing" process, has had the mortification to see his measure disposed of in a far less formidable way -- namely, by being laid on the table. Mr. MORRILL stated that the Committee of Ways and Means had in contemplation to propose a bill levying a tax in some form -- perhaps by stumps -- on all newspapers, and also on telegraphic communications. He did not announce what shape the scheme would assume: but this is undoubtedly the right direction for legislative action. A suitable bill, embodying this principle, will give satisfaction both to the reading public and to newspaper proprietors, and when reduced to legal form, will have the effect to produce the desired replenishment of the treasury, at least to the amount of three or four millions, whithout the cumbersome and vexatious accompaniments of Mr. COLFAX's bill.

abstract: -- We see with the greatest satisfaction that a resolution has been introduced into the Senate instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the propriety of so amending the naturalization laws as to confer rights of citizenship on foreigners who may serve in the war. Nothing can be more proper, and the proposition will undoubtedly have the hearty concurrence of all right-feeling Americans. If it be made to take the form that the certificate of honorable discharge at the end of the war shall stand as an instrument of naturalization, it will be a simple and effective formulating of the law.

abstract: Died in Virginia, aged 71, on January 17; biographical sketch; Tyler, John; ex-Pres. of US
snippet: Died in Virginia, aged 71, on January 17; biographical sketch; Tyler, John; ex-Pres. of US
lead_paragraph: JOHN TYLER, of Virginia, the only Ex-President resident in the seceded States, is dead. There are yet some gentlemen living who have sat in the presidential Chair -- VAN BUREN and FILLMORE in New-York, PIERCE in New-Hampshire, and BUCHANAN in Pennsylvania -- all in the loyal States. The events of Mr. TYLER'S career, though familiar to almost everybody, may, now that he has passed forever off the stage, be briefly recapitulated.

abstract: -- Our armies are now fairly on an income footing. The work of construction and organization is complete and the lines begin to care back the vast treasures which have been expended upon them. That they will be operated with skill by the General Superintendent we have every confidence. His Division Engineers have nearly all been placed. One of them has just furnished a glorious report of his first train over the Cumberland. Another sends word of his trial trip down the Mississippi, from Cairo, after having cleared the obstructions to his branch line through Missouri by capturing thirteen hundred incendiaries at a single dash, who were threatening to destroy his stations. A third is heard from as far down the Southern Atlantic coast as Hatteras Inlet, and altogether we may soon expect to hear of a telling and prosperous business all along the great. National lines. No reasonable doubt remains of the early fruition of the hopes of the country -- the reward of its generous expenditures, and the relief of its painful anxieties.
lead_paragraph: -- Our armies are now fairly on an income footing. abstract: The United States vs. One Butt &c. of Wine. -- The renewal of the motion to open the default in this case against the United States, which was heard and denied some days since, was heard yesterday morning on new affidavits. It was argued at length by Mr. Evarts, for the motion, and Mr. McKeon in opposition. Judge BETTS finally decided to open the default, that the case might be tried, though he warned the bar that this case must by no means be construed as a precedent upon which to build up a practice.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. One Butt &c. of Wine. -- The renewal of the motion to open the default in this case against the United States, which was heard and denied some days since, was heard yesterday morning on new affidavits. abstract: A short play and a merry one is MORTON'S "Cure for the Heartache," revived here last night with much applause. What it lacks in plot and incident--and a stickler for the best models would hardly accept it as a respectable imitation in those respects-- is abundantly counterbalanced by sprightliness of dialogue and a free-handed sketchiness in the treatment of the male characters. It is unfortunate that in deal-
lead_paragraph: A short play and a merry one is MORTON's "Cure for the Heartache," revived here last night with much applause. What it lacks in plot and incident -- and a stickler for the best models would hardly accept it as a respectable imitation in those respects -- is abundantly counterbalanced by sprightliness of dialogue and a free-handed sketchiness in the treatment of the male characters. It is unfortunate that in dealing with the other sex the author seems to lose his buoyancy, and falls either into a condition of maudlin sentimentalism, or of a mood absolutely unamiable. Thus whilst we all recognize the flightiness of Young Rapid and the solidity of his sire, we can only accept Miss Vortex with the deference due to an old stage tradition, and feel quite sure that, if the other two female parts were not intrusted to pretty women, they would be tiresome if not superfluous. MORTON was afflicted with a mania for moral sentiments, and with gallant but injurious prodigality he has bestowed an undue proportion thereof upon his fair friends, who in consequence are rather severe. This remark applies more especially to the character of Jessy Oatland, the remaining part of Ellen being too slight for analysis. Both, we may here add, were benefited by the talents of Mrs. HOEY and Miss HENRIQUES. Their presence on the stage made us almost forget the niggardly inefficiency of the dramatist.

abstract: -- We learn from Washington this morning that the House Committee of Ways and Means, who adhere to their preference for the Treasury Note bill for a United States Currency as a legal tender, (prepared before the recent conference with the Bank gentlemen from this and other cities,) have harmonized with Mr. Secretary CHASE, and will, in a day or two, report the bill to the House. Mr. CHASE accepts the measure as the most available means for the present crisis, with an additional section to authorize the loans asked for in his recent report, and into which all Treasury notes and other demands upon the Government will be convertible. It will be noticed from our dispatch that the legal tender will be made an indispensable feature of the Currency notes, and will no doubt be passed by Congress, while the loans arc made to bear the uniform rate of 6 per cent., irredeemable for twenty years, unless a provision should be added for their repurchase by the Government at any time after five years.
lead_paragraph: -- We learn from Washington this morning that the House Committee of Ways and Means, who adhere to their preference for the Treasury Note bill for a United States Currency as a legal tender, (prepared before the recent conference with the Bank gentlemen from this and other cities,) have harmonized with Mr. Secretary CHASE, and will, in a day or two, report the bill to the House. Mr. CHASE accepts the measure as the most available means for the present crisis, with an additional section to authorize the loans asked for in his recent report, and into which all Treasury notes and other demands upon the Government will be convertible. It will be noticed from our dispatch that the legal tender will be made an indispensable feature of the Currency notes, and will no doubt be passed by Congress, while the loans arc made to bear the uniform rate of 6 per cent., irredeemable for twenty years, unless a provision should be added for their repurchase by the Government at any time after five years.
