abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of emancipating the slaves, and for a continuance of the Coast Survey. The resolution to allow certain officers to receive presents from the Japanese Government was passed. The Judiciary Committee was directed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the Naturalization laws as to confer rights of citizenship upon foreigners serving in the present war.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of emancipating the slaves, and for a continuance of the Coast Survey. The resolution to allow certain officers to receive presents from the Japanese Government was passed. The Judiciary Committee was directed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the Naturalization laws as to confer rights of citizenship upon foreigners serving in the present war. The bill to complete the detences of Washington was considered, and after being amended in various particulars, was laid over until to-day. The bill authorizing the Secretary of War to appoint two Assistant Secretaries for one year, at a salary of $2,000 each, was passed. The report of the Judiciary Committee on the resolution to expel Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, was then taken up and considered, until the adjournment, without any vote. Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, argued in favor of his expulsion, as did Mr. LANE, of Indiana. Mr. BRIGHT made a speech in his own defence, in which he denied any treasonable instant, and declared that he had no [???] collection of writing the letter to JEFF. DAVIS, introducing a man who desired to sell firearms.

abstract: -- The Winter Term of the Hudson County Courts was commenced yesterday at the Court-house in Hudson City, Judge OGDEN and Associate-Judges POPE and MORRIS, presiding. The Grand Jury were sworn in, and Judge OGDEN delivered his charge, during which, he called particular attention to the retailing of liquor illegally, disorderly houses, the liabilities of landlords for the unlawful acts of their tenants, and to prize-fighting, an exhibition of which recently took place in Hudson County. There are, at present, thirty-three persons confined in the jail, on the charges of rape, burglary, attempt to kill, passing counterfeit money, larceny, &c. Of the above number, fifteen are females.

abstract: Editorial on British views of war
snippet: Editorial on British views of war
lead_paragraph: It is rarely the outside observer has an opportunity to sound the opinions of the English people. In England far less than in America does the Press reflect the sense of the masses; and when Parliamentary orators go down to their constituents, to deliver themselves upon the urgent topics of the moment, the audience is very apt to be packed like an unfair jury, and not only the resolutions, and vote of thanks, but the very cheers, come in by preconcert. By the latest arrival from Europe, however, we are favored with two unmistakably fair expressions of what "the people" think upon the American difficulty, and the right attitude of England. There was a public meeting at Brighton, and a public meeting at Birmingham, to both of which resolutions favoring a reference of the Trent, question to arbitration were submitted, and there were speeches made by influential people, arguing for and against those resolutions. In Brighton, the arbitration policy prevailed by a unanimous vote; in Birmingham, it was bowled down by a large majority, and a declaration adopted favorite a support of the action taken or proposed by the Ministry. An attempt to procure a reversal of this judgment was at once quelled. At Brighton there was a disposition to take the most friendly view of the subject; at Birmingham, which returns to Parliament Mr. JOHN BRIGHT, that friend of peace and of America, and the dauntless champion of the rectitude of our struggle with rebellion, the hostility to this country was undisguised, and the decision in favor of the Government was just so much sympathy with the known belligerent yearnings of the Premier.

abstract: The number of regular troops now in and around  Washington, amounts to about three thousand, consisting of companies of the First, Second, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Cavalry, and the Second, Third, Fourth, Sixth, Eighth, Ninth and Tenth infantry. Many of the troops are under orders to march at 15 minutes' notice, and the officers have provided themselves with outfits suitable for a long campaign.

abstract: The second and third batteries of WIARD's steel rifted cannon for the State of Ohio were forwarded, via the New-York Central Railroad, yesterday, in complete fighting order. These batteries are to be designated as "Buckingham's" and "Wood's." The first battery, "Wolcott's," which was forwarded some two weeks since, as mentioned in the TIMES, did capital service in the late battle at Somerset, in Southern Kentucky, Mr. WIARD himself being present with his battery during the conflict.

abstract: A meeting of the employes in the Navy-yard was called to be held last evening at 5 o'clock in Tammany Hall, York-street. At the hour named there were perhaps one hundred people present, principally persons from the ship-joiners' department. Mr. LEAK, who has heretofore presided, took the Chair on this occasion, and called the meeting to order. Messrs. ARCHIBALD and WOOLSEY, of the Committee appointed to proceed to Washington and look after the interest of the employes of the Navy-yard, made a verbal report, showing that in accordance with instructions they went to Washington and consulted with the Naval Committees of both Houses, the Secretary of the Navy, and also a number of Congressmen, relative to repealing the eighth section of the law recently passed regulating the pay and hour of labor for men employed in the different navy-yards. They received but little encouragement, but Mr. ARCHIBALD, in behalf of the Committee, prepared a petition asking a repeal of the obnoxious section referred to, and it had been presented by Mr. VAN WYCK to the House. The report of the Committee was accepted and adopted. After a somewhat lengthy discussion as to what course it was best to pursue, the Chairman was authorized to appoint a Committee to proceed to Washington to press forward the petition, and also to appoint a committee of one in each department of the Navy-yard to collect money to pay the expenses of the committee. Several persons present complained bitterly that they had been misrepresented by the Press in this movement; that they were disloyal, &c., when in fact they wore loyal citizens, and only sought to secure their rights as mechanics, and in a legitimate way. As we understand it, the new law has not as yet seriously affected their interest. The pay remains the same, but there has been a change in the working hours, which conflicts with their ideas of justice. The most serious objection to the law is, that it leaves the price of work in the Yard to the caprices of those who may be tempted to speculate upon the misfortune of others. For instance, under the new law, the rate of wages to be paid is to be governed by the rates paid in similar employment outside; so that if Messrs. WEBB, and other ship-builders, have it in their power to obtain workmen for $1 50 per day, then the wages in the Yard on that class of work must be reduced to that standard. It is the operation of the law in the future, more than at the present time, which they design to guard against by taking action at the present time. The meeting adjourned to assemble again at the call of the Chairman.

abstract: -- The London Saturday [???], of the latest date, seems to be greatly distressed at the prospect that, after all, peace will be preserved between England and the United States. Its hatred of Democracy is so intense, and the chance of gratifying it seemed so near at hand, that disappointment would be doubly severe. It is still doing its best to distort and misrepresent everything done by our Government toward preserving peace. And we must be prepared for a tremendous outburst of vexation and wrath on its part when it shall finally hear of the surrender of SLIDELL and MASON.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held last evening, to pass resolutions necessary to obtain funds for the relief of the families of volunteers. The President, Supervisor CROOKE, occupied the Chair. A report was received from the Volunteer Relief Commission, showing that they had paid out all the funds placed at their disposal. The report was referred to the Committee on Accounts. The draft of a memorial was presented calling upon the Legislature to pass a law to assume the payment of the United States tax, which was adopted, and the clerk directed to forward the same to the Legislature. Mayor KALBFLEISON and Mr. HENRY RUGGLERS having offered to loan the County $5,000 each, to enable the Relief Committee to continue payments to the families of volunteers, a resolution was adopted accepting the same, and the Committee was directed to pay the families in full for all the time since the suspension of payments. The Board adjourned to Feb. 5.

abstract: A NEW WAY OF SWINDLING BEGGING ON HIGH AUTHORITY. An Italian woman, named JULIA B. CONTI, alias MARY CONTI, was brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH yesterday, upon the charge of swindling a large number of citizens in the upper part of the City by means of false pretences. Her plan has been to go from house to house, presenting a petition which sets forth that she is an Italian refugee, who landed...
lead_paragraph: A NEW WAY OF SWINDLING -- BEGGING ON HIGH AUTHORITY. -- An Italian woman, named JULIA B. CONTI, alias MARY CONTI, was brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH yesterday, upon the charge of swindling a large number of citizens in the upper part of the City by means of false pretences. Her plan has been to go from house to house, presenting a petition which sets forth that she is an Italian refugee, who landed in New-York, with her husband and three children, about one year ago; that her husband died as soon as he arrived here, and she was left with the three small children to support. The petition states that her only object in applying to the charitable for aid, is to enable her to return with her children to Italy, where she left six other little ones, who are now in great want. The interesting part of this woman's case, however, consists in the fact that in order that her petition should have weight, and her story be the more readily believed, she has acknowledged it before a Commissioner of Deeds. The certificate of the Commissioner was then taken to the County Clerk of the City and County of New-York, who gave his certificate, in the usual way, as to the Commissioner of Deeds, and then he attached thereto the seal of the county. These were all taken to the Governor at Albany, and to the State Department. The Governor signs his name, the Secretary of State his, and the great seal of the State of New-York is affixed thereto. Of course, the certificate from Albany is only to the effect that at the date thereof. JOHN CLANCY was County Clerk for the County of New-York. Thus is obtained the signatures of two of the highest officers in the State, also that of the County Clerk and a Commissioner, which, with three large seals attached to the several papers, really make a very imposing appearance, and apparently a very deserving case for the exercise of charity. The police state that sums of money to a very large amount have been obtained in all parts of the City by means of these papers. Copies of them have been made and circulated by different parties. The woman taken into custody sometimes goes by one name and sometimes by another, and she has papers to suit all filenames she bears. When brought before the Court she pretended to be unable to understand a word, either of English or French. But when the Justice admonished her, and begun to tell her what must necessarily be the consequence of her many impositions upon the public, she began to protest, and showed by her conversation and actions that she knew all that was said. Papers were also found upon her having the seal of the State of Massachusetts, whereby it appeared that not long ago she had been practicing the same impositions in Boston. She is a very good-looking woman, about thirty years of age. The Justice committed her for examination. He desires that all parties who have been swindled by this woman should appear before him to-day, at Jefferson Market Police Court, and give their testimony.

abstract: Notwithstanding the blusterings and vaporings of the London Times, and the war Press generally, there is a perceptible diminution of the war feeling throughout this Kingdom. The popular impression fomented by designing men was "that the American people desired to insult the British flag." Under this idea the clamor for prompt "chastisement upon the Yankees" was fired up to a great heighth; but the necessity of delay, and the consequent time afford.

abstract: The problem before the country is the reorganization of the finances of the Government. That the credit of the Government, under the circumstances, is  so well sustained, shows the entire confidence of the people in their ability, and their willingness to meet all the burdens necessary to be imposed upon them to maintain this credit unfurnished; and their conviction, that when this is done the whole financial problem is solved. Capital was never more abundant.

abstract: signally routed the Falstaffian HEMPHREY MARSHALL, is well known in Ronsselaer County, New-York. On leaving college he went to Ohio and became President of an institution of learning -- abandoning that position, however, at the call of his country. He is known in the army as the "Praying Colonel," and is almost a "John Balfour of Burley" in his rigid piety, yet high courage.

abstract: Col. T.B. THORPE'S lecture, on Monday night, entitled "An Inside View of the Great Rebellion," in spite of the inclemency of the weather, was listened to by a crowded audience, and though nearly two hours was consumed in its delivery, a large number of persons remained throughout its delivery, though compelled to stand up.
lead_paragraph: Col. T.B. THORPE's lecture, on Monday night, entitled "An Inside View of the Great Rebellion," in spite of the inclemency of the weather, was listened to by a crowded audience, and though nearly two hours was consumed in its delivery, a large number of persons remained throughout its delivery, though compelled to stand up. The fact that a gentleman, who had a wide-spread reputation as a writer and a humorist, and fortified by the experience of twenty years residence in Louisiana, was to speak on the rebellion, raised high expectations, and the most sanguine were not disappointed. Col. THORPE combines in his manner of oratory the best characteristics of the Southern stump, chastened by his Northern associations. While he has an argument, he enforces his ideas almost exclusively by illustrations, anecdotes and incidents, and we question if there is any one before the public who can tell anecdotes better, or with such an inexhaustible fun. The audience, as they came crowding one upon another with a marvelous rapidity, were one moment all excitement at the details of some tragic incident, and than by some unexpected humorous and witty recital, were convulsed with laughter. The lecturer displayed deep study, joined with great natural ability as a public speaker. At the close of the lecture a spontaneous expression was made by the audience that it should be repeated, a desire the lecturer will probably gratify.

abstract: -- Advices from Washington, which will be found among our telegraphic dispatches this morning, put a new and not very welcome construction on the views of the Trent case, which various continental cabinets have seen fit to reduce to form and present to our Government. It appears that it was English intrigue and English influence that called forth the declarations of both Austria and Prussia. England gave too word and Austria and Prussia obediently followed her beck. We have already pointed out that these diplomatic manifestoes unfairly represented our position in the matter -- putting absolute right on the side of Great Britain, and absolute wrong on the side of the United States. This animus is perfectly accounted for by the revelations of our correspondent, though it places those two Governments in the attitude of servilely following the bidding of England. There was some propriety in the prompt declaration of France -- she was interested, indirectly at least, if not directly in the case; but it can hardly be expected that we are to receive in the most gracious of moods the ready-made international wisdom of every continental sovereignty.

abstract: -- The Attorney of Albany County has complied with the requisition of the Legislature for the testimony taken in the case of F.S. LITTLEJOHN, charged last Winter with corrupt practices in influencing legislation. The testimony only proves, what no member of the Legislature with average intelligence doubts, the existence of systematized corruption in every avenue and hall of the State Capitol. Officers of the Assembly were, last Winter, the treasurers of funds, designed to pervert the course of legislation, or were induced under ingenious pretenses to become the recipients of donations, for which the donor looked for some equivalent in the way of promoting their particular measures. There is, we are glad to say, no distinct evidence that money has been paid to members of either house to secure their votes. We are expected to believe the influence and activity of lobby agents, their powers of suasion and remonstrance, and such little helps on the part of Clerks as calling bills out of time, or having them engrossed for passage with unusual promptitude, have alone been the objects of purchase. But so dense and prevalent an atmosphere of corruption can hardly leave the members themselves free from unwholesome taint of suspicion at least; and if out of this disclosure any means of purification can be extracted, let it be at once presented and used. The present Legislature has its own character for good or evil to make. Can it better facilitate its task than by exercising the lobby?

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a memorial was presented asking for fortifications at the mouth of the Genesee River. The Commissioners of the Land Office sent in a communication asking for a law authorizing the sale of lands held by the same title as Washington Market. The communication was referred to the members from this City.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a memorial was presented asking for fortifications at the mouth of the Genesee River. The Commissioners of the Land Office sent in a communication asking for a law authorizing the sale of lands held by the same title as Washington Market. The communication was referred to the members from this City. Bills were introduced to amend the law of 1859 relative to Courts of Sessions and Police Courts, and to amend the Kings County Court Act. That portion of the Governor's Message relating to capital punishment, was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The bill supplementary to the act to continue Flatbush-avenue, in Brooklyn, was ordered to a third reading. Mr. TRUMAN introduced his bill to amend the Usury law. It provides that when more than seven per cent, interest, is charged, the loaner shall forfeit only the interest, and double the amount charged in excess.

abstract: editorial on victory strengthening loyal Union sentiment in Tennessee
snippet: editorial on victory strengthening loyal Union sentiment in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The loyal sentiment of all the border Southern States will be greatly strengthened by the victory on the Cumberland. Its influence will extend to Tennessee, North Carolina and Eastern Virginia. It may even find a response from Louisiana and her commercial metropolis, whose trade relations with the Upper Valley of the Mississippi were madly and wickedly suspended last Winter to the behests of the Cotton rebellion. The truth is, that Louisiana had as little heart in the first movement of secession as Tennessee or North Carolina. The Northwestern States, now in arms for the Constitution and the Union, as well as Kentucky and Missouri, were tributary to her commerce. For more than fifty years Ohio and Kentucky had been building up New-Orleans, and when the growth of Illinois, Indiana and Missouri, and the immense surplus products which they were enabled to market, were added, the strides of that city to commercial greatness were rapid and in every sense surprising beyond precedent. We do no violence to probability, therefore, in saying that Louisiana must feel that the victory already won, and the battles yet to be fought in the same quarter, are so many blows to unshackle her own trade and prosperity -- to give to New-Orleans the busy life it was wont to enjoy mainly through the custom of the Upper Valley, and to her sugar interest the profitable markets, which, until recently, it almost monopolized.
headline: {'main': 'The Victory Its Effect in Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Victory Its Effect in Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our news from Kentucky this morning, though still meagre, fully confirms the account published yesterday of the battle and victory at Somerset. We are still in doubt, however, whether there were two engagements one on Saturday, followed by another on Sunday or whether there was only the battle of Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Our news from Kentucky this morning, though still meagre, fully confirms the account published yesterday of the battle and victory at Somerset. We are still in doubt, however, whether there were two engagements -- one on Saturday, followed by another on Sunday -- or whether there was only the battle of Sunday. The Louisville dispatch gives the latter view of the case; but that is not by any means conclusive, as it is principally occupied with the details of THOMAS' engagement, and the ultimate route of the rebels; while all the previous accounts agree that ZOLLICOFFER marched out of his "den," and attacked SCHOEPF the previous day. But we will, doubtless, have the precise details of the case immediately. At all events, it seems to have been a complete defeat of the rebels. Two hundred of their dead and wounded are said to have been left upon the field, and they left, also, their cannon, stores, and everything they had besides a steamboat and several barges in the river. Our loss seems to have been heavy, as one regiment alone reports seventy men hors du combat; but this is probably not to be taken as a measure of the loss in other regiments. No mention is made of the rebels under CRITTENDEN, which were reported by the rebel journals to have gone to the support of ZOLLICOFFER. They have probably retired to the Cumberland Gap. The rebels are so completely routed that they cannot make another stand short of that point. We shall probably have the official report by to-morrow.

abstract: Misapprehension prevails of the nature of the business which took Mr. Collector BARNEY, Mr. Assistant Treasurer CISCO and Mayor OPDYKE to Washington yesterday evening, and of that which calls Messrs. STUART BROWN, ROBERT B. MINTURN, SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, and F.S. WINSTON there to-day. Mr. BARNEY and Mr. CISCO go merely upon matters connected with their departments; the other gentlemen, as a deputation from the Associate Members of the Sanitary Commission in this City, to press certain important measures upon the attention of Congress. The visit of these distinguished citizens to the National Capital has not the financial purpose which is attributed to it, -- though doubtless such men can hardly be in Washington at a time like the present and not be consulted upon finance. But the Committee of Ways and Means has decided definitively upon the principal measures which it will recommend to Congress; and we believe wisely; and advice upon this point would be at least superfluous.

abstract: -- The House Committee or Ways and Means yesterday reported their bill for the creation of a legal tender, in United states Notes of Circulation, of $150,000.000 including the $50,000,000 already in circulation under the act of July 17. The bill also authorizes the creation of a Funded 6 percent stock equal to five hundred Millions, for the service of the remaining [???] of the current fiseal year, ending June 30, 1862, and for the ensuing year ending June 30, 1862, This provision corresponds with the estimates of the Secretary of the Treasury in his recent Report -- $200,000,000 for the present, and $313,000,000 for the next fiscal year It wisely assumes that war may be continued through another fiscal year, thus indieatiag that there is no purpose on the part of the Secretary or of the Committee to disguise a possible contingency, or hold out faise hopes in regard to the continuance of the War, to the great end of the restoration of the authority of the Constitution ad Laws over the whole thirty four States of the Union. The Stock to be issued may be paid for, at par in the United States Notes of Circulation, or in any other demands upon the Treasury. The amount of the former is limided to $150,000,000, while the amount to be floated or put in circulation is left to the diseretion of the Secretary and currency wants of the country

abstract: It is a vexations illustration of the base conditiions which hedge and hamper human affairs, that the blow which is all ready to fall on the rebellion is completely baulked by one pitiful yet pitiless element Mud. Here are we ...
lead_paragraph: with bated breath, hushed in expectancy, awaiting the climax that is to shake the Continent to its foundations; and there are the roads from the Potomac to Kansas one mass of mud and nice against which gods, man and mules are impotent. The great anaconda. The giant constrictor, we have faith to believe, now understands his paces thoroughly, and is fully prepared for the final flex of his folds; but what can he do stuck in the mud, and helpless as a pleiscosaurus the morning after the subsidener of the Deluge?

abstract: Editorial on Stanton's new regime in War Dept
snippet: Editorial on Stanton's new regime in War Dept
lead_paragraph: -- Our Washington correspondent mentions that at the inteview, yesterday, between the new Secretary of War and the Congressional committee, the quality which every one remarked in him was his rare business talent. We can easily understand this, for Mr. STANTON evidently has a thoroughly practical, organizing and executive mind; and he has proved it by the severest of tests. He has introduced an entirely new regime into the Department of which he is the head. First, he will do no business at his house, and receive no man whatsoever who comes thereon business. Second, letters and written communications will be attended to the first thing in the morning when they are received, and will have precedence over all other business. Third, six days in the week have [???] been surrendered to [???] the War Department: Mr. STANTON will consecrate Saturday to them -- Monday he will give to all other people whose business requires a personal interview. Fourth, to carry the war to a speedy and successful issue. Tuesday, Wednesday. Thursday and Friday will be given to the war, and to nothing else. The Department will, on those days, be closed to all business not connected with active operations in the field. Lastly, to save army officers from becoming idlers, and to compel them to attend to their commands, the names of all such as frequent Washington, save on the orders of superior officers, and on military business exclusively, will be �dropped from the list."

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to amend the 13 Revised Statutes in relation to unauthorized banking, and legalizing the acts of the Common Council of this City for the relief of the families of volunteers. Notice ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to amend the 13 Revised Statutes in relation to unauthorized banking, and legalizing the acts of the Common Council of this City for the relief of the families of volunteers. Notice was given of bills to establish a council of conciliation to determine cases pending in the Court of Appeals, amending the Divorce laws, and making the printing of the Insurance. Department chargeable to the Insurance Companies. The bill amending the General Insurance law was passed. Concurrent resolutions were reported from the Finance Committee and laid over, in favor of allowing each State to assume the payment of and collect its quote of the National tax.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. - Mr. GRAU'S season of Italian Opera, consisting of two weeks' performances here and in Brooklyn, will not commence until Wednesday next, the interim being occupied with rehearsals and the necessary preparations for the debut of Mme, BORCHARD. The possession of this singer enables the manager to produce some of the most favorite operas of the Italian repertoire, Mme, BORCHARD being a dramatic artist. It was in the opera of "Lucrezia Borgia" that the lady had the good luck to win the approval of the Boston critics. Mr. GRAU is peculiarly fortunate in his prime donne. They are all young and handsome, and so different in styles that the Usual jealousies and heartburnings are not likely to prevail amongst them. What is better, they draw, the public being really interested in each new part that one or the other sustains. Miss KILLOGG, we hear, is studying two new operas. It is clear that Mr. GRAU intends to labor hard for success, [???] we doubt not, will secure it. People have confidence in a man who does not make too many promises.

lead_paragraph: are by no means so desperate looking a set as they have been represented, wore uniforms in every singe of [???] and the necessity for full suit of new clothing seemed as pressing as for the "thousand [???] which Col. WILSON ordered at the close of his official report of the attack on his camp. On our way to the quarters of the Colonel. We encountered a Squad of Zouaves, who entertained our party with some wonderful stories of the nocturnal visit of the rebels. One of them, who more than any scorned to represent the class of society from which the regiment was recruited, exhibited a couple of bullets flattened by contact with some hard substance, which he, with au air of apparent sincerity, white a sardonic smile lighted up his hardened features, declared they had been lodged in his kaapsack by a "secesh," at the same Lime expressing, in language more emphatic [???] refined, a devout wish that the rebels were in a certain place, the locality of which may be some. degrees nearer the equator than Santa Rosa Island. The Zouavcs seemed contented, and although they acknowledged that they would like to go to New York. said they didn't want to leave as tong as there were any rebels on the Other side.

abstract: -- We must not underrate the difficulties of the Western campaign. Not only to commander FOOTS hindered and embarrassed in many ways in his naval expedition; Gen. BUELL, also has more to encounter than those who form their opinions from the late condition of the [???] army, under JOHNSTON, probably conjecture. His force is superior in members to that of the enemy. That is a fortunate circumstance certainly. But the rebels are every day strengthening their fortifications about Bowling Green, their forces have been reorganized  and their communications made more secure. Seventy thousand men -- if the rumor is true that there are so many -- thus fortified and intrenched, are no insignificant. [???] -- especially under the conduct of so able a General as JOHNSTON is known to be.

abstract: -- If we are to credit Southern judgment, the fifteen hundred men, which the City of Lowell has furnished to the army, are to be considered as a fair specimen of our volunteer force; and we are to look upon our whole army as a band of mercenaries -- of men who enlisted under the flag simply because they had nothing else to do. Now, we will venture the opinion that no, thousand and a half of the soldiers in Dixie know better what they are fighting for than the Lowell volunteers. The real truth is, the South is chagrined at the prosperity which the North enjoys in spice of the war, while she herself -- lacking this -- fights at a desperate venture, and throws back this prosperity upon us as a. taunt of cowardice. The fact that Lowell and other cotton-manufacturing cities do not immediately collapse, as a result of Southern rebellion, distinctly ml intimates that cotton will not be needed before it can be obtained, and that the thousands who depended upon the manufacturing interests for a livelihood are in no danger of the starvation, which certain journals predicted, in the Fad of 1861, a [???] to result from hostilities between the North and South. What aggrieves the rebels is that the starvation all seems to be on their own side.

abstract: It is very hard for us, as a nation, to be "crowed over," as the boys say. But it is becoming very evident that we must make up our minds to meet a good deal of that sort of thing from our affectionate British cousins' ...
lead_paragraph: The tone of many of their papers, commenting upon the state of feeling among us, before the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL is already most offensive in this respect. And we must expect when the news of that surrender reaches the shores of England, to leave it echo back to us in a full chorus of charges of cowardice, meanness and everything that is disgraceful to us, coupled with the loftiest eulogies of British power and valor and vitue of every kind. This is inevitable. From a portion of the English press we need expect nothing whatever of that "charily which thinketh no evil." It is never difficult for men tom find fault, especially with those whom they dislike. If we had refused to give the men up, if we had even temporized, the air of England would have been filled with outeries against our audacity, our deceit, our boorishness and the necessity of our being at once laught a lessen by that pattern of good manners - John Bull. As it is, the air will be as full of scorn for our cowardice, and threats of future lessons to be given to us by that eminent master, even if we have escaped for the present. This will be partly the natural outbreak of English feeling and partly it will be caused by a deliberate purpose. The party in England which sympathizes with the slave holders in the South rejoiced heartily over the prospect which the Tront affair affereded of their being able to assist their friends by bringing the army and navy of England [???] their waning fourtunes. This party will be woefully disappointed at the moderation of our Government which thus takes the ground from under their feet, and they will lose no opportunity of fanning the dying members of strife. They will do all in their power to vex as with words since they cannot as yet assail us with bullets, and thus in overpower that self-control of which we have shown so much more than they had given us credit for.

abstract: The New Orleans Bee says: "The Yankees conceive themselves moulded of a different clay from the rest of mankind." Now, this is precisely what "the Yankees" never have conceived. It has, however, on the other ...
lead_paragraph: hand, been the claim of Southerners for a generation or more that they were moulded our of a very superior sort of porcelain, while the North folks were fashioned of a very coarse potter's stuff. All that we have long asked is, that they should understand that they "clay" of both is very much of a piece; but it has required a surgical operation to get the idea into their heads.

abstract: ARREST OF A SOLDIER FOR SHOPLIFTING. Officer OATS, of the Third Precinct, yesterday arrested one of our volunteer soldiers upon the charge of stealing large quantities of goods form different stores in the City. The name of the accused is JOHN JOANS, ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A SOLDIER FOR SHOPLIFTING. -- Officer OATS, of the Third Precinct, yesterday arrested one of our volunteer soldiers upon the charge of stealing large quantities of goods form different stores in the City. The name of the accused is JOHN JOHNS, a private in one of the regiments of the New York volunteers. The stolen articles have been recovered. They consist of a soldier's secretary, a lady's secretary, three musical instruments, a large number of sold pens and pencil cases, six meerschaum pipes, two dozen pains of kid gloves and various other articles. Parties having lost property of this kind, are requested to appear at the Lower Police Court and identify it. Justice BRENNAN committed the accused for trial.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  As public attention is now being drawn toward this State as an important point for military operations, it occurred to me that a slight sketch of the secession movement there might be of some interest to yourself and the public generally. It was my misfortune to live through the per- ...
lead_paragraph: formance -- to watch the thing from the uprolling of the curtain, the beginning of the last act of the tragedy. That part, as well as the afterpiece, I hope to have the fortune to see performed. If I have my choice as to what the afterpiece shall be I think I shall suggest "A Tight Rope Performance," by WIGFALL and others.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, were presented petitions in favor of emancipation, and a memorial  against the appointment of a Solicitor of Customs. The resolution to approriate ten thousand dollars for the expenses of the Special Committee on the conduct of the War was passed. The House bill, ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, were presented petitions in favor of emancipation, and a memorial against the appointment of a Solicitor of Customs. The resolution to approriate ten thousand dollars for the expenses of the Special Committee on the conduct of the War was passed. The House bill, providing that the examination of a Witness before a committee of Congress shall not example him from examination before a court of justice, was debated for some then , and finally passed as it came from the House. A bill to authorize the President to take possession of certain railroads and telegraph lines was reported from the Special War Committee, and referred. Mr. Bright's case was then taken up, and Mr. Davis, of Kentucky, occupied the time until the adjournment, without concluding, in an argument in favor of Mr. Bright's expulsion.

abstract: The latest intelligence from Western Virginia is to the effect that Gen. JACKSON is near Romney, and partially occupies the town, while Gen. LANDER has fallen back a few miles toward Cumberland. There has been no action. Gen. WILLIAMS' brigade remains at Hancock.

abstract: The Citizen President to whom I have given account of the communication directed to you by the Commander of the Spanish naval forces, and of that which you sent tot that Chief in reply, has ordered me to say to you to follow punctually the instructions which have been given by him before hand for the case, which has now arrived, of the open commencement ...
lead_paragraph: The Citizen President to whom I have given account of the communication directed to you by the Commander of the Spanish naval forces, and of that which you sent tot that Chief in reply, has ordered me to say to you to follow punctually the instructions which have been given by him before hand for the case, which has now arrived, of the open commencement of hostilities on the part of the subjects of Spain, and that it is to be now left to the military action of Gen URADA, who commands in chief the Mexican army, to proceed in his sphere in conformity with the provis loss that have been made.

abstract: There remained unsold 208 head, at Twenty fourth street, the beginning of the week. There has been no transaction in fine stock of any description Sixteen head very good plain horses sold for shipping at $100 each. Railroad and omnibus Companies have purchased about a dozen this week at $80@$100 each. No demand for draught horses. There has been 30 condemned horses belonging to Government sold at auction -- prices from $4@$75 each. Sales for the week amount to 31 head, leaving on hand this evening, 197 head. There has been but one arrival of stock this week. The stables are remarkably healthy for this season of the year.

abstract: POLICY SHOP BROKEN UP. -- The Police of the Ninth Precinct, having broken up all the bone-boiling establishments, and abated nuisances generally in their district, are now turning their attention to the policy shops. On Tuesday night, Capt. WADDY, with a squad of men, made a sudden descent upon an in. stitution of this kind at the corner of Myrtle and Nostrand avenues, kept by a German named JACOB GESOE which they found in full operation, and arrested the proprietor and several other persons who were tempting dame Fortune in games of hazard. The partie were all brought before .Justice PERRY yesterday, and the proprietor was held to answer. His customer gave bail to appear as witnesses when wanted.

abstract: The British schooner Truro, of Maitland, N. S., Capt. COLTON, from Acquian, St. Domingo, arrived a this port yesterday, after a passage of 66 days, having touched at Gret inagua and Fortune Island for medical aid, the Captain, mate and two of the seamen being down with fever. At the latter place they were attended by a female physician, the widow of an English doctor, who treated the cases in a most skillful manner. After having partially recovered, and there being no seamen to be had. they proceeded to sea, and to their already unfortunate voyage, the were run Into by the bark Sea Eagle, from Gibara for Philadelphia, and left in a sinking condition, although repeatedly asked to lay by her ; and to still further cripple the. Schooner one of her crew, who had not been sick, got on tear the bark and was taken into Philadelphia, where it was reported that the Truro had sunk soon after the collision. But Capt. COLTON although very feeble an yet far from well, was not the man to give up, notwithstanding his how was stove it his bulwarks gone, Blank-shear split, foremast almost useless, and the ship leaking 1,000 strokes per hour, he by throwing overboard a part of his deck part, succeeded in stopping the leak, and almost the gales came from every quarter but a favorite one, succeeded in teaching Montank, and thence to Long Island Sound, and so to this City.

abstract: The loyal people south of Green River and this side of Bowling Green are getting impatient. Their criss of "Come over and help us" are louder and louder. They may soon be relieved. The buccaneers are burning railroad depots and other buildings, hotels, dwelling-houses, barns, everything which they can no longer use, and which would be of use to us, and are doing all they can to impede our progress.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Friday, Jan. 17, 1862.

abstract: The London Spectator one of the longest established, ablest, and highest-toned or English journals is among the first to attain that correct appreciation of the character and position of the Herald, to which the British public is gradually approaching, and which, when it has become general. Will tend greatly to the restoration of a mutual good understanding between the two countries. abstract: The Louisville Journal, of yesterday, says that twelve cannon were captured at Somerset, and thinks that the rebel army cannot escape, as from  seven to ten National regiments were thrown across the Cumberland River some days since to intercept their retreat. Unless they divide into squads and find their way into Tennessee by unfrequented paths they must all be entrapped.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI, Wednesday, Jan. 22.

abstract: -- There is no uniform method of settling the slave question possible. It will be settled, or will settle itself as the war goes on, in one way here, in other ways there. In Missouri, it is being solved by the removal of large numbers of the slaves into Arkansas and Texas, and by the flight of large numbers into Kansas and the Indian Territory. The disposal of the thousands who have freed themselves by flight there has been entirely different front the mode adopted in any other section; and the plan is, for that part of the country and for the domestic institution as it exists there, exceedingly simple and feasible. Rev. H. H. MOORE, of Kansas, who has lately been in charge of a large number of those slave refugees, has given, in a local newspaper, an account of his mode of disposing of them. It is briefly thus: He had on his hands, recently, 218 Missouri ex-slaves men. Women and children. The farmers and other residents, in the vicinity of his encampment across the Kansas line, came to his in large numbers, seeking to engage the services of these negroes as farmhands, laborers, servants, &c. One person wanted two or three of the men to work on his farm; another wanted a boy; another a family to occupy a vacant house; another a housemaid; another a little girl to bring up, and so on. And in that way homes and employment for the whole body were found among the farmers, and many more of these poor ex-slaves could have there found eager employers. Before parting with any one of them, his name, his age and the name of his old master were taken, a new name was given to him, and a written pledge was required from his guardian that he should he treated kindly and honestly. Several thousands of them have thus been disposed of in Kansas within the last few months, and so anxious are the farmers to secure the services of these faithful and industrious laborers, that it is [???] that all the spare slaves of Missouri would be gladly received and provided for. For the present Winter they will not, In general. receive much compensation other than boarding and lodging; but, with the planting time of next season, their regular wages will begin. Several free schools have been established for them, and there is nothing in the way of their indefinite social improvement. Thus and otherwise, the difficult question of solving the slave question in Missouri, is in the way of an easy enough solution; and one free State of the West is in the way of being furnished with an invaluable supply of labor. The slaves in Missouri are, in general, tolerably intelligent. Well trained to work, and quite capable of taking care of themselves as free workmen; and as hired labor has always been very difficult of obtainment in the free Western States, there is little fear of their becoming public burdens.
lead_paragraph: -- There is no uniform method of settling the slave question possible. It will be settled, or will settle itself as the war goes on, in one way here, in other ways there. In Missouri, it is being solved by the removal of large numbers of the slaves into Arkansas and Texas, and by the flight of large numbers into Kansas and the Indian Territory. The disposal of the thousands who have freed themselves by flight there has been entirely different front the mode adopted in any other section; and the plan is, for that part of the country and for the domestic institution as it exists there, exceedingly simple and feasible. Rev. H. H. MOORE, of Kansas, who has lately been in charge of a large number of those slave refugees, has given, in a local newspaper, an account of his mode of disposing of them. It is briefly thus: He had on his hands, recently, 218 Missouri ex-slaves men. Women and children. The farmers and other residents, in the vicinity of his encampment across the Kansas line, came to his in large numbers, seeking to engage the services of these negroes as farmhands, laborers, servants, &c. One person wanted two or three of the men to work on his farm; another wanted a boy; another a family to occupy a vacant house; another a housemaid; another a little girl to bring up, and so on. And in that way homes and employment for the whole body were found among the farmers, and many more of these poor ex-slaves could have there found eager employers. Before parting with any one of them, his name, his age and the name of his old master were taken, a new name was given to him, and a written pledge was required from his guardian that he should he treated kindly and honestly. Several thousands of them have thus been disposed of in Kansas within the last few months, and so anxious are the farmers to secure the services of these faithful and industrious laborers, that it is [???] that all the spare slaves of Missouri would be gladly received and provided for. For the present Winter they will not, In general. receive much compensation other than boarding and lodging; but, with the planting time of next season, their regular wages will begin. Several free schools have been established for them, and there is nothing in the way of their indefinite social improvement. Thus and otherwise, the difficult question of solving the slave question in Missouri, is in the way of an easy enough solution; and one free State of the West is in the way of being furnished with an invaluable supply of labor. The slaves in Missouri are, in general, tolerably intelligent. Well trained to work, and quite capable of taking care of themselves as free workmen; and as hired labor has always been very difficult of obtainment in the free Western States, there is little fear of their becoming public burdens.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, Judge MCCUNN presiding, William Griffin alias McDonald, native of Ireland, 34 years of age, was tried and Convicted of biga- my, in having married Anne Cannon, Dec. 13, 1861, he having another wife living at the time, whom he married in June, 1860. lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, Judge MCCUNN presiding, William Griffin alias McDonald, native of Ireland, 34 years of age, was tried and Convicted of biga- my, in having married Anne Cannon, Dec. 13, 1861, he having another wife living at the time, whom he married in June, 1860. Both of the marriage certificates were produced, the first marriage having been performed by Rev. Benjamin C. Cutler, rector of St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn, and the last by Rev. Geo. W. McC1osky, pastor of the Church of the Nativity, New-York. The prisoner was remanded for sentence on Saturday.

abstract: The Committee of Ways and Means yesterday reported to the House of Representatives the National Currency and Loan bill, which they had adopted after mature consideration in Committee. The bill proposes to legalize, as lawful tender in all money transactions of the country, United
lead_paragraph: The Committee of Ways and Means yesterday reported to the House of Representatives the National Currency and Loan bill, which they had adopted after mature consideration in Committee. The bill proposes to legalize, as lawful tender in all money transactions of the country, United States Notes of Circulation to the amount of $150,000,000, including the fifty million issue under the Act of July 17. This Circulation, and all other audited demands upon the Treasury, are made convertible into the Public Stocks. hearing six per cent. interest, and having twenty years to run. The new creation of these Stocks is limited by the bill to the recent estimates of Secretary ChASE for the service of the next seventeen months, -- that is, to the close of the fiscal year 1863. The Stocks are to bear the uniform rate of six per cent., but may, when so applied for, be expressed in the currency of any foreign State, and made payable abroad, to the equivalent of their par value in the Federal currency. Tue Notes of Circulation are to be made of the denominations of five dollars and upward.

abstract: CITIZEN PRESIDENT: Progress is a law of humanity: but this to develop itself has required among all peoples these terrible crises which are called revolutions. History teaches us that all nations to reach reform and true civilization have had to pass through terrible proofs and to suffer unhappy sacrifices, and it has been often seen that the most powerful peoples have touched upon the border of ruin, but have saved themselves notwithstanding by the faith and by the union of their sons.

abstract: The British schooner Truro, from St. Domingo, reached this port yesterday, alter a passage of sixty-six days. During the voyage, the Captain, mate, and two of the seamen, were attacked by a fever, and treated skillfully by a female physician ...
lead_paragraph: The British schooner Truro, from St. Domingo, reached this port yesterday, alter a passage of sixty-six days. During the voyage, the Captain, mate, and two of the seamen, were attacked by a fever, and treated skillfully by a female physician at Feriune Island, at which place the vessel stopped for medicinal aid. When the Truro left this place. She came in collision with the bark Sed Eagle, which disabled her seriously, but at length she succeeded in reaching this port. One of the crew of the Truro, who was in good health. jumped on board the bark and arrived in Philadelphia, leaving his companions to get along the best they could. The log-book of the Truro shows the many trials and privations through which the crew passed before they reached this port.

abstract: CHURCHES IN BOSTON. -- Unitarian, 24;Baptist, 14; Unitarian, Congregational, 12; Methodist, 12 Roman Catholic, 12; Episcopal,11 ; Universalist, 5; Presbyterian, 4; Second Advent, 2; Free-Will Baptist, 1; Friends, 1; Union Evangelical, J; Christian Church, 1 -- in all, 100. Of the above, there are four churches, dedicated within the last two months, viz.; Two Unitarian, one Methodist, and one Episcopal One of the Unitarian churches (Dr. GANKETT'S) is probably the most costly Protestant church in NewEngland. It is situated near the "Common" and public garden, in a commanding position; is built of New-Jersey freestone, with a stone spire 100 feet high, containing a chime of 15 bells. Their late place of worship, in Federal-street, was sold because of its t, inconvenience, and the Society realized from the sale seven-eighths of the cost of the new [???] The new Methodist Church is one of the most beautiful buildings in Boston, and is eligibly situated on Tremont-avenue.

abstract: We are still without intelligence from the Burnside Expedition, excepting through rebel channels. By way of Fortress Monroe, we have a dispatch dated Goldsborough, N. C., 21st, which states that one hundred vessels of the expedition were in Pamlico Sound, while twenty large steamers were outside at [???]. The women and children were leaving Newbern, in anticipation of an attack upon that city ; and it was believed that a simultaneous attack was to be made on Roanoke Island. Newbern is in Hyde County, on the Neuse River, and is a station of the Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad.

abstract: By the steamship City of New- York, which left Liverpool on the 8th and Queenstown on the 9th inst., we have intelligence four days later from Europe. The news is important. The English Dress and people bed learned of the Surrender of MASON and SLIDELL, which was received with the greatest satisfaction. Consols immediately advanced over one per cent., and cotton also had [???]. The day before the news was received in England, the London Times said that the surrender of those personages would be a greater blow the Confederate than a National victory on the Potomac, and be worth millions to the National Exchequer. Almost simultaneously with he arrival in England of the news of the rendition of the rebel Commissioners, another letter of Dr. RUSSELL's from this country, was published, predicting the Cabinet at Washington would refuse to surrender them. Time newspapers were still arguing about the recognition of the so-called Southern Confederacy, some pro and others con.

abstract: Gen. ARTHUR's report is one of the most interesting and valuable documents presented to the Legislature this year. Gen. ARTHUR has been on duty in this department only since December last, and has had but insufficient time to gather the important facts he sets forth before the Legislature. He treats of the forts and fortifications under the control of the United States Government, of their capability of armament and their present condition, with the guns new mounted, referring to the previous reports made to the Governor with regard to the ammunition and projectiles on hand at the forts. He states there is most urgent need at this moment to render existing fortifications efficient, and for an ample supply of heavy guns to complete their armament, and for ammunition and projectiles for their use. This subject is fully treated in the concluding recommendations of the report.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, petitions were presented for the employment of homeopathic physicians in the army. A joint resolution from the Michigan Legislature, in favor of the exchange of prisoners, with special reference to the case of Col. WILCOX, was presented and referred. A remonstrance from the underwriters, shipowners and others of Boston, against any interference with the Coast Survey, was presented.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, petitions were presented for the employment of homeopathic physicians in the army. A joint resolution from the Michigan Legislature, in favor of the exchange of prisoners, with special reference to the case of Col. WILCOX, was presented and referred. A remonstrance from the underwriters, shipowners and others of Boston, against any interference with the Coast Survey, was presented. The resolution presented by Mr. HALE, in reference to Marshal LAMON, declaring that he has been guilty of contempt of the Senate, was called up and passed. The bill for the completion [???] defences of Washington was passed, after being amended so that the forcing of safe. guards shall be punishable with death, and so that no new works of defence can be commenced. The bill to increase the clerical force of the War and Navy Departments was passed. The case of Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, was then taken up, and Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, concluded his speech advocating his expulsion, touching incidentally upon the Slavery question - emancipation, confiscation, etc. He was followed by Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa, and the Senate subsequentlv went into Executive Session without a vote on Mr. BRIGHT's case.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, petitions were presented for the erection of fortifications along the frontier, and in favor of the Metropolitan Health bill. The bill in reference to the Brooklyn Normal School was reported favorably, as was also the bill to prevent "shysters" from practicing in the Courts of Kings County. Among the bills introduced was one to regulate the fees of Sheriffs; one to reduce the expenses of the Insurance Department; one to regulate places of amusement in this City; one to alter the map of the City regarding Lexington-avenue, and one authorizing the construction of a railroad from Brooklyn to Newtown. The concurrent resolution in favor of the State assuming its quota of the National Tax was adopted.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, petitions were presented for the erection of fortifications along the frontier, and in favor of the Metropolitan Health bill. The bill in reference to the Brooklyn Normal School was reported favorably, as was also the bill to prevent "shysters" from practicing in the Courts of Kings County. Among the bills introduced was one to regulate the fees of Sheriffs; one to reduce the expenses of the Insurance Department; one to regulate places of amusement in this City; one to alter the map of the City regarding Lexington-avenue, and one authorizing the construction of a railroad from Brooklyn to Newtown. The concurrent resolution in favor of the State assuming its quota of the National Tax was adopted.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN the trial of Dr. Chas. Cobel for procuring an abortion' was commenced and occupied the entire day. The crime is alleged to have been committed on the 30th of September last, upon the person of Mary Ann Baker. The victim was placed upon the stand, and from her evidence it appeared that she came here from Troy, and consulted Dr. Cobel, who produced the abortion and strangled the child after it was born, Dr. Cobel is a German physician, about 50 years of age, and has been twice tried before on indictments for a similar offence. There are two indictments now pending against him. The case will be resumed this morning.

abstract: The Constitutional Convention of this State has been in session at Springfield, since the first Tuesday of this month. But little progress has been made, as yet. The Convention started off with the assumption of some novel powers claiming to be the supreme authority in the State, and that they were neither bound by the existing Constitution or the acts of the Legislature.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Monday, Jan. 20, 1862.

WELSR Forty-fifth Pennsylvama Volunteers, and Major WATSON, of the Eighth Michigan Volunteers, who was severely, and it was at first feared fatallv wounded in the battle a Port Royal Ferry on Jan. 1. abstract: It appears, by the latest accounts, that the rebel ranks first broke, at the battle of Somerset, before the bayonet charge of an Ohio regiment, and that a battery was taken by the sturdy Tennesseeans, also at the point of the bayonet. At Port Royal, the "chivalry" were in force enough to have withstood the landing of the National troops, and made, at least, a formidable resistance; but the moment it became apparent that a fight at close quarters Was imminent, they took themselves out of the way as quickly as possible. At rifle-cannon and long musket range, behind intrenchments, and on horseback, the insurgents stand to their arms and night well; but they, thus far, have shown little inclination to look their loyal countrymen in the face and resist the upholders of the Constitution hand to hand, except at overwhelming odds and advantage of position, as at Ball's B1uff It is but natural that men who know that they are defying law and trampling upon right should shrink from a direct encounter with the armed supporters of the law. This is ever the way with culprits. They keep out of reach if they can, and only fight when they are cornered. They must be met at close quarters. Pound away at them with cannon if you cannot get close to them, but if you can, then charge bayonets!
lead_paragraph: It appears, by the latest accounts, that the rebel ranks first broke, at the battle of Somerset, before the bayonet charge of an Ohio regiment, and that a battery was taken by the sturdy Tennesseeans, also at the point of the bayonet. abstract: The steamers from England are making long Winter voyages. The new ship City of New-York, of the Dale line of Liverpool, Queenstown and New-York packets, should have been here, in due course, on Tuesday last, whereas she only passed Cape Race, nearly fourteen days out, yesterday morning. Our news dispatch from that point will be found on another page of this paper.
lead_paragraph: It relates mainly to what was thought of the political advices carried out by the Europa which left Boston on Wednesday, Dec. 25' before Mr. SEWARD's reply to Earl RUSSSELL had been written. There was much disappointment felt in England at the inclusive tenor of the news. Generally, the effect was to add to the painful suspense between peace and war. A portion of the London Press drew the most unfavorable conclusion from the delay, and the special American correspondent of the London Times, in his letter by the Europa, gave apparent license, to this erroneous option. The mistake was not his first on the political situation of the United States, nor is it probable that it will prove to be his last. He has blundered most deplorably throughout his Washington correspondence. In the instance under notice he must have written at random, and without the slightest effort to inform himself as to the probable result of the Trent affair. He would have found, as late as the 23d or 24th December, no intelligent opinion to the purport that. MASON and SLIDELL would certainly not be given up. The whole drift of' newspaper diplomatic speculation at that time in New -- York and Washington was in the opposite direction,

abstract: editorial lauds Stanton praise of men after battle
snippet: editorial lauds Stanton praise of men after battle
lead_paragraph: A collection of NAPOLEON's speeches and general orders would show eloquence that would disgrace no orator of any age. Before the battle there came the few stirring words, reminding the Frenchmen of the glory past and the glory to come, or appealing to the dearest national sentiments -- and then the bolt was launched. All historians relate, too, that one of the secrets of his power over his soldiers were the few words of praise he could speak, even to the humblest private, after some heroic deed. A common soldier has distinguished himself. In the very battlefield, while the act is fresh. the happy man is called forth. The great General, addressing him familiarly, praises his bravery ; puts about his neck the cross of honor; his name is sent forth to Europe in the report; and henceforth he and his comrades are ready to dare wounds and death for such applause What, of all this, have we had in our service?

abstract: The secret of Gen. BURNSIDE'S destination has been well kept. Even the rebels, who are usually better informed than ourselves, seem to have been wholly at fault with regard to it; and now admit its presence in the sounds and waters of North Carolina with unaffected surprise. They certainly speak of being prepared ...
lead_paragraph: The secret of Gen. BURNSIDE's destination has been well kept. Even the rebels, who are usually better informed than ourselves, seem to have been wholly at fault with regard to it; and now admit its presence in the sounds and waters of North Carolina with unaffected surprise. They certainly speak of being prepared at every interior point for its reception. Form such speech, however, liberal discount must be indulged for braggadocia, and of the remainder little account need be made, in view of the time and facilities enjoyed for defence. There is this about the various ports and harbors within the waters of Albemarle and Pamlico: they cannot avail themselves of the fortifications erected by the National Government for the exclusion of foreign enemies, to shut out a National, forts for the defence of the upper North Carolina coast were fortunately placedUpon that outer sand-barrier, which, by the capture of the [???] forts and the destruction of Fort Morgan, at Ocracoke, has fallen into our hands. Left to their own resources, the rebels may have erected temporary works here and there at the months of the several estuaries discharging into the sounds; but we have no reason to believe any of them to be formidable in character, or more difficult to silence than those when protected Port Royal. The work of Gen. [???] sample force is therefore, free from serious obstacles. It has only to effect a landing at points as yet [???] to the rebels, and proceed without material resistance -- possibly with the aid of the loyal population of the State -- to the execution of its important plans.
headline: {'main': 'The Burnside Expedition in Pamlico Sound.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Burnside Expedition in Pamlico Sound.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An official account of such remarkable experiments, in this direction, conducted by Mr. STEVENS, at Hoboken, on the 11th inst. Before Gen. SCOTT, Gen. ANPERSON, Col. DEALAFIELD and other experts; and the detailed results of Mr. STEVENS' experiments on the 4th inst., already referred to in these columns, will be found in another part of this paper. A teninch navy gun was tilted into line with the steam-loading cylinder, swabbed, loaded with a 124-pound ball and fired four times in 139 consecutive seconds, the shortest time occupied by one series of these operations, being twenty-five seconds. A 225-pound elongated shot was afterward loaded with equal celerity; and it is , therefore, evident that projectiles of any weight and size can be rammed home by steam, as fast as that subtle artillerist, can lay hands on them, just as the hundred-inch piston of the ocean steamer can safely travel as many feet in a minute-as the miniature plunger of the "one-horse" engine. To prevent the possibility of accident from the heating of the gun by this almost continuous combustion within it, Mr. STEVENS has developed, we understand, an automatic apparatus for injecting water after each discharge, so that the half-minute firing may be continued for hours.
lead_paragraph: An official account of such remarkable experiments, in this direction, conducted by Mr. STEVENS, at Hoboken, on the 11th inst. Before Gen. SCOTT, Gen. ANPERSON, Col. DEALAFIELD and other experts; and the detailed results of Mr. STEVENS' experiments on the 4th inst., already referred to in these columns, will be found in another part of this paper. A teninch navy gun was tilted into line with the steam-loading cylinder, swabbed, loaded with a 124-pound ball and fired four times in 139 consecutive seconds, the shortest time occupied by one series of these operations, being twenty-five seconds. A 225-pound elongated shot was afterward loaded with equal celerity; and it is , therefore, evident that projectiles of any weight and size can be rammed home by steam, as fast as that subtle artillerist, can lay hands on them, just as the hundred-inch piston of the ocean steamer can safely travel as many feet in a minute-as the miniature plunger of the "one-horse" engine. To prevent the possibility of accident from the heating of the gun by this almost continuous combustion within it, Mr. STEVENS has developed, we understand, an automatic apparatus for injecting water after each discharge, so that the half-minute firing may be continued for hours.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF MR. GOTTSCHALK. This eminent artist the greatest and most original that America has yet produced arrived on Wednesday evening, in the steamship Columbia, from Havana. His concerts will commence immediately on the termination of Mr. GRAU'S opera season.
lead_paragraph: WALLAK's THEATRE. -- Mr. COWLEY's admired comedy, entitled "A Bold Stroke for a Husband," was the revival here last evening. It belongs to that large family of Spanish pieces of which LOPE DE VEGA is the honored patriarch. Given, a certain number of gallants, a coquettish heiress, an importunate father and a clever chambermaid, find the result, in ordinary literary hands, will be an addition like this to the same numerous progeny. Mrs. COWLEY was a woman of esprit, and could not be dull. Her conception of character is never injurious to the intellect. All her people speak well; they would shine in the best society, but they have "gone out" in the world's esteem, simply because they have no heart. HORACE WALPOLE, when he saw the sculptures at Florence, said that the statues formed a congregation of highly respectable people, for whom he had a great deal of unruffled regard; and a feeling somewhat similar is now experienced for the characters of all the old comedies that depend on gallantry and intrigue for their interest. Not that these qualities have gone out of fashion, but because society no longer regards them as the sufficient attributes of gentlemen and chambermaids.

abstract: The tone of the English papers most recently received, indicates quite clearly that the surrender of MAS0N and SLIDELL will remove but one of the pretexts by which the Tories have hoped to bring about a war with our Government. Very probably we shall, in time, hear more of the stone blockade, notwithstanding its apparent inefficiency at Charleston. We observe a lingering inclination here and there to hunt up precedents to justify a resort to such an expedient, and some of our cotemporaries continue to lay much stress upon the fact that half a century ago England tried to close some 6f the harbors on our Northern lakes, as well as that of Boulogne, in the same way.

abstract: Our special correspondent, who has been stationed at Port Royal, recounts at the close of his letters, elsewhere in this paper, the circumstances attending his peremptory dismissal from the lines of Gen. SHERMAN. An ambiguous expression in the published description of the engagement at Port Royal Ferry was understood by that commander as transferring the credit of the affair referred to from himself to Gen. STXVENS. He at once charged our correspondent, whose relations with the General had previously been of the most friendly character, with violating the truth of history at his expense, and used language which reflection soon suggested the necessity of qualifying -- a direction in which he went so far as to explain his strictures as applying not merely to the correspondence of the TIMES, but to that of the entire Press. Nevertheless, the writer for this paper Was selected as the victim of singular malignity. He was suddenly placed under arrest, carried forcibly on board the steamer about to sail for New-York, and was thus most unjustly removed from the theatre of his appointed labors.

abstract: editorial on news from Port Royal
snippet: editorial on news from Port Royal
lead_paragraph: The chemist LIEBIG affirms that the civilization of a people is accurately determined by the amount of soap it uses. Without disputing the justness of this standard we may hazard the assertion that it should not exclude others, and that one important measure of intellectual advancement is the degree of extension of epistolary correspondence. In this regard we are able to report good progress for South Carolina under the Union r�gime. The mail which the Atlantic brought yesterday from Port Royal to this City was swelled by no less than thirty thousand letters. It is stated, moreover, that the number of letters now sent from the New -- York post-office to Port Royal is equal to twice the amount formerly transmitted to the whole State of South Carolina. These are certainly notable statistics, and they bring out in startling antithesis the differentiating element of Northern and Southern civilization. It. cannot be said that either the disposition (on our part) or the facility for a free interchange of correspondence between New-York and South Carolina has been hitherto wanting. New-York has always been more Southern than any other city of the North, has always cultivated the closest ties, commercial and social, with the South. And yet the presence of a few thousand Northern volunteers on the Carolina coast swells the mails to an extent which the entire correspondence of the State never approached in ante-secession days.

abstract: The letters from Hilton Head, to which we gave place yesterday, contain no more interesting information than that relating to the condition of the negroes. On the several islands occupied by our troops the aggregate number is about 8,000.
lead_paragraph: The letters from Hilton Head, to which we gave place yesterday, contain no more interesting information than that relating to the condition of the negroes. On the several islands occupied by our troops the aggregate number is about 8,000. These, we are told, generally continue of occupy the quarters, and pursue the labors which constituted their homes and business before their masters became fugitives, yielding readily to the superintendence of Col. REYNOLDS and his assistants, who have been intrusted with the duty of utilizing the products of their industry. They go early afield, perform the customary daily task, receive pay either in coin or in liberal rations of food and supplies of clothing -- the majority wisely preferring to forego the money - and show no disposition to lapse into that incurable indolence, which is so freely predicted of the slave uncompelled by the lash of an overseer. From involuntary they have suddenly become voluntary laborers. From the condition of machines they have been raised to the responsibility of free agents. And yet, abrupt and radical as the change has been, we discover no tendency to insubordination and disorder; no defective appreciation of the relation between labor and food; no eagerness to test their freedom by unlimited riot and self-indulgence. The industrial machinery moves on as if eight thousand brutes had not, like the victims of Ciree, been converted in a twinkling into men, with all the rights, privileges and liberties of manhood. They realize the necessity of education, and resort to the schools benevolence has opened for them. They value religious instruction, and attend voluntarily the church of which a Northern clergyman is the minister. In every way they exhibit a reasonable sense of the duties and exigencies of their condition, and if that sense partake rather of the instincts of the child, than of the judgment of the man, we know too well where the accountability for the defect is to be placed; and at the same time discover a sure foundation upon which a more decided character, and more matured understanding, may be raised.

abstract: The Saturday Review in a speculative article on the chances of a pacific reply from our Government to the English demand for the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL, justly observes that, had the Transatlantic Telegraph been an actuality, the British Government might haven been spared the heavy cost of her recent war preparations.
lead_paragraph: The Saturday Review in a speculative article on the chances of a pacific reply from our Government to the English demand for the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL, justly observes that, had the Transatlantic Telegraph been an actuality, the British Government might haven been spared the heavy cost of her recent war preparations. This is no doubt true, and the fact is one which John Bull will feel in his most sensitive spot - for twenty millions will not cover the cost of what he had been and done all along of the honor of the flag. It can hardly be expected, however that we are to feel any great pity for him on that score. And, besides, there are some other aspects of the telegraphic question that are worth looking at a moment.

abstract: -- Messrs. APPLETON & Co., the eminent publishers, are devoting much attention to the manufacture of those ornaments of the drawing-room table, Photographic Albums. abstract: -- The meagre knowledge of the art of embalmment of human bodies has heretofore been so little known anti practiced in this country, that very few, comparatively speaking, have availed themselves of its gratifying utility. Even thus far have many of our best soldiers fallen, whose homes were so far away that absent friends have been deprived of even looking upon their faces again, front the horrifying spectacle of decay. Drs. C.D. BROWN and J.B. ALEXANDER, of this City, have opened In Washington a place where our heroes may be embalmed on the most approved French principles. These gentlemen possess, perhaps solely in this country, the celebrated [???] secret.
