abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill appropriating $10,000 for the expenses of the Committee on Contracts, was passed. A bill to create two new bureaus in the Navy Department was referred. A bill providing a charter for certain banks in the District of Columbia was also referred.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill appropriating $10,000 for the expenses of the Committee on Contracts, was passed. A bill to create two new bureaus in the Navy Department was referred. A bill providing a charter for certain banks in the District of Columbia was also referred. The credentials of ROBERT WILSON, the new Senator appointed form Missouri were presented, and after some explanations by Senators POMPROY of Kansas, and DAVIS of Kentucky going to prove that the charges of disloyalty made against Mr. WILSON were unfounded, he was admitted to his seat, and took the requisite oath. The bill relating to certain judicial districts of the united States Circuit Court, was passed. Mr. BRIGHT'S case was then again considered, but not disposed of. Speeches were made by Messrs. DAVIS of Kentucky, HARLAN of Iowa, Cowan of Pennsylvania HARRIS of New-York, TEN EYEK of New Jersey, and CLARK of New-Hampshire. The Senate then went into executive session and subsequently adjourned until Monday.

abstract: TIMES of yesterday, we gave place to the complaint of "A Parent," in regard to the merciless lessons assigned to pupils in one of our primary schools.
lead_paragraph: TIMES of yesterday, we gave place to the complaint of "A Parent," in regard to the merciless lessons assigned to pupils in one of our primary schools. Of the confirmatory statements with which we have since been deluged, we can only publish one or two ; and say of the rest, that they present painful evidence that the wisdom and sound judgment which, in other matters, prevail in our public school system, fail to reach this all-important subject. The scholars. We fear, are too generally overtasked. Health is the first requisite of manhood and womanhood. But when hours of confinement in school are too much protracted, and are then followed by hours of confinement at home over tasks with which the memory wrestles vainly, education does all it can accomplish to destroy the body, dwarf the mind, and discourage wholesome emulation. The error probably lies in assuming the capacity of the readiest scholar as the standard for all, and then by marks of merit or deficiency endeavoring to spur all to the attainment of that standard. It very often happens, however, that memory is given to those who have no other valuable mental trail, and the stimulus only places the light weights in advances ; while the student of far clearer perceptions, and sounder understanding -- the embryon of the future great man -- is degraded. disheartened and most unjustly shamed by his roll of demerit. What is wanted is a reduction of scholastic difficulties to a half-way plane, to which the slower minds will have to climb, and to which the more rapid ones may descend. Then, by a moderate appeal to the principle of emulation, justice may be done to the merits of all ; no mind will be overwrought ; physical education will have a chance to keep pace with intellectual ; and to the labors of the juvenile student will not be added that intense and cruel sense of care and anxiety, from which childhood should be scrupulously screened, and to which the actual system of excessive stimulus untimely exposes it. The error of the prevalent system may be ascribed to the well-intentioned, but inconsiderate ambition of teachers, to "bring on" their scholars with the utmost rapidity. It results in making no intelligent scholar a bit more intelligent while it creates dunces by the score. Let us, ladies and gentlemen, have a little less of the whip and spur! It is helpless childhood that cries to you.

abstract: get from our correspondent at Topeka some documents in relation to the recent battle, or rather battles, between the Union Indians and the rebels. It appears that there have been three different engagements, in which some four thousand loyal warriors from the five principal Nations had taken part against the mongrel rebels, under ALBERT PIKE.
lead_paragraph: get from our correspondent at Topeka some documents in relation to the recent battle, or rather battles, between the Union Indians and the rebels. It appears that there have been three different engagements, in which some four thousand loyal warriors from the five principal Nations had taken part against the mongrel rebels, under ALBERT PIKE. In the first two battles the united tribes of loyalists were successful in repulsing the enemy ; but PIKN, taking advantage of a moment when the majority of the warriors were off obtaining supplies, attacked their camp, routed their unsuspecting forces, slaughtering them indiscriminately, and drove the remnant out of the Nation. At latest advieces they had arrived on the Cherokee Neutral Lands in Kansas, utterly destitute, with worn-out ponies and worn-out feet, leaving bloody tracks wherever they went. The concocter and leader of this atrocious massacre of these poor but loyal redskins, was the poet, ALBERT PIKE, a native of Boston, formerly a schoolteacher in Newburyport, Mass., and who, but few years ago, published his "Hymns to the Gods," in his native city. But PIKE had the misfortune to marry a woman with a dozen Slaves, in Arkansas, and from that time he has been gradually transformed into a savage, till now he has taken up arms against his Government, and taken the field with his halfbreeds against the full-blooded Indians who would defend it.

abstract: Hon. D.S. DICKINSON, the Attorney-General of the State, lectured at the Hoboken Baptist Church, last evening, on The Union Its Hopes and Its Fears. The lecture was the third in the course before the Hoboken Baptist Church, and, as usual, the citizens of our promising neighbor turned out in large numbers in support of this, the first attempt to establish a course of lectures in Hoboken.
lead_paragraph: Hon. D.S. DICKINSON, the Attorney-General of the State, lectured at the Hoboken Baptist Church, last evening, on The Union -- Its Hopes and Its Fears. The lecture was the third in the course before the Hoboken Baptist Church, and, as usual, the citizens of our promising neighbor turned out in large numbers in support of this, the first attempt to establish a course of lectures in Hoboken. The lecture was mainly that recently delivered by Mr. DICKINSON at the Academy of music. The speaker commenced by reviewing the position of the Republic at the out break of this infamous rebellion, and the reasons why it was impossible for us to do anything else but put down that rebellion. Since it had not been crushed as it should have been, it must be plucked up by the roots. [Applause.] It was fox in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, and lion in strength. He who would crush would be remembered when the shades of tradition had passed away forever. [Applause] Its ministering spinets were not the ignorant and vulgar, but the interregna men in whom a confiding people had reposed their trust. They could see its origin in the work of Senators. Cabinet officers and every department of the Government who had deliberately betrayed the Government and people upon whom they had fattened. Treachery in the army and navy and betrayed the union through us sworn defenders. The Confederated robbers who had stolen the Government's gold, had not even left a subcultures of cotton. As to their bends, they treated men own citizens worse than the Governed. As HOSEA BIGELOW said, "They went off middle well for drinks, when there was a knee beheads them".[Laughter and applause.] The exile object of the rebellion was to rear a mannerly on the ruins of this Republic with cotton for its king, and Slavery as the principal jewel in its diadem Judas Iscariot had lived before his time; if he had lived in the Nineteenth Country he would have been called upon to do the work of murkier for less than thirty pieces of silver. [Laughter.] But Judas set a good example to traitors -- lie went and hanged himself [Laughter and applause.] The speaker thrillingly destitute the signings of the traitor ARNOLD in his later info If just had lived to this time, he might have asked that java should secede under his urea -- [Laughter] -- and [???] too, might taken share in the same Government and glut his avarice on secession bonds. [Laughter.] Smith Carolinas hated our original Union and had inaugurated the rebellion. It was bow reaping its harvest. Like Narcissus, it would be wasted by its own passion. If it should be reproduced as a dower, it would be fortunate if like the century plant, it would bloom but once in a had years, and of a kind that could not propagate its peruses. [Laughter.] The goal of the exportations of south Carolina has been reached. Direct trade with foreign nations has been granted her by Commodore Durant. He his opened a cadet without tariffs or custom-houses, or unembarrassed by long credits. As the Yankee save she shell out, [Laughter.] A portion of Causation is in asnes; -- who was the consequences of war. They have been anxious for secession. But now they have turned to contemplate their terrible picture of coronation. North [???] has been plunged in the dismast swamp of secession by conspiring pebble lands But her loyal noble ware trying to secede from secession. Where old Virginia -- the old Denison, the both-was place and gave of WASHINCROS, where is she how? Dragged, against the popular will into secession. In a empting to tear her of away from the Union, she has torn out her own vitas. Like CASAR, her heart has been pierced by conspirators and traitors, button ANTONY comes to bury, much less to praise her. [Applause.] Slavery, for which she has gone to war, has worked its own abolition. Her wealth, instead of taking wings to fly away, has taken legs and run away. [Laughter.] And all this too, not to bring [???] or freedom to man, but that a few scurvy politicians might rule a bark imps mob , called the Confederate states. [Applause.] If Virginia survives, the poisoned tunic of repetition will cling to her; if she expires, she will remain a monument of self destruction. Time has leaped toward half a century at a singles bound. Great events a wait us. We should [???] it in the destruction of party, the enlargement of patriotism, the expanse of linearity. But we must first crush the rebellion a rebellion raised by those who would rather reign in hell than serves in heaven" We are paying at stakes with the cause of liberty at the hazard. The masses of the sonar people are yet level and would return to their allegory expect for an armed mob directed by conspiracy. They will now yield only to force, and we are now bound to put for ward our whole power and strike our fee where it is weakest. We can strike between the joints of the harness. We should contacted the property of rebels tonally, absolutely [???] take every one of their slaves, and let Congress take some homage disposition of them -- [Applause] -- rush the retention by any and every means known by Christiaruy. [Applause] There can be no compromise with rebellion. It we compromise these we shall soon have no Government to compromise. The traitors have deliberately done their work. They seized upon an occasion when they might best inflating the Southern in and . If this ribbon was about [???] it would hare spring up [???] Success. But, on the contrary, the Border States had thought against session. The secret of the rebellion was in the horse of office seekers and fortune [???]. Florida, that could never live a fortnight without the General Government, was seeking her rights. [Laughter.] Why, She had hardly supported her own alligators. [Laughter.] Now either Government must conquer rebellion or sick beneath it. The very vitality and existence of this Government is at stake. We may weil in [???], "Who is upon the Lord's side?" Those who are not for the Union are against it. Lukewarm friends were worse than open enemies. We should be able to say with the elder BRUTUS, "A man may have many children, but he can have but one country." The hope of the rebellion had been in the countenance of loyal States, and if we should present a united front. It would carry terror to the hearts of the traitors. We must act in concert, all [???] together, and let the standard of merit be ardor in the cause, as when at the con fiagration none ask how it came, but all with one accord work to extinguish the flames; just so when they went to save the burning fabric of the Union, they stopped not to ask the cause of the fire, or which were the Democrats or Republicans, but they went as men to save the Republic. [Applause.] To consent to division of the Union, is to consent to destruction. We must strangle the serpent by the best means known to modern warfare. Whoever counsels division as a means of peace, counsels death. We can only consent to a disruption with the last breath of a strangled Union. [Applause.] Like the several members of the human frame, all parts of the Union are essential to each other. What section of the Union could surrender its right to Lexington and Bunker Hill? Who will carry a rebel passport to the grave of WASHINGTON? But can Government coerce a State? It can maintain the laws, and it will be for metaphysicians to determine whether the State has been coerced. When any State should refuse to send representatives to places of emolument, the day of millenium would have arrived. [Laughter] The rebellion was based upon infantry, cavalry and artillery, instead of liberty, equality and fraternity. [Laughter.] They were entitled to the benefit of having made the discovery of a system of government like the note of a swallow in a sand-bank, after the sand-bank had been removed. [Laughter.] The principles of the Confederate Government would shame a pirate or freebooter -- DICK TURPIN or ROBIN Hone. They did not steal -- oh, no. They merely "resumed" possession of the Government property. [Laughter.] Our fathers courted independence, but the struggle is forced upon us. The history of man is a history of conflicts. What though there be volumes of taxation and effusion of blood --

abstract: -- Whoever will call to mind the promptness with which Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, has equipped and sent forward regiments to the seat of war, must acknowledge that he is a man of deeds; his famous Message to the State Legislature proved that he was a man of words as well, and a respectable pamphlet of eighty-six pages, containing correspondence which he has had during the last five months with Gen. BUTLER, demonstrate quite conclusively that he is also a man of letters. The provocation to the interchange of compliments which resulted in this formidable volume, was certain unwarranted assumptions which the General made as commander of the Department of New-England. The fact that the conclusion of the whole matter was a pledge from the War Department to carry out any programme which Gov. ANDREW might lay down, even to the abolition of the Department of New-England, shows which got the better of this epistolary duel. Perhaps the community at large would feel more interest in the affair, did they know that this dispute added at least $37,500 to the expenses of the war, by detaining the Constitution with part of Gen. BUTLER'S Brigade on board, fifteen days in Boston Harbor, at a cost of $2,500 per day for the charter of the vessel alone.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to prohibit County Treasurers from using the money of the State, relative to the United States Deposit Fund, and to increase the duty on salt.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to prohibit County Treasurers from using the money of the State, relative to the United States Deposit Fund, and to increase the duty on salt. Bills were introduced -- to define the duties of State Prison Inspectors, and to amend the City Charter of Brooklyn. The bill to increase the powers of Notaries Public was passed. A resolution introduced by Mr. PRUYN, providing for a general law authorizing aliens to hold and convey real estate under certain restrictions, was laid on the table. A Committee was appointed to ascertain what clerkships the Senate can dispense with. A motion was made to adjourn over until Monday evening, but it was lost by the casting vote of the Lieutenant-Governor.

abstract: An order has been received from the War Department to discharge the bandsmen of the First Infantry, who were taken prisoners in Texas, and came North about six months ago. All the members of the band have accordingly been discharged, except  Mr. DUNLEAVY, the Bandmaster, who is absent on fur- lough.
lead_paragraph: An order has been received from the War Department to discharge the bandsmen of the First Infantry, who were taken prisoners in Texas, and came North about six months ago. All the members of the band have accordingly been discharged, except Mr. DUNLEAVY, the Bandmaster, who is absent on furlough. When these men came from Texas, several of them applied for their discharge, but no notice has been taken of their applications until now.

abstract: of War has the genius to speak the words the Nation will welcome. His first order had the tone of the trumpet in it, and addressed itself to the instinct of military glory; but his order to-day strikes a softer tone, and will vibrate through the hearts of the people.
lead_paragraph: -- It is obvious that the new Secretary of War has the genius to speak the words the Nation will welcome. His first order had the tone of the trumpet in it, and addressed itself to the instinct of military glory; but his order to-day strikes a softer tone, and will vibrate through the hearts of the people. This Department recognizes as the first of its duties to take measures for the relief of the brave men who, having imperiled their lives in the military service of the Government, are now prisoners and captives." Accordingly two Commissioners are ordered to be appointed to proceed to Richmond and elsewhere, and, so far as the Confederate authorities will permit, take such measures as, may be needful to provide for the wants and contribute to the comfort of the prisoners they find, at the expense of the United States. It will be seen that it is the relief, not the release, of the captives that is contemplated. The latter result can best be brought about by the informal process of exchange now inaugurated; but so far as alleviating the sufferings of our captured soldiers goes-and those sufferings we know are neither few nor slight -- there can be no objection to the Government's taking such steps as may be conducive to that end. The country will recognize in this measure the appreciation of the tender solicitude felt at the North for those who pine in the prisons and dungeons of the South.

abstract: A passenger on the Covington and Lexington Railroad informs the Cincinnati Enquirer that a terrible tragedy took place on the Billoe's Mill Road, near Harrodsburgh, Ky., on Saturday evening, June 11. It appears that a man named EDWARD SCOTT, a school.
lead_paragraph: A passenger on the Covington and Lexington Railroad informs the Cincinnati Enquirer that a terrible tragedy took place on the Billoe's Mill Road, near Harrodsburgh, Ky., on Saturday evening, June 11. It appears that a man named EDWARD SCOTT, a school teacher of much distinction in that part of the State, had married a widow TILFORD. Daughter-in-law of the late Major TILPORD, of Lexington, Ky., and on the evening above named Scott entered the room where the family were sitting, and without saving a single word, drew a revolver and fired at EDWARD TILFORD, a lad 11 years of age, killing him instantly. At this juncture the children rushed screaming out of the room. As the family were flying in great consternation, SCOTT fired at Miss EMMA TILFORD, aged about 18 years, and she fell bleeding to the floor, and died the next morning, A younger Miss TILFORD was also shot in the aim. SCOTT pursued the remainder of the family, but they succeeded in eluding him. and escaped. All the children were these belonging to his wife. SCOTT ransacked the house from top to bottom, breaking and destroying everything in his reach, and fearful of being pursued by his neighbors, who had assembled to protect the family, he ran above stairs, fastened the trapdoor, and cut loop-holes in the roof to fire upon his captors when they approached. After much man�nvering, he was felled by a blow from a neighbor, who came upon him in a different way from then safely secured and lodged in jail, to wait an examination. When taken, SCOTT was found to be well armed with revolvers, two double-barreled shot guns, a United States musket, a hatchet and a butcherknife; so that the horrible butchery of the helpless and unoffending family must have been coolly premeditated.

abstract: No direct news from the Burnside expedition has yet reached us; and we are this morning even without the usual rumors from the rebels regarding it. A flag of truce came down from Norfolk to Fortress Monroe on Thursday, but brought nothing additional. We obtain some knowledge
lead_paragraph: however, of the measures taken by the rebels in North Carolina to repel the expected invasion. The militia have been ordered out in the thirty three most eastern counties, and a draft has been made in Wake County.

abstract: The Grand Jury for the December term concluded its tabors yesterday. The presentment states that the jurors have been in session twenty-eight days, during which time they have acted upon 456 bills of indictment, of which they have presented 297 true bills, and ignored 159. reference is made to visits to the public institutions, and the grand jurors say that the County Prison should be relieved from the care of certain insane persons now confined there and who are more properly subjects for the Almshouse. At the Almshouse the Grand Jury that 1,000 pairs of socks had been manufactured and contributed to the army. A play-ground is recommended for the insame patients at the Almshouse. The following reference is then made to the concert saloons now open in the city: "They regard as very injurious to the morals of the community the increase in the number of drinking and concert saloons, particularly where liquor is dealt out by women of doubtful character, to minors."

abstract: "Wriggles" has a kind of influence, and so has the Herald; and the influence is of the same sort, and has been obtained in the same way. In fact, so similar are the means taken to secure success by "Wriggles" and the edittor of the Herald, and so identical is the kind of success which they have both attained, that it has been reasonably supposed that they are one and the same person.
lead_paragraph: "Wriggles" has a kind of influence, and so has the Herald; and the influence is of the same sort, and has been obtained in the same way. In fact, so similar are the means taken to secure success by "Wriggles" and the edittor of the Herald, and so identical is the kind of success which they have both attained, that it has been reasonably supposed that they are one and the same person. "Wriggles" was determined to make a sensation, and of course also to get money by it. And, therefore, you suppose he came out with a flaming advertisement, telling the world, once for all, that he was the great "Wriggles," the "Wriggles" unequaled in time past, present and to Come; the "Wriggles" who lived by eating his own words, and took exercise by jumping down his throat, and then waited, expecting the pot of public excitement to boil over, and its froth to turn into fairy gold for his expectant pocket. Not a bit of it. That is not Wriggletonian style.

abstract: At a late hour last night, the United States authorities in this City took into custody two men, who are charged with being engaged in fitting out a vessel for the coast of Africa, to obtain a cargo of negroes. One of the accused is stated, upon good authority, to be a wealthy and prominent New-York merchant. As a matter of prudence, the names of the parties implicated and the circumstances attending the seizure are withheld from the public for a day or two.

abstract: Gen. SIGEL and we are sure there are few men in the loyal States who are not the friends and admirers of that time, gallant and scientific soldier will be glad to learn semi-offici-  ally from Washington that no news of his...
lead_paragraph: -- The friends of Gen. SIGEL -- and we are sure there are few men in the loyal States who are not the friends and admirers of that time, gallant and scientific soldier -- will be glad to learn semi-officially from Washington that no news of his reported resignation has been received at headquarters. The President assured the German Committee from this City, who waited upon him, of that fact, and added that so highly did he esteem Gen. SIGEL'S services that he should decline to accept his resignation, but would give him a command in or out of Missouri, in accordance with his eminent abilities. He further said that he had instituted inquiries with the view to redress any wrong the General may have suffered; and that nothing had transpired to diminish his personal confidence in his skill and valor. This contradiction of a rumor which has caused such deep feeling among a large class of citizens, is very gratifying, and will do much to put at rest the charges of Know-Nothingism and West Point persecution which are rife in certain quarters. There is little danger in this war of the services of any officer or soldier who does anything, being long overlooked or undervalued. The people keep an eye on every movement, and know the names of every actor, and a thousand Presses chronicle their deeds; while no injustice or partiality will be tolerated. The President was but the mouthpiece of the nation, in using the language and expressing the sentiments which he did.

abstract: A delegation of newsboys were Friday evening present by invitation at the Temperance gathering in the Factory building. Cottage-place. After eloquent addresses by the missionaries most active in this laudable movement, the audience were pleasingly entertained by a patriotic song from "Paddy Beef," a bright particular star of the "Lodging-house." He was succeeded by another shining light of the same fraternity, dubbed by his comrades "Henry Ward Beecher." The performances were highly satisfactory to those of the friends of the Temperance movement who were assembled, and the increased interest in each succeeding meeting indicates a substantial support for the workers who are actively employed throughout this Industrial School district.
lead_paragraph: A delegation of newsboys were Friday evening present by invitation at the Temperance gathering in the Factory building. Cottage-place. abstract: In the Senate a petition was presented for the incorporation of the State Homoeopathic Society. A bill to stop the sale of swill milk was reported. The bill in relation to unauthorized banking was then debated in Committee of the Whole during the rest of the session.
lead_paragraph: In the Assembly, a favorable report was made on the bill to repeal the act relative to the publication of legal notices. The report was laid on the table. The bill to incorporate the New-York and Brooklyn Passenger and Baggage Express Company was introduced. Objection was made to its introduction, on the ground that it had already been rejected by the Assembly; but the objection was overruled, and it was referred to the Committee on the Affairs of Cities. Other bills were introduced -- to regulate the lees for searches in the County Clerk's Office in this City; to punish frauds on laborers; to authorize Justices of the Peace to act in absence of Coroners; to establish academical departments in the free schools and other institutions of learning, and to authorize the incorporation of juvenile reformatory associations. In reply to a resolution of inquiry passed in the Assembly, the Governor sent in a communication, stating that volunteers who had enlisted, and had been honorably discharged after medical examination, had not been paid. The question whether legislation is necessary to secure pay to such men was referred to the Judge Advocate. The resolution recommending butter as a portion of the army rations was called up and passed, after being amended so as to include cheese also. The concurrent resolutions from the Senate, assuming the State's quota of the National tax: in favor of a law of Congress authorizing the States to assess and collect their proportion of the tax; and fixing the 30th inst. for the election of a Superintendent of Public Instruction and a Regent of the University. The bill to authorize the Supervisors of Kings County to raise a fund for the support of the families of volunteers was set down for debate in the first Committee of the Whole.
headline: {'main': 'THE STATE LEGISLATURE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE STATE LEGISLATURE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A railroad engineer, who was present at the Green River fight, which the rebels claim as a victory, gives the following account of it:
lead_paragraph: "Four weeks ago, the tressel which we ??? last September over Rolling Fork, in place of the burned bridge, was washed away by afreshet, and it was necessary to rebuild it in the shortest possible time, as the army beyond were without supplies and depending entirely upon the railroad. After Rolling Fork was built up again, another bridge, which in the meantime had been destroyed a second time by the rebels, (and this in the fane of our own army,) had to be repaired ; and after this was done the army moved to the north bank of the Green River, where I have been for the last week engaged in tresseling the two spans destroyed by the rebel forces. They have blown up the southern pier, which was ninety feet high, and made a total ruin of the two southern spans.
headline: {'main': 'THE FIGHT AT GREEN RIVER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FIGHT AT GREEN RIVER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: For some time past, worthy citizens have been endeavoring to establish a new up-town free school for German scholars. Their efforts have met with cheering success, and the half-yearly report of the Fourth-street Free School, the institution alluded to, is gratifying to the friends of that excellent undertaking.
lead_paragraph: Instruction is imparted to some hundreds of scholars of both sexes by five German and two American male teachers, and one female teacher, and the condition of the classes is eminently satisfactory.

abstract: To-day a poor woman, a widow, arrived here from the neighborhood of Campton, county seat of Wolfe County, having left home (once a home) to try to avoid starvation. The rebels, under FICKLEN, a subordinate of HUMPHREY MARSHALL, had robbed her of her all. She left home to try to find bread by begging from Union men.

lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star, ten days from Aspinwall, with the mails, passengers and treasure from California, arrived at this port last night. She left New-York on the 1st inst., at 12 M., and arrived at Aspinwall on the 10th inst., at 6 P.M.; sailed again on the 15th inst., at 12 M., and arrived at New-York on the 25th inst., at 9 P.M. She experienced heavy head winds in the Carribean Sea, and encountered a very heavy gale from the northeast on the southern edge of the Gulf stream, which lasted three days. She brings $602,767 in specie, consigned as follows:

abstract: By letters received from Cequimbo at Valparai so, we hear that the American ship Panama, which arrived at the former place from Puget Sound, fell in, in the latitude of Ecuador, with the Chilian bark Coronel Picarte, Capt. HALEY, abandoned, and at the...
lead_paragraph: By letters received from Cequimbo at Valparaiso, we hear that the American ship Panama, which arrived at the former place from Puget Sound, fell in, in the latitude of Ecuador, with the Chilian bark Coronel Picarte, Capt. HALEY, abandoned, and at the mercy of the winds and waves, which bark sailed from California on the 12th of July last for Valparaiso, with a cargo of pine lumber for Senor JOSE SALAMANCA, of Valparaiso. Nothing is yet known of the fate of the officers and crew, but it is feared there has been a revolt and an assassination, as the Panama found on board the bark a box containing all the papers of the bark, which, if the Captain had been obliged to abandon his vessel, he certainly would have taken with him. Besides, the bark had sustained, from appearances, no injury which could cause her to be abandoned. Neither the vessel or cargo were insured.

abstract: The following is the present location of the National regiments in Western Virginia: The Forty-seventh Ohio, Col. PORCHNER, is at Tompkins' Farm above Gauley Bridge; the Twenty-eighth Ohio, Col. MORSE, at the Bridge; the Twenty-third and Thirtieth Ohio, of Schenck's Brigade, at Fayetteville, near Cotton Mountain, ten miles from Gauley; the Thirty-seventh Ohio, Co'. SFIPEIL, at Clifton, on the Kanawha, between Charlestown and Gauley Bridge, though now absent on an expedition; Col. GILBERT's Regiment is now on the Kanawha, ten miles above Charlestown; The Twelfth Ohio, Col. WHITE, is at Charlestown; the Eighth Virginia at Buffalo, below Charlestown; the Eleventh Ohio, Col. DEVILLIERS, at Point Pleasant; and detached companies of the Thirty-fourth of Col. PILATT's Zouaves at Windfield, Barboursville and Guayandotte, below Charlestown. These troops are all in fine fighting condition, with few sick -- the hospitals well supplied with every necessary.

abstract: As I wrote you in my last, the revolutionary attempt of Gen. FERNANDEZ and Col. MORALES against the Government of President ACHA proved a failure. Gen. ACHA having been absent from La Paz at the time of the attempt of Col. BALZA, was sent for by a...
lead_paragraph: As I wrote you in my last, the revolutionary attempt of Gen. FERNANDEZ and Col. MORALES against the Government of President ACHA proved a failure. Gen. ACHA having been absent from La Paz at the time of the attempt of Col. BALZA, was sent for by a deputation of the people. At three leagues from the Capital he was met by the foreign Ministers and consuls, at the head of whom was Mr. DAVID CARTER, United States Minister, who presented him a paper containing the capitulation of the revolutionists, upon which he entered the city in the midst of the acclamations of the people. During the day, a considerable body of Government troops entered the city, to preserve order. President ACHA revoked the military commissions of FERNANDEZ, MORALES, BALZA, FLORES, SOTO, CUETO and others, and named a new Cabinet: Minister of Justice, Interior and Foreign Relations, Don MANUEL L. SALINAS; Minister of War-Gen. C. AVILA; Secretary of the Treasury, Dr. R. CARBAJAL; Minister of Worship and Public Instruction, Don MNAUEL JOSE CORTEZ.

abstract: A private letter from a soldier in Gen. JAMESON'S Brigade, says:
lead_paragraph: "Our division, or rather brigade, took eighteen prisoners yesterday, down at Polite Church. They were taken by Col. HAYS, of the Sixty-third Pennsylvania Volunteers, an active and efficient officer. The Sixty-third were out on picket duty, and the attention of the sergeant of the guard being drawn to the tinkling of a cow bell in the bushes, with visions of new milk running through his head, he examined carefully, and to his intense astonishment, he found himself euchered of his milk, and no cows there, but he made the discovery that as he advanced, said cowbell retreated. The sergeant smelt a moderate-sized mice, and made a double-quick retrograde movement without investigating further. He immediately reported the fact to Col. HAYS. The Colonel secreted a squad of men in the woods, and the Sergeant again made himself conspicuous. Soon the gentle tinkle of a cow-bell was again heard. The Sergeant kept threshing in the bushes, and the bell gently tinkled, approaching all the while. Soon the squad in ambush had the satisfaction to observe the cautious approach, not of a cow, but of a veritable secesher with a cow-bell around his neck, and a six-shooter stuck in his belt. He came slowly on until within easy range of our men. The Sergeant then hailed him, and asked him where he had rather go 'to -- or to Washington.' 'To Washington, I reckon,' drawled the Secesher, 'I aint clothed for warm weather," and he came up, without looking to the right or left, and delivered himself up. He would have been looked upon as quite a hero by our men if the revengeful Secesher had not given information where the balance of his comrades were. That night Co. A, Pennsylvania Sixty-third, went about six miles outside our pickets, and took seventeen prisoners and six horses. One of the Seceshers requested the hostler to take good care of his horse, for he had had nothing to eat for two days."

abstract: This splendid sloop-of-war, eleven guns, Commander LYONS, has paid us another visit, and is, at present, anchored off Quarantine. The Racer is one of the fastest and most perfect sloops in the British navy. The principal object of her mission here now is, to await the arrival of the Cunard Mail steamer, in order to carry the mails to Admiral MILNE of Bermuda for the navy, as well as convey dispatches thereto from Lord LYONS, the British Minister at Washington; and also from Mr. ARCHIBALD, the British Consul of New-York. Her guns are all mounted, and range beautifully upon the main deck, being fully from six to eight inches in diameter. Her compartments are splendidly laid out, being both commodious and comfortable. The Racer confirms to the very letter the report of the reception which the rebel Commissioners, MASON and SLIDELL, received on their landing in Bermuda, which was of a truly humiliating character.

abstract: - The City of New-Orleans must be indeed in a dreadful way when it is reported that all the gambling-houses have been closed. When a profligate comes to that pass that he has to leave off his vices, it is well accounted a sign of breaking-up. New-Orleans without gambling-hells? Preposterous! One might as well think of London without cockneys, Cologne without stinks, or New-York without Aldermanic thieves! It is announced, however, that the "sports" are holding indignation-meetings over this unheard-of raid on the profession. Well they may! If this measure does not make the Crescent City long to get back to the good old Union times, pray, what will?
lead_paragraph: - The City of New-Orleans must be indeed in a dreadful way when it is reported that all the gambling-houses have been closed. abstract: A coresspondent of the Gloucester Telegraph writes from Fort Warren that there are nocturnal entertainments spritual phenomena mix themselves up with the midnight duties of the sentinels who keep their "lonely rounds," and that figures of a supernatural character have recently appeared to some of them in the lonely hour of night, in the vicinity of some rebel graves, and the image of an old woman has been seen vindictively frisking about the ruins of an old building from which she was ejected some time previous to her death. "If," he adds, "they should prove to be the veritable ghosts of the buried rebels, they may some night feel the effects of a Yankee bullet, as it would be some satisfaction to shoot even the appalition of a rebel, as long as we are where we cannot get a sight at a real one. On the other hand, the proprietly of shooting the female ghost might be seriously questioned as a breach of true gallantry, where the presence of the fair sex is so unusual as at Fort Warren."

abstract: The Topeka correspondent of the Leavenworth Times gives the following sketch of Gov. ROBINSON'S Message to the Legislature:
lead_paragraph: "He begins by thanking Providence, for a bountiful harvest, jumping from wheat and corn to the revolted district. He then speaks of the military preparations and expenses of the State; is justly severe on jayhawking; gives the present military organization of Kansas; pays a well-merited tribute to the valor of the First and Second at Springfield, and recommends that a list of the killed and wounded at that battle, and elsewhere, during the war, be entered on the documents of the State. The expenses of military organization have reached only about $10,000, which is owing to the personal application of the officers to their respective duties. He gives much credit to the Quartermaster and Adjutant-General, and recommends a suitable remuneration for their services. The apportionment to Kansas of the war tax is $71,743 33, which he recommends the State to assume. It is gratifying to know that the finances of the State are in a good condition, and that her credit is improving. We quote the Governor's remarks in relation to the Senatorial Question:

abstract: The Fourteenth Infantry, regulars, has now in camp at Perryville, Maryland, over one thousand men. In Vermont, New-York, and Pennsylvania this regiment has twenty recruiting stations, at all of which men are actively enlisted. Capt. SAMUEL ROSS, the superintendent of the recruiting stations, raised the first company at Providence, R.I., in the short period of eight days. This activity caused him to be detailed for superintendent, by Major GIDDINGS, the commander of the Fourteenth. Capt. Ross distinguished himself during the Mexican war, and was brevetted for gallantry at Chapultepec.

abstract: Able and successful as Earl RUSSELL has, in general, been as Foreign Minister, he has certainly not been consistent as an interpreter of international law.
lead_paragraph: Able and successful as Earl RUSSELL has, in general, been as Foreign Minister, he has certainly not been consistent as an interpreter of international law. Our St. Thomas correspondent recently communicated a case to us somewhat similar to the Trent affair, in which his Lordship made a very different decision from that pronounced by him touching the abduction of MASON and SLIDELL; and his very contrary interpretations in these two parallel cases lead inevitably to the conclusion that the British Secretary has two strings to his juridical bow, and that his expositions of international law have been dictated by expediency rather than by conviction of immutable right. The case reported in the letter of our St. Thomas correspondent occurred in Central America. Anarchy, as is well known, is the normal condition of the Spanish-American Republics, and New-Granada, unfortunately, is no exception to the general rule. Now it happened, some time since, that the Conservative faction having gained the ascendancy in Santa Marta, certain commercial men of the defeated party, with their families, fled thence, and sought refuge in Jamaica. But when ARBOLEDA, the Conservative leader, and his principal followers, had been expelled from Santa Marta, the said refugees determined to return. Accordingly, they sailed from Kingston in the British steamer Saladin, and, in due time, arrived at Aspinwall, where ARBOLEDA and his faction had, in the interim, established themselves. The Conservative chief, on learning that some of his enemies were on board the Saladin, gave orders that they should be seized, and taken forcibly from the vessel; but the British Consul at Aspinwall commanded the Captain of the steamer to hoist the British flag, and defied the New-Granadian officers to lay hands on the passengers. Under these circumstances ARBOLEDA thought it better to desist, and the returning refugees were suffered to proceed unmolested. Now in this case the British Consul acted well and with spirit, casting the aegis of his protection over innocent people, and shielding them from the vengeance of a sanguinary outlaw, who had no legitimate authority to claim them. But when the matter was reported to the Imperial Government, what was his reward? Why, a letter of reproof from the British Foreign Secretary to the British Minister at Bogota, condemning the Aspinwall Consul's conduct, and laying it down as a rule, that no MERCHANT steamer or vessel could give right of asylum to any person or persons charged with either civil or political offences.
headline: {'main': 'Vagaries of International Law.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Vagaries of International Law.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer tells these stories regarding the contrabands at Fortress Monroe:
lead_paragraph: There is a devout old colored man at Camp Hamilton, who acts as preached or pastor to several hundred of his yellow-contrabands. Some weeks since, the Government overseers furnished "Uncle Peter" with a house for the use of himself and congregation. On a bright Sunday afternoon the sable minister called his flock together in the frame chapel of ease, and told them that, he desired particular attention that day to his remarks. Unfortunately, during the sermon, several of the more mischievous contrabands obtained a pack, of playing cards, and creeping up the stairs, had an hour's amusement at a game that negroes are passionately fond of -- bluff!

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship North Star at this port, from Aspinwall on the l5th inst., we have later intelligence from the United States of Colombia and the South Pacific States. She also brings the mails and passengers from California, and $602,767 in specie.
lead_paragraph: We have no later dates from Central America, on account of the failure in the arrival of the steamer at Panama. At Bogota nothing new had transpired; but the new Government of MOSQUERA was operating regularly. In the State of Santander four battles took place on the 7th, 8th, 9th and 10th of December, between MOSQUERA's forces and the revolutionists, in which the former were successful. MOSQUERA had left Bogota to go to Antioquia to quell the rebellion there. In the State of Canca, also, there are still factions in arms against MOSQUERA. Venezuela is said to be in a horrible political condition, though no details are given. Arrangements were being made for opening the new French line of steamers between Havre and Aspinwall. Little driblets of cotton were passing across the Isthmus from Peru for Europe. It is very fine, but the staple is short.

abstract: A DELPHIC UT-  TERANCE. The Emperor of the French is in the habit of making brief speeches to the members of the Diplomatic Corps and the...
lead_paragraph: --A DELPHIC UTTERANCE. -- The Emperor of the French is in the habit of making brief speeches to the members of the Diplomatic Corps and the other officials, on the occasion ol the New-Year's reception at the Tuileries. As for several years past these informal utterances of the master-spirit of European statecraft have been found to be remarkable foreshadowings of the events of the year, it is customary to attach a Delphic significance to the words that fall from the Imperial lips on these occasions. In this view there may be a really weighty meaning in one of the remarks which he dropped at the reception on the past 1st of January.

abstract: Editorial on Union's growing naval power
snippet: Editorial on Union's growing naval power
lead_paragraph: in any waters. The steamships which have been purchased and converted into armed vessels are many of them models of naval architecture, and nearly as strong as anything with wooden walls afloat -- built for braving the stormy waters of our South Atlantic coast in Winter time as well as Summer, for traversing in all seasons the iron-bound coast line from New-York to Halifax, and for other service equally trying and dangerous. Elsewhere we publish a list of these purchased vessels, with their present armaments, from which it will be seen that, in a few months, our navy has been increased by seventy-nine steamers, mostly new, carrying 335 guns; beside sixty ships, and other craft, carrying nearly 200 guns. This, of course, is exolusive of an immense number of transport vessels which have been purchased, and which, armed with a pivot gun, might, in case of necessity, be very efficient in certain kinds of naval warfare. Beside this, too, the fleet of steam vessels now getting built by the Government is rapidly being launched and put into active service. That fleet consists of fourteen screw sloops twenty-three screw gunboats, twelve light-draft steamers, and three iron-clad steamers, carrying altogether nearly 300 guns. A considerable number of these vessels are now doing good service on our coast and elsewhere; and our European news this morning announces that one of them, the screw sloop Tuscarora, has arrived at Southampton in pursuit of the Nashville. We should not be sorry if it came in contact with that insolent pirate craft not far out of the British Channel, so that John Bull might see out of what stuff our Navy -- which he so much despises -- is made. A letter this morning from one of our correspondents at Port Royal, also tells us what fine work our new gunboats are doing down there. They run up the creeks and rivulets, everywhere scattering and frightening the chivalry. Getting aground is to them a matter of no consequence; they ran ashore and then ran off again half a-dozen times during the last fight, and the conduct of the officers and crew of these plucky little ships seems to revive the old days of American naval gallantry. Our navy, everywhere, has done wondrously well during the war, and those who criticize it on account of the inefficiency of the blockade at certain points, should remember that our naval fleet has been very limited, and the work it had to perform prodigious.

abstract: We have no word of news from the Burnside Expedition this morning. Our latest dispatch from Baltimore, dated at 10 o'clock last night, states that up to that hour, the boat from Old Point Comfort, due in the morning, had not arrived detained doubtless by the storm which prevailed on Friday night. She will probably bring some definite intelligence regarding the expedition.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Halleck is determined that his order regarding the assessment of the property of rebels for the benefit of Union fugitives shall be carried out to the very letter. Several of the St. Louis rebels, who were recently assessed, having failed to pay promptly, their property has been seized, and additional assessment of twenty-five per cent. has been levied, in accordance with the terms of the order. One of these persons, a prominent merchant named Samuel Engler, having served a writ of replevin on the Provost Marshal, for the recovery of the property taken from him, he and his attorney were arrested, lodged in the military prison, and subsequently, under a special order issued by Gen. HALLECK, they were sent beyond the lines of the Department of Missouri, with a warning not to leturn without permission from the Commanding General, under penalty of being punished according to the rules of war. All persons attempting to interfere with the course of military law, will be dealt with in the same manner.

abstract: The British screw-steamer City of Manchester, of Mr. JOHN G. DALE'S line, Capt. HALCROW, arrived at this port Friday morning, having left Liverpool on New-Year's Day, and Queenstown Jan. 3, at 6 A.M.
lead_paragraph: The British screw-steamer City of Manchester, of Mr. JOHN G. DALE's line, Capt. HALCROW, arrived at this port Friday morning, having left Liverpool on New-Year's Day, and Queenstown Jan. 3, at 6 A.M. She brings 3,000 tons of merchandise on freight, the United States mails, passengers and specie. During the entire passage she has encountered most boisterous weather. On the 8th inst., at noon, in the latitude of 50° 34', and longitude 31° 21', she had a violent gale, commencing at S.S.W. and ending at 7 P.M. at N.W. The barometer at 3 P.M. marking 28° 16', during which she shipped a sea which did considerable damage.

abstract: At 5 O'clock last evening a fire broke out in the Government Store-house No. 2 Bridge-street, between State and Whitehall streets. The firemen were on hand as speedily as possible, considering the fact that...
lead_paragraph: At 5 O'clock last evening a fire broke out in the Government Store-house No. 2 Bridge-street, between State and Whitehall streets. The firemen were on hand as speedily as possible, considering the fact that the engines could make but little headway through the streets, owing to the snow and water, and many of them were permited by the Police to run upon the sidewalks. The damage done to the building and stock which was stored therein will probably amount to $60,000. The firemen worked with des�perate energy to save the adjoining buildings, after it became known that the fire could not be quenched in the building where the fire originated. The Govern�ment storehouse contained cotton, whisky and other combustible materials, and when the fire reached them the efforts of the firemen proved unavailing. The rear and part of the front walls fell with a tre�mendous crash, soon after 6 o'clock.

abstract: Editorial on Southern military heroes
snippet: Editorial on Southern military heroes
lead_paragraph: of the uncertainly of human prevision that the genius of the South, now that it has been left free to develop itself, expands in a wholly different direction from any set down in the prophetic programmes. It does not need to be half as philosophical as DE BOW's Review Mr. CALHOUN or the Charleston Mercury, to see that the manifest destiny of the South lies in the line of the Comic. Already, during the brief period of the war, she has given us a group of grotesque characters, as genuinely funny and mirth-provoking as any in SHAKESPEARE or CERVANTES. Pass mentally in review the prominent figures in the rebellion and it will be seen that at least every other one displays elements that are intrinsically comic, and were it not for the grim earnestness of the cause they illustrate, they would perform the invaluable service of keeping the whole country in a broad grin. Take in illustration a couple of typical military and the same number of naval heroes; and as they and their exploits must be very fresh in the public memory, the lightest limning will answer all the purpose.

lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN FIREMAN AT THE NEW-YORK FIRE. -- Nine companies of the firemen of this city turned out with their apparatus and assisted in putting out the fire at the corner of Pearland Fulton streets, in NewYork, yesterday morning. At 7 o'clock A.M. Chief Engineer FUREY received a request for assistance from Chief Engineer DECKER, of New-York, when Engine Companies Nos. 3, 4, 7 (steam) and 14, (steam,) of the Western District Department, and No. 13, (steam,) of the Eastern District Department; Hose Companies Nos. 2, 4 and 5, of the Western District Department, turned out promptly, and rendered efficient assistance -- No. 17 being the last to leave the fire. The order for assistance was first communicated to Mr. JOSEPH MARK, at the office of the Inspector of Police, who immediately notified the Chief Engineer, and by their united efforts the Companies above named were sent to New-York without giving any alarm.

abstract: Fulton Bank, 9 other buildings destroyed, Fulton St, Brooklyn; Destroyed by fire
snippet: Fulton Bank, 9 other buildings destroyed, Fulton St, Brooklyn; Destroyed by fire
lead_paragraph: About 6 o'clock yesterday morning, one of the most disastrous fires that has occurred in the City for a long time, broke out in the rear of No. 43 Fultonstreet. For hours previous the Police-officers in the vicinity were satisfied that there was a fire in some building in that immediate neighborhood, but where it was could not for a long time be ascertained. They were diligent in investigating the whereabouts of the fire, but not until 6 o'clock did they venture upon the breaking in of the front door of No. 43 Fulton-street. As soon as this was done, the smoke and flames burst out from all parts of the building. The scene at this time is represented as being both grand and terrific. The pent-up air, smoke and flame came out with such force as to produce a loud report like that of the firing of many cannons. The residents in the vicinity believed it to be an explosion, caused by powder igniting in the building, and were much alarmed for a short time. The fire had no doubt been progressing for hours inside of the building, but owing to the fact that it had no vent, it spread itself through the building very slowly, and it was only when the front door was forced open that it burst forth with alarming fury. Every door and window in the building was torn and shattered into fragments by the explosion. The manufactured goods of DAVID WOODS, wire-worker, were thrown with great force in all directions; many of them across the street and against the opposite buildings, and up and down Fulton-street to a great distance.

abstract: As a general thing, when the HARPERS publish a book, it is found worth reading, and the multitude which hungereth and thirsteth after literature invest in it without scruple, relying implicitly on the judgment and taste of the discriminative publishers who have so often proven themselves competent to the duty of catering for the mind. An occasional exception, of course, is...
lead_paragraph: -- As a general thing, when the HARPERS publish a book, it is found worth reading, and the multitude which hungereth and thirsteth after literature invest in it without scruple, relying implicitly on the judgment and taste of the discriminative publishers who have so often proven themselves competent to the duty of catering for the mind. An occasional exception, of course, is necessary to prove the rule -- that exception wc have in The Pilgrims of Fashion, by one KINAHAN CORNWALLIS. The faithful and conscientious reader always reads the preface of a book -- the more industrious ones commence at the title-page. The preface of Mr. CORNWALLIS' book ia simply an editorial on the war, written in that peculiarly diffuse and ornamental style for which the Herald has become so justly celebrated. It refers not at all to the book itself -- not even so much as to offer an apology for printing it. A rather mythical element of society, delicately distinguished as "the shoddy aristocracy" -- if we mistake not, the phrase originated, and finds daily repetition, in the columns of the journal before referred to -- comes in for the bitterest denunciation. The writer is also particularly severe upon snobs,-- and dates his preface from the Fifth-avenue Hotel.

abstract: Editorial on Congress attempts to establish national currency; Editorial on Congress efforts to establish national currency
snippet: Editorial on Congress attempts to establish national currency; Editorial on Congress efforts to establish national currency
lead_paragraph: The United States notes of circulation, as a National Currency, have been flippantly compared to the assignats of revolutionary France; to the old Continental money, and to various other wild, insecure, irredeemable or worthless mediums. It is also said that the Government cannot make then good; that an empty Treasury cannot create a substantive value. These things are said and written professedly in no unfriendly spirit to the Government, but mainly to enforce some favorite theory about bullion, or to drive the Treasury into a condition of dependence and vassalage to the State banks, or to alarm and warn the public against what is termed an inflation. The last is even charged upon the advocates of the bill, as their ruling motive for insisting upon the use of United States notes, in place of the present irredeemable or non-specie paying notes of the thousand and one local banks of the country. And then, as to their legal tender, that is altogether reprobated, not so much because the sovereign right of the National Government to regulate commerce and the currency is seriously traversed, but because it would inflict a wrong upon the creditor class.
headline: {'main': 'The National Currency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The National Currency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Not a word of intelligence from the Burnside Expedition has reached us. Ever, the first accounts which reached us from the rebels, that the fleet had made its appearance in Pamlico Sound, and threatened Newbern, N.C., are now contradicted by them -- a fact which suggests the probability that the vessels, if they were at any time in the Souud, merely went in for a harbor during the great storm which prevailed on the coast during the last part of the last week. The hint as to the destination of the Expedition, given in our Washington dispatches a day or two ago, may, after all, prove correct, and ere this Charleston or Savannah, or perhaps beth, may have felt the weight of its blows.

abstract: Historical review of how Government financed wars
snippet: Historical review of how Government financed wars
lead_paragraph: It has been urged that, in any commercial country, a currency composed largely of paper, even though it he accredited by the Government, accepted by the people, payable as taxes, and convertible into public securities, must of necessity depreciate in value, as compared with gold. If then, there be any safeguards disclosed by financial science, and capable of being applied by financial skill, so as to prevent such a pernicious result, it is of the highest moment that they should be known. The history of our Continental money, as also that of the assignats and manuals of the French Revolution, may afford us some instruction. But these examples of an inconvertible paper money, present a record of constant decline and depreciation, and terminate in a catastrophe of final extinction of value. Hence the only information they can offer is that of caution.

abstract: The prize bark Jarger Leorentzen, (Danish,) in charge of prize-master Lient. GERAUD, from Rio Ja�neiro to Havanna in 50 days, to which port she was going for orders, has arrived at this port. She has a cargo of 4,800 bags of coffee, and was captured Dec. 26, in lat. 7° N., and long. 38° 30°, W., by United States ship Morning Star, in consequence of informality in her papers, from which it was supposed she was destined for New-Orleans. On the 16th inst. while off Bermuda, spoke brig John Butler, beund to Antigua. The Butler had lost her deck load, and had sustained some damage. The Leorentzen experienced heavy casterly winds on her way from Bermuda.

lead_paragraph: -- Hon. Noah H.A. Swayne, of Ohio, just confirmed by the Senate as an Associate Judge of the United States Supreme Court, is a native of Culpepper County, Virginia, and emigrated to Ohio immediately after finishing his law course under the instruction of the late distinguished Robert I. Taylor, in Alexandria. His age is now perhaps fifty years. He has grown as a public man with the growth of Ohio, having played perhaps the most important part in building up for that State its material eminence. As a jurist he is reputed to be without a superior in the West, and as the conductor of the State's largest financial operations his fame is equal to his reputation as a lawyer. In politics he is a Republican, with strong conservative proclivities.

abstract: Col. FRY, of the Fourth Kentucky Regiment, who killed ZOLLICOFFER, was lying in ambush, with a squad of his regiment, when ZOLLICOFFER appeared at the head of a detachment of troops, which detachment was marching rapidly in advance of the main Confederate force. When the General had arrived within twenty feet of the ambush where FRY and his men were concealed, the Col. sprang forward and drew his navy revolver, and presented it at the Confederate General. We may here state that FRY and ZOLLICOFFER were for many years personal friends, and in their youthful doys assiciates in sheool.

abstract: Editorial on effects of Civil War; Editorial on war effects in Colorado Territory
snippet: Editorial on effects of Civil War; Editorial on war effects in Colorado Territory
lead_paragraph: Colorado Territory is now attracting enough of public attention to deserve more than cursory notice. It is the former self-styled and self-organized territory of Jefferson, situated directly between Kansas and Utah. Covering 100,000 square miles of the public domain, inclusive of its gold fields, it contains a population of 35,000 people -- males chiefly, whose non-resident family attaches are sufficient, if removed there, as most of them will be the present year, to swell the number to 125,000. Its climate is delightful its soil productive, its mines abundant and rich, and its prospects of inviting to itself a large immigration at the close of the present war are unusually flattering.

abstract: ACCIDENT TO A NEWSPAPER EXPRESS. -- Among other incidents of the great storm of Saturday morning, and the consequent high tides, was an accident to MOUNTFORT's Newspaper Express, running to Bergen, Newark and Elizabeth, by which the delivery of the City papers in those towns was much delayed. The tide on the Jersey Flats submerged the causeway, and swept heavy floes of ice against the Express wagon with such force that it was forced off into deep water, when the driver was necessitated, in order to save himself, to unhitch his horse, mount, and ride out as best he could -- leaving his wagon and papers until the tide fell sufficiently to permit their recovery.

abstract: Reviews of various issues for February
snippet: Reviews of various issues for February
lead_paragraph: -- We had occasion to speak in terms of well-merited praise of the January Atlantic. The February number is entitled to an equally kindly greeting. True to the instincts which have led it to reflect the color of the day, a "Battle Hymn of the Republic" leads off the well-ordered columns. Despite the refrain of "Marching on" -- which seems to have been suggested by the song we have all heard the Massachusetts regiments sing, as they marched with bristling bayonets down Broadway -- we like this lyric much. If poetry can be said to have color -- and it is contended that music has -- we fancy that this would reveal itself to the subtle sense in a rich crimson, winning and nerving the soldier's soul like the notes of a trumpet. "At Port Royal, 1861," a poem by Whittier, is worthy of that sweet singer and Quaker, though the introduction of the "Song of the Negro Boatmen" into the body of the poem does not, to our thinking, add to its quiet beauty. A devotional hymn, be the sentiment holy and refined as it may, written out in the mutilated English of a plantation, is too suggestive of negro minstrelsy. It were better heard than read. Esquire Bigelow contributes a magnificent poetical paper, whereof the baptismal name is "Mason and Slidell -- A Yankee Idyll " -- one of the most refulgent effusions that has yet been thrown from the Bigelow pen. In a sort of waking dream the poet heareth Concord Bridge and the Bunker Hill Monument discussing the Mason and Slidell question -- it is needless to say that they discuss it with more wit and wisdom than did the daily papers, both English and American. And then we have " Midwinter," a pretty little poem, suggestive of the pure thoughts and feelings that should full with the snow-flakes. Maj. WINTHROP's story, "Love and Skates," is concluded in this number. We like it rather better than the longer stories, from the same sparkling pen, which have lately been published. It has the same sparkle and snap, but the diamond is better cut, -- the eccentric edges that detract from the beauty of the gem, are not there. The reader of WINTHROP cannot fail to notice the element of moral purity that abounds in his works, -- a highsouledness that shrinks with mimosa-like sensitiveness from all grossness. If fair to judge men by their writings, truly must WINTHROP have been a noble BAYARD in character, a chevalier sans peur et sans reproche. In addition to the papers before mentioned, we have continuations of AGASSIZ's "Methods of Study in Natural History," Mrs. STOWE's "Agnes of Sorrento," "A Story of To-day" and Chapter II of the Chronicles of "Fremont's Hundred Days in Missouri;" "Our Artists in Italy;" "The Experiences of the A.C.;" "Ease in Work," and the usual reviews and literacy notices, crown the cup of this brimming and sparkling Atlantic.

abstract: A correspondent informs us that on the forenoon of Saturday last, at their residence, on the Varna and Bayfield gravel-road, in the township of Stanley, a dreadful calamity suddenly befel the family of Mr. JosPeH Calloway, an old and respected resident, resulting in the violent death of his daughter-in-law, a smart, active woman of about 30 years of age, and the mother of five children, the youngest of whom is only about one year old. It appears that her husband, on hearing that a deer was feeding in his fallow, hastily took his rifle from its usual place, and was rushing with it out of the house, when his sleeve or some other part of his clothing got entangled by the door-handle, causing the hammer to descend, when the rifle instantly went off, discharging the brill and part of the ramrod into the breast of his unfortunate wife. The ball having penetrated the heart, she instantly dropped dead, while streams of blood gushed from the wound over the floor. The husband is of course, inconsolable. -Toronto Leader, Jan, 23.

abstract: -- The earliest detailed accounts of the engagement ta Mill Creek, in Kentucky, are laid before our readers in other columns. The Herald, with characteristic enterprise, anticipated the arrival of mail and express by publishing in its Saturday issue, a letter from Kentucky, curiously uniform in tone and matter and volume with the scattered telegraphic reports previously received. We have only to say, no genuine descriptive report of the battle could have reached this City before yesterday; a fact that sufficiently demonstrates the character of the Herald's enterprize.

abstract: -- An act of the South Carolina Legislature has ostracised and rendered infamous certain loyal officers of the United States Navy. Their crime is to have been true to their oath of allegiance, and to have refused to cast in their destiny with traitors and parricides. For this they are held up by statute, to "the execration of posterity." Poor bewildered, deluded, ruined State, this is the only immortality it is now in her power to bestow, though the act at the same time puts the seal to her own eternal infamy! There is a very peculiar interest attaching to those South Carolina officers in the United States service who have proved faithful among the faithless. That same intense individualism which makes South Carolinians the bitterest of rebels, makes those, also, who are true, the most devoted of patriots. And their conduct stands out the more nobly when we think how impossible it is, educated in that society, to escape the poison of the State Rights doctrine -- which is but a generalized form of individual selfishness, the root of all evil. South Carolina has ostracised them; but the instinct of all loyal men but anticipates History's verdict of reversal, when it looks upon this decree of incivism as the proudest patent of nobility that could be conferred on those true and loyal Americans.

abstract: The news received this morning from Europe sets all doubt at rest as to the reception encountered by the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL. The London journals -- the extracts furnished by the telegraph are unfortunately drawn exclusively from those of the most belligerent antecedents -- accept the dispatch of Mr. SEWARD and the rendition of the two rebels, as a full satisfaction of the British demand, and as a restoration of the tarnished lustre of the British crown. It is conceded that the act of the American Government was at once graceful and consistent. Of that spirit of bravado, and disposition to represent cowardice as the motive at the back of our conciliatory temper, which there was too much reason to apprehend from journals so malignant as the London Post and Herald, we have no evidences whatever. The absence of these offensive traits may be merely due to the meagreness of the telegraphic summary. But we are disposed to think otherwise, and to believe that the amende of America has been as frankly received as it was frankly offered. It is, indeed, significant of the real direction of public opinion that the Press bespeaks anything but a welcome for the restored Commissioners. They are stigmatized as a brace of conspirators who have been balked in an attempt to embroil England in war; and who are entitled to no more respectful consideration than a pair of negroes fortuitously extricated by diplomacy from the clutches of a slave-catcher. In this curt dismissal of the candidates for a British ovation, the South will find little prospect of instant recognition and alliance.

abstract: Great interest had been excited relative to the movements of the Tuscarora and Nashville. At the latest dates they continued at Southampton, watching each other. The Tuscarora remained at her anchorage, about a mile from the dock mouth with her fires banked up and ready to slip her anchor and start at a moment's notice.
lead_paragraph: Great interest had been excited relative to the movements of the Tuscarora and Nashville. At the latest dates they continued at Southampton, watching each other. The Tuscarora remained at her anchorage, about a mile from the dock mouth with her fires banked up and ready to slip her anchor and start at a moment's notice. She only required coals, water and provisions, which were being supplied her. On her arrival Capt. CRAVEN communicated with the captain of the frigate Daunt�less, expressing regret at Prince Albert's death, and asking if he might lire, as a tribute of respect, twenty-one minute guns. He was notified that the Queen had requested that no guns be fired in the vicinity of Osborne. The compliment, therefore, although fully appreciated, could not be accepted.

abstract: Two very destructive fires occurred yesterday, in which property amounting in the aggregate to not less than half a million of dollars was destroyed. At about 2 o'clock A.M. the bells sounded an alarm for a fire at No. 4 Bridge-street. A large storehouse, extending through from Bridge to Pearl-street, was nearly destroyed. While the firemen were still working here, another fire broke out in Fulton-street, which resulted in the destruction of ten large brick buildings, including the Fulton Bank building. The Brooklyn firemen came over in large numbers, and brought with three of their steam engines, which rendered very efficient service.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Europe, at Halifax, we have advices from Europe three days later than were received by the City of New-York. She left Liverpool on the 11th inst., and Queenstown on the 12th. Neither troops nor stores were sent on board of her by the British Government, all such shipments by the Cunarders having been discontinued. The news generally is of the most gratifying character.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Europe, at Halifax, we have advices from Europe three days later than were received by the City of New-York. She left Liverpool on the 11th inst., and Queenstown on the 12th. Neither troops nor stores were sent on board of her by the British Government, all such shipments by the Cunarders having been discontinued. The news generally is of the most gratifying character. The response of our Government to the British demands regarding the Trent affair appear to have been almost universally satisfactory; and although the warlike preparations at Woolwich and other points had not been stopped, it was understood that they gradually would be. Mr. SEWARD's dispatch was considered in Cabinet Council on the 9th, and it was so perfectly satisfactory to the British Government that a further Council, which had previously been called for on the 14th, was considered unnecessary, and the order for it had been countermanded. As a result of the deliberations of the Council, it was announced by the London Morning Post that a thorough understanding had been arrived at with the American Government. The Times intimates that an answer will be returned expressing gratification at the disavowal of Commander WILKES' act, accepting the satisfaction rendered, and assuming that the precedent will rule in other cases. The general discussion of the law of neutrals, however, would be deferred until the proper law officers could be consulted.

abstract: Yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, while the men were at work on the ruins of the building, No. 2 Bridge-stret, a fire was discovered on the roof of the next store, No. 4, belonging to SQUIRE & JOHNSON. The flames soon gained sufficient headway to assure the firemen that their energies would be thoroughly taxed to subdue them. But they went at it with several steam-engines with a will, and prevented any of the adjacent property receiving damage. Before they got it under, the devouring element had consumed the third, fourth and fifth stories.

abstract: The naval recruiting returns for last week show that three hundred and twenty-five a men were shipped in this City, one hundred and eighty of whom were for Capt. The number of disposable seamen on board the North Carolina is eight hundred.

abstract: Through our  Fortress Monroe dispatch this morning, we have the rebel accounts of the defeat and rout at Somerset. The death of ZOLLICOFFER is admitted. The wounding of four Colonels and a Major, and the loss of two entire batteries, are also reported. The nature of the rout seems...
lead_paragraph: -- Through our Fortress Monroe dispatch this morning, we have the rebel accounts of the defeat and rout at Somerset. The death of ZOLLICOFFER is admitted. The wounding of four Colonels and a Major, and the loss of two entire batteries, are also reported. The nature of the rout seems to have been not unlike our own retreat from Bull Run; but not, like that, by accident or mistake. The rebel forces were fairly driven from the field by the gallant regiments of Kentucky and the Northwest. They retreated when no hope of success remained. They were routed and dispersed by our pursuing soldiery, and stayed not their coming even behind their own strongly intrenched camp-works, out of which they had marched for attack early in the morning. In a word, their army became a wild band of beaten and dismayed fugitives. That the foremost of these greatly exaggerated the extent of the disaster, as alleged in one of the Southern dispatches, is not unlikely. It was so with our own disorganized bands that rushed pell-mell into Washington, on the morning of the 22d July. But the fact of the disaster remains conceded.
