abstract: Editorial on London Times reactions to stone blockade in South Carolina harbors
snippet: Editorial on London Times reactions to stone blockade in South Carolina harbors
lead_paragraph: -- The conciliatory action of our Government in the case of MASON and SLIDELL has not entirely silenced the vituperation of the London Times. It still inveighs fiercely against us for having perpetrated, to the prejudice of Charleston, that stone blockade. "Among the crimes," says the Times, in one of its recent diatribes, "which have disgraced the history of mankind, it is difficult to find one more atrocious than this. Even the savage tribes of the desert will not destroy the well which gives life to the enemy."

abstract: A SINGULAR CHARGE AGAINST AN EX-POLICEMAN, Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinet Police, appeared before Justice BEENNAN, yesterday, and preferred a charge of lareeny against ROBERT M. WEBB, who, until the 20th inst., was an officer in that Pre-...
lead_paragraph: A SINGULAR CHARGE AGAINST AN EX-POLICEMAN, Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinet Police, appeared before Justice BEENNAN, yesterday, and preferred a charge of lareeny against ROBERT M. WEBB, who, until the 20th inst., was an officer in that Precinct. On the day last named, WEBB was tried by the Police Commissioners, and received a discharge from the Department. Capt. DOWLING had due notice of his dismissal, and at the same time was requested by the Commissioners to demand from WEBB his cap, shield, the buttons on his coat, and the book of rules and regulations -- they being, as is alleged, the property of the Police Department. Capt. DOWLING read the order to WEBB, and demanded of him the property in question. WEBB, instead of complying, suddenly made his escape from the Station-house. An officer was sent in pursuit, and when the fugitive was overtaken, he informed his pursuer that he would return without delay, and surrender the property to the Captain. He, however, did not fulfill his engagement, and has not since been seen at the Station-house. Upon a statement of these circumstances to the Commissioners, they at once ordered the arrest of WEBB, upon the charge of purloining public property. Capt. DOWLING found the accused in Broome-street, and demanded again, the restoration of the property; but WEBB refused to deliver it. Whereupon he was taken by force before the Commissioners, and afterwards committed to the cells. Justice BRENNAN held him to bail, yesterday, to appear before the Court of General Sessions. This is the first case of the kind which has occurred, and much feeling is manifested throughout the Department upon the subject. WEBB intends to contest the legality of his dismissal, and also the right of the Commissioners to compel the restoration of the property in question. The Commissioners are quite indignant at the course which WEBB has thought proper to pursue.

abstract: tress Monroe to a morning paper in this city, made some statements concerning Rev. Dr. WILMER, late of this city, which were commented on in these columns and in those of many other journals. We learn now that the statements made were incorrect. Gen. WOOL, and the Provost-Marshal at Fortress Monroe, deny the assertion that Dr. WILMER had papers, plans, &c., concealed in his neck-cloth and other clothing. The reports concerning his baggage were also greatly exaggerated, and after a little delay all the articles he took from the North were forwarded to him. We make this correction with pleasure, in justice to a gentleman who has many friends here, and we request that it be made also by distant papers that have been led into error by the false reports of the correspondent in question. -- Philada. Eve. Bulletin.

abstract: A MAN AND BOY MISSING. Capt. JAMES CLARK, of the schooner Editor, lying at the Morris canal Pier, In Jersey City, has been missing since the 7th inst., at which time he left his vessel to go to NewYork, where he was last seen.
lead_paragraph: A MAN AND BOY MISSING. -- Capt. JAMES CLARK, of the schooner Editor, lying at the Morris canal Pier, in Jersey City, has been missing since the 7th inst., at which time he left his vessel to go to NewYork, where he was last seen. It is feared that he has met with foul play, or has been drowned while attempting to go on board the vessel, on returning.... A lad named FRANK DRAKE, between 10 and 11 years of age, disappeared from his residence, No. 43 1/2 Newark-avenue, Jersey City, on the 30th of December, and has not since been heard of. He was playing in the street when last seen, and was attired in brown pants, drab jacket, short black oversack and cloth cap. He has dark blue eyes and brown hair. Any information as to his whereabouts will be thankfully received and properly rewarded by applying at the residence of E. BARTON, No. 43 1/2 Newark-avenue, Jersey City.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of Emancipation; for the employment of homoepathic physicians in the army; for the establishment of a national armory in the West, and against any further traffic in the public lands.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of Emancipation; for the employment of homoepathic physicians in the army; for the establishment of a national armory in the West, and against any further traffic in the public lands. A memorial was also presented from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, in favor of the continuance of the Coast Survey. A report was made from the Naval Committee in relation to the answer of the Secretary of the Navy to the resolution of inquiry in regard to the Morgan contracts. We publish the report this morning. A resolution was passed authorizing the Superintendent of the Census to furnish the Secretary of War with such war statistics, from time to time, as the Secretary of War may deem necessary for the use of his Department. A resolution was offered, and laid over, inquiring of the Secretary of the Navy relative to the cost and capabilities of certain vessels-of-war. A bill for the more effectual suppression of the Slave-trade was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, and referred. The resolution from the Legislature of New-York, instructing our Senators to vote for the abolition of the franking privilege, was presented and referred. The joint resolution making an alteration in the rules of the two Houses, providing that war matters can, when considered necessary, be debated in secret session, was called up by Mr. WADE, of Ohio. The resolution was modified somewhat, and the subject was postponed until to-day. Mr. BRIGHT's case was then considered again, and Mr. LATHAM, of California, made a speech, opposing his expulsion. No vote was taken, and the Senate, after an Executive Session, adjourned.

abstract: We published yesterday morning a letter to Secretary CHASE from a lawyer of this City, in relation to the bill creating a Solicitor of Customs for this port. The letter claimed to give "a few facts" in relation to the matter. We have caused some inquiries to be made, which have satisfied us that the lawyer was misinformed in some of the most important of his facts.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday morning a letter to Secretary CHASE from a lawyer of this City, in relation to the bill creating a Solicitor of Customs for this port. The letter claimed to give "a few facts" in relation to the matter. We have caused some inquiries to be made, which have satisfied us that the lawyer was misinformed in some of the most important of his facts.

abstract: Editorial attempts to disprove rumor that France is considering intervention; Editorial protests high price of gas in NYC
snippet: Editorial attempts to disprove rumor that France is considering intervention; Editorial protests high price of gas in NYC
lead_paragraph: There have been, as all are aware, for some time, various rumors circulating in society will reference to an unofficial proposition from the Emperor of the French to the British Government. An American gentleman, formerly in high diplomatic position, now traveling in Europe, is represented as having been assured by Lord PALMERSTON himself, in an interview with him, that the French Government were desirous of breaking this annoying blockade, and that they were ready and had proposed to unite with the English Administration, acknowledging the Southern Confederacy as a de facto Government. Similar reports are received here from other sources. The rumors, in the indirect way in which they reach us, may reasonably be considered as of very doubtful authority. Yet it is worth while to consider what are the probabilities for and against a French interference in our struggle.

abstract: Mr. Punch, in his  penultimate caricature of the Trent affair, shows John Bull disturbed at table by a creature supposed to represent a Yankee, (and about as like all American as Punch to Hercules,) who, armed to the teeth, and carrying a United States flag, says, "I just stopt to...
lead_paragraph: -Mr. Punch, in his penultimate caricature of the Trent affair, shows John Bull disturbed at table by a creature supposed to represent a Yankee, (and about as like all American as Punch to Hercules,) who, armed to the teeth, and carrying a United States flag, says, "I just stopt to see if there was any rebels in he-a-ar." So also, in caricaturing the flight from Manassas the same omniscient puppet made the foremost soldier of the rout say that he is "just gwine to take Canada." This is about as near as brother Bull gets to an understanding of American affairs. These words -- he-a-ar for hear, and gwine for going -- are, as every American knows, the two which of all others distinguish the [???] man of the extreme South from his fellow-citizens of the North and West. They are, in fact, negro words, and have been caught by masters from slaves not much below them in intelligence. Indeed, the "Yankee" of the British stage, British story and caricature, is in nearly every moral and physical trait a monstrous exaggeration of the one-slave, back-country Carolinian who works in the field with own "nigger." It is all of a piece with this, the placing in large letters under the latter caricature, as a justification for it, the words, "For the outrage offered in the Queen's proclamation, the United States will possess itself of Canada. New-York Herald." The knowledge of American affairs which puts exactly the wrong words in the months of "Yankees," is exactly that which leads to the assumption that the Herald expresses public opinion in America, or even in New-York.

abstract: Last night an order was issued to all the regiments here to cook three days' rations, and to hold themselves in readiness to march at a moments warning. It was a pretty  sight the companies all gleaming brightly in the dense darkness of a cloudy night.

abstract: The eighth annual meeting of the New-York Infirmary for Indigent Women and Children, was held last evening at the institution, No. 126 Second-avenue. After the minutes of the report for 1860 had been read, the Secretary read the report of the past year, wherein he stated that 4,792 women and children had received medical attendance, out of when,2,197 were natives of the United States. During the year of 1860, 3,343 patients applied for relief, showing an increase of 1,149 patients for 1861. The report was adopted unanimously. The Treasurer then read this report, stating that $4,365 17 had been received from various sources by the Society, during the past year; that $3,823 24 had been expended, leaving a balance of $541 93. This report was also adopted.

abstract: The event of the present week will be Mr. GRAU'S season at the Academy of Music, commencing to-morrow evening and terminating with the sixth subsequent performance. In Brooklyn the opera will commence on Thursday and continue on...
lead_paragraph: The event of the present week will be Mr. GRAU's season at the Academy of Music, commencing to-morrow evening and terminating with the sixth subsequent performance. In Brooklyn the opera will commence on Thursday and continue on alternate nights for a like period. For the first representation here Mr. GRAU has selected FLOTOW's popular opera of "Martha," and for the first in Brooklyn, VERDI's famous "Trovatore." Both operas are likely to answer the expectations of the manager, namely, to fill the houses. The mere fact that Miss KELLOGG sustains the principal role in the first-named work is a guarantee that the fashionable world of the Metropolis will take an interest in the event; the public, too, has its preferences, and "Martha" is undoubtedly one of them. To add to the completeness of Mr. GRAU's arrangements it may be mentioned that he has effected a combination with Mr. MAX MARETZEK, who will assume the entire direction of the musical department. The thousand friends of this energetic and accomplished gentleman will not fail to give him a warm welcome on his return to the City.

abstract: Meets, NYC
snippet: Meets, NYC
lead_paragraph: The New-York Teachers' Association held an interesting meeting on Saturday evening, on the occasion of the opening of their newly-finished rooms in the Board of Education Building, corner of Grand and Elm streets. The unsightly furniture of the old room has been removed, the walls renewed, the woodwork repainted, the library replenished, and last though by no means least, through the excellent taste of Mr. BOESE, the Clerk of the Board, the floor has been covered with an elegant, durable, and even artistic carpet. The room is designed for meetings of the Teachers' Association, and as a place for social gathering, either for reading and conversation. In spite of the storm and the almost impassable condition of the streets, there was a comparatively large attendance of teachers, professors, members of the Board of Education, and other invited guests.

abstract: We give a partial statement below of the losses sustained by the insurance companies in this City and else where, upon the occasion of the fire in Fulton and Pearl streets, a pretty full account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: We give a partial statement below of the losses sustained by the insurance companies in this City and elsewhere, upon the occasion of the fire in Fulton and Pearl streets, a pretty full account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES. It is impossible to obtain an entirely correct statement at present, owing to the fact that there are a great number of sufferers, and in many instances the policies of insurance are supposed to be in the safes under the ruins. The Fire Marshal was busily at work all day yesterday in endeavoring to ascertain the cause of the fire, the actual amount of property destroyed, and the insurances thereon. But many of the owners of the stock and buildings could not be found, and some of those who were on hand could not give much information because their books and policies were not accessible.

abstract: editorial lauds pending reforms
snippet: editorial lauds pending reforms
lead_paragraph: It seemed right and eminently proper that the charge of Mr. Geo. D. MORGAN, of this City, of $70,000 to the Government for a few months' occasional service in purchasing steamers, sail vessels, &c., and its allowance by his brother-in-law, the Secretary of the Navy, should not be suffered to pass without further notice by Congress. Accordingly, we have a report from Mr. HALE, of the Senate Naval Committee, strongly condemnatory of the whole transaction, and insisting that the $70,000, unjustly taken by Mr. MORGAN, should be restored to the public Treasury, and a fair compensation or salary allowed to him as the agent of the Department, instead. It may be that Mr. MORGAN is beyond the reach of this persuasion to the right. Indeed, if, as we have heard intimated, he has already declined an opportunity to restore the money, afforded him by the Chairman or some member of the House Committee of Investigation before the publication of their report, we deem it quite probable that he will not surrender his more than questionable gains, now that all the facts, in their naked deformity, have been made public. Be this as it may, the question cannot be surrendered, in silence, as one of private conscience with Mr. MORGAN himself. He has deemed it proper to come before the public in a labored defence of the head of the Navy Department, who threw this $70,000 in his way, and incidentally, in his own justification, for clutching it. The shallow reasoning of his letter might pass for the little that it is intrinsically worth, but for the circumstance of the country and family relationship which surround the whole transaction, and the indignity to the common intelligence of the public, and especially of a commercial public like that of New-York, by the use of such logic.

abstract: Editorial on efforts being made to obtain Presidential pardon for convicted slave trader N Gordon
snippet: Editorial on efforts being made to obtain Presidential pardon for convicted slave trader N Gordon
lead_paragraph: A strong and well-concerted effort is making to procure from President LINCOLN a pardon for GORDON, the convicted slave-trader. The movement is headed by Hon. GEORGE, EVANS, at one time a, United States Senator from Maine, and now, perhaps, better remembered for his connection with a commission for the adjustment of Mexican claims. The grounds assumed by these petitioners are not given to the public. In view of the overwhelming evidence against GORDON, so powerfully corroborated by his own admissions, it is hardly probable that doubt is suggested as to the justice of his conviction.

abstract: The Burnside Expedition is at this date a seven-days' wonder twice told. More than two weeks have now passed, and still not one authentic word of the great armada. As for the theory that located its scene of operations at a definite point in the inland waters of North Carolina, it appears no longer tenable. All that remains of the theory is the instructive illustration it affords of how very slender a foundation of fact suffices for an assumption that meets with universal acceptance.

abstract: The giving-out of money down in Dixie is obliging Southerners to fall back on the primitive pecunia cotton and niggers. But a bale of the floculent fibre must be rather an awkward purse of specic, quite impossible to...
lead_paragraph: The giving-out of money down in Dixie is obliging Southerners to fall back on the primitive pecunia -- cotton and niggers. But a bale of the floculent fibre must be rather an awkward purse of specic, quite impossible to carry in the pocket, and needing a wagon for its transportation. Negroes are not much more disposable these times, though a late dispatch from Louisville brings report of an original device which Gen. HARDEE adopted for meeting a little outstanding obligation to his washerwoman. "Gen. HARDEE," thus it goes, "second in command, could not pay a colored woman employed by him, and gave her a pass through the rebel lines as the only means he had of liquidating her demand." This way of paying "in kind" was a shrewd bit of tactics on the part of HARDEE, though the plan is not unattended with inconvenience in respect of the change --

lead_paragraph: The idea of a Quaker Sunday School met at first with much disfavor with the more conservative of this staid sect, yet after a few years of faithful experiment, it has developed the most successful results. abstract: The Brooklyn and Newtown Railroad was formally opened yesterday to Broadway the Directors inaugurating their enterprise by giving free rides to all why chose to avail themselves of the facilities afforded by the road, and also gave a special entertainment...
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn and Newtown Railroad was formally opened yesterday to Broadway -- the Directors inaugurating their enterprise by giving free rides to all why chose to avail themselves of the facilities afforded by the road, and also gave a special entertainment to the authorities, distinguished citizens, members of the Hress and representatives of the other railroad interests in the city. The route thus completed commences at Fulton Ferry, the cars passing through Front-street, Gold-street, Willoughby-street, Debevoise-street and De Kalb-avenue to Stuyvesant-avenue, one block from Broadway, a distance of four and one-fourth miles. The Company obtained right of way from the City through Water-street, but as there is some difficulty with the Coney Island Railroad Company, which has also a right of running on the same street, between Fulton and Main streets, and the latter Company having obtained an injunction restraining the Newtown Company from using that street, that route will not be operated for the present. The new road passes for the most part through a populous portion of the city, and affords facilities for teaching a large section of the city heretofore unimproved for the want of just such facilities as this road affords. Fifteen new cars of the Albany pattern, containing all modern improvements and weighing only 3,000 pounds -- 1,000 pounds less than any other car in use -- have been placed on the road, and eighteen more will be added as soon as they can be completed. The road will be completed to Newtown -- nine miles -- early next Spring, and will thus open up for improvement a [???] of unimproved property. The officers of the Company are well-known and substantial citizens -- men who have had large experience in Brooklyn affairs, and who will take pride in endeavoring to make the interests of the public identical with those of the stockholders. At 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the invited guests assembled at the office of the Company, [???] of Front and Dock streets, where they took cars and passed over the route. The citizens resident on the line of the route manifested their satisfaction at the consummation of this enterprise by displaying the National banner at different points. Near Stuyvesant-avenue, the Company will have erected, as soon as the weather permits, a brick stable, 200 feet square, and two stories high, with accommodations for 330 [???], at an expense of $36,000. The guests, after viewing the present ferment of the Railroad, were reseated in the cars, and returned to the place of starting, where they partook of a substantial collation, to which ample justice was done. Toasts to the President of the Company, and the success of the enterprise, to the Press, &c., were drunk, and elicited appropriate responses; and at a late hour the company dispersed, much pleased with all that they had seen and heard. The officers of this Company are: President, EDWARD PELL; Superintendent, WARREN E. RUSSELL; Secretary, J.H. PROUT.

abstract: Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, the presentation of a handsome stand of colors was made to the New-York Volunteer Enginees Regiment, by the Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen. Two companies of the regiment, under command of Major...
lead_paragraph: Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, the presentation of a handsome stand of colors was made to the New-York Volunteer Enginees Regiment, by the Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen. Two companies of the regiment, under command of Major BUTTS, were present, the remaining eight companies being at Hilton Head, S.C. The presentation took place in the large drill-room of the armory belonging to the Seventh Regiment, National Guard. At the north end of the room a platform had been elected, from which the presentation was to be made. The two companies, on arriving at the armory, were drawn up in front of the platform, and awaited the presentation. Shortly afterward, Hon. WILLIAM M. EVARTS, who was to make the address, accompanied by Gen. Hall, Joseph Hoxie, Col. Stevens, Rev. Dr. Vinton, Noah Worrall, Matthias Bloodgood, George W. Farnham, and various other members of the Society, made their appearance on the platform. Mr. GEORGE W. FARNHAM, in a short speech, then introduced to the soldiers Hon. WILLIAM M. EVARTS, who said:

abstract: Col. JOSEPH W. ALLEN, of the Burnside Expedition, who lost his life while gallantly attempting to procure water for the distressed troops, was a native of Burlington, New-Jersey, and was Colonel of the New-Jersey Ninth Regiment. He had reached of the forty-fifth year of his age at the time of his death. By profession he had been a civil engineer; but, at the call, of his country, took up arms, and led to the field one of the best regiments which has been furnished by the State of New-Jersey. He had previously been for several years Colonel of one of the New-Jersey militia regiments. His present regiment arrived at Annapolis January 4, and embarked on the Burnside Expedition the following morning on the brig Dragoon and ship Ann. E. Thompson. But he never reached the field of battle and of glory for which he thirsted. The troops wanted water; and, with his surgeon, Dr. S.P. WELLIER, the second mate of one of the vessels on which his regiment was embarked, and a boat's crew, he went in a life-boat to try and obtain it. The boat swamped, and the Colonel, the surgeon and the mate sank to a watery grave' to rise no more.

abstract: The Burnside Expedition has turned up at Hatteras Inlet, N.C., at which place the large majority of the vessels which left Fort Monroe on the 11th inst., arrived between the 12th and 15th in good condition. Some portion of the troops' transports were delayed by stormy weather, but
lead_paragraph: The Burnside Expedition has turned up at Hatteras Inlet, N.C., at which place the large majority of the vessels which left Fort Monroe on the 11th inst., arrived between the 12th and 15th in good condition. Some portion of the troops' transports were delayed by stormy weather, but no vessels carrying troops have been lost. The object of the Expedition, which circumstance compelled the Government to change from it original destination, appears to be, now, to complete the work which Gen. BUTLER undertook, but did not finish. The vexatious delays, the loss of time, the expenditure of life and money, and other evils too numerous to recite, which have waited on this Expedition, all attest the grave mistake referred to and exhibit the folly of leaving things half done impositions practiced on the leaders of the Expedition, as to the draft of water on the Hatteras bars, as well as deceptions concerning the draf of water of vessels sold to the agents of the Government, combined with exceedingly stormy weather, continuing for two weeks together, are given as the causes of the delay -- not the defeat -- of the Expedition. The City of New-York with ordnance stores, has been wrecked; the Zouare, one of the propeller gunboats; one of the coal vessels; one of the floating batteries (canal barges,) have been lost. Two officers of the Ninth New-Jersey Regiment, col. ALLEN and Surgeon WELLER, have been drowned. At last accounts, however, over thirty armed and unarmed vessels had crossed the inner bar, and were preparing to strike a blow at some point of the North Carolina coast, and affairs were in a for ward state. The official report of Gen. BURNSIDE to Gen. MCCLELLAN, which we publish this morning in connection with our own account, makes no mention of the loss of any other vessel but the City of New-York. The loss of the Zouare and the Grapeshot is not alluded to.

abstract: The authoritative tidings of the Burnside Expedition which we publish this morning, brought to us in the official dispatch from Washington and in the detailed and authentic recital of our special correspondent with the
lead_paragraph: The authoritative tidings of the Burnside Expedition which we publish this morning, brought to us in the official dispatch from Washington and in the detailed and authentic recital of our special correspondent with the fleet, will convey to the public mind a gratifying sense of relief. Although it brings intelligence of some disasters to the Expedition, it completely dispels the growing apprehensions that prevailed respecting the safety of the whole fleet. The stormy weather which it was known to have met almost. from the time of its departure, conjoined with the traditional dangers of navigation off the North Carolina coast, below Hatteras, was well calculated to excite gloomy fears for the safety of the Expedition. Add to this the ominous silence that for the extraordinary period of two weeks rested over its fate, and it was quite natural that the suspense of the public mind should have become painfully heightened.

abstract: THE STREET CONTRACTOR PAID. The Mayor yesterday signed the warrant for the pay of the Contractor for clearing streets, (Mr. HACKLEY,) amounting to $11,625, which was due on the 15th January, but his signature was accompanied by a letter to the Con
lead_paragraph: THE STREET CONTRACTOR PAID. -- The Mayor yesterday signed the warrant for the pay of the Contractor for clearing streets, (Mr. HACKLEY,) amounting to $11,625, which was due on the 15th January, but his signature was accompanied by a letter to the Contractor, which gives fair warning that another warrant presented under similar circumstances will not receive the same favor. The Mayor does not concede the validity of the original contract, and questions whether, if legal, it has not been frequently invalidated by the Contractor, and renews the recommendation made in his annual Message to abrogate the contract. He assures Mr. HACKLEY further, that he only signs the present warrant, in consideration of the fact that due notice had not been given by the City Authorities of the non-fulfillment of that portion of the contract which requires him to keep the gutters at the crossings and at all the culverts free from snow and ice. The men were paid off yesterday afternoon, and gangs were promptly set at work clearing away the culverts, &c., many of which were frozen up.

abstract: SOCIAL REUNION. -- The Young Men's Christian Association held their regular monthly social reunion last evening in the Brooklyn Institute. The rooms were well filled, a majority of those present, as usual, being ladies. The exercises consisted of singing by the TREMAINE Family, Mrs. W. PARSONS, Miss H.C. MARIAN, Messrs. C.S. HUNTINGTON, A.H. WOOD and others. Between the different parts of the exercises were intervals devoted to social intercourse and short speeches, suitable to the occasion.

abstract: It is evident now that the first general engagement in this year's campaign is to take place in the West in Kentucky or Tennessee. The National army of over one hundred thousand soldiers in Kentucky, with
lead_paragraph: It is evident now that the first general engagement in this year's campaign is to take place in the West -- in Kentucky or Tennessee. The National army of over one hundred thousand soldiers in Kentucky, with its heavy supporting columns at Cairo and St. Louis, are now at last in a state of readiness for action, and but await the signal of the Commander-in-Chief for the southward march. The means of transport are on hand, the supplies laid in, the obstructions cleared away, the bridge over Green River completed, and the cars crossing and recrossing it; MARSHALL and ZOLLICOFFER routed, and our army brought into as high a state of martial efficiency as it is possible to bring temporary volunteers. The enthusiasm of the troops, too, has been wrought up to the highest pitch by the recent victories in the eastern part of the State, which have undoubtedly been brought about, and timed, for that very purpose, by Gen. BUELL. With bold and capable leaders -- and such we believe they have -- this hundred thousand loyal soldiers are now prepared to achieve as great results with their swords as were ever achieved by an equal number of men since man was made.

abstract: Editorial urges Government order iron-clad ships as means of strengthening navy
snippet: Editorial urges Government order iron-clad ships as means of strengthening navy
lead_paragraph: The arguments against armor-cased ships for war purposes have been virtually exhausted. and the fact still remains that France and England continue rivaling each other in the construction of such vessels with all the assiduky and resources at their disposal. In England, especially, the opposition to iron-sides has been peculiarly strenuous and uncompromising; yet the Warrior is completed, and pronounced an unequivocal triumph, and half a dozen consorts to her are being pressed forward with all possible dispatch. The British Government is not composed of idiots; and if they, with an intimate knowledge of what can be achieved by Armstrong guns, still go on spanding millions sterling on the building of this class of naval fortresses, surely we cannot be far wrong if we risk a few million dollars in similar experiments.

abstract: A private letter from Hong Kong gives an interesting account of the movements of Hon. ANSON BURLINGAME, the American Minister to China.
lead_paragraph: A private letter from Hong Kong gives an interesting account of the movements of Hon. ANSON BURLINGAME, the American Minister to China. He had recently been to Canton, where he had an interview with LAOU, the Governor-General of the Provinces of Kwangtung and Kivangsi. These Provinces contain 35,000,000 of the people. Mr. BURLINGAME visited the Governor at his official residence, accompanied by Messrs. DELANO and DANA, merchants of Hong Kong, Rev. Mr. HUPPER and Rev. Mr. PRESTON, Interpreters, and O.H. PERRY, Consul. The Minister and his retinue were borne in chairs, the bearers dashing along with an air of great importance and haste, crying, "Get out of the way, a gieal man is coming."

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, Detective C.V. MCDOUGALL was passing down Broadway, and when opposite to the Chemical Bank, in the vicinity of Chambers-street, he saw a man pass very rapidly out of the door of that Bank, and run swiftly across Broadway, to ward the Park. The excited appearance of the man raised the suspicions of the officer, and without waiting to make any inquiry as to the cause, started in pursuit. And then began a race of a very exciting, and to the crowds of spectators who thronged the streets, of a very amusing character. The two passed across a corner of the Park into Chambers-street, thence along that street to Chatham, up Chatham, to the neighborhood of Duane-street, where the suspected party was caught by his pursuer. The officer took his prisoner to the Chemical Bank, where he learned that a few minutes before the accused had presented to the Paying Teller a check, purporting to have been drawn by WOODS & LOWREY, of No. 5 Mercerstreet, for the sum of $785. Mr. PARSONS, the Teller, upon presentation of the check, suspected that it was not right, and began to question the man, who at one became confused and agitated, and upon being further pressed for an answer, made a sudden effort to seize the check from the hand of the teller. Not succeeding in this, he quickly turned and passed through the door into the street, in the manner mentioned above. The parties whose names were signed to the check were sent for, and upon an examination, pronounced it a forgery. The accused, being unable to give any satisfactory account as to how it came into his possession, was taken to Police Headquarters, where he is now confined. He says his name is AUGUST MAYER, but beyond that nothing can be learned from him. The officers of the Chemical Bank are quite certain that this is the same person who, about one year since, obtained the sum of $500 from that Bank, upon a check purporting to have been drawn by the same parties. The signature and filling up of the check were so well executed as to deceive the Bank officers; this time, however, they have been more fortunate.

abstract: The Committees appointed at the German Sigel Demonstrations in this City and Williams burgh to proceed to Washington and there lay the resolutions and a report of the other proceedings of the two meetings before the President, have returned this City. We have already published their statement of the manner in which they were received by Mr. LINCOLN, and the main result of their mission. A few other facts in connection therewith many not be uninteresting to a large number of our readers. The deputation called upon Messrs. HARRIS and KING, Senators from this State, whose sentiments were found to differ, in some degree, from many of the view expressed by the Germans; but the interview was, in other respects, very cordial and pleasant . There seems to have been no direct call upon either the Secretary of War, Mr. STANTON, or the acting Commander-in-Chief, Gen. MCCLELLAN. The reasons for this omission will, with other matters, be made the subject of a special report by the two delegations.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition in favor of the restoration of the warehousing system, from a large number of New-York merchants, was presented by Mr. HARRIS. A petition from citizens of Illinois, asking Congress not to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, and asking for the expulsion of members who advocate it, was presented by Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware. The petition also asks that the title of General be taken from Gen. FREMONT, and that his frauds in the Western Department be exposed. A resolution was offered by Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, and adopted, asking the Secretary of the Treasury whether any further legislation is necessary in order to take charge of the cotton and other lands of South Carolina, now in possession of the Government, and to place them under cultivation, and also in relation to the blacks in these localities. A bill, to define the pay and emoluments of certain officers of the army was introduced by Mr. WILSON, and referred. A bill to provide for the revision and consolidation of the statutes of the United States, was introduced by Mr. SUMNER, and referred. The bill to authorize the President to take possession of certain railroads and telegraph lines, was taken up and debated at considerable length. Mr. WADE explained that the bill was only intended to affect roads the directors of which were not willing should be used by the Government. The bill was debated at considerable length, and finally passed, after being amended so as to confine the operation of the bill to any State or District in which the laws of the United States were opposed. The Senate then adjourned.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bill to amend the General Manufacturing law, and on the bill to amend the Revised Statutes, relative to judgments in cases of ejectment. A bill to amend the Divorce law was introduced: also, one to prevent and punish stand by the use of false stamps, Lands, trade marks, &c. The Canal Appropriation bill was passed; also the bill to amend the law in relation to unauthorized banking. A statement of the Canal Awards male, and the amount unpaid, was sent in by the Canal Auditor. The resolution Introduced by Mr. BELL. In favor of appointing three Commissioners to draft a general tax bill. Was laid on the table and ordered to be printed, after some debate. The bill to ament the Brooklyn Common School law was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: The papers report that Capt. GREGG, of the regular army, has been appointed to the Colonelcy of the regiment of Pennsylvania Cavalry formerly commanded by Col. CHANTRY. There are two Captains of this name both in the Sixth United Sates Cavalry.
lead_paragraph: The papers report that Capt. GREGG, of the regular army, has been appointed to the Colonelcy of the regiment of Pennsylvania Cavalry formerly commanded by Col. CHANTRY. There are two Captains of this name both in the Sixth United Sates Cavalry. The senior of the two is Capt. DANIEL MCM. GREGG, a native of Pennsylvania, and a graduate of West Point, who entered the service on the 1st July, 1855, as Brevet Second Lieutenant in the Second Dragoons. He was promoted to a Captaincy in the Sixth Cavalry, On the organization of that regiment, on the 14th May, 1861. The other Captain is I. IRVIN GREGG, also a native of Pennsylvania, entered the service from citizen life on the 14th May, 1861, as Captain in the Sixth Cavalry.

abstract: The invasion of their territory by three of the most powerful of European States, has not awed the spirit of the Mexicans. Instead of intimidating them, the unprovoked aggression has thoroughly aroused their indignation and patriotism. Party distinctions and party antipathies are obliterated, and all classes and sections of the people are now alone animated by hatred of the foreigner, and the determination to resist him. The appeal of the President in behalf of the country, has been nobly and unanimously responded to and the masses are rising in their might to defend their liberties and national existence. That formidable guerrilla system, of which the Iberian race is so fond, and which proved so fatal to the French in the Peninsular war, as well as to the Spaniards during Mexico's struggle for independence, is already in course of reorganization among the Mexicans, and should the invaders have the temerity to attempt penetrating into the interior, they will have to contend not only with the regular army of the republic, numbering some 150,000 men, but also with myriads of armed bands, which will hover continually around their forces, harass them in their march, cut off all stragglers and all supplies of provisions, and prove as terrible and invincible as CRASSUS found the Parthians of old.
lead_paragraph: The invasion of their territory by three of the most powerful of European States, has not awed the spirit of the Mexicans. abstract: At about 9 o'clock, last evening, smoke was seen issuing from the four-story granite building No. 13 Atlantic Dock, by the watchman on duty there. An alarm was immediately given, and the Union Ferry Company's boat Bedford was at once moored into the Hamilton-avenue Ferry-slip, and two lines of hose were stretched to the scene of the conflagration.
lead_paragraph: At about 9 o'clock, last evening, smoke was seen issuing from the four-story granite building No. 13 Atlantic Dock, by the watchman on duty there. An alarm was immediately given, and the Union Ferry Company's boat Bedford was at once moored into the Hamilton-avenue Ferry-slip, and two lines of hose were stretched to the scene of the conflagration. Long, however, before any water was thrown upon the building, the fire had burst from the windows of the upper stories, and was burning with fearful violence, threatening destruction to all the property in the vicinity. In fact, had there been any wind blowing, the whole property on this wharf would have been endangered, owing to its position and the small space -- only some twenty feet in front, on the wharf, in which the firemen had to operate their machines. To these difficulties may be added that of defective hose. When the firemen did reach the scene of conflagration, they were seriously impeded in their operations by the constant bursting of the hose. The Chief Engineer of the Fire Department a long time ago applied to the Common Council for a supply of hose -- stating that the hose on hand was of a poor quality and nearly worn out. Through this neglect alone several thousand dollars worth of property was sacrificed at this fire. The firemen did, however, all that could have been expected of them, and worked faithfully under the most discouraging circumstances, and succeeded in confining the damage to where the fire originated and the adjoining buildings, Nos. 12 and 14.

abstract: Any strong curiosity to learn how the news of the release of the Trent captives would be received in England, the ample extracts we reproduce this morning from our English files must entirely satisfy.
lead_paragraph: Any strong curiosity to learn how the news of the release of the Trent captives would be received in England, the ample extracts we reproduce this morning from our English files must entirely satisfy. But there has, in reality, been no marked interest in the matter. Having sent the worthless subjects of dispute about their business, we have chosen to regard the transaction as entirely ended. The public has had domestic topics enough, and in excess indeed, to engage its profoundest attention. The occasional exhibitions of vitality in the conduct of the army; the intensely interesting discussions of financial questions, and a proper scheme of taxation; the naval expedition of Gen. BURNSIDE; the vexed and interminable question of the negro; these have hastened in and crowded from their stools issues and interests which, during December, had everything their own way. We paid the British demand in full. We have had no time to waste over time receipt.

abstract: Certain of our returned prisoners state that the clothing, , sent from Fortress Monroe by Gen. WOOL some time since, for the use of our imprisoned soldiers at Richmond, never reached there at all.
lead_paragraph: -- Certain of our returned prisoners state that the clothing, &c., sent from Fortress Monroe by Gen. WOOL some time since, for the use of our imprisoned soldiers at Richmond, never reached there at all. We are not surprised at the statement. We were informed personally some time since, by one who was released from Charleston jail, that our men there reported that money sent to them by their friends had never come to hand. It could hardly be otherwise. When has there been a chance for a rebel to steal that has not been improved? They have lived so long upon the fruits of stolen labor that the appropriation by them of other people's property occurs to them as the most natural thing in the world. And, moreover, a "Yankee" is so much beneath a "nigger" in their estimation that it could not be supposed that our prisoners would have any rights which the Southern chivalry would feel itself bound to respect. In the present state of things there, with gold at 25 per cent. premium and upwards, with boots at £25 a pair, and all kinds of clothing in proportion, is it to be supposed that they would see money and clothing pass from their hands into those of a prisoner who could not help himself if he was wronged? He who should expect such a thing cannot have studied the natural history of secession.

abstract: Messrs. FRIEDRICH KAPP, of the New-York, and SIGISMUND KAUFMANN, of the Brooklyn Committee, which recently waited on the President at Washington, in reference to the Sigel difficulty, have informed us that Senator KING was found to agree heartily with the German sentiment in reference to Gen. SIGEL's past and future course, but that no formal visit of the Committees, as such, was made to Senator HARRIS, because that gentleman was declared to deprecate the whole movement from beginning to end. These gentlemen profess to be unaware who the Mr. ROEMER may be to whom the President is said to have offered a Brigadier-General's command. The Abend Zeilung, of this City, of Tuesday afternoon last, authoritatively gives the statement above referred to, and that paper may be able to announce that Mr. ROEMER is somewhat noted politician and now military aspirant, of the great Northwest, and a friend of Gen. SIGEL. Our local information is always collected with care from reliable sources.

abstract: In the senate, yesterday, notice was given of a bill to incorporate the Homoeopathic Medical Society of New-York.
lead_paragraph: In the senate, yesterday, notice was given of a bill to incorporate the Homoeopathic Medical Society of New-York. A bill was introduced authorizing the Greenwood Cemetery Association to sell a gore of land; and another, to provide for a Court-house in Kings County. Bills were introduced -- to correct abuses in regard to laying pavements in this City; relative to the trial of offences against Joint-Stock Associations; and for the relief of the owners of land formerly under water in front of New-York and Kings County. A concurrent resolution, asking the New-York Senators in Congress to vote for the expulsion of Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, was introduced, but laid over under the rules.

lead_paragraph: ADES. -- The submarine blockade of Charleston is very generally denounced in Europe as opposed to the civilization of the age. And the condemnation is not confined to British journals whose transparent Secessionist sympathies and hostility to the United States clearly reveal the animus of their objurgations. The Moniteur also pronounces the blockade improper, and expresses "regret and indignation at the vindictive act of destroying the port of Charleston." This formal expression of opinion by the official French journal gives a character of generality to the question, and though it is not likely to become a matter of negotiation -- being without the province of diplomacy -- the stone blockade is, it must be owned, not ill-fitted to raise a clamor in the journals; and late experience has shown us that such popular clamor cannot be altogether ignored.

abstract: We have telegraphic news from San Francisco to the 22d inst. The rainy weather still continued, and business was generally suspended in consequence. Sacramento was still under water, and the members of the Legislature went to and from the Capital in boats. A proposition to adjourn to San Francisco was being debated, and would probably be carried. The steamer St. Louis sailed for Panama on the 21st, having on board $600,000 for this City.

abstract: We have the satisfaction to learn, from many sources, that the full, detailed and accurate history of the Burnside Expedition, from our special correspondent with the fleet, which we published yesterday, has met with the appreciation it merits.
lead_paragraph: We have the satisfaction to learn, from many sources, that the full, detailed and accurate history of the Burnside Expedition, from our special correspondent with the fleet, which we published yesterday, has met with the appreciation it merits. No other New-York journal was able to publish anything beyond the meagre, inaccurate and contradictory dispatches to the Associated Press. The official dispatches from Washington erred by underrating the extent of the disaster which befell our fleet -- representing but one vessel as having been lost. On the other hand, the unofficial dispatch from Fortress Monroe sinned far worse on the other side, by grossly exaggerating the extent of our losses. It spoke of "unknown schooners" going down with many of those on board, threw out dark hints of treachery on the part of the pilots, in consequence of which many of the vessels were stranded, and both in what was stated and in what was left to be inferred, managed to convey a most distressing impression of disaster and defeat. The result was, that these vague hints of woe carried the most poignant distress to the hearts of the thousands who had those near and dear to them on board the fleet. But the minute and accurate statement, filling over a page of yesterday's TIMES, put an end to all this anxiety and suspense. We were able to state definitely what were our losses and what were the circumstances, and what was the true nature of the stops and hindrances met with. The consequence was that the fearful apprehensions excited by the unofficial dispatch -- and which were rather heightened than otherwise by the obvious and ominous suppressions of the official account -- gave way to a definite realization of the true state of the matter. And this was such as to inspire the best hopes of success for the Burnside Expedition.

abstract: Editorial on freed slaves cultivation of cotton in Union-held areas of South Carolina; Editorial on cotton cultivation in Union-held territory of South Carolina by newly freed slaves
snippet: Editorial on freed slaves cultivation of cotton in Union-held areas of South Carolina; Editorial on cotton cultivation in Union-held territory of South Carolina by newly freed slaves
lead_paragraph: A resolution has been offered and adopted in the Senate, that the Secretary of the Treasury furnish information as to what, if any, further legislation is necessary to enable the Executive Department to take charge of the cotton and other lands of South Carolina now in possession of the Government, and to place the same under cultivation; also, if any further legislation is required to provide for the "blacks" in those localities, and to furnish them with proper employment. About two months ago, it will be remembered, the Secretary of the Treasury issued a circular making provision for the appointment of agents to reside at such points as might he occupied by the National forces, whose duty it should be to secure and prepare for market the cotton and such other products as were brought within the army lines, or under control of the National authorities. These agents were authorized to employ in this work those "persons hold to service for life under State laws" who might be found within our lines, under certain regulations set forth by the Secretary in his circular. In accordance with this policy, a considerable quantity of Sea Island cotton has been gathered, baled, shipped to this City, and sold for the benefit of the Government.

abstract: The steamer City of New-York, of the Burnside Expedition, which was wrecked off Hatteras Inlet, on the 14th Inst., was built at Hoboken, N. J., in 1851-52, by CAPES  ALLISON, and was of about 575 tone register. Her engines were constructed, by HOGG  DELA.
lead_paragraph: The steamer City of New-York, of the Burnside Expedition, which was wrecked off Hatteras Inlet, on the 14th Inst., was built at Hoboken, N. J., in 1851-52, by CAPES & ALLISON, and was of about 575 tone register. Her engines were constructed, by HOGG & DELA MATER, of this City. She was rebuilt in Boston about three years since, and furnished with new boilers at a cost of nearly $30,000. Since that time she has been run but little, except while in Government service. She was newly coppered in June last. Her ordinary draft of water was about 15 fee -- a draft unusual for a vessel of her tonnage.

abstract: LLOYD has issued a new map of the State of Kentucky, to which region all eyes are now turned in anticipation of the great battle which some think is about to be fought in that State. It gives the counties, towns, railroads, post-roads, etc., and many of the points of interest in connection with recent military movements there are put in large characters, and their connections clearly shown. The mountain ranges, rivers, and other natural features are also lined out with greater accuracy than in any other map. It professes, also, to give the forts and fortifications; but this is much less perfect than it would have been if the designer had carefully studied up the newspapers for the last half year. The degrees of longitude and latitude also do not seem to be very strictly proportioned. Still, the map is an exceedingly good one; and being the latest out, is necessarily the best for studying up military movements.

abstract: Last evening a crowded meeting was held of Harmony Division No. 5 of this Order, in celebration of the nineteenth anniversary, at No. 187 Bowery. G.W.P. THOMAS and T. SHEFFIELD presided. From the report that was read, it appears that the Division was instituted Jan. 18, 1843. Since which time about six hundred members have joined, and some $1,000 expended in relieving the sick. Besides this $1,200 have been given for funeral benefits, and to help the widows and orphans of deceased members. Over 2,000 Sons of Temperance are members of Massachusetts regiments. At the close of the meeting it was announced that 22 new members had been proposed, and would be initiated on the 12th of February. The arrangements for the celebration were excellent, and reflected great credit upon the Committee and Mr. Wm. J. SPENCE, an old and highly-esteemed member of the Division.

abstract: To-morrow afternoon this regiment will leave Riker's Island, where it has been quartered for some time past, for Washington. The men have lately been paid off for some three months' services which amounted to about $40,000 -- more than half of which has been transmitted to the families of the soldiers in Oswego and Albany.

abstract: editorial on conditions among Europeans occupying Vera Cruz

lead_paragraph: Our latest advices from Mexico do not represent the condition of the Allies there as a very enviable one. The close proximity into which they have been brought in Vera Cruz has not tended to promote harmony among them. Their national antipathies are in process of development, and the special object of each seems to be to wound the sensibilities of her confederates, and to sever as soon as possible the bonds which unite them.

abstract: The London Times is nursing its wrath to keep it warm, and, having the ground of its objurgations apropos of the Mason and Slidell case taken from under it, falls back with renewed fervor on our stone blockade of Charleston harbor. Unhappily its knowledge is not equal to its fervor. �When,� it asks, �has such an act been perpetrated by any European Power?" As the query is evidently sincere, we answer, in the Nineteenth Century, by that great European Power -- John Bull. The Times then goes triumphantly on to hold up to us England's blockade of the French coast during the Napoleonic war, as a shining example of how such things are managed by the �guardians o civilization.� We accept the illustration with due humility, and proceed to give an example of what England actually did during that model blockade. It rather upsets the case of the Times, but is historical fact none the less We quote from SCOTT's Napoleon. vol. II chap. 10:

abstract: An important order has been issued by the Secretary of War, which directs -- in view of the fact that the urgent necessity which required the immediate purchase of arms, clothing and other military supplies from foreign countries no longer exists -- that no further contracts be made for any article of foreign manufacture, which can be produced in the United State, and that all outstanding orders and authorities for the purchase of such articles are revoked and annulled. The order also directs that all persons claiming to have any contract or agreement, or any authority whatever from the War Department for furnishing such articles, shall notify the Department within fifteen days. The method of making contracts is also strictly laid down, and any departure from it will render them of no effect.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. It is so natural to praise an operatic evening when Mr. MAX MARETZEK occupies the conductor's chair, that the incident of a good performance of an opera so well known as FLOTOWS's  "Martha " seems trivial. Yet, if we will but honest
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- It is so natural to praise an operatic evening when Mr. MAX MARETZEK occupies the conductor's chair, that the incident of a good performance of an opera so well known as FLOTOWS's "Martha" seems trivial. Yet, if we will but honestly recall the numberless bad performances that have taken place during Mr. MARETZEK's absence, and remember, too, that art has steadily retrograded since he abandoned the field to less competent, but far noisier competitors, it will be conceded that there was nothing more than a graceful recognition of positive merit in the hearty applause which greeted that gentleman on his appearance in the orchestra last night. And the opera went so smoothly, and with so much spirit, that a blind man might have known a new chief was at the head of the musical forces. Mr. MARETZEK possesses qualities that cannot be exaggerated. He is one of the best on chestral accompanists that we have ever had, and can nurse a voice to the absolute development of all its strength. This purely Italian faculty is blended with a broad, massive German sense of effect, and the combination, even under the most unfavorable circumstances, produces what is called a fine performance. There are men, who, with innumerable rehearsals, can arrive at the same results, but we know of none that can infuse a spirit of completeness into a representation that has had but little preparation, so well as he. Let us always be just to the truth that we recognize, and acknowledge this freely of an energetic, accomplished and unrewarded man.

abstract: About 12 o'clock on Wednesday night, Sergeants WILSON, WADE and TAFT, of the Eighth Precinet, with a platoon of men, made a descent upon the gamblinghouse of the person who is known in sporting circles as "Dad" CUNNINGHAM, No.575 Broadway. They arrested thirty-nine persons in the eatabliahment, (including CUNNINGHAM himself,) the most of whom were at the time actually engaged in gambling.
lead_paragraph: About 12 o'clock on Wednesday night, Sergeants WILSON, WADE and TAFT, of the Eighth Precinet, with a platoon of men, made a descent upon the gamblinghouse of the person who is known in sporting circles as "Dad" CUNNINGHAM, No.575 Broadway. They arrested thirty-nine persons in the eatabliahment, (including CUNNINGHAM himself,) the most of whom were at the time actually engaged in gambling. They alsoseized, and conveyed to the Station-house, a large quantity of gambling tools and apparatus, and also $5 42 in money which was lying on a faro-table at the time the officers entered. Yesterday the prisoners were taken before Justice KELLY, and, after an examination, CONNINGHAM and fourteen others were held to bail for trial at the Court of Sessions. The remainder of those arrested were unconditionally set at liberty. The following are the names and occupations of the persons who were arrested, as given by themselves when arraigned before the Court: Daniel Cunningham, (proprietor,) gilder, committed for examination; John Thompson, clerk, discharged; George Spencer, clerk, discharged; John O'Brien, the doorman, not held; Chas. Mitchell, actor, discharged; Richard Donald, hotel-keeper, discharged; Albert W. Walton, clerk, discharged; Martin Frink, alias Theodore Allen, butcher, discharged; Albert Rousseau, molder, discharged; Edward Valentine' mechanic, discharged; Peter Ferris, liquor dealer' discharged; John Kennedy, no occupation, held to bail in the sum of $100; Robert Watson, butcher, discharged; Paul James, no occupation, discharged; Chas. P. Archer, jeweler, discharged; Wm. Lockwood, held to bail; John McCarty, pedler, discharged; Edmund Fox, glass cutter, discharged; Geo. Franklin, barkeeper, held to bail; Henry Thompson, clerk, held to bail; Wm. Vosburgh, boatman, held to bail; Richard Barry, butcher, held to bail; Charles Townsend, clerk, held to bail; John Fraser, no occupation, discharged; Charles Pelham, ship carpenter, discharged; John Taylor, broker, discharged; Lewis Martin, butcher, discharged; John McCormicK, butcher, discharged; John Marshall, "[???]," (a decoy) held to bail; Benjamin Hack, [???], held to bail; Edward Parmelee, bartender, discharged; John, Hamilton, mason, discharged; John Kelly, broker, held to bail; Charles Painter, brass finisher, held to bail: Henry Johnson, speculator, discharged; Charles Collins, brush-maker, discharged; Henry Corse, grocer, discharged; James Sharp, butcher, discharged; William Forbes, clias Foster, shoemaker, and James Turner, cooper, held to bail.

abstract: Yesterday morning, the Ericsson battery was launched from the ship-yard of Mr. T.F. ROWLAND, Greenpoint. L.I. Notwithstanding the prognostication of many that she would break her back or else swamp, she was launched successfully. The keel of the vessel was laid on the 25th of October, and on the 31st of December the engines were put in and operated on. Her draft forward is 7 feet 3 inches; aft, 8 feet 1 inch. With all her armament, coals and provisions on board, she will draw 9 feet 9 inches, leaving twenty-one inches height above the water-line. On the deck is a bomb-proof revolving turret, containing two 11-inch Dahlgren guns, the heaviest that are used in the navy. This turret is for the protection of the men while working the guns, none of whom are exposed or seen by the enemy. The machinery of the battery is being made by Mr. C.H. DELAMATER, which will be of sufficient power to propel the battery at the rate of about eight knots an hour. The propeller is nine feet diameter, sixteen feet pitch, and has four blades. All her machinery is below the water-line. A condensing apparatus is also on board for the purpose of supplying fresh water to the officers and crew.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from citizens of Iowa, for a general bankrupt law. A bill prohibiting the Coolie trade in American vessels was introduced. A resolution directing the Committee on Commerce to inquire into ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from citizens of Iowa, for a general bankrupt law. A bill prohibiting the Coolie trade in American vessels was introduced. A resolution directing the Committee on Commerce to inquire into the propriety of requiring captains of vessels sailing to foreign ports to take the oath of allegiance was adopted. The Secretary, of War was authorized to procure from officers and soldiers, now prisoners with the rebels, allotments for the benefit of their families. The Secretary was also asked to furnish a tabular statement of all the vessels purchased or chartered for the Department since April, with the particulars relating to them. The Secretary of the Navy was asked for information relative to the ship Franklin, changed into a steamer. The resolution for printing five thousand copies of the eulogies of the late Senator BAKER was debated at considerable length, and was defeated -- the disposition being to cut off all such expenses, now and hereafter. The Committee on Military Affairs was directed to inquire into the condition of all the Army Hospitals, and to report such measures as may be necessary to correct abuses. A bill was reported relating to the construction of a military road from Kentucky to Tennessee. Mr. BRIGHT's case was then again considered, but not disposed of. The Senate held an Executive session, and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: The Committee on Public Health met yesterday, to consider the subject of providing special conveyances for parties afflicted with infectious diseases to the various hospitals, &c. Mr. DRAPER, President of the Board of Charities and Correction, was present, and strenuously urged the great danger of permitting such parties to be conveyed in public hacks, and, after some remarks, it was concluded to report an ordinance prohibiting that practice, under heavy penalties, and granting power to the Commissioners ofCharities and Corrections to provide special vehicles for the conveyance of all persons afflicted with contagious diseases.
lead_paragraph: The Committee on Public Health met yesterday, to consider the subject of providing special conveyances for parties afflicted with infectious diseases to the various hospitals, &c. abstract: The Ericsson battery, notwithstanding the many prognostications of its failure, was successfully launched yesterday from the ship-yard of Mr. T.F. ROLAND, Greenpoint, L.I. Her draft forward is 7 feet 3 inches; aft, 8 feet 1 inch. When all her armament, coals and provisions are on board, she will draw 9 feet 9 inches, leaving only 21 inches above the water line. She will be armed with two 11-inch Dahlgren guns, which are the heaviest now used in the navy. During an engagement the men employed in working the guns will be protected from the shots of the enemy by a bomb-proof turret in the centre of the deck.
lead_paragraph: The Ericsson battery, notwithstanding the many prognostications of its failure, was successfully launched yesterday from the ship-yard of Mr. T.F. ROLAND, Greenpoint, L.I. abstract: Editorial on Dr. W T G Morton suit for patent on sulphuric ether as anesthetic
snippet: Editorial on Dr. W T G Morton suit for patent on sulphuric ether as anesthetic
lead_paragraph: Our legal columns this morning contain a case of very great interest to the medical profession. We refer to a suit brought by Dr. W.T.G. MORTON against the New-York Eye Infirmary, to recover damages for the infringement by them of the patent granted to him in 1846 for an "improvement in surgical operations," it being the famous patent for the use of sulphuric ether as an anaesthetic agent. This is the first time that this patent has made its appearance in Court in this State, we believe, although there have been some legal proceedings involving it in Massachusetts.

abstract: After the presentation of petitions and many resolutions for the appointment of Commissioners of Deeds, the President announced that he had appointed Henry Sayder as Reader of the Board, at a salary of $750. Mr. KEECH offered a preamble and series of  patriotic resolutions connected with the approaching anniversary of the Birthday of WASHINGTON, which were appropriately referred.
lead_paragraph: After the presentation of petitions and many resolutions for the appointment of Commissioners of Deeds, the President announced that he had appointed Henry Sayder as Reader of the Board, at a salary of $750. Mr. KEECH offered a preamble and series of patriotic resolutions connected with the approaching anniversary of the Birthday of WASHINGTON, which were appropriately referred. A communication was received from D.T. Valentine, Esq., Clerk of the Common Council, relative to the City Manual, in which he repels any insinnation as to the number of copies sold by him, or the pecuniary benefit derived by him. The number sold annually for the past three years does not exceed twenty-five, and the proceeds were appropriated by him to the City Library. In 1860 the edition was 4,500, of which the members of the Common Council received 2,800, and in 1861, 6,000 wore printed, the Common Council receiving 3,800, the remainder being distributed to various public institutions, distinguished citizens, &c. He states that he has no control over the expenses incurred in printing, binding, &c., and only obeys the directions of the Common Council in getting it out, and is perfectly ready to abide by any directions or changes they may designate.

abstract: The documentary history of the Trent business is completed by the publication of Earl RUSSELL'S rejoinder to the letter of Mr. SEWARD. The British Foreign Secretary frankly accepts the surrender of the Envoys and their ...
lead_paragraph: The documentary history of the Trent business is completed by the publication of Earl RUSSELL'S rejoinder to the letter of Mr. SEWARD. The British Foreign Secretary frankly accepts the surrender of the Envoys and their suite as the full reparation England had a right to exact. The omission of an apology is approved, because, the act of Capt. WILKES having been unauthorized and disavowed, an apology would be purely formal and ridiculous. With regard to the points of international law raised and "ably argued" by the American Secretary, Lord RUSSELL admits the propriety of making them the topic of thorough discussion and arrangement, and informs Lord LYONS that in the course of a few days he may expect to receive from the Foreign Office an enumeration of the questions in respect to which there appears to be ambiguity, and upon which agreement is desirable. With a merited compliment to the skill and good temper with which Lord LYONS had conducted his part of this delicate negotiation, the dispatch of Lord RUSSELL closes.

abstract: The steamer City of Washington arrived here last evening, and the Anglo-Saxon at Portland, yesterday morning, bring four days' later news from Europe. It was reported that the Nashville had been sold to an English shipowner.

abstract: The medical profession and the public generally, will regret to hear that Dr. H.G. Cox, the widely known professor to the New-York Medical College met with a severe accident on Wednesday evening He was passing through Twenty-seventh-street, near Seventh-avenue, on his way to his home from the house of one of his patients, when he slipped upon the sidewalk, which was coated with ice, dislocating his left ankle, and breaking the smaller bone of his leg. Some time must elapse ere Dr. COX can resume the active duties of his profession.

abstract: While the question of the way for supplying the means immediately needed for the exigencies of the Treasury is postponed from day to day by our House of Representatives, a sound of rejoicing at the prospect of its bankruptcy and utter ruin comes to us from the other side of the water, through the London Times.
lead_paragraph: While the question of the way for supplying the means immediately needed for the exigencies of the Treasury is postponed from day to day by our House of Representatives, a sound of rejoicing at the prospect of its bankruptcy and utter ruin comes to us from the other side of the water, through the London Times. Itwould be useless, of course, to expect anything less uncharitable from that quarter, in the present temper of the leading English journal toward the Government of the United States and the people of the North. The evidences of its deliberate and persistent hostility have been continuous from the very beginning of the war. But this last attack, founded upon the news from this side of the suspension of specie payments by the Banks and the Treasury, carries with it a lesson to our Representatives in Congress, and to the loyal moneyed interest of the country, which it would be well to improve, in spite of its malignity and gross exaggeration. The article referred to is an editorial leader in the Times of the 15th January, received last evening by the steamer of the 16th. It is copied at length on another page.

abstract: Surgeon-Gen. FINLEY has sent to the hospitals at Washington a newly-invented spring couch, which is intended to take the place of the old fashioned slat cot or bedstead. This new bed is equally adapted to camps and hospitals, and can be taken apart and tied up almost in a man's handkerchief. The bottom is made of thin slats of pine of the smoothest quality,
lead_paragraph: Surgeon-Gen. FINLEY has sent to the hospitals at Washington a newly-invented spring couch, which is intended to take the place of the old fashioned slat cot or bedstead. This new bed is equally adapted to camps and hospitals, and can be taken apart and tied up almost in a man's handkerchief. The bottom is made of thin slats of pine of the smoothest quality, which are provided with elastic springs of finely tempered metal, which yield comfortably to the pressure of the sick or wounded. These couches will require only a very light mattress, weighing four pounds, thus dispensing with the heavy straw or hair mattress, generators of malaria or fever, and giving beside a much more comfortable bed to the soldier.
headline: {'main': 'Oanches for the Hospitals.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Oanches for the Hospitals.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A discourse was delivered at the Church of the Puritans, (Union-square,) last evening, by Rev. M.D. CONWAY, of Cincinnatti, on the subject of Slavery, as involved in the present war. The reverend speaker argued to a large and insterested audience that emancipation was the only means by which the nation could be released from its present difficulties. But the powers at Washington were paralyzed and puzzled over the problem of "How not to do it," and the country was dissolving into ruin. The golden moment for saving her was passing, and he urged the necessity of the people speaking in tones which should revive the President and the Cabinet, and forcing them into adopting the only policy which could be of advantage. The lecture abounded in logic and fact, and was much applauded. We have a full report of it in type, which may be published hereafter. At the conclusion of Mr. CONWAY's discourse. Rev. Dr. CHEEVER briefly spoke. He said that he was just from Washington, where he had been asked by Senators and Congressmen to return and deliver to New-York the message that an expression of the people's sentiments in mass meeting was desired by the Government. It waited to hear their views. Did they desire a decree of emancipation or not? Upon the motion of Dr. ROBERT F. HALLECK, a Committee of twenty-one persons, comprising many of our most prominent citizens, was appointed for the purpose of calling a mass meeting at an early day.
lead_paragraph: A discourse was delivered at the Church of the Puritans, (Union-square,) last evening, by Rev. M.D. CONWAY, of Cincinnatti, on the subject of Slavery, as involved in the present war. The reverend speaker argued to a large and insterested audience that emancipation was the only means by which the nation could be released from its present difficulties. But the powers at Washington were paralyzed and puzzled over the problem of "How not to do it," and the country was dissolving into ruin. The golden moment for saving her was passing, and he urged the necessity of the people speaking in tones which should revive the President and the Cabinet, and forcing them into adopting the only policy which could be of advantage. The lecture abounded in logic and fact, and was much applauded. We have a full report of it in type, which may be published hereafter. At the conclusion of Mr. CONWAY's discourse. Rev. Dr. CHEEVER briefly spoke. He said that he was just from Washington, where he had been asked by Senators and Congressmen to return and deliver to New-York the message that an expression of the people's sentiments in mass meeting was desired by the Government. It waited to hear their views. Did they desire a decree of emancipation or not? Upon the motion of Dr. ROBERT F. HALLECK, a Committee of twenty-one persons, comprising many of our most prominent citizens, was appointed for the purpose of calling a mass meeting at an early day.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to amend the Brooklyn Charter, and the bill to prohibit Concert Saloons in this City, were reported for consideration. Another bill to amend the Charter of Brooklyn was introduced by Mr. MURPHY. A bill, appropriating $250,000 to facilitate the construction ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to amend the Brooklyn Charter, and the bill to prohibit Concert Saloons in this City, were reported for consideration. Another bill to amend the Charter of Brooklyn was introduced by Mr. MURPHY. A bill, appropriating $250,000 to facilitate the construction of the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad, was introduced. A bill to enable married women to insure the lives of their husbands was also introduced. The resolution instructing Senators HARRIS and KING to vote for the expulsion of Mr. BRIGHT from the United States Senate was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment -- no vote was taken.
