abstract: Editorial urges speedy capture of Confederate Gen. Price in Missouri because of his strategy in border warfare
snippet: Editorial urges speedy capture of Confederate Gen. Price in Missouri because of his strategy in border warfare
lead_paragraph: What the Sumter is on seas, Gen. PRICE is on the land -- everywhere present, yet never to be caught. Now he is up on the Missouri River, now on the Osage, and now away down among the Ozark hills; anon he skirts along the Kansas border, skulks down into Arkansas, or rushes toward the red man's reserve; now he turns his front toward St. Louis, and again, no man but himself can tell of his whereabouts. The military "traps" in which he is to be caught, he adroitly evades; the military sacks in which he is to be "bagged," he carefully keeps away from; and even the great military "anaconda" cannot get a chance of bringing him within its coils. Yet, both the pirate PRICE and the pirate Sumter must be caught, and that speedily. We want two heroes -- a naval hero to catch the sea-pirate, and a military hero to catch the land-pirate; and we promise that both heroes, when their work is done, shall be crowned with such honors and glory as will reverse forever the false old saw, that republics are ungrateful.

abstract: by the Anglo Saxon -- that the Nashville has changed owners -- prove to be a fact, the Englishmen who have been so stupid as to purchase her may learn to their cost that needy Confederate thieves are sharper than bargain-driving Yankees. There are parties in this City, we believe, who have never relinquished the claims which they have upon this famous vessel by virtue of the fact that they were stockholders in the Company to which she belonged, and it is hard to see how any who may have purchased her from the piratical crew which took her into Southampton could establish their title to her, if it should be called in question. At any rate, if Capt. PEGRAM has pocketed a price for his craft, it would be the part of prudence for him to act as a cautious horse-thief would undersimilar circumstances -- promptly leave for parts unknown.

abstract: SUICIDE BY HANGING. About 8  o'clock yesterday morning the body of an unknown man was found in the front area of No. 31 West Eleventh street. It was evident that he had hanged himself by the neck from the railing of the stoop, by means of a tarred rope. Life was extinct when deceased was found, though some parts of body were moving.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE BY HANGING. -- About 8 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning the body of an unknown man was found in the front area of No. 31 West Eleventh street. It was evident that he had hanged himself by the neck from the railing of the stoop, by means of a tarred rope. Life was extinct when deceased was found, though some parts of body were moving. It is believed that he could not have been dead more man ten minutes. When discovered, the body was lying stretchec at full length on the flag-stones, in such a position as to warrant the belief that the rope parted after strangulation had taken place. A passport, dated January, 1862, was found upon the person of deceased. From this document, it appears that he was a native of Holland, and that his name was JEAN HENRY WALTERS. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday. The Jury rendered a verdict of "Suicide by hanging."

abstract: The latest information from the West is that our army is encamped at Lebanon in considerable number. Major WRIGHT'S battalion is quartered in a house lately occupied by Secessionists, but the greater portion of the troops are encamped just beyond the town. No troops except scouts have advanced beyond that town, nor is it probable they will until other regiments on the way shall have arrived.

abstract: Our dispatches and correspondence from Fortress Monroe contain some additional intelligence from the Burnside Expedition. Everything, at last accounts, was progressing quite favorably.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches and correspondence from Fortress Monroe contain some additional intelligence from the Burnside Expedition. Everything, at last accounts, was progressing quite favorably. The pleasant weather now prevailing in that region has enabled the water and tugboats delayed at Hampton Roads to proceed to Hatteras Inlet, where the services of the tugs will be of the greatest value. An official dispatch has also been received at the Navy Department from Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH, which represents everything to be progressing favorably. He anticipates being soon "at the enemy."

abstract: UNION MEN RETURNED HOME. -- JEAN GILBERT of Powers-street, this city, reached here a few days since, having deserted from the rebel army, with two other men at Columbus, into which they were impressed at New-Orleans. Mr. GILBERT and his associates were engaged in the battle of Belmont, and they then attempted to make their escape, but were arrested just below Cairo by Southern scouts, tried and sentenced to be shot. Four days before the day of execution they succeeded again in making theirescape, and this time they successfully reached the lines of the Twentieth Illinois Regiment, Col. MARSH, at Camp Jefferson, north of Mayfield Creek. Mr. GILBERT says there are 40,000 men at Columbus, and the men are at work day and night on the entrenchments and hourly expect to be attacked. Mr. GILBERT intends returning, but as a Union, not as a rebel soldier. He was formerly connected with DAN RICE's Circus.

abstract: that beset the North Carolina expedition, as portrayed in the correspondence of this and other journals, there is one figure that cannot but have arrested the public attention. It is that of Gen. BURNSIDE, military chief of the expedition. Throughout that week of horrors -- more terrible by far than the triste noche through which CORTES and his comrades passed -- he remained calmly indefatigable, master of himself, master of the occasion, sympathetic, courage-giving. He was everywhere among the fleet, directing, counseling, cheering. It is horrible to conceive what might have happened with a leader of a different sort. But BURNSIDE is obviously one of those men who, behind the guise of the gentlest and suavest behavior, have a reserved force of lofty and commanding qualities, which come forth when occasion calls. The same presence of mind, tender solicitude, cool courage and skillful leadership that marked him during the panic and chaos after the battle of Manassas, were still more conspicously displayed throughout those days and nights of wrack and tumult off Hatteras. We can well believe the report that comes, from the expedition, that the Commander has, in consequence, greatly endeared himself to his men, and has inspired universal affection, devotion and trust. A leader can do much who is able to evoke and utilize these qualifies. It remains yet to be seen, indeed, what he will actually do; but he has already, so shown himself as to inspire the country with general confidence that the work is in good hands.

He was everywhere among the fleet, directing, counseling, cheering. It is horrible to conceive what might have happened with a leader of a different sort. But BURNSIDE is obviously one of those men who, behind the guise of the gentlest and suavest behavior, have a reserved force of lofty and commanding qualities, which come forth when occasion calls. The same presence of mind, tender solicitude, cool courage and skillful leadership that marked him during the panic and chaos after the battle of Manassas, were still more conspicously displayed throughout those days and nights of wrack and tumult off Hatteras. We can well believe the report that comes, from the expedition, that the Commander has, in consequence, greatly endeared himself to his men, and has inspired universal affection, devotion and trust. A leader can do much who is able to evoke and utilize these qualifies. It remains yet to be seen, indeed, what he will actually do; but he has already, so shown himself as to inspire the country with general confidence that the work is in good hands.
